PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1967 Code, as supplemented through January 4, 1988, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1967 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Numbering System 
    The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of Chapter 1 is numbered 1-2 and the first section of Chapter 4 is 4-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 3-1 and 3-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 3-1.5. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between Chapters 12 and 13, it will be designated as Chapter 12.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. 
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited and the appropriate page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised sheets are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of the editorial staff of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Mr. Robert Tolson, Jr., City Attorney, for his cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
Tallahassee, Florida 
ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 5396 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE CITY OF PINE BLUFF, ARKANSAS; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF PINE BLUFF, ARKANSAS: 
    Section 1.  The Code entitled "Code of Ordinances, City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas" published by Municipal Code Corporation consisting of Chapters 1 through 29, each inclusive, is adopted. 
    Section 2.  All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before May 7, 1990, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
    Section 3.  The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4.  Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof, shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or double such sum for each repetition thereof, or imprisonment for a term not exceeding thirty (30) days, or both such fine and imprisonment. If the violation is, in its nature, continuous in respect to time, the fine for allowing the continuance thereof shall not exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each day that the same is unlawfully continued. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided shall apply to the amendment of any Code section whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief, and revocation of licenses or permits. 
    Section 5.  Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in the form as to indicate the intention of the city to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
    Section 6.  Ordinances adopted after May 7, 1990 that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code, shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
    Section 7.  This ordinance being necessary for the preservation of the public's health, safety and welfare, an emergency in hereby declared to exist, and this ordinance shall take effect from and after the date of its passage. 
    PASSED AND APPROVED THIS 20th DAY OF August, 1990.

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1967, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Authority to codify ordinances, A.C.A. § 14-55-701 et seq. 
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council: 
    Generally. All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
    A.C.A. The abbreviation "A.C.A." means the Arkansas Code of 1987 Annotated. 
State Law reference- Designation of state code, A.C.A. § 1-2-113. 
    City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall mean the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas. 
    Code. The term "Code" refers to the "Code of Ordinances, City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas," as designated in section 1-1. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done, or in computing a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given, or such act is done, is not counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had is counted. 
    Council. Whenever the words "council" or "city council" are used they shall be construed to mean the City Council of the City of Pine Bluff. 
    County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Jefferson, Arkansas. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or other officer of the city to do some act or perform some duty, or granting some right of him as such official it shall be construed to authorize such department head or officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to do the required act or perform the required duty, or it shall grant to them such right, unless the terms of the provisions designate otherwise. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships, and corporations as well as to males. 
    Include, including. The term "include," "including" or any other similar term of inclusion means without limitation or restriction. 
    May. The term "may" is to be construed as being permissive and not as being mandatory. 
    May not. The term "may not" has a prohibitory effect and states a prohibition. 
    Municipal court. The term "municipal court" means the Municipal Court of Pine Bluff, Arkansas. 
    Must. The term "must" is to be construed as being mandatory and not as being permissive. 
    Number. Words used in the singular include the plural, and the plural includes the singular number. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend to and include firms, partnerships, associations, organizations and bodies politic and corporate, or any combination thereof, and includes a trustee, receiver, administrator, executor, guardian or other representative, as well as to individuals. 
    References to other city officials, officers, etc. Whenever reference is made to officials, boards, commissions, departments, etc., by title only, i.e., "city clerk," "chief of police," etc., they shall be deemed to refer to the officials, boards, commissions and departments of the City of Pine Bluff. 
    Shall. The term "shall" is to be construed as being mandatory and not permissive. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" means a strip of land in front of or on the sides of a house or lot of land lying between the property line and the street. 
    Signature or subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark when a person cannot write. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Arkansas. 
    Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the city. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past or present. 
    Written or in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
(Code 1967, § 1-2) 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections, references. 
(a)  The catchlines of sections of this Code printed in boldface type, italics or otherwise are intended merely as catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(b)  The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. Cross references and state law references which appear after sections or subsections of this Code, or which otherwise appear in footnote form, are provided for the convenience of the user of this Code and have no legal effect. 
(c)  All references to chapters, articles or sections are to the chapters, articles and sections of this Code unless otherwise specified. 
(Code 1967, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at any time the ordinances repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1967, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-5. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repealed chapters, sections or subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code should be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of Ordinances of The City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, is hereby amended to read as follows: ...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full. 
(c)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances of The City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, is hereby amended by adding a section (or article or chapter) to be numbered ____________ , which such section (or article or chapter) reads as follows: ...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1967, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-6. - Additions and amendments deemed incorporated in Code. 
    Any and all additions and amendments to this Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the city to make the same a part hereof, are deemed to be incorporated in this Code, so that reference to the Code includes such additions and amendments. In addition, any addition to this Code that was not passed in such form but that has been published in this Code is considered a part of this Code. 
Sec. 1-7. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1967, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-8. - Penalty for violations. 
(a)  In this Code "violation of this Code" means: 
(1)  Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful; an offense or a misdemeanor authorized by ordinance or by rule or regulation; 
(2)  Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; or 
(3)  Failure to perform an act if the failure is declared a misdemeanor or an offense or unlawful by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(b)  In this Code "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a city officer or city employee to perform an official duty unless it is provided that failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided, violators of city ordinances shall be punished by a fine not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), for any one (1) specified offense or violation of a bylaw or ordinance, or double that sum for each repetition of such offense or violation, or, where applicable, imprisonment for a term not exceeding thirty (30) days. If a thing prohibited or rendered unlawful is, in its nature, continuous in respect to time, the fine or penalty for allowing the continuance thereof, in violation of the bylaw or ordinance, shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each day that it is unlawfully continued. 
(d)  If a violation of this Code is also a misdemeanor under state law, the penalty for the violation shall be as prescribed by state law for the state offense. 
(e)  The imposition of a penalty does not prevent revocation or suspension of a license, permit or franchise. 
(f)  Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, are a public nuisance and may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent equitable relief. 
(Code 1967, § 1-8; Ord. No. 6291, § 1, 9-21-09) 
State Law reference- Ordinance violations, A.C.A. §§ 14-55-501 et seq., 14-55-601 et seq. 
Sec. 1-9. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code affects any ordinance: 
(1)  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligations assumed by the city. 
(2)  Granting any right or franchise. 
(3)  Dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city. 
(4)  Making any appropriation. 
(5)  Adopting a budget or amending same. 
(6)  Creating or relating to specific funds. 
(7)  Establishing or creating sewer improvement district. 
(8)  Relating to the crime commission. 
(9)  Appointing individuals to office. 
(10)  Levying or imposing taxes. 
(11)  Establishing or prescribing grades of any street in the city. 
(12)  Providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor. 
(13)  Dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city. 
(14)  Extending or contracting the boundaries of the city. 
(15)  Prescribing the number, classification, benefits or compensation of any city officers or employees. 
(16)  Adopting or amending zoning maps or street master plans. 
(17)  Which is temporary, although general in effect. 
(18)  Which is special, although permanent in effect. 
(19)  The purpose of which has been accomplished. 
Sec. 1-10. - Continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions of this Code, so far as they are the same as ordinances existing at the time of adoption of this Code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 1-11. - Prior acts, obligations or uses unaffected. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code affects any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code does not authorize or permit any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance of the city in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Government of first class cities, A.C.A. § 14-43-201 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Referendum procedure for ordinances, resolutions. 
(a)  A petition for a referendum of any ordinance or resolution of the city shall be filed as provided by law within thirty (30) days from the date of passage of such ordinance or resolution. 
(b)  Whenever any referendum petition is filed, the city council shall give notice by publication by one (1) insertion of a time not less than five (5) days after the publication of such notice at which they will hear all persons who wish to be heard on the question whether such petition is signed by the requisite number of petitioners. At the time named the city council shall meet and hear all who wish to be heard on the question, and its decision shall be final, unless suit is brought in the county chancery court within thirty (30) days to review its action. 
(c)  If the city council finds that such a petition is signed by the requisite number of petitioners, it shall order a special election to determine by a vote of the qualified electors whether the ordinance shall stand or be revoked. The date for such election shall be not less than ten (10) days after the order therefor has been made by the council. Such election shall be had and conducted as general municipal elections held in the city. 
(d)  If any ordinance referred to the people is defeated at the polls, a notation of such fact shall be made on the ordinance. 
(Code 1967, §§ 2-43-2-46) 
State Law reference- Referendum petitions, A.C.A. §§ 14-55-302, 7-9-101 et seq. 
Sec. 2-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 5510, adopted August 3, 1992, repealed former § 2-2, regarding nominating petitions for independent candidates for office, which derived from Ord. No. 5121, § 1, adopted Feb. 18, 1986. 
Sec. 2-3. - Five-year plan. 
(a)  The mayor and city council, as a committee of the whole, shall formulate a five-year plan for the advancement of the City of Pine Bluff. 
(b)  The five-year plan shall address all facets of community development, including urban renewal, economic development, tax policy, neighborhood revitalization, downtown renewal, land use, cultural advancement, and public works. 
(c)  The plan shall identify areas of need, both as to category and neighborhood; set goals and objectives; formulate a strategy to attain the goals set and meet the needs identity; detail resources, actual and potential, financial, material and personnel, available to the city for use; and identify what actions are within the city's legal authority to take to take with reference to the goals and needs and what actions are possible for the city in conjunction with Jefferson County or via passage of legislation by the Arkansas General Assembly. 
(d)  The committee of the whole shall invite and receive input and assistance from all segments of the community and city government. 
(e)  The committee of the whole may retain such consultants and experts as necessary to accomplish its task. 
(f)  The committee of the whole shall formulate a blueprint for action within ninety (90) days of the final passage of this section. Thereafter the committee shall make periodic reports, at least once a quarter, until the final five-year plan shall be completed. 
(Ord. No. 6025, §§ 1-5, 9-3-02) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6025, §§ 1-5, adopted Sept. 3, 2002, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 2-3 at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 2-4. - Use of city owned vehicles. 
(a)  Areas of operation. No city owned vehicle shall be operated outside the corporate limits of the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, unless the vehicle is being operated in the line of duty on city business, pursuant to city contracts, or as required by Arkansas law. 
(b)  Return of city owned vehicles. At the conclusion of the workday or employee shift, the employee entrusted with the operation of a city vehicle to assist him or her in the performance of assigned duties shall park the vehicle in a lot or parking area designated by the department head or mayor, unless one or more of the following is applicable: 
(1)  The employee is on twenty-four (24) hour call for emergency services and rapid or immediate response directly to the site of the emergency is required (for example, the chiefs of the police and fire departments, the assistant and deputy chiefs of these departments, officers with twenty (20) years of service who reside in the city and are available for rapid response, and the non-uniformed heads of the street and animal control departments); or 
(2)  The employee is on-call and drives a city owned vehicle specially to fulfill his duties under the department mission (for example, employees who are called out for public safety, such as officers assigned to the narcotics/vice and detective divisions of the police department, officers who are on a call out list, and employees who are on-call in the street, animal control or inspection departments); or 
(3)  The mayor certifies, subject to city council confirmation, that permitting an employee to continue in possession of the vehicle after hours is in the public interest, in light of a cost/benefit analysis and is otherwise in the public interest; or 
(4)  In cases of travel relating to training or other employment related meetings or conferences, where doing so would reduce travel time and costs, a department head may allow an employee to take a city owned vehicle to his or her residence when the travel is scheduled for the following work day. 
(c)  List of authorized employees. 
(1)  The mayor shall create and maintain a list of the employees who are authorized to regularly retain possession of city owned vehicles after hours under the rubric of subsection (b)(3) herein. This list shall be filed with the city clerk's office, with a copy provided the finance department, and updated regularly. The mayor shall conduct an annual review of persons authorized to retain city owned vehicles after hours to ensure that use of the vehicles is not abused. 
(2)  All departments shall provide, on a periodic basis and reporting period to be established by the finance department, an itemized accounting of containing the name, position and justification of each employee who has been authorized by the department under subsection (b)(4) above to take vehicle home for business travel. The finance director shall create a reporting form for this purpose and provide the ways and means committee of the city council with a least a quarterly report (or as requested by the committee) of vehicle usage. 
(d)  Personal use of city owned vehicles. 
(1)  Employees (excluding the command staff of the police and fire departments) who are allowed to retain possession of a city owned vehicle after hours are prohibited from use of the vehicle for personal errands or travel not directly related to the employee's duties, except in the case of an emergency. Only the employee or authorized city official shall operate the vehicle. 
(2)  An employee who uses a city owned vehicle for travel which is unrelated to his or her duties or permits the vehicle to be operated by an unauthorized person may be disciplined consistent with the seriousness of the abuse, including suspension or termination, as well as being disqualified from further after hours use of a vehicle. 
(3)  The finance director shall ensure compliance with the applicable rules and regulations of the Internal Revenue Service pertaining to employees' after hours possession of city-owned vehicles. 
(e)  Definition. "City owned vehicle" means all city vehicles, whether or not bearing a decal, including police and fire department vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 6178, §§ 1-3, 7-5-06; Amd. of 7-5-06, §§ 1-3) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6178, §§ 1-3, adopted July 5, 2006, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 2-4 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2-5. - City vehicles to bear identification. 
(a)  All city-owned vehicles shall be painted or equipped with a decal, of a size and in a location on the vehicle so as to be easily visible to the public, clearly identifying the vehicle as a public vehicle owned by the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas. The paint or decal shall be of a permanent nature so as to prevent unauthorized tampering or removal. 
(b)  Vehicles used in public safety are exempt from subsection (a). 
(Ord. No. 6495, § 1, 11-3-14) 
Secs. 2-6-2-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-26. - Regular meetings. 
    The regular meetings of the city council shall begin at 5:30 p.m. or immediately after public comments are received, on the first and third Mondays of each month. 
(Code 1967, § 2-6; Ord. No. 5537, § 1, 3-1-93; Ord. No. 5545, § 2, 6-7-93) 
State Law reference- City council to provide for time and place of holding meetings, A.C.A. § 14-43-502(b)(2)(A). 
Sec. 2-27. - Issuance of process by mayor. 
    The mayor shall have power to issue all process to bring persons and witnesses before the city council when necessary, in the exercise of the power conferred on him by law, and all such process shall run in the name of the state, be sealed with the seal of the city council, signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 2-16) 
Secs. 2-28-2-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RULES OF ORDER AND PROCEDURE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Disorderly conduct, A.C.A. § 5-71-207. 

Sec. 2-46. - Called meetings. 
(a)  A meeting of the city council may be called by the mayor, fixing the time of meeting and issuing or causing to be issued a notice directed to the chief of police commanding him to notify each alderman of the city to attend such meeting. The object for which such meeting shall be called shall be stated in general terms in the notice of such meeting. 
(b)  Whenever three (3) aldermen shall sign a notice to the other members of the city council of a special meeting of the council, stating therein the object of the meeting, such special meeting may be held at the time designated in the call; such notice to be served by the chief of police. 
(c)  At any called or special meeting no other business shall be transacted than that for which such meeting was called. 
(Code 1967, §§ 2-8, 2-9, 2-13) 
State Law reference- Public notice of special meetings, A.C.A. § 25-19-106; special meetings to be called in the manner provided by ordinance, A.C.A. § 14-43-502(b)(2)(B); authority of mayor to call meeting, A.C.A. § 14-43-502(b)(2)(B). 
Sec. 2-47. - Duty to attend. 
    It shall be the duty of each alderman to attend all meetings of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-10) 
State Law reference- Authority to compel attendance at meetings, A.C.A. § 14-43-501(a)(2)(C). 
Sec. 2-48. - Presiding officer; mayor's vote. 
    The mayor shall be ex officio president of the council and shall preside at its meetings during the term for which he shall have been elected. The mayor shall have a vote when his vote is needed to pass any ordinance, bylaw, resolution, order, or motion. In the absence of the mayor, the council shall elect a president pro tempore. 
(Code 1967, § 2-14) 
State Law reference- Mayor to preside over council, A.C.A. § 14-43-501(b)(1). 
Sec. 2-49. - Adoption of rules of procedure. 
(a)  The regular meetings of the city council shall follow the following pattern, which shall be reduced to writing in the form of an agenda distributed to council members prior to the meeting: 
(1)  Public comments; 
(2)  Call to order; 
(3)  Invocation; 
(4)  Pledge of allegiance; 
(5)  Roll call; 
(6)  Approval of minutes of prior meeting; 
(7)  Committee reports; 
(8)  Presentation of proposed ordinances and resolutions; 
(9)  Adjournment; and 
(10)  All other public comments. 
(b)  "The "Procedural Rules for Municipal Officials" published by the Arkansas Municipal League, as amended and updated from time-to-time, and a copy of which shall be on file with the city clerk, shall serve as the rules of procedure governing meetings of the city council. The rulings of the chair regarding matters of procedure shall be final, unless reversed by the council as provided in section 2-51. 
(Code 1967, § 2-1; Ord. No. 5999, 3-18-02) 
State Law reference- City council to determine its own rules, A.C.A. § 14-43-501(a)(2)(C). 
Sec. 2-50. - Motions on questions before council. 
    During the pending of any question before the council, the following motions may be made by any member: 
(1)  To adjourn. 
(2)  To lay any motion, resolution or ordinance on the table. 
(3)  To postpone. 
(4)  To call for the previous question. 
(5)  To refer to a committee. 
(6)  To amend. 
(Code 1967, § 2-2) 
Sec. 2-51. - Appeal from decision of chair. 
    Any member may appeal to the council from the decision of the chair, but no decision of the mayor shall be reversed unless by a majority of two-thirds of all the members present. 
(Code 1967, § 2-27) 
Sec. 2-52. - Amendments must be in writing. 
    No amendment to any action to be acted upon by the city council shall be offered except in writing, and the question shall first be put on the last amendment offered, and in filling blanks the question shall always be taken on the longest time, largest and highest number proposed. 
(Code 1967, § 2-42) 
Sec. 2-53. - Reading resolutions, action on motions. 
    All resolutions shall be read, seconded and stated by the chair. All motions shall be seconded and stated by the chair before they shall be subject for debate. 
(Code 1967, § 2-38) 
Sec. 2-54. - Ordinances and resolutions must be reduced to writing. 
    No ordinance or resolution coming before the city council shall be acted on until it shall have been reduced to writing. 
(Code 1967, § 2-39) 
State Law reference- Ordinance adoption procedures, A.C.A. § 14-55-201 et seq. 
Sec. 2-55. - Procedure for discussion, debate, and filing of ordinances and references. 
(a)  An original ordinance or resolution must be filed with the city clerk for consideration by the city council. 
(b)  Each ordinance or resolution must be sponsored by the mayor or a member of the council, and must be approved as to form by the city attorney or an assistant city attorney. 
(c)  The city council shall not pass or consider at a regular meeting any resolution, ordinance, petition, contract, lease, appointment or any other matter, other than communications affecting the general public, that is not filed with the city clerk on or before 12:00 noon on the Wednesday preceding the meeting. Should the Wednesday filing date fall on a holiday, the filing date will then be twenty-four (24) hours prior to that time; provided, however, that this requirement may be waived by a unanimous vote of the council members present at any regular or special meeting of the city council. 
(d)  No ordinance shall be read unless it shall have first been reviewed by the city council committee or committees with jurisdiction over the subject matter of the legislation; provided, however, that this requirement may be waived by a majority of the council members present at any regular or special meeting of the city council. 
(e)  A period of time for debate and comment shall be allowed after each reading of an ordinance. 
(f)  Issues or questions raised in the post-meeting public comments which need investigation or review shall be referred to the appropriate council committee for action, with the committee to report back with its findings by the next regularly scheduled council meeting. 
(Ord. No. 6512, § 1, 4-6-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6512, § 1, adopted April 6, 2015, amended § 2-55 in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former § 2-55 pertained to procedure for filing ordinances and resolutions and derived from Ord. No. 6018, § 1, adopted June 17, 2002. 
State Law reference- Ordinance adoption procedures, A.C.A. § 14-55-201 et seq. 
Sec. 2-56. - Distribution of veto statements to council members. 
    In the event the mayor shall exercise a veto, the city clerk shall enclose a copy of the veto in the materials provided each council member in the week preceding the next scheduled council meeting. Should the mayor have elected to provide the explanation for the veto prior to the deadline for distribution of the materials to council members, then the city clerk shall also include a copy of the explanation with the materials. Nothing in this section should be understood to require the mayor to submit the explanation for veto in time to be included in the materials or otherwise truncate the time period provided by Arkansas law for the mayor to lay before the council his explanation of a veto. 
(Ord. No. 5721, §§ 1, 2, 10-20-97; Ord. No. 6358, § 1, 7-18-11) 
Sec. 2-57. - City council to receive public comments; procedure. 
(a)  Time periods to receive comments. There shall be two (2) periods during which the city council shall receive public comments. Persons desiring to speak on a particular agenda item will be given the opportunity to do so prior to the council meeting. Persons desiring to speak on an issue or item not on the meeting agenda shall be at the conclusion of the city council meeting. No person making a public comment shall speak more than once to make a public comment at a council meeting. 
(b)  Time limit. Each speaker at each comment session shall be limited to three (3) minutes to make his or her remarks. If more than five (5) people desire to speak at either session, the mayor may reduce the time for each speaker to two (2) minutes. Persons interested in commenting at a council meeting shall contact the mayor's office to request a place on the public comments agenda. Persons wishing to address an agenda item shall designate when requesting a place on the agenda of "FOR" or "AGAINST" when signing up so that speakers and positions may be alternated. All persons not designating a position of "FOR" or "AGAINST", or desiring to speak on a topic not on the meeting agenda, shall be assigned to speak at the "All Other Comments" period at the conclusion of the meeting. The cutoff time for registering to speak at a council meeting shall be 5:00 p.m. on the day of the meeting. 
    The city council may, by two-third's ( 2/3 ) vote of the members present, waive the sign-up or time limitation requirements for a person or speaker. 
(c)  Duties of the mayor. The mayor shall administer both public comment periods and shall be responsible for enforcing time limits on speakers and prohibiting the use of obscene, abusive or inflammatory language. 
(d)  Disorderly conduct in meetings. Individuals who use obscene or abusive language or make obscene gestures under conditions likely to provoke a violent or disorderly response from persons present at the meeting, or to disrupt the ordering conduct of the meeting, may be cited or arrested for disorderly conduct. The violator may be banned from speaking at council meetings for a period of no less than two (2) council meetings. However, no speaker is to be curtailed for remarks which are merely critical in nature. 
(e)  Statutory requirements. This section shall not affect statutorily required public hearing periods held during council meetings. 
(Ord. No. 6085, §§ 1-5, 3-1-04) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6085, §§ 1-5, adopted March 1, 2004, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 2-57 at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 2-58. - Procedure to cancel regularly scheduled meeting of city council. 
    In the rare circumstance that there is no new business, old business, or public hearing scheduled before the city council on a given meeting date, and, extraordinary events dictate canceling that regular meeting date, upon concurrence of the mayor and four (4) council members or upon concurrence of a majority of the whole council, said meeting may be canceled upon three (3) hours notice. The mayor, if one of those requesting the cancellation, shall cause to be issued a notice directed to the chief of police commanding him to notify each alderman of the city that said meeting has been canceled. The notice shall recite that there is no new business, no old business nor any public hearing scheduled for the given meeting date and setting forth in general terms the extraordinary circumstance which compels cancellation of the meeting. Whenever a majority of the aldermen seek to cancel a meeting and the same criteria exist, they shall sign a notice to the mayor and other members of the city council of cancellation of the meeting, reciting the requirements that there is no new business, no old business nor any public hearing scheduled for the given meeting date and setting forth in general terms the extraordinary circumstance which compels cancellation of the meeting. Such notice shall be served by the chief of police or his designee. The finance director will pay the usual, ordinary or expected bills against the city and said action presented for ratification by the council at its next regular meeting. 
(Ord. No. 6626, 10-1-07) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6626, adopted October 1, 2007, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 2-58 at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 2-59. - [Printed list of outstanding bills of the city.] 
    The finance director of the city is directed to provide to the city clerk for inclusion with the agenda packet distributed to each council member before every council meeting, a printed list of the outstanding bills of the city to be paid, including the following information: 
(1)  The name of the vendor; 
(2)  The amount billed the city by the vendor; 
(3)  The department which generated the expense; and 
(4)  The service(s) or items(s) for which the bill is submitted by the vendor. 
(Ord. No. 6532, § 1, 11-16-15) 
Secs. 2-60-2-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Personnel, Ch. 19. 
State Law reference- Municipal officers and employees generally, A.C.A. § 14-43-401 et seq.; municipal civil service system, A.C.A. § 14-50-101 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-71. - Oath of officers. 
    Every officer whose office is one of profit or responsibility shall be required to take the following oath of office: 
"I, ____________ , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Arkansas, and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of ____________ , upon which I am now about to enter." 
(Code 1967, § 2-95) 
Sec. 2-72. - Unlawful harassment prohibited. 
(a)  The city expressly prohibits its officials or employees from engaging in any form of unlawful harassment of employees based on race, religion, color, gender, national origin, disability or status as a veteran or special disabled veteran. 
(b)  (1)  Harassment is any annoying, persistent act or actions, deliberately done, that singles out an employee, over that employee's objection to his or her detriment, because of race, sex, religion, national origin, age (over forty (40)) or disability. Harassment may include, but is not limited to, the following actions: 
a.  Verbal abuse or ridicule, such as offensive verbal comments about an individual's appearance, sexually degrading words to describe an individual, words, jokes or comments based upon an individual's race, sex, religion, national origin, age, disability, veteran's status or ethnicity; 
b.  Interference with an employee's work or creating an intimidating, hostile, or offensive working environment; 
c.  Displaying or distributing sexually offensive, racist or other derogatory materials; 
d.  Discriminating against any employee in work assignments or job-related training because of one (1) of the above-referenced bases; 
e.  Intentional physical contact with either gender-specific portions of a person's body or that person's private parts; 
f.  Making offensive sexual, racial or other derogatory hints or impressions; repeated offensive sexual flirtation, advances, or propositions; repeated verbal abuse of a sexual nature; 
g.  Demanding favors (sexual or otherwise), explicitly, as a condition of employment, promotion, transfer or any other term or condition of employment. 
(2)  No employee, supervisor, department head, or official shall threaten or insinuate, either explicitly or implicitly, that he or she has the right or authority to offer any benefits, including, but not limited to, tangible items, whether business-related, such as raises or promotions, or nonbusiness-related, such as gifts, trips, or any other item, in exchange for sexual favors, nor does any employee, supervisor, department head or official possess such authority. An employee receiving such an offer should immediately report it to the department head, or if the accused is the department head, the personnel director. 
(c)  It is every employee's and official's responsibility to ensure that his or her conduct does not include or imply harassment in any form. If, however, harassment or suspected harassment has or is taking place: 
(1)  An employee should report harassment immediately to the department head. If the department head is the alleged harasser or if the complainant reasonably believes that complaints made to the department head will be unavailing, then the complaint should be reported to the personnel director. Complaints should be made in writing. 
(2)  Any employee who has knowledge of harassment she shall inform the department head, or if the department head is the alleged harasser or the employee reasonably believes that reporting the conduct to the department head will be unavailing, then inform the personnel director, in writing. Department heads shall actively monitor workplace conduct for potential harassment. All city employees have a duty to report suspected harassment in the workplace. 
(3)  Each complaint shall be fully investigated. The complainant, accused, and witnesses identified by both, including, where necessary, former employees, shall be interviewed. A determination of the facts and appropriate action will be made on a case-by-case basis. Investigations will be conducted in an impartial and objective manner. Investigations of officials will be performed by the Internal Affairs Division of the Pine Bluff Police Department, or, where that is impractical or objected to by either the complainant or the accused party, by an independent party or agency not a part of city government. The investigative findings and recommendations shall be reduced to writing and provided to the complainant, accused party, mayor and personnel director. To the extent allowable by law, confidentiality will be maintained during the investigation process. 
All city employees have an affirmative duty to cooperate in the investigation of complaints. Failure or refusal to cooperate in an investigation shall subject an employee to disciplinary action, including termination. 
(d)  The city will not tolerate harassment or any form of retaliation against an employee who has either instigated or cooperated in the investigation of alleged harassment. Disciplinary action, including termination, will be taken against offenders who are employees; officials may be subject to censure by the city council. 
(e)  Department heads and supervisors for the city shall undergo periodic training in the detection, investigation, and prevention of unlawful harassment in the workplace. Certificates of such training shall be maintained by the personnel director. 
(Ord. No. 5855, §§ 1-5, 12-20-99) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5855, §§ 1-5, adopted Dec. 20, 1999, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, its inclusion as § 2-72 was at the editor's discretion. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Secs. 2-73-2-85. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-86. - Monthly report. 
    On or before the first Monday of each month the city treasurer shall file with the city clerk a report showing the financial condition of the city as of the last day of the previous month. 
(Code 1967, § 2-59) 
Sec. 2-87. - Required records. 
    It shall be the duty of the city treasurer to keep in a proper book an accurate account with each of the several funds in his hands, showing by proper entries therein, from whom, and on what account any money or warrant received by him is received, and when, to whom, and on what account all disbursements made by him are paid out. Such account book shall be furnished by the city, and shall be a public record, and shall be delivered by the treasurer to his successor in office, taking duplicate receipts thereof, one (1) of which shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 2-60)

DIVISION 4. - MAYOR[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6032, §§ 1-3, adopted Oct. 7, 2002, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been added Art. III, Div. IV, § 2-111 at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 2-111. - Authority of the mayor concerning the police and fire departments. 
(a)  The Mayor of the City of Pine Bluff shall have the general superintending and administrative authority over the fire and police departments, and may issue binding orders to the chiefs thereof, except for those matters reserved to the civil service commission by state law or city ordinance, such as the appointment and removal of the chiefs of the departments, the hiring and promotion of officers, the review of the suspension or termination of an officer by a chief, and the enforcement of commission's own rules and regulations. 
(b)  Any chief of the fire or police department who shall willfully fail to execute or obey a valid order of the mayor may be disciplined for insubordination. 
(c)  The mayor shall have the authority to caution, reprimand, or suspend without pay and for cause, the chief of the police or fire departments. No suspension shall exceed thirty (30) days in duration. 
(Ord No. 6032, §§ 1-3, 10-7-02)

ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENTS[7] 

Footnotes:

Cross reference- Inspection department, § 7-26 et seq.; office of emergency services, § 9-26 et seq.; fire department, § 10-26 et seq.; municipal court, Ch. 15; personnel, Ch. 19; police department, § 21-26. 

Sec. 2-121. - Enumerated.[8] 
    The administrative framework of city government shall consist of the following departments: Police, fire, street, transit, inspection, cemetery, animal control, community and economic development, finance, collection, human resources, legal, executive, parking meter, building maintenance, municipal court, planning and zoning. 
(Code 1967, § 2-103; Ord. No. 5269, § 2, 7-18-88; Ord. No. 5932, § 1, 2-5-01) 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Animal control department made a division of the police department, § 21-61. 

Sec. 2-122. - Legal department; composition, practice restricted, head. 
    The legal department shall consist of the city attorney and two (2) assistants. No attorney in the legal department shall engage in the private practice of law. The city attorney shall be responsible for the functions and operation of the legal department. 
(Ord. No. 5290, § 1(2-109), 12-19-88) 
Sec. 2-123. - [City residency required; department directors.] 
(a)  No one may serve as a director of a department of city government, including the chiefs of the police and fire departments, who is not a resident of the city continuously during the term of his or her service as a department director or chief. Continued residency in the city during such term of such service shall be considered a condition of employment and failure to do so shall constitute grounds for termination. 
(b)  All existing employees of the city will be grandfathered in and may serve as a director of a department of city government and are not required to comply with subsection (a) hereof. However, any such department director or chief cannot subsequently transfer to and serve as the department director or chief of another department unless he or she is in compliance with subsection (a) hereof. 
(Ord. No. 5863, §§ 1, 2, 1-18-00) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5863, §§ 1, 2, adopted Jan. 18, 2000, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, its inclusion as § 2-123 was at the discretion of the editor. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 2-124. - [Residency rules for department heads.] 
(a)  Residency required. All city department heads appointed on or after January 1, 2017, must reside within the city limits of the City of Pine Bluff. Those appointed prior to January 1, 2017, are exempt from this requirement. 
(b)  Continuing obligation. A department head required to reside in the city by the provisions of this section is under the obligation to maintain continuous, uninterrupted residency in the city after January 1, 2017. 
(c)  Verfication of residence. The mayor, city council, or resources department may, from time to time as part of administrative routine, upon a reasonable belief of a violation, require that a department head provide proof of continuous residency in the city. Such proof may include, but not necessarily be limited to, voter registration, utility statements, real or personal property assessments, and other documentation generated by third parties in the course of business. 
(d)  Condition of employment. Compliance with the provisions of this section constitute a condition of employment with the City of Pine Bluff. 
(e)  Penalty for noncompliance. A department head found to be in violation of the requirements of this section is subject to termination for cause. 
(Ord. No. 6551, §§ 1-5, 9-19-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6551, §§ 1-5, adopted Sept. 19, 2016, added provisions to the Code but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as § 2-124 herein. 
Secs. 2-125-2-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCE[9] 
Footnotes:
