DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-141. - Payment of claims, debts, liabilities. 
    The mayor, or a duly authorized representative, may approve for payment out of any funds previously appropriated for that purpose or disapprove any bids, debts or liabilities asserted as claims against the city when funds on hand are inadequate to pay such bills, debts or liabilities. All items not covered by a previous appropriation shall require confirmation of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-81) 
State Law reference- Payment of claims, etc., A.C.A. § 14-58-305. 
Sec. 2-142. - [Returned check fee.] 
(a)  That effective January 1, 1999, city departments shall assess and collect a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) from the maker or drawer of a check which is returned to the city due to insufficient funds being available to pay the check when it is presented for payment. 
(b)  Proceeds derived from collection of this fee shall go into the city's general fund. 
(Ord. No. 5779, § 1, 11-16-98) 
Sec. 2-143. - City collector's office designated; collection of court fines and costs. 
    The City Collector's office for the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, is hereby designated the primary agency for the collection of fines, costs and fees assessed and imposed by the First and Second Divisions of the District Court of Pine Bluff/Jefferson County, Arkansas, in all cases in which the district court has allowed the defendant to pay such fines, costs and fees on a time or installment basis. For purposes of this section, "fines," "costs," and "fees" shall includes all monetary penalties and charges assessed or imposed by the court, as set forth in A.C.A. Section 16-13-701(b), as amended. The district clerk for each division of the court shall forward to the city collector a copy of the time or installment payment agreement or order for each defendant within one business day of the date of execution. 
    Consistent with Arkansas law, all fees or assessments heretofore imposed by the first or second division of the district court, and retained or paid as consideration or compensation to any private contractor or concern for its services in the collection of fines and costs pursuant to a contract or agreement with the City of Pine Bluff and/or the Pine Bluff/Jefferson County District Court, shall continue to be assessed by the each division of the district court and same shall be retained by the collector's office to defray administrative expenses. 
    The city collector shall prepare and maintain such reports and records pertaining to the collection of said fines, costs and fees as mandated by State law and shall be required to prepare no additional report or record unless by mutual agreement with the district court clerk as approved by the city council. The finance department shall remit the funds collected by the collector's office to the district clerk for each division on a monthly basis or as required by state law, to allow the clerk to fulfill the obligations of A.C.A. Section 16-10-209, as amended. 
    The uninterrupted collection of fines, costs and fees imposed by each division of the District Court of the City of Pine Bluff/Jefferson County, Arkansas, being essential to the public peace, health and welfare, an emergency is declared to exist and this section shall be in full force and effect from and after the date of its passage. 
(Ord. No. 5985, § 1, 12-17-01; Ord. No. 6011, §§ 1, 2, 6-3-02; Ord. No. 6045, §§ 1-4, 2-3-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6045, §§ 1-4, adopted Feb. 3, 2003, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 2-143 at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 2-144. - Reallocation of budget line items by city departments. 
    The amounts approved by the city council for each department in the annual budget for the city, as reflected by line items dedicated for particular purposes, shall not be increased or changed without prior approval of the council. 
    No department head shall have the authority to reallocate the funds budgeted for his department by shifting the amounts approved for one line item to another without the prior approval of the council. A department head who authorizes or directs such a reallocation shall be subject to discipline. 
    The finance director of the city shall monitor compliance with this section and immediately report any violation thereof in writing to the mayor and the chairperson of the councils ways and means committee. 
    In the event of an emergency, declared by the mayor or manifest from the circumstances, which make it impossible or impractical for prior approval by the council of reallocation of funds within a department, the mayor may authorize a department head to shift funds between budgeted line items to meet the emergency. At the next meeting of the council subsequent to the emergency, the mayor shall report the circumstances constituting the emergency and the finance director shall report all such reallocation of funds. 
    The rigorous control of expenditures being essential to the fiscal vitality of city government and its ability to protect the public health, welfare and safety, an emergency is declared to exist and this section shall be in full force and effect from and after the time of its passage. 
(Ord. No. 6054, §§ 1-5, 4-7-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6054, §§ 1-5, adopted April 7, 2003, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 2-144 at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 2-145-2-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PURCHASES[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Purchases and contracts generally, A.C.A. § 14-58-303. 

Sec. 2-156. - Purchases of less than one thousand dollars; and exception. 
(a)  The mayor, or mayor's designees, have the exclusive authority to purchase supplies, equipment, and materials, commodities and services for the city where the total expenditure, excluding applicable taxes, does not exceed more than one thousand dollars ($1,000). 
(b)  Exception: Notwithstanding subsection (a), or section 2-157(a), the quality of life division shall be authorized to spend up to five thousand dollars ($5,000) through December 31, 2017, to secure the services of eligible contractors for the sole purpose of clearing grass and weeds, and removal of minor debris from typical lots, as defined by departmental guidelines. Beginning January 1, 2018, the aforementioned amount shall be reduced to two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500). 
(Code 1967, § 2-77; Ord. No. 5700, § 1, 8-4-97; Ord. No. 6467, § 1, 11-4-13; Ord. No. 6579, § 1, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 2-157. - Purchases from one thousand to twenty thousand dollars. 
(a)  All purchases for the city of supplies, equipment, materials, commodities and services requisite for public purposes in excess of one thousand dollars ($1,000) but not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000), exclusive of applicable taxes, may be made by the mayor or the department head after securing at least than three (3) telephone quotations. 
(b)  All purchases for the city of supplies, apparatus, equipment, materials, commodities and services requisite for public purposes in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000) but not more than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000), exclusive of applicable taxes, shall may be made by the mayor or the department head after securing at least than three (3) written quotations. 
(Code 1967, § 2-78; Ord. No. 5700, § 2, 8-4-97; Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 11-4-13; Ord. No. 6579, § 2, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 2-158. - Purchases over twenty thousand dollars. 
    When the amount of an expenditure for any purchase or contract is greater than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000), the mayor, city clerk, and department head shall invite competitive bids therefor by legal advertisement in any local newspaper, as well as such publication on other media as required by ordinance or resolution. Bids received pursuant to such notification shall be opened and read on the date set for receiving the bids in the presence of the mayor or mayor's designee, city clerk or designee, and the department head or designee. The contract shall be awarded to the lowest, most responsible bidder, unless subject to the requirements of section 2-161; provided, however, that the city may reject any and all bids received and may waive any or all formalities. 
(Code 1967, § 2-79; Ord. No. 5700, § 3, 8-4-97; Ord. No. 6467, § 3, 11-4-13) 
Sec. 2-159. - Waiver of competitive bidding. 
(a)  The city council may waive the requirements of competitive bidding in exceptional situations where such procedure is deemed not feasible or practical. 
(b)  Emergency purchases. When the public health, safety, and welfare of the city are threatened and the need for immediate action precludes use of regular procurement procedures, the mayor may authorize a department head to make the needed purchases of materials, supplies, apparatus, equipment or things to meet the emergency. The circumstances of the emergency shall be fully documented by the mayor and department head. Requisitions and purchase orders in such cases shall be prominently labeled as "emergency request" or "emergency purchase." A prompt report of the circumstances and all purchases made to meet the emergency shall be made to the city council at first opportunity and the council must ratify and approve all purchases which exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(c)  Whenever the expenditure is to purchase goods manufactured by the Arkansas Department of Correction, and the expenditure is less than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000), the requirements of section 2-157 are waived if authorized by the mayor upon request of the department head. 
(Code 1967, § 2-80; Ord. No. 5700, § 5, 8-4-97; Ord. No. 6467, § 4, 11-4-23) 
Sec. 2-160. - Sale or exchange of municipal property. 
    The mayor, the city clerk and the department head may sell or exchange any municipal supplies, materials or equipment without competitive bidding if such supplies, materials or equipment have a value of less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). No supplies, materials or equipment shall be sold without receiving competitive bids therefor if the value thereof exceeds the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00); provided, however, if the mayor shall certify in writing to the city council, in his opinion, the fair market value of such item or cost to be disposed of (in one (1) unit) is less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), the unit may be sold by the mayor without competitive bidding. 
(Code 1967, § 2-82; Ord. No. 5700, § 4, 8-4-97) 
State Law reference- Authority to so provide, A.C.A. § 14-58-306. 
Sec. 2-161. - Competitive selection of professional services. 
(a)  The city and all its boards, commissions and authorities not otherwise authorized to do so by state law, shall competitively select professional service contracts based on qualifications and other relevant evaluation criteria other than price or cost: 
(1)  As required by the A.C.A. § 19-11-801, et seq., all legal, financial advisory, architectural, engineering, construction management and land surveying services done for or on behalf of the city; 
(2)  All services declared to be a professional service, if done for or on behalf of the city, its boards, commissions or authorities, including the following: 
a.  Accounting services. 
b.  Planning. 
c.  Actuarial services. 
d.  Investment consulting. 
e.  Data processing. 
f.  Training services. 
g.  Insurance program administration. 
h.  Bond writing. 
i.  Abstract and real estate title services. 
j.  Financial services. 
k.  Consultant services. 
l.  Information system services consultant. 
m.  Disciplines associated with development and implementation of tests and systems designed for hiring and promotion of municipal employees. 
n.  Employee benefit plan consultant services. 
(3)  The city council may add, by a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote, any other appropriate service that the city council may from time to time designate to be a professional service because "cost" or "price bidding" is found to be impractical, unfeasible, or, if based solely upon price, would result in an outcome that would not meet the best interests of the city. 
(b)  It is the policy of the city to publicly announce all requirements for the competitive selection of professional services as referenced above, and to negotiate contracts for such services on the basis of demonstrated competence and qualifications for the type of professional services required provided that the services are rendered at fair and reasonable prices. 
(c)  All municipal boards, commissions, and authorities established pursuant to state statute or other legislative authority shall be responsible for the implementation of such policies and procedures as are hereinafter compiled. 
(d)  The competitive selection for such services shall be conducted by a review committee which has been selected by the appropriate governing board, commission or authority as the case may be, which may include appropriate city personnel and professionals, and/or individuals with community expertise based on the nature of the services to be selected. The review committee for each proposed contract, may establish the qualifications and evaluation criteria necessary for the specific services to be provided. 
(e)  The department head or manager for the relevant board, commission or authority will cause to be advertised in a newspaper of general circulation a notice that the city has a need to contract for a particular professional service and shall invite all interested parties to submit within ten (10) days, to the extent permitted by the ethical standards of the profession, a statement of their qualifications and other relevant information based on the evaluation criteria specifically developed for the proposed services to be provided. 
    Whenever state law or city ordinance requires that the city use competitive bidding or request for proposals for the purchase of items or for professional or other services, the city department or agency must, in addition to publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the area, also cause to be posted on the city's local cable television access channel and on the city's internet web site the same or substantially similar notice of the bid or request for proposal as published in the newspaper. The notice posted on the television channel and on the city's internet web site shall be maintained for the entire period that the bid or request for proposals may be submitted. 
(f)  The review committee shall evaluate all statements of qualifications and other submittals and may conduct interviews with up to five (5) firms regarding anticipated concepts and the relative utility of alternative methods of approach for furnishing the required services and then shall select therefrom, in order of preference, based on criteria established and published by the review committee, no less than three (3) of the firms deemed to be the most highly qualified to provide the services required. 
(g)  The review committee or its designee shall then negotiate a contract with the highest qualified firm for the services to be rendered, at compensation which the review committee, or its designee, determines is fair and reasonable to the city, subject to the approval of the governing board, commission or authority as referred to in subsection (c) of this section. In making such determination, the review committee or its designee, shall take into account the scope, complexity, and professional nature of the services to be rendered. 
(h)  Should the review committee, or its designee, be unable to negotiate a satisfactory contract with the firm considered to be the most qualified, at a price determined to be fair and reasonable to the city, negotiations with that firm shall be formally terminated. The review committee, or its designee, shall then undertake negotiations with the second most qualified firm. Failing accord with the second most qualified firm, the review committee, or its designee, shall terminate negotiations. The review committee, or its designee, shall then undertake negotiations with the third most qualified firm. If unable to negotiate a contract with any of the selected firms, the department head or designee shall reevaluate the professional services, including the scope and reasonable fee requirements, and again compile a list of qualified firms and proceed in accordance with the aforestated procedure until an agreement is reached. 
(i)  The requirement for a review committee shall be waived and the review of qualifications as hereinabove stated and approval or disapproval of the contract shall be delegated to the responsible department head for all professional services contracts in an amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or less. 
(Code 1967, § 2-83; Ord. No. 5600, § 1, 12-5-94; Ord. No. 5630, § 1, 10-16-95; Ord. No. 5927, § 1, 1-2-01; Ord. No. 6299, § 1, 11-16-09; Ord. No. 6447, § 1, 6-3-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6299, § 1, Nov. 16, 2009, amended § 2-161 title to read as herein set out. Former § 2-161 title pertained to competitive selection of technical services. 
Sec. 2-162. - Local government cooperative purchasing authorized. 
(a)  The mayor and the chief of police for the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, hereby request authority in the name of the city to participate in state contracts which the department of finance and administration, office of state purchasing, has entered into for the purchase of supplies, equipment and certain materials pursuant to the state purchasing law and Amendment 54 to the Arkansas Constitution. 
(b)  The mayor and the chief of police are hereby authorized to agree in the name of the City of Pine Bluff to be bound by all contract terms and conditions as the department of finance and administration, office of state purchasing, prescribes. Further, that the mayor and chief of police do hereby agree to be bound by all such terms and conditions. 
(c)  The mayor and the chief of police are hereby authorized to agree in the name of the City of Pine Bluff to directly pay the vendor, under such state contracts in which it participates, for items it receives pursuant to the contract, and that the mayor and the chief of police do hereby agree to directly pay the vendor 
(Ord. No. 5666, §§ 1-3, 10-7-96) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5666, §§ 1-3, adopted October 7, 1996, did not specifically amend the Code; hence inclusion as § 2-162 was at the discretion of the editor. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 2-163. - Acquisition of real property by the city. 
(a)  Prohibition against contracting or committing to purchase real property without council approval. No city department shall contract to acquire or purchase, or commit to acquire or purchase, and no city officer, official or employee shall sign or deliver a contract, offer and acceptance, or commitment to acquire or purchase, any real property on behalf of the city without the approval of the city council being first obtained. 
(b)  Prohibition against expending city funds for acquisition or purchase of real property without council approval. No city officer, official or employee shall expend or authorize the expenditure of any city funds for the acquisition or purchase of real property unless the approval of the city council shall have first been obtained. "City funds" means all monies received by the city from whatever source and for whatever purpose. 
(c)  Penalty for violation. Any person who violates the proscriptions found in subsection (a) or (b) or this section shall have committed a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined a sum not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or sentenced to term of incarceration in the Jefferson County Detention Facility not to exceed one (1) year, or to both a fine and incarceration. An official or officer who is not an elected official and who is convicted of a violation of this section shall be terminated from employment. 
(d)  Exclusion for city boards and commissions. This section shall not apply to the members, officers, officials and employees of the city's independent boards and commissions. 
(Ord. No. 6353, §§ 1-4, 6-20-11) 
Sec. 2-164. - Fixed assets listing-Requirements. 
(a)  A "fixed asset" of the municipality includes the following: 
(1)  Land; 
(2)  Buildings; 
(3)  Improvements to buildings or property; 
(4)  Infrastructure; 
(5)  Motor vehicles; 
(6)  Equipment; 
(7)  Heavy machinery; 
(8)  Any property purchased or leased with a value of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) or more which has a useful life one (1) year or more. 
(b)  The mayor shall be responsible for ensuring that each city department and agency creates and maintains a current list of fixed assets within the possession or control of the department. The list shall be organized by category, the same being subsections (a)(1)-(a)(8) above, and in the applicable category contain, at a minimum, the following information: 
(1)  Property item number (if available, real estate should include the Jefferson County parcel number if known); 
(2)  A brief description of the property sufficient to identify it; 
(3)  Serial number (if available, motor vehicles should include VIN number); 
(4)  Date of acquisition and name of the vendor; 
(5)  Cost of property and estimated useful life; 
(6)  For fixed assets leased with a purchase option, the monthly payment, the down payment, and the interest rate. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of each department or agency head to ensure that the fixed asset list for the department or agency is maintained current. It shall be the duty of the mayor to monitor the compliance of each department of agency head for adherence to this requirement. 
(Ord. No. 6441, §§ 1-3, 5-20-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6441, §§ 1-3, adopted May 20, 2013, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, these provisions have been included at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 2-165. - [Requirements for all contractors involved in construction projects administered by the city.] 
    No contractor may be awarded a construction contract, or a contract for installment or repair of heating or air equipment or plumbing, by the City of Pine Bluff unless the contractor provides written documentation that the contractor is licensed by the State of Arkansas for the work involved in the project, and that the license is in effect and in good standing. 
    No contractor may commence work or proceed with a construction project unless the contractor provides a surety or performance bond in an amount equal to the amount of the contract, or the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), whichever is greater, which provides a means by which the city may claim compensation for the costs of redoing poor work or replacing substandard materials. 
    A contractor performing a construction project per contract awarded by the City of Pine Bluff must, prior to commencement of work, have in effect one (1) or more policies of liability and performance insurance, in amounts acceptable to the city covering the city and/or the property owner against injury, harm, or loss occasioned by the work of the contractor, and the contractor's agents, officers and employees, as well as any subcontractor utilized by the contractor in performing the work. 
(Ord. No. 6531, §§ 1-3, 11-2-15) 
Sec. 2-166. - Preference among municipal bidders-Definitions. 
(a)  The following words and phrases shall for the purpose of section 2-166 have the following meanings: 
    City means the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas. 
    Commodities means all property, including, without limitation, equipment, printing, stationery, supplies, materials, goods, and other tangible things requisite for public purposes, but not including leases on real property, real property, or an interest in real property, or exempt commodities or services; 
    Firm resident in the city means any individual, partnership, association, or corporation, whether domestic or foreign, that: 
(1)  Maintains at least one (1) staffed place of business located within the corporate limits of the city; 
(2)  For not less than two (2) consecutive years immediately before submitting a bid, has paid taxes to the county that benefit the city on either real or personal property used or intended to be used in connection with the firm's business; and 
(3)  Has a valid business registration/license with the city. 
    Lowest qualified bid means the lowest bid that conforms to the specifications and request for bids. 
    Nonresident firm means a firm that is not included in the definition of a "firm resident in the city;" and 
    Services means labor, time, or effort furnished by a contractor. 
(Ord. No. 6590, § 1, 12-18-17) 
Sec. 2-167. - Same-Application. 
(a)  In the purchase of commodities or services by competitive bidding, a preference of five (5) percent shall be granted to the lowest qualified bid for a bidder that qualifies as a firm resident in the city. 
(b)  The maximum monetary amount of any preference granted, regardless of the bid amount or percentage of preference, shall be one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). 
(c)  (1)  In calculating the preference to be allowed, the total amount of each bid of each firm resident in the city who claims the preference shall be reduced by five (5) percent from the total amount of each bid. 
(2)  If after making the deduction, the bid of any firm resident in the city claiming the preference is lower than the bid of the nonresident firm, then the award shall be made to the firm resident in the city that submitted the lowest qualified bid, whether or not that particular firm resident in the city claimed the preference. 
(d)  (1)  The preference provided for in this section only applies in comparing bids when one (1) or more bids are by a firm resident in the city and the other bid or bids are by a nonresident firm. 
(2)  The preference provided for in this section only applies in comparing bids of firms resident in the city after preferential rejection of bids of nonresident firms, or to the situation where all bidders are firms resident in the city. 
(3)  a.  If any provision of this section conflicts with any provision of federal or state law or any rule or regulation made under federal or state law pertaining to federal grants-in-aid programs or other federal or state aid programs, the provision shall not apply to the state supported or federal supported contract(s) for the purchase of commodities or services to the extent of the conflict. 
b.  Provided, however, that all other provisions of this section which do not conflict apply to contracts to purchase commodities or services to be paid, in whole or in part, from federal funds. 
(4)  The provisions of this section apply to public works projects, capital improvements, commodities, materials, equipment, and services procured by the city, including those purchases and contracts for services as provided in this article. 
(5)  Should this section and A.C.A. § 19-11-259 (regarding preferences among bidders) apply, both the preference provided in this section and the preference provided in § 19-11-259 shall apply. 
(6)  Should any provision of this section conflict with federal purchasing laws or bidding preferences relating to projects to the supply water or wastewater utility services, operations, or maintenance to a federal military installation by a municipality of the state, said provision shall not apply or be given effect. 
(Ord. No. 6590, § 1, 12-18-17) 
Secs. 2-168-2-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, ETC.[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- There is a Pine Bluff-Jefferson County Port Authority which is governed by A.C.A. 14-185-100 et seq. 
Cross reference- Aviation commission, § 6-26 et seq.; health facilities board, § 12-26 et seq.; board of trustees of arts and science center, § 17-29; civic auditorium complex commission, § 17-51 et seq.; parks and recreation commission, § 17-76 et seq.; retirement board, § 19-39; city planning commission, § 20-26 et seq.; utility commission, § 28-46; board of zoning adjustments, § 29-35. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-181. - Limitation of terms. 
(a)  No person shall be eligible for reappointment to the following commissions of the city: 
(1)  Aviation commission. 
(2)  Civic auditorium complex commission. 
(3)  Civil service commission. 
(4)  Crime commission. 
(5)  Parks and recreation commission. 
(b)  Reappointment shall be defined as to not include the appointment of a person who has served an unexpired portion of the term of another. 
(c)  No person shall serve more than ten (10) consecutive years on any board or commission of the city, excluding any period the person served fulfilling the unexpired term of another person, and excluding a period in which the person "held over" as a member of the board or commission after expiration of the term pending replacement or reappointment. 
(d)  No person shall serve more than two (2) consecutive terms on a board or commission of the city, excluding any period the person served fulfilling the unexpired term of another person, and excluding a period in which the person "held over" as a member of the board or commission after expiration of the term pending replacement or reappointment. 
(Ord. No. 5133, §§ 1-4, 5-5-86; Ord. No. 5801, 4-5-99; Ord. No. 5996, 3-4-02; Ord. No. 6002, § 3, 5-6-02; Ord. No. 6218, § 1, 2-20-07; Ord. No. 6376, § 2, 2-6-12; Ord. No. 6506, §§ 1, 2, 2-17-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6218, § 1, adopted Feb. 20, 2007, shall apply retroactively to all persons currently serving as members of a city board of commission. 
Cross reference- Aviation commission, § 6-26 et seq.; civic auditorium complex commission, § 17-51 et seq.; parks and recreation commission, § 17-76 et seq.; utility commission, § 28-46. 
Sec. 2-182. - Appointment of employees of independent commissions or boards to other commissions or boards. 
(a)  An employee of an independent commission or board of the city may be appointed to another independent board or commission (but not the board or commission which employs him) of the city. 
(b)  An individual who is employed by one (1) independent commission or board and is appointed to another such body must abstain from voting or participating in any action of the commission or board to which he is appointed which may impact, effect, or concern the commission or board which employs him. 
(Ord. No. 6328, §§ 1, 2, 8-16-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6328, §§ 1, 2, adopted Aug. 16, 2010, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, said provisions have been included as § 2-182, at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 2-183. - Boards and commissions; notice period before an available position is filled. 
(a)  No appointment to a vacancy in a position on any city board or commission shall be made or confirmed by the city council until at thirty (30) days has passed between the date the vacancy was created and the date a successor is confirmed, and the availability of the position shall be posted as prescribed in subsection (c) below. 
(b)  The re-appointment of any person to a position on any city board or commission shall not be made or confirmed by the city council until at least thirty (30) days notice of the availability of the position shall be posted as prescribed in subsection (c) below. 
(c)  An available position on any of the city's boards or commissions shall be advertised on the city's website and on the city's local access cable television channel for at least thirty (30) days before an appointment to the position is made or confirmed by the city council. Additionally, the mayor shall be responsible for ensuring that a notice of the available position is published in a newspaper with local circulation on at least one (1) occasion at least ten (10) calendar days before an appointment to the position is made or confirmed by the city council. For all media, the notice shall: 
(1)  Inform the public that there is a vacancy or available position on the board or commission; 
(2)  State the qualifications for the position or make reference to the relevant provision of the Arkansas Code or City Code which prescribes the qualifications; 
(3)  State that interested persons should submit or complete a written statement setting forth his or her qualifications and desire for the position; and 
(4)  State the deadline for submission or completion of statements of interest. 
(d)  As used in this section: 
(1)  "Vacancy" means that the incumbent in the position has resigned, is deceased, is incapacitated, or is otherwise unable or unwilling to continue service in the position to the expiration of the term of appointment. 
(2)  "Available position" means any position on a city board or commission, for which the incumbent's term of appointment is due to expire within sixty (60) days, or which has expired and the incumbent is holding over awaiting the appointment and confirmation of a successor. 
(Ord. No. 6352, § 1, 5-2-11) 
Secs. 2-184-2-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HISTORICAL RAILROAD PRESERVATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-191. - Established, purpose. 
    A historical railroad preservation commission is hereby established with authority and responsibility to preserve, restore, maintain and operate Steam Locomotive 819, and any and all equipment, rolling stock, or property which may accrue to the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-240) 
Sec. 2-192. - Composition. 
    The historical railroad preservation commission shall be composed of seven (7) members appointed by the mayor, with city council approval. 
(Code 1967, § 2-241) 
Sec. 2-193. - Terms of office. 
    The term of office for each member of the historical railroad preservation commission shall be four (4) years. 
(Code 1967, § 2-242) 
Sec. 2-194. - Organization. 
    The members of the historical railroad preservation commission shall, immediately after their appointment, meet and organize by the election of one (1) of their members as chairman, and by the election of such other officers as they may deem necessary. They shall make and adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for their own guidance as they see fit. They shall meet once a month, and oftener if necessary, for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1967, § 2-243) 
Sec. 2-195. - Fiscal policies, procedures. 
(a)  All money received by the historical railroad preservation commission, whether by taxation or otherwise, shall belong to and be designated as the historical railroad preservation commission fund. The funds shall be paid into the city treasury, and kept separate and apart from other funds of the city and drawn upon by the proper officers of the commission upon the properly authenticated vouchers of the commission. The historical railroad preservation commission shall have exclusive control of the expenditures of all moneys collected to the credit of the historical railroad preservation commission fund, and for the restoration, preservation, maintenance and operation of railroad locomotives, and other rolling stock, or any other equipment necessary for the above purposes. The commission shall have the power to purchase or lease ground or to purchase, lease, erect and occupy an appropriate building or buildings for the use of the commission. When a building erected or acquired by the historical railroad preservation commission is not adapted to its purpose or needs, the commission may remodel or reconstruct such building. The commission may also sell or otherwise dispose of any real or personal property that it deems no longer necessary or useful for its purpose. 
(b)  The historical railroad preservation commission shall have exclusive control of any maintenance of museum buildings and the supervision, care and custody of the grounds, rooms or buildings constructed, leased or set apart for that purpose. 
(Code 1967, § 2-244) 
Secs. 2-196-2-205. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PUBLIC FACILITIES BOARD[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference- Public Facilities Boards Act, A.C.A. § 14-137-101 et seq. 

Sec. 2-206. - Findings and determinations. 
    The city council of the city hereby finds and determines: 
(1)  There exists within and near the city a shortage of necessary wastewater and sewage collection, treatment and disposal facilities to adequately provide for the needs of the citizens and residents of the city, which needs cannot reasonably be met by presently available facilities. 
(2)  The availability of financing to assist in the constructing, acquiring or equipping of waterworks and sewer facilities will be aided by the providing of funds for financing of such facilities by the creation of a public facilities board pursuant to the provisions of the Public Facilities Boards Act [A.C.A. § 14-137-101 et seq.]. 
(3)  The providing of financial assistance in order to enable the constructing, acquiring or equipping of wastewater and sewage collection, treatment and disposal facilities within or near the city is a proper public purpose as declared by such act and this determination of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-255) 
Sec. 2-207. - Created, purpose. 
    There is hereby created and established the "City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, Public Facilities Board," to accomplish, finance, contract concerning and deal with or dispose of waterworks and sewer facilities, and to otherwise act in such manner as may be permitted by the Public Facilities Boards Act [A.C.A. § 14-137-101 et seq.] to provide adequate waterworks and sewer facilities within or near the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-256) 
State Law reference- Authority to create board, A.C.A. § 14-137-106. 
Sec. 2-208. - Meetings. 
    The chairman of the public facilities board, or in his absence the vice-chairman, shall preside at, and the secretary-treasurer shall keep a record of each meeting. Each meeting shall be a public meeting. 
(Code 1967, § 2-257) 
State Law reference- Officers, A.C.A. § 14-137-109; meetings, A.C.A. § 14-137-110. 
Sec. 2-209. - Organization; reports. 
    The public facilities board may adopt bylaws and other rules and regulations as shall be necessary for the conduct of its business and consistent with the provisions of the Public Facilities Boards Act [A.C.A. § 14-137-101 et seq.]. The board shall have a seal. The board shall cause to be filed with the city clerk of the city an annual report as described in A.C.A. § 14-137-123. 
(Code 1967, § 2-260) 
Sec. 2-210. - Powers. 
    The public facilities board is empowered to acquire, construct, reconstruct, extend, equip and improve, assist in the financing of, and otherwise contract concerning waterworks and sewer facilities serving the citizens and residents of the city, provided, the board is limited to acting in respect of such waterworks and sewer facilities pursuant to this division unless and until specifically authorized otherwise by subsequent ordinance of the city council. In addition, the board shall have each of the powers set forth in A.C.A. § 14-137-111, as amended, and appropriate to the purposes for which the board is created. The board may enter into such contractual or cooperative agreements with such persons as may, in the discretion of the board, be advisable to accomplish the purposes of this division, including, without limitation, any private firms or corporations and any public departments, agencies, instrumentalities of the United States of America, the state, or the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-258) 
Cross reference- Water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 28. 
Secs. 2-211-2-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CRIME ADVISORY COMMISSION[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6372, § 1, adopted Dec. 5, 2011, amended Div. 4 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Div. 4, §§ 2-221-2-223, pertained to crime commission, and derived from Ord. No. 5564, § 1, adopted Feb. 7, 1994. 

Sec. 2-221. - Established, purpose. 
    A crime advisory commission is hereby established to advocate crime prevention and crime control. The commission shall advise the mayor and the city council regarding programs and initiatives deemed worthwhile to reduce and prevent crime in the city. The commission will not have any supervisory authority over the police department. 
(Ord. No. 6372, § 1, 12-5-11) 
Sec. 2-222. - Composition. 
(a)  The crime advisory commission shall consist of nine (9) members, with each member of the council and the mayor having one (1) appointment, all confirmed by the city council. All members shall be qualified electors of the city. 
(b)  Appointments shall be for a term of five (5) years. As provided in section 2-181, members are not eligible to succeed themselves, but they shall hold over in the position until a successor is confirmed. The commissioners first appointed hereafter shall serve staggered terms determined by the drawing of lots: three (3) for a term of three (3) years; three (3) for a term of four (4) years, and three (3) for terms of five (5) years, with their successors to serve full terms. 
(Ord. No. 6372, § 1, 12-5-11) 
Sec. 2-223. - Organization, meetings. 
(a)  The members of the crime advisory commission shall, promptly after their appointment, shall meet and elect a chair, vice-chair and secretary. The chair shall preside at all meetings; the vice-chair will preside in the absence of the chair; the secretary shall ensure that all meetings are recorded and minutes of the meetings created and maintained. A copy of the minutes shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(b)  The commission shall adopt such rules of procedure, such as Roberts' Rules of Order, as conducive to the conduct of its meetings. 
(c)  The commission shall establish a regular time and date for its meetings, and vary the locations to meet in the various wards and neighborhoods of the city, to maximize public attendance and participation, including providing for public comment. The commission shall meet at least once every quarter of the year, and more frequently as necessary, with it being preferred that, at least initially, the commission meet monthly. 
(Ord. No. 6372, § 1, 12-5-11) 
Secs. 2-224-2-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT COUNCIL[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6057, §§ 1-4, adopted May 5, 2003, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as div. 5, §§ 2-251-2-254 at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 2-251. - ADA council established. 
    There is hereby created and established the Americans with Disabilities Act ("ADA") Council ("the council") for the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas. 
(Ord. No. 6057, § 1, 5-5-03) 
Sec. 2-252. - Composition of council. 
(a)  The council shall consist of seven (7) members, who shall be appointed by the mayor, and subject to the approval and confirmation of the city council. The membership shall represent a wide spectrum of experience and ability, and shall include at two (2) persons with who are disabled within the meaning of the ADA or who are employed by an agency which serves as an advocate for the rights of the disabled. The director of human resources of the city, in his capacity as ADA coordinator for the city, shall be an ex officio member of the council and shall serve as its secretary. In addition the following persons shall sit without voting rights on the council: the ADA coordinator for the transit department, a representative of the street department, a representative of the police department, and a representative from the city attorney's office. 
(b)  The initial appointees to the council shall, at their first meeting, draw lots for the purpose of determining initial terms. Two (2) members shall serve one (1) year terms; two (2) members shall serve two (2) terms; and three (3) members shall serve three (3) year terms. Thereafter, all appointees shall serve three (3) year terms. Appointees to the council shall be eligible for reappointment. 
(c)  At the initial meeting of the council, and thereafter at the first meeting of the calendar year, the members shall choose one of their number as chairman and another as vice-chairman, who shall preside over of the council in the absence of the chairman. 
(Ord. No. 6057, § 2, 5-5-03) 
Sec. 2-253. - Adoption of by-laws and procedures. 
    As soon as practical the council shall prepare and adopt by-laws and rules for its governance and establishing regular meeting times. The council shall meet at least quarterly. 
(Ord. No. 6057, § 3, 5-5-03) 
Sec. 2-254. - Responsibilities of the council. 
(a)  The council shall advise the city and all its departments and agencies of all matters relating to compliance with the ADA and implementation of the city's ADA transition plan, and in carrying out the objectives of the ADA. 
(b)  The council shall receive, review and make recommendations as warranted concerning all complaints filed with the ADA coordinator regarding the city's compliance with the ADA. 
(c)  As regards the transit department, the council will: 
(1)  Assure that qualified individuals are permitted to ride on the paratransit bus; 
(2)  Advice the department head regarding outreach to eligible persons not currently availing themselves of paratransit; 
(3)  Receive and hear appeals from a denial of certification and as promptly render a decision; and 
(4)  Assist the department in improving and expanding its service to paratransit riders. 
(d)  The council will conduct periodic public hearings and receive comments and suggestions regarding improvements to city facilities and services to better serve disabled persons and forward to the mayor and appropriate official for their consideration. 
(Ord. No. 6057, § 4, 5-5-03) 
Secs. 2-255-2-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - BEAUTIFICATION FACILITIES BOARD[15] 

Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5623, adopted Aug. 7, 1995, has been codified herein at the discretion of the editor as Div. 6, §§ 2-271-2-275. 

Sec. 2-271. - Creation of board. 
    Pursuant to the authority of the Act [Title 14, Chapter 137 of the Arkansas Code of 1987 Annotated], there is hereby created and established, the "City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, Beautification Facilities Board (the "board") with authority as hereinafter provided to extend, equip, improve and maintain the appearance and aesthetics of scenic roadways, public medians, and rights-of-way, including planting thereon and beautification thereof. 
(Ord. No. 5623, § 1, 8-7-95) 
Sec. 2-272. - Members of the board; term of office. 
    The board shall consist of five (5) persons. The initial members shall be appointed by the mayor for terms of one (1), two (2), three (3), four (4), and five (5) years respectively. Successor members shall be selected as provided in the Act. 
(Ord. No. 5623, § 2, 8-7-95) 
Sec. 2-273. - Powers. 
    The board is empowered to extend, equip, improve and maintain the appearance and aesthetics of scenic roadways, public medians, and rights-of-way, including plantings thereon and beautification thereof, contract concerning or otherwise deal in such said public facilities as may now or hereafter exist; provided, however, that the authority of the board shall be limited so as to prohibit the issuance of bonds, the mortgaging or sale of real property belonging to the city, and incurring of debt. With these exceptions, the board shall have all of the powers provided for in the Act, and shall carry out its duties in accordance with the Act. 
(Ord. No. 5623, § 3, 8-7-95) 
Sec. 2-274. - Funding. 
    The board is authorized to receive and use any available funds which are, or may hereafter be designated or available from federal, state, and local governments, as well as from private sources, to accomplish the purposes for which the board is created. 
(Ord. No. 5623, § 4, 8-7-95) 
Sec. 2-275. - Organization; reports. 
    As soon as practicable after the adoption of this division, the board shall meet and elect officers. The board may adopt bylaws and such other rules and regulations, if any, as shall be necessary or desirable for the conduct of its business and consistent with the provisions of the Act. The board shall cause to be filed with the city clerk, the annual report described in A.C.A. § 14-137-123. 
(Ord. No. 5623, § 5, 8-7-95) 
Sec. 2-276. - Procedures. 
    The board shall establish procedures, rules, regulations, and adopt any form(s), consistent with the provisions of the codes set out in section 7-271, as deemed appropriate for the conduct of its responsibilities under this article, in accordance with Arkansas law. The procedures, rules, regulations and forms will be filed with city clerk. 
    The board will schedule a time for its meetings or a regular periodic basis. Additionally the board may meet at the call of the chair, or upon the written request of any three (3) of its members. The board shall meet to hear an appeal received for its consideration within forty-five (45) days after the appeal is filed, and render a decision as provided in section 7-279. 
(Ord. No. 6507, § 1, 2-17-15) 
Secs. 2-277-2-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - TAYLOR FIELD OPERATIONS FACILITIES BOARD 

Sec. 2-281. - Creation of board.

With these exceptions, the board shall have all of the powers provided for in the Act, and shall carry out its duties in accordance with the Act.

The board shall cause to be filed with the city clerk the annual report described in A.C.A. § 14-137-123.
