Such commission is an airport commission within the meaning of A.C.A. §§ 14-359-101 et seq. 
(Code 1967, § 3-1; Ord. No. 6139, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Cross reference- Limitation on number of terms of members of aviation commission, § 2-181. 
State Law reference- Authority to create airport commission, A.C.A. § 14-359-104. 
Sec. 6-27. - Compensation; self-interest. 
    The members of the aviation commission shall receive no compensation for their services but shall be entitled to reimbursement for all expenses reasonably incurred by them in the performance of their duties as members of the commission. No member of such commission shall hold any elective office under the municipal government while a member of the commission, nor shall any such member be a candidate for any such elective office while a member of the commission. No member of the commission shall engage financially in any aeronautical enterprise other than minority ownership of stock of a certified air carrier not operating on or from the Pine Bluff Municipal Airport, nor shall any member have any financial interest in any concession, right or privilege to conduct any business or render any service for compensation upon the premises of the municipal airport. 
(Code 1967, § 3-3) 
State Law reference- Authority of city council to fix compensation of members of airport commission, A.C.A. § 14-359-107. 
Secs. 6-28-6-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GRIDER FIELD AIRPORT ZONING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; planning and development, Ch. 20; basic zoning ordinance, Ch. 29. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt and enforce airport zoning regulations, A.C.A. § 14-363-204. 

Sec. 6-46. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the Grider Field Airport Hazard Zoning Ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 3-23) 
Sec. 6-47. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Airport shall mean the Grider Field Airport, located at Pine Bluff, Arkansas. 
    Airport elevation shall mean the highest point of an airport's usable landing area measured in feet from mean sea level. Grider Field Airport has an elevation of two hundred six (206) feet mean sea level (MSL). 
    Airport hazard shall mean any structure or object of natural growth located on or in the vicinity of a public airport, or any use of land near such airport, which obstructs the air required for the flight of aircraft in landing or takeoff at such airport or is otherwise hazardous to such landing or takeoff of aircraft. 
    Board of zoning adjustments shall mean the board of zoning adjustments for the city. 
    Height, for the purpose of determining the height limits in all zones set forth in this article and shown on the zoning map, shall mean the elevation datum, which shall be mean sea level elevation unless otherwise specified. 
    Instrument runway shall mean a north-south runway having an existing instrument approach procedure. 
    Landing area shall mean the area of the airport used for the landing, takeoff or taxiing of aircraft. 
    Landing strip shall mean a defined area on an airport prepared for landing and takeoff of aircraft along its length. 
    Nonconforming use shall mean any structure, tree, or use of land which is lawfully in existence at the time the regulation as prescribed in this article or an amendment thereto becomes effective and does not then meet the requirements of such regulation. 
    Primary surface instrument runway shall mean the surface longitudinally centered on the instrument runway. It has a width of one thousand (1,000) feet. This primary surface extends two hundred (200) feet beyond each end of the instrument runway. The elevation of any point on the primary surface is the same as the elevation of the nearest point on the centerline of the instrument runway. 
    Primary surface visual runway shall mean a surface longitudinally centered on a runway or landing strip. This primary surface is two hundred fifty (250) feet wide. When the runway has a specially prepared hard surface, the primary surface extends two hundred (200) feet beyond each end of that runway; but when the runway has no specially prepared hard surface, the primary surface ends at the end of the landing strip. The elevation of any point on the primary surface is the same as the elevation of the nearest point on the runway landing strip centerline. 
    Runway shall mean the paved or sod surface of an airport landing strip. 
    Structure shall mean an object constructed or installed by man, including, but without limitations, buildings, towers, smokestacks, earth formation and overhead transmission lines. 
    Tree shall mean any object of natural growth. 
    Visual runway shall mean an east-west runway intended solely for the operation of aircraft using visual approach procedures. The runway may be a turf landing strip as well as a paved runway. 
    Zoning administrator shall mean that person charged with investigation and enforcement of the zoning ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 3-24) 
Sec. 6-48. - Zones. 
    In order to carry out the provisions of this article, there are hereby created and established certain zones which include all of the land lying within the approach zones, transition zones, horizontal zones and conical zones. Such areas and zones are shown on the Grider Field Municipal Airport Zoning Map consisting of two (2) sheets, prepared by Southeast Arkansas Regional Planning Commission and dated June 21, 1976, which is attached to Ordinance No. 4552 and made a part hereof. The various zones are hereby established and defined as follows: 
(1)  Visual approach zone. The inner edge of this approach zone coincides with the width of the primary surface and is two hundred fifty (250) feet wide. The approach zone extends outward uniformly to a width of one thousand two hundred fifty (1,250) feet at a horizontal distance of five thousand (5,000) feet from the primary surface, its centerline being the continuation of the centerline of the runway. 
(2)  Instrument approach zone. The inner edge of the instrument approach zone coincides with the width of the instrument primary surface and is one thousand (1,000) feet wide. The instrument approach zone expands outward uniformly to a width of sixteen thousand (16,000) feet at a horizontal distance of fifty thousand (50,000) feet from the primary surface, its centerline being the continuation of the centerline of the instrument runway. 
(3)  Transitional zones. These zones are hereby established as the area beneath the transitional surfaces. These surfaces extend outward and upward at ninety (90) degrees to the runway centerline, and the runway centerline extended, at the slope of seven (7) feet horizontally for each foot vertically from the sides of the primary and approach surfaces to where they intersect the horizontal and conical surfaces. Transitional zones for those portions of the instrument approach zones which project through and beyond the limits of the conical surface, extend a distance of five thousand (5,000) feet, measured horizontally from the edge of the approach zones and at ninety-degree angles to the extended runway centerline. 
(4)  Horizontal zone. The horizontal zone is hereby established by swinging arcs of ten thousand (10,000) feet radii from the center of each end of the instrument runway primary surface and connecting the adjacent arcs by drawing lines tangent to these arcs. 
(5)  Conical zone. The conical zone is hereby established as the area that commences at the periphery of the horizontal zone and extends upward and outward therefrom a horizontal distance of four thousand (4,000) feet. 
(Code 1967, § 3-25) 
Sec. 6-49. - Zone height limitations (surfaces). 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, no structure or tree shall be erected, altered, allowed to grow, or be maintained in any zone created by this article to a height in excess of the applicable height limit herein established for such zones. Such applicable height limitations are hereby established for each of the zones in question as follows: 
(1)  Visual approach surface. This surface slopes upward twenty (20) feet horizontally for each foot vertically, beginning at the end of and at the same elevation as the visual runway primary surface and extending outward a horizontal distance of five thousand (5,000) feet along the extended runway centerline. 
(2)  Instrument runway approach surface. This surface slopes upward fifty (50) feet horizontally for each foot vertically beginning at the end of the instrument runway primary surface and extending outward to a horizontal distance of ten thousand (10,000) feet along the extended runway centerline; thence it slopes upward forty (40) feet horizontally for each foot vertically to an additional horizontal distance of forty thousand (40,000) feet along the extended runway centerline. 
(3)  Transitional surface. Slopes upward and outward seven (7) feet horizontally for each foot vertically beginning at the sides of and at the same elevation as the primary surface and approach surface, and extending to a height of one hundred fifty (150) feet above the airport elevation which is two hundred six (206) feet above mean sea level. In addition to the foregoing, there are established height limits sloping upward and outward seven (7) feet horizontally for each foot vertically beginning at the sides of and at the same elevation as the approach surface, and extending to where they intersect the horizontal and conical surface. Where the instrument approach zone projects beyond the conical zone, height limits sloping upward and outward seven (7) feet horizontally for each foot vertically shall be maintained beginning at the sides of and at the same elevation as the approach surface, and extending to a horizontal distance of five thousand (5,000) feet measured at ninety-degree angles to the extended runway centerline. 
(4)  Horizontal surface. One hundred and fifty (150) feet above the airport elevation or a height of three hundred fifty-six (356) feet above mean sea level. 
(5)  Conical surface. Slopes upward and outward twenty (20) feet horizontally for each foot vertically beginning at the periphery of the horizontal surface and at one hundred and fifty (150) feet above the airport elevation and extending to a height of three hundred and fifty (350) feet above the airport elevation. 
(b)  Where an area is covered by more than one (1) height limitation, the more restrictive limitation shall prevail. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the growth, construction or maintenance of any tree or structure to a height up to fifty (50) feet above the surface of the land. 
(Code 1967, § 3-26) 
Sec. 6-50. - Use restrictions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, no use may be made of land or water within any zone established by this article in such a manner as to create electrical interference with navigational signals or radio communication between the airport and aircraft, make it difficult for pilots to distinguish between airport lights and others, result in glare in the eyes of pilots using the airport, impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport or otherwise in any way create a hazard to endanger the landing, takeoff, or maneuvering of aircraft intending to use the airport. 
(Code 1967, § 3-27) 
Sec. 6-51. - Nonconforming uses. 
(a)  Regulations not retroactive. The regulations prescribed by this article shall not be construed to require the removal, lowering, or other changes or alteration of any structure or tree not conforming to the regulations as of July 6, 1976, or otherwise interfere with the continuance of a nonconforming use. Nothing contained herein shall require any change in the construction, alteration, or intended use of any structure, the construction or alteration of which was begun prior to July 6, 1976, and is diligently prosecuted. 
(b)  Marking and lighting. Notwithstanding the preceding provision of this section, the owner of any existing nonconforming structure or tree is hereby required to permit the installation, operation, and maintenance thereon of such markers and lights as shall be deemed necessary by the Grider Field Airport Manager to indicate to the operators of aircraft in the vicinity of the airport, the presence of such airport hazards. Such markers and lights shall be installed, operated, and maintained at the expense of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 3-28) 
Sec. 6-52. - Permits. 
(a)  Future uses. No material change shall be made in the use of land and no structure or tree shall be erected, altered, planted or otherwise established in any zone hereby created unless a permit therefor shall have been applied for and granted. 
(1)  However, a permit for a tree or structure of less than seventy-five (75) feet of vertical height above the ground shall not be required in the horizontal and conical zones or in any approach and transitional zones beyond a horizontal distance of two thousand and seven hundred (2,700) feet from each end of the runway except when such tree or structure, because of terrain, land contour, or topographic features, would extend above the height limit prescribed for the respective zone. 
(2)  Each application for a permit shall indicate the purpose for which the permit is desired with sufficient particulars to determine whether the resulting use, structure, or tree would conform to the regulations herein prescribed. If such determination is in the affirmative, the permit shall be granted. 
(b)  Existing uses. No permit shall be granted that would allow the establishment or creation of an airport hazard or permit a nonconforming use, structure, or tree to become a greater hazard to air navigation than it was on July 6, 1976, or on the effective date of any amendments to this article or than it is when the application for a permit is made. Except as indicated, all applications for such a permit shall be granted. 
(c)  Nonconforming uses abandoned or destroyed. Whenever the zoning administrator determines that a nonconforming tree or structure has been abandoned or more than eighty (80) percent torn down, physically deteriorated, or decayed, no permit shall be granted that would allow such structure or tree to exceed the applicable height limit or otherwise deviate from the zoning regulations. 
State Law reference- Nonconforming uses, A.C.A. § 14-363-205. 
(d)  Variances. Any person desiring to erect or increase the height of any structure, or permit the growth of any tree, or use his property not in accordance with the regulations prescribed in this article, may apply to the board of adjustments for a variance from such regulations. Such variances shall be allowed where it is duly found that a literal application or enforcement of the regulations would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship and relief granted would not be contrary to the public interest but will do substantial justice and be in accordance with the spirit of this article. 
State Law reference- Variances, A.C.A. § 14-363-206. 
(e)  Hazard marking and lighting. Any permit or variance granted may, if such action is deemed advisable to effectuate the purpose of this article and be reasonable in the circumstances, be so conditioned as to require the owner of the structure or tree in question to permit the owner of the nonconforming use, at such owner's own expense, to install, operate, and maintain thereon such markers and lights as may be necessary to indicate to pilots the presence of an airport hazard. 
(Code 1967, § 3-29) 
Sec. 6-53. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the zoning administrator to administer and enforce the provisions of this article. Application for permits and variances shall be made to the zoning administrator upon a form furnished by him. Applications required by this article to be submitted to the zoning administrator shall be promptly considered and granted or denied by him. Applications for action by the board of adjustments shall be forthwith transmitted by the zoning administrator. 
(Code 1967, § 3-30) 
Sec. 6-54. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved, or any taxpayer affected, by any decision of the zoning administrator made in his administration of this article may appeal to the board of adjustments. 
(b)  All appeals under this section must be taken within a reasonable time as provided by the rules of the board of adjustments, by filing with the zoning administrator, a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The zoning administrator shall forthwith transmit to the board of adjustments all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(c)  An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from unless the zoning administrator certifies to the board of adjustments, after the notice of appeal has been filed with it, that by reason of the facts stated in the certificate a stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property. In such case, proceedings shall not be stayed except by order of the board of adjustments on notice to the zoning administrator. 
(d)  The board of adjustments shall fix a reasonable time for hearing appeals, give public notice and due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing, any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. 
(e)  The board of adjustments may, in conformity with the provision of this article, reverse or affirm, in whole or in part, or modify the order, requirement, decision, or determination appealed from and may make such order, requirement, decision or determination, as may be appropriate under the circumstances. 
(Code 1967, § 3-31) 
Sec. 6-55. - Judicial review. 
    Any person aggrieved, or any taxpayer affected, by any decision of the board of adjustments, may appeal to the county circuit court as provided for in A.C.A. § 14-363-208. 
(Code 1967, § 3-32) 
Sec. 6-56. - Conflicting regulations. 
    Where there exists a conflict between any of the regulations or limitations prescribed in this article and any other regulations applicable to the same area, whether the conflict be with respect to the height of structures or trees, the use of land, or any other matter, the more stringent limitation or requirement shall govern and prevail. 
(Code 1967, § 3-34) 
Chapter 7 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Grider Field airport zoning, § 6-46 et seq.; fire prevention code, § 10-51 et seq.; flood damage prevention, Ch. 11; planning and development, Ch. 20; signs and advertising, Ch. 22; subdivisions, Ch. 25; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 28; zoning, Ch. 29. 
State Law reference- Authority to legislate on matters pertaining to municipal affairs, A.C.A. § 14-43-601 et seq.; authority to enact building regulations, A.C.A. § 14-56-201 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Energy efficiency standards for new buildings adopted. 
    The 1979 Arkansas rules and regulations for energy efficiency standards for new building construction, as adopted by the Arkansas Department of Energy, are adopted by reference. 
(Code 1967, § 6-30(a)) 
State Law reference- Adoption of technical code by reference, A.C.A. § 14-55-207. 
[Sec. 7-1.1. - International Existing Energy Conservation Code adopted.] 
    The 2009 edition of the International Existing Energy Conservation Code, the ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 90.1-2007 Energy Standards for Buildings Except Low-Rise Residential Buildings, and the Arkansas Energy Code for New Buildings for New Buildings Construction Supplements and Amendments (2011 edition) are adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 6432, 3-18-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6432, adopted March 18, 2013, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, these provisions have been added at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 7-2. - Boarding of structures within city. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and misdemeanor for the owner or manager of a structure within the city to board up the structure except as provided herein. 
(b)  A building inspector may direct that a structure be boarded up and secured for a period necessary for the owner or manager to secure the necessary permits and bring the structure into compliance with city Code or until the structure is razed and removed. The fire marshal of the city may direct a structure be boarded up and secured consistent with the city's fire code. 
(c)  The boarding and securing of a structure or condition does not relieve the owner or manager of the requirement to diligently pursue rehabilitation and repair or demolishment and/or removal of the structure or condition. All boards and materials used to secure shall be weatherproofed or treated and shall be painted and maintained with a color of paint which blends with the overall structure. For purposes of this section, "diligently pursue" means to secure the necessary permits and begin actual work to rehabilitate or repair the structure or condition, or cause its demolition or removal, within thirty (30) days of the date the structure was boarded and secured. 
(Ord. No. 5997, §§ 1-3, 3-18-02) 
Sec. 7-3. - Penalty for failure to complete repairs within time specified in building permit. 
(a)  Any person or entity desiring to repair property which previously has been submitted to the city council for condemnation, but which the council extended additional time to make repairs to the property to bring into compliance with city Codes, must obtain a building permit from the department of inspection within three (3) business days after the council meeting in which the person or entity received the extension. A building permit issued for property which has previously been submitted to the council for condemnation as a public nuisance but which the council has granted an extension of time to make repairs should bear the following notation: "Issued by virtue of city council extension granted on (date of action).", and further state prominently the time allowed within which repairs must be completed. 
(b)  Any person or entity who fails to secure the building permit within three (3) business days of the council meeting in which an extension was granted shall be deemed to have forfeited the extension and shall not be issued a permit. It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for a person or entity to begin repair work without the permit. The property will promptly be resubmitted to the city council for condemnation. 
(c)  Any person or entity who, having obtained the extension and the building permit, shall fail to complete the repairs necessary to bring the property in compliance with city Codes within the time specified, shall be assessed a penalty of ten dollars ($10.00) per day for each day the repairs are not completed or until such time the property is condemned as a public nuisance by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 5998, §§ 1-3, 3-18-02) 
[Sec. 7-4. - Nonresidential construction surcharge.] 
(a)  That chapter 7 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, buildings and building regulations, is hereby amended to include a section assessing a surcharge of fifty cents ($.50) per one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) of construction authorized by any nonresidential construction permit issued by the city, to support the construction industry craft training program in vocational and technical schools and colleges in the state. 
(b)  The inspection department, as issuer of said construction permits, shall be responsible for collecting the surcharge and remitting it by the fifteenth (15th) day of the following month after collection thereof to the department of finance and administration/revenue division/miscellaneous tax section. 
(c)  The City of Pine Bluff will retain five (5) percent of each permit surcharge collected for the cost of administration. 
(d)  That said surcharge is need of immediate collection and shall be forthwith collected and remitted to the state. Said collection affects the ability of the state to properly train those involved in the construction industry, failure of which has a detrimental effect on the public health, safety and welfare. Therefore an emergency is hereby declared to exist and this ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after the date of passage. 
(Ord. No. 6306, §§ 1-4, 12-21-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6306, §§ 1-4, Dec. 21, 2009, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, said provisions have been included as § 7-4, at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 7-5. - Contractors. 
(a)  For purposes of this chapter, "home improvement contractor" means any person, firm, partnership, co-partnership, association, corporation or other organization or any combination that attempts to or submits a bid, or contracts, undertakes, or assumes charge in a supervisory capacity or otherwise manages the reconstruction, alteration, renovation, repair, modification, improvement, removal, demolition, or addition to any preexisting single-family residence or the property or structures appurtenant thereto. 
(b)  A person who is the owner of a single-family residence acting as his or her own home improvement contractor on his or her own property shall not be required to submit to any additional professional qualification imposed by the city to perform the work. 
(c)  A contractor licensed as a residential building contractor or a residential remodeler (by the State of Arkansas) is considered to be a "general contractor" and is authorized to perform any of the "specialties" associated with the classification in question. A contractor licensed as a residential specialty contractor is authorized to only perform the functions of the specific specialty for which a license is held. 
(d)  A person who acts as a residential building contractor in the construction of his or her own residence is not required to be licensed as a residential building contractor unless the person builds more than one (1) residence per year. 
(e)  A person, performing work on a residential structure located on his or her own property, shall not be required to have a residential contractor's license and may perform any work, except electrical or plumbing work, on the property, unless Arkansas law explicitly requires the work in question be performed by a licensed contractor in the field. 
(Ord. No. 6479, § 1, 3-17-14) 
Sec. 7-6. - Failure to obtain a permit. 
    In case it shall be discovered that any work has been performed or put into use for which no permit has been issued as may be required by any provision of this chapter or by a provision of a technical code adopted in this chapter, the violator shall pay a fee equal to three (3) times the permit fee which shall have been paid for work done requiring said permit, and no additional permits shall be granted until all fees are paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 6594, § 4, 3-5-18) 
Secs. 7-7-7-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INSPECTION DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Departments, Ch. 2, Art. IV. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-26. - Personnel. 
(a)  Reserved. 
(b)  The personnel of the zoning and inspection department shall be chief inspector, chief housing inspector, building inspector, electrical inspector, plumbing inspector, housing inspector, administrative assistant, and such other personnel as may be authorized by the city council. 
(c)  The personnel of the inspection department shall be selected by the chief inspector subject to the approval of the mayor. 
(Code 1967, § 6-1; Ord. No. 5624, § 1, 9-5-95; Ord. No. 5791, § 1, 2-1-99; Ord. No. 5959, § 2, 8-6-01; Ord. No. 6003, 5-6-02) 
Sec. 7-27. - Duties. 
    In addition to the enforcement of this chapter, the following members of the inspection department shall have the duties herein prescribed: 
(1)  The chief inspector shall have direct general supervision over the entire inspection department and all other duties and responsibilities given to the various branches of the inspection department as the chief inspector may be licensed or otherwise qualified to perform. 
(2)  The building inspector and all inspectors cross-certified and/or otherwise trained in building regulations shall be charged with the supervision of the issuance of building, razing and removing permits, notices of violations, condemnation notices, the enforcement of all regulations of the building code and all state and local codes pertaining to buildings and structures and keeping of records of his unit. 
(3)  The plumbing inspector and all inspectors cross-certified and/or otherwise trained in plumbing regulations shall be charged with the supervision of the issuance of plumbing, gas, water and sewer connection permits; the enforcement of all state and local codes pertaining to plumbing, gas, water and sewer installations; and keeping of records of his unit and the issuance of notices of plumbing violations, condemnation notices, and razing and removing permits. 
(4)  The electrical inspector and all inspectors cross-certified and/or otherwise trained in electrical regulations shall be charged with the supervision of the issuance of electrical permits and the enforcement of the regulations of the electrical code and local codes pertaining to the construction and maintenance of electrical wiring and apparatus; keeping of records of his unit, and the issuance of notices of electrical violations, condemnation notices and razing and removing permits. 
(5)  The mechanical inspector and all inspectors cross-certified and/or otherwise trained in mechanical regulations shall be charged with the supervision of the issuance of mechanical permits; the enforcement of all state and local codes pertaining to mechanical installations and apparatus, notices of mechanical violations, condemnation notices, and razing and removing permits. 
(6)  The housing inspector and all inspectors cross-certified and/or otherwise trained in housing regulations shall be charged with the enforcement of the housing code and local codes pertaining to existing housing, maintenance of property, notices of housing violations, condemnation notices, and razing and removing permits. 
(7)  The administrative assistant shall be responsible for duties assigned by the director of the inspection department, including but not limited to maintaining records of activities of the department as assigned by the director; coordinating daily activities involving inspection; dealing with the public in a problem-solving environment; representing the inspection department and promoting a more positive image of the department within the community, including working with neighborhood groups in meeting their specific needs; developing and maintaining an interactive web site for the department to allow access by the public to information; and working with the director to improve efficiencies and systems for the department. 
(Code 1967, § 6-2; Ord. No. 5436, § 1, 5-20-91; Ord. No. 5959, § 3, 8-6-01) 
Sec. 7-28. - Qualifications of members. 
(a)  The chief inspector shall be a person of proven executive ability conversant with the duties of the personnel of the department and of good moral character. 
(b)  The building inspector shall have had at least ten (10) years' experience as an architect, construction engineer, building inspector, building contractor, or superintendent of building construction, for five (5) years of which he shall have been in responsible charge of work. 
(c)  The plumbing inspector shall be an experienced plumber with at least six (6) years' plumbing experience, or at least four (4) years' experience as a plumbing inspector. 
(d)  The electrical inspector shall have had at least five (5) years' experience as an electrician, preferably holding a master's license, or at least four (4) years' experience as an electrical inspector. 
(e)  The mechanical inspector shall have had at least five (5) years' experience as a mechanical inspector or as a superintendent, foreman, or competent mechanic in charge of mechanical construction. 
(f)  The housing inspector shall have the ability to detect faults and knowledge of testing and corrective measures in construction or rehabilitation of residential structures and also must have an understanding of real estate and possess the ability to understand and determine legal descriptions for real property. 
(Code 1967, § 6-3) 
Secs. 7-29-7-35. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IIA. - CODE ENFORCEMENT DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 7-41. - Personnel. 
(a)  The code enforcement department shall consist of a department head appointed by and serving at the discretion of the mayor. The department head will have the general supervision over the personnel and activities of the department. The department head will be the chief enforcement officer for the city. 
(b)  The remaining personnel of the code enforcement department shall be as authorized and provided for in the annual municipal budget. 
(Ord. No. 6600, § 3, 3-19-18) 
Sec. 7-42. - Duties. 
(a)  The personnel of the code enforcement department shall enforce provisions of the technical codes adopted by the city council, or as otherwise required by law, and all other duties and responsibilities assigned to the department by ordinance. 
(b)  Personnel of the department shall be qualified and trained to perform the essential functions of his or her position and have the technical expertise required for the position. Personnel shall undergo continuing training to remain abreast of developments in their field of expertise; personnel shall also be cross-trained in the different areas of responsibility within the department, to maximize productivity and efficiency. 
(c)  Personnel may be authorized by the mayor to issue citations and summons to any person it is reasonable believed has or is in violation of the provisions of one or more of the city's technical codes, or in enforcement of the city's provisions regarding nuisances and nuisance abatement found in chapter 16 of this Code, which shall direct the person cited to appear in the Pine Bluff District Court to answer the citation or summons. 
(Ord. No. 6600, § 3, 3-19-18) 
Secs. 7-43-7-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 7-46. - Code adopted. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted for the city the building code, known as the International Existing Building Code, being particularly the 2012 edition thereof, with subsequent amendments and revisions, and the whole thereof, save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified, or amended, of which not less than three (3) copies have been and are now filed in the office of the city clerk, is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein. 
(b)  In case it shall be discovered that any work has been performed or put into use for which no permit has been issued as may be required by the code adopted in subsection (a), the violator shall pay a fee equal to three (3) times the permit fee which shall have been paid for work done requiring said permit, and no additional permits shall be granted until all fees are paid in full. 
(Code 1967, §§ 6-18, 6-28; Ord. No. 5437, § 1, 5-20-91; Ord. No. 5508, § 1, 7-20-92; Ord. No. 6201, § 2, 12-4-06; Ord. No. 6395, § 2, 7-16-12; Ord. No. 6428, 1-22-13; Ord. No. 6594, § 1, 3-5-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6395, § 2, adopted July 16, 2012, amended § 7-46 which pertained to adopted, violations. In accordance with this amendment § 7-46 title has been amended to reflect the current codification. 
State Law reference- Adoption of technical codes by reference, A.C.A. § 14-55-207. 
Sec. 7-47. - Amendments. 
    The building code adopted by this article is amended and changed in the following respects: 
(1)  Not withstanding any provision of the Residential Code, when a building or structure is to demolished, it shall be done so in accordance with provisions of an ordinance or resolution passed by the city council condemning the building or structure and ordering it razed and removed. 
(2)  Section 101.4. Referenced codes. Codes referenced elsewhere in this code shall be interpreted to mean the applicable code adopted by the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas. 
(3)  Section 103.1 Enforcement agency. The Inspection Department shall be the agency charged with enforcement of the provisions of this code, and the official in charge thereof shall be the building official for purposes of this code. 
(4)  Appendix K. Permit Fees as referenced in Section 108.7 shall be as follows: 
"(a)  Permit fees: 
"1.  Where the valuation does not exceed $500.00, no fee shall be required, unless an inspection is necessary, in which case there shall be a $15.00 fee. 
"2.  For a valuation over $500.00 up to and including $50,000.00, the fee shall be $15.00 for the first thousand plus $6.00 for each additional thousand or fraction thereof. 
"3.  For a valuation over $50,000.00 up to and including $100,000.00, the fee shall be $204.00 for the first fifty thousand plus $4.00 for each additional thousand. 
"4.  For a valuation over $100,000.00 up to and including $500,000.00, the fee shall be $504.00 for the first one hundred thousand plus $2.00 for each additional thousand. 
"5.  For a valuation over $500,000.00 up to and including $1,000,000.00, the fee shall be $1,304.00 for the first five hundred thousand plus $1.00 for each additional thousand. 
"6.  For a valuation over $1,000,000.00, the fee shall be $1,804.00 for the first million plus $0.50 for each additional thousand or fraction thereof. 
"(b)  Moving of building or structures. For the moving of any building or structure, the fee shall be $40.00. 
"(c)  Demolition of building or structures. For the demolition of any building or structure, the fee shall be $25.00 per building or structure. 
"(d)  The fee for an existing building inspection for a new business shall be $75.00." 
"(e)  Plan review fee. When the valuation of the proposed construction exceeds one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and a plan is required to be submitted by the Code, a plan review fee shall be paid to the inspection department, equal to one-half (1/2) of the building permit fee as set forth in the Code. Such plan review fee is in addition to the building permit fee and is non-refundable. 
The plan review fee is due at the time the plan and specifications are submitted for review. 
"(f)  All permit extensions or permit renewal, thirty dollars ($30.00)." 
(Code 1967, § 6-19; Ord. No. 5443, § 1, 5-20-91; Ord. No. 6030, § 1, 9-16-02; Ord. No. 6055, § 1, 4-21-03; Ord. No. 6201, §§ 3, 4, 12-4-06; Ord. No. 6487, § 1, 6-16-14) 
Sec. 7-48. - Fire districts. 
    The fire districts of the city shall be formed in accordance with applicable law and regulation and shall consist of those lands as described upon a plat, which shall be filed and maintained in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1967, § 6-17; Ord. No. 6201, § 5, 12-4-06; Ord. No. 6487, § 1, 6-16-14) 
Sec. 7-49. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5438, § 1, adopted May 20, 1991, repealed § 7-49, which pertained to appeal from decision of building official and derived from Code 1967, § 6-19.1. 
Secs. 7-50-7-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICITY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-71. - Exemptions of public utilities. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed or interpreted as applying to any firm or corporation, or employee thereof, engaged in providing communication facilities to the public through a central office operated by it, or a firm or corporation, or employees thereof, engaged in the generation of electric current for distributing electric energy for light, heat, or power, or electricity-operated transportation. 
(Code 1967, § 12-4) 
Sec. 7-72. - Liability. 
    This article shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibilities of any person owning, operating or installing electrical wires, appliances, apparatus, construction or equipment for damage to property or persons injured by any defect therein; nor shall the city or any agent thereof be deemed to assume any such liability by reason of the inspection authorized herein or the certificate of inspection issued by the city electrical inspector. 
(Code 1967, § 12-46(j)) 
Sec. 7-73. - Electrical code adopted. 
    There is adopted the National Electrical Code published by the National Fire Protection Association, 2017 edition, together with its Annexes A through G, I and J, and Sections 80.1 through 80.13 of Annex H. Sections 80.15 through 80.35 of Annex H are not adopted. 
(Ord. No. 6586, § 2, 11-20-17) 
Secs. 7-74-7-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
Subdivision I. - General Provisions 

Secs. 7-86-7-88. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5438, § 1, adopted May 20, 1991, repealed §§ 7-86-7-88, which pertained to appeals, time limit; decisions of the city council, variations and modifications; decisions of city council, and derived from Code 1967, §§ 12-6-12-8. 
Sec. 7-89. - Disconnection of electrical service by city. 
    The city electrical inspector is hereby authorized and empowered to cause the turning off of all electric current from all conductors or apparatus which are deemed by him to be in an unsafe condition or which have not been installed in conformity with the provisions of this article. No person shall supply or cause to be supplied any electric current to conductors or apparatus which have been deemed by the city electrical inspector to be in an unsafe condition or which have not been installed in conformity with the provisions of this article and from which the city electrical inspector has caused the electric current to be turned off. 
(Code 1967, § 12-9) 
Secs. 7-90-7-100. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Permits, Inspections, Etc. 

Sec. 7-101. - Permit required. 
    No person shall install any electrical wire or electrical apparatus used to convey electrical current without an electrical permit. When a project consists of more than one (1) structure, each separate structure shall have a separate electrical permit. For purposes of determining where separate permits are needed, buildings not having a common attic space, connected only by a canopy, walkway or similar connection shall be deemed to be separate buildings. 
(Code 1967, § 12-46(a), (f)(1)) 
Sec. 7-102. - Failure to obtain permit, penalty. 
    In case it shall be discovered that any electrical work has been installed or put to use for which no permit has been issued, the violator shall pay a fee equal to three (3) times the permit fee which shall have been paid for work done in violation thereof and no additional permits shall be granted until all fees have been paid. 
(Code 1967, § 12-46(b)) 
Sec. 7-103. - Issuance of permits limited to licensees; homeowners. 
(a)  The electrical inspector is hereby prohibited from issuing electrical construction permits to any person other than those licensed under this article except in the event such person has a permanent employee who is a licensed master electrician to install or maintain electrical wires or apparatus in or upon their own premises. 
(b)  A permit may be issued to a property owner to do work in his own home provided he has a current master or journeyman electrician's license with the city or can submit sufficient proof that he owns the home and is presently residing or will reside in the structure after completion. All electrical work shall be done by the applicant. Prior to the issuing of an electrical permit the applicant must submit in writing a statement containing his name, current address, telephone number and agreement to comply with the applicable provisions of this code. 
(c)  All permits required for electrical work of any nature must be secured by the master electrician in charge prior to the commencement of such work. 
(d)  A building contractor shall be permitted to secure electrical permits and to request inspections on temporary power centers for use during construction of one- and two-family dwellings. The permit may be taken and scheduled for inspection the following workday or it may be placed on a special "will call" file to be held until being requested. The actual construction and maintenance of the temporary construction meter shall be secured by the electrical contractor. When a reinspection fee is required as a result of an improper installation, it shall be secured by the electrical contractor making the correction. 
(Code 1967, §§ 12-45(a), (b), 12-46(c)) 
Sec. 7-104. - Application for permits. 
    Applications for electrical permits shall give the exact address by street and number, approximate date inspection is desired, the name of the master electrician in charge of the work and a complete description of the extent of the installation. 
(Code 1967, § 12-46(d)) 
Sec. 7-105. - Fees. 
(a)  All applications for permits shall be accompanied by the inspection fees set forth in this section. A minimum of three dollars ($3.00) will be required for each permit. 
(b)  Applications for permits shall be made according to the following table for charges:

a.  Each "hot" wire is considered a circuit. 
b.  A complete rewire job is considered as new circuits. 
c.  Old circuits reconnected to a new or relocated panelboard are considered new circuits if more than five (5) feet of new wire is required for the tie-in. 
d.  The minimum number of circuits that must be declared for new work is determined by the square foot area.

a. b.  A permit shall not be granted for a meter loop only on a prewired house used for demonstration purposes and then set up for occupancy within the city. A licensed electrician must take out a permit for the entire wiring job and be responsible for its proper installation.

(Code 1967, § 12-46(e), (f)(2-6, 8), (g), (k); Ord. No. 5608, § 2, 2-6-95; Ord. No. 6030, §§ 2, 3, 9-16-02) 
Sec. 7-106. - Condition precedent to permanent connection; temporary connections. 
    Before any electrical power is supplied to the permanent distribution system of a building under construction, written notice must be submitted to the electrical inspector noting the length of time the temporary power will be needed before final electrical inspection is made, the understanding that the structure will not be occupied until after the final inspection, and that the party submitting the request will assume liability of any damage incurred as a result of disconnection of power from the building as a result of a violation of this article. The time limit on temporary power being furnished to a building will be determined on the basis of need, not to exceed thirty (30) days. An extension of time may be granted only by special permission. 
(Code 1967, § 12-46(f)(7)) 
Sec. 7-107. - Rough inspection. 
    Before any interior electrical wiring shall be concealed from view, or in case such wiring is in conduit, before such conduits can be concealed from view, the person installing same shall give a written notice to the electrical inspector, who shall, as soon as possible after the receipt of such notice, inspect such work; and no such work shall be concealed from view before such inspection is made. Such inspection is to be made within a twenty-four-hour period, holidays, Saturdays and Sundays excluded. 
(Code 1967, § 12-46(h)) 
Sec. 7-108. - Final inspections. 
(a)  Before any electrical current shall be used upon any electrical wiring of any character, the electrical contractor or his master electrician shall notify the electrical inspector or his assistants that the job is ready for final inspection. The electrical inspector or his assistants shall schedule the inspection for the following workday or as soon as conditions permit. If the electrical inspector finds the installation has been constructed in accordance with the rules and requirements of this code, he shall record approval of inspection on the appropriate form provided by the inspection department. Such approval shall state the name of the inspector and the date of inspection. 
(b)  When final inspections are requested, it will be necessary for the electrical contractor to arrange for the structure or structures to be inspected to be open in order that the inspection can be made. Occupied structures or structures containing personal property will not be entered by inspectors unless accompanied by owner or owner's representative. 
(Code 1967, § 12-46(i)) 
Sec. 7-109. - Approval before connection. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating in the city to furnish current of any kind, nature or description without first obtaining approval from the city electrical inspector and a permit has been issued for the use of current. 
(Code 1967, § 12-9) 
Secs. 7-110-7-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONTRACTORS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxation and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 13. 

Subdivision I. - General Provisions 

Sec. 7-121. - Classifications and qualifications of license applicants. 
    The classifications of the various branches of the electrical industry and qualifications required of applicants shall be as follows: 
(1)  Electrical contractor: 
a.  Electrical contractor shall be defined to include any person, member and/or employee of a firm, partnership or corporation engaged in the business of installing, erecting or repairing, or contracting to install, erect, or repair electric wires or conductors to be used for the transmission of electric light, heat or power purposes. The installation, repair or alteration of wiring or equipment of thirty (30) volts or more or the connection of wiring of thirty (30) volts or more shall be done by a contractor employing a master electrician. 
b.  Any person, member and/or employee of a firm, partnership or corporation desiring to engage in the business as an electrical contractor may apply for and be issued a license upon satisfactory proof that he or it is either a master electrician or employs a master electrician as its superintendent or manager and shall pay a license fee as provided in the privilege license ordinance of the city and shall execute the bond hereinafter provided. 
c.  Before any person shall engage in the business of electrical contracting, the name, residence and place of business of such person shall be registered with the electrical inspector. Such registration shall indicate the name of the master electrician managing or supervising the business of such person as superintendent or manager and the date on which such person qualified as a master electrician under the terms and provisions of this division. Every change of place of business, or change in the name of the organization or change in the licensed master electrician in charge of the business shall require immediate notice thereof to the electrical inspector, who shall make the proper changes in the record heretofore mentioned. Every electrical contractor shall promptly report to the electrical inspector the death, resignation or discharge of his or its master electrician; and if another master electrician is not secured within three (3) days after the next succeeding examination held by the state board of electrical examiners, the license of such contractor shall be suspended until a new licensed master electrician is employed. 
d.  No licensed master electrician can represent more than one (1) firm at a time. The master electrician will be responsible for the layout and supervision of all electrical installations performed by the company he represents. The actual work shall be done by a qualified master or journeyman electrician. 
(2)  Electrical sign contractor: 
a.  Electrical sign contractor shall be defined to include any person engaged in the business of manufacture, installation, erection and repair of electrically illuminated or operated signs. They shall be entitled to install, repair and maintain electrical equipment and wiring within the sign enclosure or structure and make supply connections provided there is an approved outlet of sufficient capacity available within fifteen (15) feet of the sign to be connected. Electrical work shall be done by a master or journeyman electrician. Only those electricians currently licensed as specialist sign electricians will be permitted to retain that classification. No more licenses will be issued for specialist sign electricians. 
b.  Electrical sign contractors shall pay the same license fee as electrical contractor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-27) 
Sec. 7-122. - Compliance with city ordinances by licensees. 
    Every person holding an Arkansas State License or City of Pine Bluff License, pursuant to the terms and provisions of this article shall conform strictly with the provisions of this article governing the installation, repair, construction and inspection of electrical work in the city. 
(Code 1967, §§ 12-34, 12-46(a); Ord. No. 5608, § 3, 2-6-95) 
Sec. 7-123. - Electrical contractor's bond. 
    Every person doing business in the city as a licensed electrical contractor shall file with the electrical inspector a bond in the penal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) with a recognized surety company authorized to do business with the city. The bond and surety shall be approved by the city attorney, the condition of the bond being that the bond shall indemnify and hold harmless the city or any citizen of the city damaged by improper electrical work; and conditioned further that the principal shall strictly comply with the ordinances of the city governing such work, that the principal will do or cause no work to be done without a permit, and will report work done for inspection in conformity with the laws and ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 12-33; Ord. No. 5441, § 1, 5-20-91) 
Secs. 7-124-7-140. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - License[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- State licensing of electricians, A.C.A. § 17-25-101 et seq. 

Sec. 7-141. - Examinations and license required; penalty for violations. 
(a)  No person, member and/or employee of a firm or corporation shall engage in the electrical business of installing, altering or repairing any electrical wiring, fixtures, devices or equipment in the city unless such persons, members and/or employees of a firm or corporation have been duly examined and have been issued a license by the state board of electrical examiners to engage in such business. Permits to perform electrical work shall be issued by the electrical inspector only to such persons, members and/or employees of a firm or corporation properly licensed. 
(b)  Any person, member and/or employee of a firm or corporation in the city engaged in performing electrical work covered by this article or holding himself or itself out as licensed to do electrical industry without first successfully passing an examination given by the state board of electrical examiners and securing a license in a manner hereinafter set forth shall, upon conviction thereof, be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 12-25) 
Sec. 7-142. - Examinations; application; fee; issuance of license; renewal. 
(a)  Every person desiring to engage in the electrical business shall, before engaging in such business, successfully pass an examination prepared, conducted and held by the state board of electrical examiners as provided by state law. 
(b)  Any person currently licensed by the city electrical examiners board shall retain such license classification as long as the license fees and any bonds required are kept current with the city. If the license is not renewed by June thirtieth of each year, the license will not be renewable by the city. After such date, such person shall obtain a license from the state board of electrical examiners as provided by state law. 
(c)  All city licenses shall expire on the thirty-first day of December of each year. All duly licensed persons who apply for such license within thirty-one (31) days after the expiration date shall pay a penalty of five dollars ($5.00) in addition to the regular renewal fee. 
(d)  Renewal fees for city-licensed electricians shall be as follows: 
(1)  Master electrician ..... $ 7.50 
(2)  Journeyman electrician ..... 5.00 
(3)  Specialist sign electrician ..... 3.00 
(4)  Apprentices, no charge, no license required. 
(Code 1967, § 12-26) 
Sec. 7-143. - License nontransferable; revocation; unlawful to operate without. 
(a)  No license certificates issued by the city shall be assignable or transferable. A license issued may be suspended or revoked by the city council for any violation of the terms of this article or any ordinance governing the installation or inspection of electrical work, or any rules and regulations promulgated by the city council after a hearing to be held at the convenience of the council. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person licensed under this division to do any electrical work covered by this article after the expiration of the license issued, or after the revocation or suspension of such license, or to perform any such work without a valid license from the city or state. 
(Code 1967, § 12-28) 
Sec. 7-144. - Display of license. 
    Every person licensed under this division shall display such license in his place of business. 
(Code 1967, § 12-29) 
Sec. 7-145. - Fraud in connection with license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person licensed under this division to alter, transfer, lend or rent his license certificate or use a license not his own. It shall also be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to be licensed under this division, or to wrongfully use a license issued by the city or the state. 
(Code 1967, § 12-30) 
Sec. 7-146. - Reciprocation of licenses. 
    The city will recognize the licenses of master or journeyman electricians from other cities provided the following criteria are met: 
(1)  An electrical examining board has been duly appointed by each local governing body to examine the qualifications of applicants for electrician's license equivalent to those required by this code. 
(2)  A regular system of inspection of electrical construction is maintained by the municipality to assure compliance with the National Electrical Code and division 4 of this article or the provisions of an equivalent code. 
(3)  The installation of electrical materials, devices, equipment or related items conforms to the requirements of the National Electrical Code, except as modified by section 7-162 of this code. 
(4)  The governing body of the other city has given written notice to the city that the conditions stipulated within this article are acceptable. A local code which meets the approval of participating member cities may be accepted in lieu of this article. 
(5)  A written verification of license has been given by the electrical inspector of the applicant's home town to the electrical inspector of the city where the application for license is made. 
(6)  The examining board of each local government has the authority to refuse or revoke the license of any person who does not display skill, knowledge or craftsmanship deemed necessary to properly comply with the accepted standards. 
(7)  That cooperation of examining boards of association member cities will assure that action will be taken by the city where the license holder has his primary license if violation of accepted standards are to the degree that remedial action is warranted. 
(Code 1967, § 12-31) 
Sec. 7-147. - Conditions for individual reciprocation. 
    Individuals or firms desiring to obtain a license under conditions stipulated in section 7-146 must have an acceptable license in the city where they have an established residence or business. Each firm operating as an electrical business or anyone desiring to obtain a contractor's license must possess a valid master electrician license of the city in which he lives or operated an office. 
(Code 1967, § 12-32) 
Secs. 7-148-7-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TECHNICAL STANDARDS 

Sec. 7-161. - Adoption of code. 
    There is hereby adopted for the city for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the construction, alteration, removal and maintenance of electric wiring and apparatus, including permits and penalties, the 2014 edition of the National Electrical Code published by the National Fire Protection Association, together with all appendices (excluding Appendix H), with subsequent amendments and revisions thereto, except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified, or amended, of which not less than three (3) copies shall be maintained on file in the office of the city clerk, and the content of which is incorporated herein as if fully set forth. The provisions of such code shall be controlling in the construction, alteration, maintenance and removal of all electric wiring and apparatus in the city. 
(Code 1967, § 12-1; Ord. No. 5440, § 1, 5-20-91; Ord. No. 5607, §§ 1, 2, 2-6-95; Ord. No. 6203, § 2, 12-4-06; Ord. No. 6304, §§ 1, 2, 12-7-09; Ord. No. 6396, § 2, 7-16-12; Ord. No. 6541, § 1, 6-20-16) 
State Law reference- Adoption of technical codes by reference, A.C.A. § 12-55-207. 
Sec. 7-162. - Work to conform to code; specifications for certain materials. 
(a)  Work to conform to code and rules. All electric work for light, heat, power or any other purposes placed in or on any building or structure in the city shall be installed in conformity with the rules and regulations as laid down in the electrical code adopted by this division and in conformity with the additional rules and regulations as set forth in this article. Where local rules and regulations are set forth in this article, they shall take preference over any rules conflicting herewith. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  Hazardous materials prohibited. No electrical apparatus, fitting or material shall be used or placed on sale when the city electrical inspector shall consider it a fire hazard or hazardous to life and property. 
(d)  Reserved. 
(Code 1967, § 12-10; Ord. No. 5608, § 2, 2-6-95) 
Sec. 7-163. - Local rules and regulations. 
(a)  Work to be neat. All electrical work of any kind and all systems shall satisfactorily fulfill the purpose for which it is installed and all work shall be executed in a neat and workmanlike manner. Slipshod or work not in keeping with good electrical practice shall be classified as defective and shall be immediately corrected by persons causing the same. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  Reserved. 
(d)  Reserved. 
(e)  Reserved. 
(f)  Circuit breakers; circuits for major appliances: 
(1)  Circuit breakers installed on multiwire circuits that are designed to operate all poles simultaneously shall be factory designed as one (1) assembly. 
(2)  All electric ranges, in residences other than split-type units, shall be supplied with conductors with minimum ampacity of fifty (50) amps and shall terminate in approved receptacles. These ranges shall be equipped with an approved pigtail of the proper ampacity for the range to be installed. Split-type units consisting of an oven and countertop shall have a separate circuit to each according to the load and may be directly connected to the circuit conductors. A range with factory-equipped armored pigtail shall be connected to an approved junction box. 
(3)  The circuit supplying electric ranges or dryers shall have an insulated neutral. A separate grounding conductor shall be provided in each circuit. 
(4)  Radiant ceiling and wall heating systems shall be on a separate circuit; wire size governed by amperage load. 
(5)  Motors of gas-fired central heating systems and attic fans shall be connected on circuits separate from other outlets; however, they can both be connected on the same circuit as each must have a separate manually operated switch and would not be operated at the same time. 
(g)  Reserved. 
(h)  Reserved. 
(i)  Reserved. 
(j)  Reserved. 
(k)  Additional meters; service mast: 
(1)  Before adding an additional meter to an existing service on a residence, the proper zoning must be verified before the installation. 
(2)  Service mast shall not be smaller than two-inch rigid conduit. 
(l)  Reserved. 
(m)  Approval of new wiring in existing structures. In existing structures, where new wiring is being installed, any existing hazardous wiring must be corrected and open knife switches, open fuse blocks, etc., removed before the new wiring will be approved. 
(n)  Roughing-in. No job shall be considered as being completely roughed-in until all joints have been properly connected, or approved connections and pigtails provided for the hanging of fixtures. 
(o)  Reserved. 
(p)  Panelboards: 
(1)  For every six (6) active circuits, there shall be space provided for one (1) spare circuit. 
(2)  A fused disconnect switch or circuit breaker shall be provided as a main for all panelboards having more than six (6) breaker spaces regardless of whether they are active or inactive. 
(3)  A disconnect switch shall be required at the service for any service line of four hundred (400) amps or greater, whether active or inactive. 
(4)  Reserved. 
(5)  Reserved. 
(6)  Reserved. 
(7)  There shall not be more than one (1) wire under each terminal screw. 
(8)  Reserved. 
(q)  Grounding. Grounding of services on the supply side of the line shall be accomplished by means of two (2) separate grounds: 
(1)  The primary ground shall be to the water piping system inside the house. A minimum of size No. 6 wire shall be run from the neutral bar of the panelboard to the nearest water pipe inside the house. This inside grounding wire may be concealed but must be in place and attached to the water pipe at the time the rough-in inspection is made. 
(2)  The secondary ground shall be a driven rod not less than eight (8) feet long and five-eighths inch in diameter for steel rods, or one-half-inch diameter for nonferrous rods. A minimum size No. 6 wire shall run exposed to view from the grounding clamp inside the meter socket to the driven grounding rod and attached to the grounding rod with an acceptable clamp. The grounding wire shall be neatly attached to the wall by means of nails, staples or clamps. 
(r)  Reserved. 
(Code 1967, § 12-11; Ord. No. 5608, § 2, 2-6-95; Ord No. 6034, § 1, 10-7-02) 
Secs. 7-164-7-180. - Reserved.
