(5)  Private companies which use an ambulance solely for the transportation of their employees for illness or injury sustained while performing their work. 
(6)  Operating a privately owned ambulance designed especially for the transportation of the infirm or physically handicapped where the ambulance is used solely for the benefit of the owner and not for hire on a fee for service or prepaid basis. 
(7)  Ambulances owned and operated by a licensed hospital and used exclusively for specialized mobile intensive care or for institutional transfers of their own admitted patients, or residents, provided such hospital shall apply for and receive a special use mobile intensive care license or be eligible for grandfather licensing, as provided for in this chapter. Such special use permit is nontransferable by the hospital. 
(Ord. No. 6451, § 1(5), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 9-46. - Intracity ambulance service. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, or entity, public or private, to operate an intracity ambulance service which provides emergency or nonemergency prehospital care or patient transports except as specifically allowed pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 6451, § 1(6), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 9-47. - Standards of production and performance. 
    The contractor shall follow the following as minimum standards: 
(1)  Equipment and management capability. Each and every ambulance and all on-board equipment utilized by the contractor in performing services which are the subject of this article shall comply with applicable standards required for licensure. The provider shall maintain the equipment and shall employ sufficient backup equipment to ensure that a safe level of reserve equipment capacity is available to provide peak period ambulance coverage even at times when unusual occurrences of equipment breakdown and routine equipment maintenance coincide. 
(2)  Personnel. The contractor shall ensure: 
a.  That two (2) persons certified under state law are on board each ambulance on ALS code 3 ambulance runs or available for dispatch, at least one (1) of which is certified as a paramedic, and the other of which is certified as a paramedic or emergency medical technician (EMT). 
b.  If only one (1) person on board is a certified paramedic, that person shall not function as the driver while the patient is on board. Every BLS ambulance subject to regulation under this article is required to have on board two (2) EMT's, one (1) to drive and the other to attend. The contractor shall establish and maintain sufficient management capability to ensure that equipment and personnel utilized are managed in an efficient and effective manner to produce the desired clinical performance and response time performance on a routine basis. 
(3)  Clinical performance. The clinical performance of the contractor and its personnel shall be consistent with and shall confirm to the operating procedures and medical protocols adopted by the local medical control. Where clinical performance deficiencies are discovered, the contractor shall demonstrate an aggressive and effective effort to correct the deficiencies in a timely manner. 
(4)  Response time performance. Response time performance standards are as follows: 
a.  Code 3 calls for life threatening emergencies. 
1.  The contractor shall furnish a diligent good faith effort to maintain an eight-minute (8:59) maximum response time for an advanced life support paramedic ambulance. The contractor shall employ enough personnel, acquire enough equipment and manage its resources in the manner necessary to meet the eight-minute response time standard on not less than ninety (90) percent of all presumptively designated code calls originating each month from within the city limits. 
2.  Where an ambulance unit is dispatched from a nontransporting first-response-only status its response time may be counted as the contractor ambulance response time even though the patient was transported by a different ambulance. In addition, the response time of a neighboring ambulance service responding by mutual aid request may also be counted as the contractor's ambulance response time, provided the level of life support capability furnished by the neighboring ambulance service is comparable to that required under this article, as determined by the local medical control, and provided that reliance upon neighboring ambulance service operators is only an occasional event and not a routine method of operation of the contractor. 
b.  Other run codes (non-life threatening). The contractor's response to other run codes shall be reasonable, but in every case where a conflicting demand for resources occurs, response to a code 3 call shall take precedence over requests for service requests. Furthermore, the contractor shall display sound judgment in developing its system status management plans to preserve a safe level of emergency response capability at all times by delaying response to requests for non-emergency service until additional ambulance units become available whenever the number of remaining ambulance units available for dispatch falls below a reasonably established safe level of emergency reserve capacity, as determined by historical demand analyses. 
c.  Retrospective designation. For purposes of this subsection, the designation of a run as code 3 shall be made by the contractor's system status management personnel at the point of dispatch on a presumptive basis and no retrospective alteration of such designation shall be allowed. However, runs may be retrospectively redesignated upward by the executive director, if the executive director disputes the original designation, and the contractor's board requests a determination from local medical control who then reviews and determines that the original designation was improper, given the information available to the EMS control center personnel at the time of the presumptive designation of the run code type. 
d.  Exempt calls. Certain types of calls may be excluded as specified by the medical director and the executive director on a standard form signed by both. Such records are maintained in the office of the operations manager. 
e.  Community response time. In addition to the response time performance standard required under this section for run code calls, the contractor shall furnish and manage its resources in the manner necessary to provide reliable emergency and nonemergency ambulance service throughout the entire city and shall perform its system status management and system status planning operations so as to minimize the differences in the respective average emergency-response-time performances among the various ambulance districts of the city to the greatest practical extent. In addition, the contractor shall take such steps as necessary to reduce or eliminate any continuing pattern of apparent discrimination in the average response time performance to any given ambulance district or portion thereof. 
(5)  Continuous physician medical control required. The contractor shall be responsible for ensuring that its field personnel at all times have access to qualified medical control and direction concerning the care of patients in the field by a base station physician or nurse. All medical control and direction shall be available by reliable radio communications, according to the communications standards and applicable standards of medical control. 
(6)  Refusal to render emergency care prohibited. It is a violation of this article to fail to respond to a call to provide emergency ambulance service, to render first-aid treatment as is necessary, or to otherwise refuse to provide any emergency ambulance services within the scope of the ambulance operations, provided that these services are not required if the patient refuses to consent to treatment. 
(Ord. No. 6451, § 1(7), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 9-48. - Vehicle permits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person subject to regulation by this article to operate an ambulance or helicopter service unless a currently valid state vehicle permit has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 6451, § 1(8), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 9-49. - Patient management and management of scene. 
    Authority for patient management in a medical emergency shall be invested in the senior paramedic designated by the contractor. Authority for the management of the scene of a medical emergency shall be vested in the senior paramedic until appropriate public safety officials arrive on the scene and take control. The scene of a medical emergency shall be managed in a manner described to minimize the risk of death or health impairment to the patient and to other persons who may be exposed to the risks as a result of the emergency condition, and priorities shall be placed upon the interests of those persons exposed to the more serious risks to life and health. Public safety officials shall ordinarily consult the senior paramedic in charge at the scene in the determination of relevant risk factors. In the event a licensed physician appears on the scene and desires to assume direction and control of patient care, the licensed physician may do so if the base station physician releases the paramedic from responsibility for directing patient care and the physician who is on scene continues care in the ambulance to the hospital. 
(Ord. No. 6451, § 1(9), 6-17-13) 
Sec. 9-50. - Extrication capabilities. 
    The ambulance service shall have extrication capabilities as defined by the Arkansas Department of Health, Division of EMS and Trauma Systems. 
(Ord. No. 6451, § 2, 6-17-13) 
Sec. 9-51. - Affiliation. 
    The ambulance service shall have a local dispatch center and its medical director shall be affiliated with Jefferson Regional Medical Center. 
(Ord. No. 6451, § 3, 6-17-13) 
Chapter 10 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Fire prevention generally, A.C.A. § 12-13-101 et seq.; authority to legislate on matters pertaining to municipal affairs, A.C.A. § 14-43-601 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Fireworks prohibited. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to manufacture fireworks in the city. It is unlawful for any person to sell fireworks at wholesale in the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of up to fifty dollars ($50.00) per offense, to discharge or cause the discharge of fireworks within the city limits, except as part of a display sponsored by patriotic or civic organizations celebrating Independence Day or other holidays or special occasions declared by mayoral proclamation, and upon certification by the chiefs of the fire and police departments that the display does not pose a fire danger or would be disruptive of the public peace and tranquility. 
(Ord. No. 5807, 5-17-99) 
Sec. 10-2. - Novelty lighters. 
(a)  Prohibitions/applicability. The retail sale, offer of retail sale, gift, or distribution of any novelty lighter within the territorial limits of the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, is prohibited. This prohibition is not applicable to: (1) Novelty lighters which are only being actively transported through the city; or (2) novelty lighters located in a warehouse closed to the public for purposes of retail sales. 
(b)  Definition. "Novelty lighter" means a lighter that has entertaining audio or visual effects, or that depicts (via logos, art work, etc.) or resembles in physical form or function articles commonly recognized as appealing to or intended for use by children ten (10) years of age or younger. This includes, but is not limited to, lighters that depict or resemble cartoon characters, toys, guns, watches, musical instruments, vehicles, toy animals, food or beverages, or that play musical notes or have flashing lights or other entertaining features. A novelty lighter may operate on any fuel, including butane or liquid fuel. 
(c)  Exceptions. The term "novelty lighter" excludes: (1) any lighter manufactured prior to 1980; and (2) any lighter which lacks fuel or a device necessary to produce combustion or a flame. 
(d)  Enforcement. The provisions of this section shall be enforced by the fire marshal, any police officer, any code enforcement officer, and any other city official empowered to enforce the provisions of the City Code. 
(e)  Violation/penalty. Any person or entity violating any provision of this section is guilty of a violation, and upon conviction therefor, shall be subject to a fine of no less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), exclusive of costs. 
(Ord. No. 6230, § 1, 11-5-07) 
Secs. 10-3-10-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Departments, § 2-121 et seq.; fire department to enforce smoke detector ordinance, § 7-204. 
State Law reference- Municipal fire departments, A.C.A. § 14-53-101 et seq. 

Sec. 10-26. - Establishment, composition and responsibilities. 
(a)  There shall be a department of fire and emergency services which shall consist of the chief of the fire and emergency services department and shall other officers and employees of such ranks and grades as may be established by ordinance. 
(b)  The department of fire and emergency services shall be responsible for the protection from loss of life and property from fire within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 13-1; Ord. No. 6252, § 1, 8-4-08) 
State Law reference- Fire department required, A.C.A. § 14-53-101. 
Sec. 10-27. - Proper maintenance of department. 
    It shall be the duty of the council to provide and keep apparatus for the efficient operation of the fire department. 
State Law reference- Council required to equip fire department, A.C.A. § 14-53-101. 
Sec. 10-28. - Schedule of positions; powers and duties of the chief of the department. 
(a)  There is hereby established and created within the fire and emergency services department the following positions: 
(1)  One (1) chief of the department. 
(2)  One (1) assistant chief of the fire and emergency services department, with the position being excluded from civil service coverage and who shall be appointed or removed at the discretion of the chief of the department. An existing member of the department appointed to the position of assistant chief, who shall subsequently be relieved of that position by the chief of the department for any reason not resulting in dismissal, shall return to that member's previous rank and pay. 
(3)  One (1) executive officer with the rank of captain. 
(4)  Six (6) battalion chiefs. 
(5)  One (1) fire marshal with the rank of captain. 
(6)  One (1) training director with the rank of captain. 
(7)  One (1) emergency vehicle technician with pay equivalent to that of a lieutenant. 
(8)  One (1) assistant training supervisor with the rank of lieutenant. 
(9)  Two (2) assistant fire marshals with the rank of lieutenant. 
(10)  One (1) public information officer with the rank of lieutenant. 
(11)  One (1) safety officer with the rank of firefighter. 
(12)  Seven (7) captains. 
(13)  Fifteen (15) lieutenants. 
(14)  Twenty-seven (27) engineers. 
(15)  One hundred eight (108) firefighters. 
(16)  One (1) non-uniform budget/human resource officer. 
(17)  One (1) non-uniform executive administration secretary. 
(18)  One (1) non-uniform administrative secretary. 
(19)  One (1) non-uniform fire training academy secretary. 
(20)  One (1) non-uniform fire prevention secretary. 
(21)  One (1) non-uniform fire prevention public educator. 
(b)  The above positions represent the total authorized complement of the fire and emergency services department. They shall perform such duties as are now or may hereafter be prescribed by law and the rules and regulations of the civil service commission or city council (as applicable), and shall obey and execute all lawful orders of the chief of the department. It is understood that authorization of a position does not imply a commitment by the city to fund the staffing of the position. 
(c)  Powers and duties of the chief. 
(1)  The head of the department of fire and emergency services shall be the chief. 
(2)  The chief of the fire and emergency services department shall: 
a.  Be in direct command of the department; 
b.  Assign all members of the department to their respective post, shifts, details, and duties; 
c.  Make and enforce rules and regulations, consistent with Arkansas law, city ordinances, and civil service regulations, concerning: 
1.  The operation of the department; 
2.  The conduct of the officers and employees of the department; 
3.  The uniforms, equipment and training of the officers and employees; and 
4.  Imposition of penalties for infractions of said rules and regulations. 
d.  Be responsible for the efficiency, discipline, and good conduct of the department. 
(3)  Orders of the mayor or the mayor's designee relating to the department of fire and emergency services shall be transmitted in all cases through the chief, or, in the chief's absence or incapacity, through the chief's designee as acting chief. 
(4)  Disobedience of the lawful commands of the chief of fire and emergency services department, insubordination or other violation of the rules and regulations promulgated by the chief of the department shall be cause for termination or other disciplinary action, consistent with department rules. 
(5)  It shall be the duty of the chief of the fire and emergency services department to secure the enforcement of all laws and ordinances relating to fire prevention and fire safety, and to issue from time to time regulations for the implementing of said laws and regulations, as allowed by Arkansas law and city ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 13-7; Ord. No. 5882, § 1, 5-1-00; Ord. No. 6252, § 2, 8-4-08; Ord. No. 6314, § 2, 5-3-10; Ord. No. 6319, § 1, 6-7-10; Ord. No. 6503, § 1, 1-5-15) 
Sec. 10-29. - Salaries paid for holidays. 
(a)  All firemen of the city shall be paid for the thirteen (13) legal holidays as set forth in A.C.A. § 1-5-101. Firemen shall also be paid for any additional holidays which may hereafter be declared by legislative act of the General Assembly of the State of Arkansas. 
(b)  Equalization pay shall be based on each man's daily rate of pay and in addition to the regular pay schedule. This equalization pay for the thirteen (13) holidays shall be prorated and paid during the regular payroll periods. 
(c)  Uniformed employees of the fire department shall be entitled to be paid the equivalent of eight (8) hours of regular compensation for their birthday. 
(Code 1967, § 13-10; Ord. No. 5785, § 1, 12-21-98) 
State Law reference- Holidays compensation for firefighters, A.C.A. § 14-53-106. 
Sec. 10-30. - Conditions of mutual aid. 
    No mutual firefighting aid is to be given to any community unless that community shall have at least five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) worth of firefighting equipment of its own in service. 
(Code 1967, § 13-10) 
State Law reference- Firefighting beyond corporate limits, A.C.A. § 14-53-102. 
Sec. 10-31. - Protection of property outside of city-Application; agreement. 
(a)  Any person within a radius of ten (10) highway miles of any fire station of the city is granted the privilege of applying to the city council for limited firefighting equipment protection. The city council may at its discretion approve or reject any such application. 
(b)  If the city council approves an application, the firefighting facilities of the city shall then be available to such applicant, but shall be available only upon the following conditions: 
(1)  An agreement shall be signed by the applicant which agreement shall state that the city agrees to furnish only limited firefighting equipment, and the applicant shall agree that any portion or all of this equipment may be recalled at any time by the city when, in the judgment of the chief of the fire department, such equipment is necessary for fire protection within the city. Such agreement shall further provide that the city does not undertake to guarantee any firefighting results, and offers only such reasonable equipment as is consistent with conditions prevailing at the time, and the applicant shall agree that no claims of any kind or nature shall ever be made against the city resulting from use and/or operation of the equipment. 
(2)  The applicant shall furnish to the city a performance bond from any reputable bonding company approved by the city collector and city attorney in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) where the appraised evaluation of the property covered by the application (which shall include real property "building" and personal property located therein) is one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) or less as reflected by the county tax records; or in the amount of two thousand and five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) where such evaluation is over one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). 
(3)  The applicant shall pay in advance to the city collector an annual ready-to-serve fee based on the appraised valuation of the real and personal property covered by each application as is reflected by the county tax records according to the following schedule of rates: 
Appraised property evaluation     Rate 
0 to $125,000.00\$100.00 
$125,000.00 to $250,000.00\200.00 
$250,000.00 to $500,000.00\500.00 
Over $500,000.00\1,000.00 
The annual fee shall be due no later than the 30th day of January of each year. 
(4)  The sole purpose of these provisions is to offer service to separate properties subject to fire damage, and the grouping of one (1) or more properties shall not be allowed for the purpose thereof. 
(5)  In addition to the above fee the applicant shall pay a usage fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per hour or fraction thereof for each firefighting company which responds to an alarm on the premises of the applicant, whether the alarm is false or comes as a result of a fire. Only one (1) firefighting company shall respond to an alarm on the premises of any applicant unless the applicant or his agent requests additional companies. The city shall not be bound to dispatch any equipment unless the equipment is available and is not needed at the time for fighting fire within the city limits. 
(6)  No application shall be considered unless and until a fire hydrant has been installed within five hundred (500) feet of the applicant's building, provided water is available. 
(7)  It is the responsibility of the applicant to remit to the city collector the appropriate fee when due, together with the most recent appraisal of the Jefferson County assessor verifying the valuation of the property. An applicant which fails to remit the proper fee by due date will be assessed a penalty equal to fifty (50) percent of the amount due. In the event an applicant shall fail to remit the proper amount together with any penalty within ninety (90) days after receiving notice by first class mail from the city collector that same is past due, all agreements between the applicant and the city for fire protection shall be void. 
(Code 1967, § 13-12; Ord. No. 5989, §§ 1, 2, 2-4-02) 
State Law reference- Firefighting beyond corporate limits, A.C.A. § 14-53-102. 
Sec. 10-32. - Same-Residential property; public property. 
(a)  The firefighting facilities of the city shall be available for residential property outside of the city limits upon the following conditions: 
(1)  The area must be contiguous to the present city limits. 
(2)  The area must have not less than four (4) blocks if the area is platted or ten (10) acres if the area is in acreage or partially platted and partially in acreage. 
(3)  There must be a petition signed by ninety (90) percent of the persons owning residences within the protected area. Such petition shall specify that the property owners agree to pay the city, in advance, an annual ready service fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for every residence located in the protection area. Such petition shall further guarantee and agree that each signor thereto shall pay a usage fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per hour or fraction thereof, for each firefighting company which responds to an alarm on the premises of the applicant. Only the owner of the property on which a fire is located shall be responsible for the one-hundred-dollar-per-hour charge. 
(b)  Fire alarms to public buildings supported and maintained by taxation and churches within the area shall be answered when in the judgment of the chief of the fire department fire equipment is not needed for fire protection within the city. The chief of the fire department or the mayor may send units of the fire department outside the city limits when there is a major conflagration destroying and endangering lives and property. The chief of the fire department may send equipment outside of the city when there is danger, in his opinion, that a fire in the immediate vicinity of the city limits will destroy property within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 13-13) 
State Law reference- Firefighting beyond corporate limits, A.C.A. § 14-53-102. 
Sec. 10-33. - Fingerprinting of prospective firemen and criminal history investigation. 
(a)  Each applicant for a position on the Pine Bluff Fire Department, as a condition for initial employment by the City of Pine Bluff, shall execute a release authorizing a local, state and national criminal records check by the Identification Bureau of the Arkansas State Police, with said check conforming to the applicable federal standards and including the taking of the applicant's fingerprint. 
(b)  Conviction information received pursuant to this section shall only be used for the purposes for which it was made available and may not be redisseminated. 
(Ord. No. 5775, §§ 1, 2, 10-5-98) 
Sec. 10-34. - Fire and emergency services department-Policies; procedures; guidelines adopted. 
    The appended policies, procedures and guidelines for the day-to-day operation of the Pine Bluff Fire and Emergency Services Department, to be contained in Book I: Administration, Book II: Operations, and Book III: Emergency Operations, are hereby adopted by reference as if set out herein. A copy of the department's policies, procedures and guidelines is maintained on file with the city clerk for public review. 
(Ord. No. 6270, 2-2-09; Ord. No. 6425, 1-22-13; Ord. No. 6426, 1-22-13; Ord. No. 6427, 1-22-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6270, adopted Feb. 2, 2009, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein as § 10-34 was at the discretion of the editor. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 10-35. - Continuity of operations plan. 
    There is hereby adopted for the city, the continuity of operations plan for city government, of which not less than three (3) redacted copies of the master plan (on DVD), have been and are now filed in the office of the city clerk, is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein. 
(Ord. No. 6439, § 2, 5-6-13) 
Sec. 10-36. - Authorized fees. 
    The fire department is authorized to assess a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per copy to a requester of a fire or incident (including first responder) report. Notice of the fees will be conspicuously posted by the fire department to apprise a requester of the cost associated with the service. 
(Ord. No. 6560, § 1, 1-17-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6560, § 1, adopted Jan. 17, 2017, added provisions to the Code but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as § 10-36. 
Secs. 10-37-10-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODES AND STANDARDS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; smoke detectors in residential units, § 7-201 et seq. 

Sec. 10-51. - Arkansas Fire Prevention Code (2012 ed.) adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted the 2012 edition of the Arkansas Fire Prevention Code (inclusive of the 2012 International Fire Code, 2012 International Building Code, and the 2012 International Residential Code), as promulgated by the Arkansas Fire Marshal, together with all revisions, reference standards, and appendices. The city clerk will maintain three (3) copies of the 2012 edition of the Arkansas Fire Prevention Code with all inclusions on file in her office for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 6312, § 2, 3-15-10; Ord. No. 6542, § 1, 6-20-16) 
State Law reference- Adoption of technical codes by reference, A.C.A. § 14-55-207. 
Sec. 10-52. - Additional codes and standards adopted. 
    The following codes and parts of codes, of which not less than three (3) copies are on file in the office of the city clerk for public examination, are hereby adopted by reference: 
(1)  NFPA 1231, "Standards on Water Supplies for Suburban and Rural Fire Fighting," 1993 Edition. 
(2)  Chapter 18, Management of Water for Fire Protection, of NFPA 1201, "Recommendations for Developing Fire Protection Services for the Public," 1989 Edition 
(3)  Arkansas Fire Prevention Code, 2007 Edition, which includes the 2006 International Fire, Building, and Residential Editions with the Arkansas amendments, appendices and reference standards. 
(Ord. No. 5587, § 1, 8-1-94; Ord. No. 5823, 9-2-99; Ord. No. 6312, § 3, 3-15-10) 
Sec. 10-53. - Assembly occupant load-Notice. 
(a)  Overcrowding prohibited/authority of fire marshal or fire code official to stop event and order remediation. Overcrowding or admittance of any person beyond the approved capacity of a building, room, or assembly space, or any portion thereof, is prohibited. The fire marshal or fire code official, upon finding overcrowding, or obstructions in aisles, passageways or other means of egress, or upon finding a condition which constitutes a life safety hazard, is authorized to cause the event to be stopped until the overcrowding, obstruction, or condition is corrected or eliminated. 
(b)  Notice required. Every room or space that is an assembly occupancy (i.e., used for assembly of persons) shall have the occupant load of the room or space posted in conspicuous place, near the main exit or exit access doorway from the room or space. Posted signs shall be of a legible permanent design and shall be maintained by the owner or authorized agent. The sign must be approved by the fire chief or fire marshal and shall be of a size, color, font, design, and wording required by the fire chief or fire marshal. A sample approved sign (such as the attachment) may be obtained from the fire and emergency services department. 
(c)  Responsible parties. The owner and the person or entity in actual possession and control of the room or space that is an assembly occupancy is responsible for ensuring that the notice required in subsection (a) is provided. 
(d)  Unauthorized tampering prohibited. Signs, tags or seals posted or affixed by the fire code official shall not be mutilated, destroyed, altered or tampered with or removed without authorization from the fire code official. 
(e)  Violations. 
(1)  It shall unlawful, and a misdemeanor, to: 
a.  Fail to post the occupancy load signage required by subsection (b). 
b.  Engage in unauthorized tampering with a sign, tag or seal posted or affixed by a fire code official as provided in subsection (d). 
c.  Permit or suffer overcrowding, obstruction, or life safety hazard described in subsection (a). It is specifically provided that each person over and above the posted maximum number of persons permitted for the building, room, or assembly space is a separate and independent violation for which the responsible party may be cited, convicted, and punished. 
d.  Permit or suffer an assembly occupancy of a room or space not posted as required under subsection (a). 
e.  Fail or refuse to comply with an abatement or violation order or directive of the fire code official to abate or correct a violation of any provision of this section. Failure to suspend an event or close a building, room, assembly space, or any portion thereof when ordered to do so by the fire code official shall constitute a violation of the occupation license of the responsible party in charge of the area, which may be revoked by the city council after notice and opportunity to be heard. 
(2)  The range of penalties for a violation of the provisions of this section shall be as follows: 
a.  As to violations of subsections (e)(1)a., b. and d. above: For a first offense within a twelve (12) month period, a fine not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or more than two hundred dollars ($200.00); for a second offense within a twelve (12) month period, a fine not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00); for a third or greater offense within a twelve (12) month period, a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
b.  As to violations of subsection (e)(1)c. above: A fine not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) per person over the occupancy limit. 
c.  As to violations of subsection (e)(1)e. above: A fine not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or incarceration in the Jefferson County Detention Center of not less than ten (10) days or more than six (6) months, or both fine and incarceration within the prescribed parameters. 
(f)  Requirements supplementary. The requirement(s) of this section are intended to supplement and be complimentary to the requirements of the Arkansas Fire Prevention Code (2007 ed.) adopted by the city, as well as subsequent versions of the fire prevention code adopted by order of the Arkansas State Fire Marshal. To the extent the requirements of this section are stricter than the provisions of the fire code or subsequent version(s), this section governs. 
(Ord. No. 6438, §§ 1-6, 5-6-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6438, §§ 1-6, adopted May 6, 2013, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, these provisions have been included at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 10-54-10-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BURNING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6255, § 1, adopted August 4, 2008, repealed the former §§ 10-79-10-86, and enacted new §§ 10-79-10-86 as set out herein. The former sections pertained to similar subject matter. See also the Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 10-76. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as the "Burning Ordinance of the City of Pine Bluff." 
(Code 1967, § 13-46) 
Sec. 10-77. - Provisions to be in addition to code. 
    No provision of this article is intended to repeal any provision of the fire prevention code of the city and shall be construed to be in addition to the standards required in the code. 
(Code 1967, § 13-56) 
Sec. 10-78. - Burning of industrial waste products. 
    None of the requirements and/or limitations imposed by this article, on the burning of combustible material, shall apply to the burning of industrial waste products where the waste products are burned in an incinerator which is so constructed and so operated as to comply with the pollution standards of the state and all applicable ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 13-47) 
Sec. 10-79. - Depositing of leaves, trash, etc. on public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to otherwise dispose of any leaves, trash, weeds, grass, litter or combustible or flammable waste by depositing or causing to be deposited the same in any ditch, street, alley, or public property of the city at any time or under any circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 1, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 10-80. - Authority to prohibit burning when certain weather or atmospheric conditions exist. 
    When the weather and/or atmospheric conditions are such that in the opinion of the fire chief any burning within the city would constitute a fire hazard, the fire chief is authorized by public announcement to prohibit all burning with the city. Any person who shall burn contrary to the fire chief's directions shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 1, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 10-81. - Fire chief to maintain list of approved containers. 
    The fire chief or his representative shall maintain a list of all approved burning containers within the city, listing the name or the owner thereof and its location. He shall make random inspections of approved containers to assure that they comply with the minimum standards set forth hereinbefore and are in a fire safe condition. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 1, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 10-82. - Application for burning permit. 
(a)  An application for a burning permit shall note the type of permit (controlled burning or approved container) desired. The time period for a controlled burning permit shall be sixty (60) days from the date of issuance. The time period for an approved container permit shall be one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
(b)  The fees for burning permits shall be as follows: 
(1)  Controlled burning permit-Twenty-five dollars ($25.00); provided, that a residential home owner age sixty-five (65) or older will be exempt from the payment of this fee. This exemption applies only to the primary residence of the home owner, and does not apply to secondary homes, vacation homes, and rental property. The residential owner must also follow the application process and rules regarding controlled burning permit. 
(2)  Approved container permit-Five dollars ($5.00). 
    Fees must be paid in advance and in cash or form of negotiable instrument acceptable to the city. When a permit expires, a new application must be submitted and the required fee paid. All fees paid for burning permits shall be retained within the fire department budget and shall be for the exclusive use of the department. 
(c)  Applicants for a burning permit shall be referred to a certain customer service site established by the fire department (site #1), where the applicant will be provided the rules and regulations relevant to the permit desired and other requirements which must be met before a permit may be issued. The applicant shall be required to sign an acknowledgment of receipt of the said rules and regulations, and his agreement to comply with same, which, along with the record of fee payment, shall be maintained of record by the fire department in a data system. Applicants will then be referred to a customer service site closest to the desired location for the permit, where, upon presentation of proof of payment of the required fee and acceptance of the rules and regulations, fire department personnel shall schedule a field inspection of the site and issue the desired permit if all requirements are met. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 1, 8-4-08; Ord. No. 6348, 4-18-11) 
Sec. 10-83. - Controlled burning. 
    At the discretion of the fire chief or his authorized representative, open burning may be permitted without the utilization of an approved container under the following conditions: 
(1)  An attendant must be with the fires at all times. 
(2)  Burning is prohibited during high winds. 
(3)  The fire must be out before sunset. Stumps may be allowed to burn after sunset, so along as an attendant is present with a means to control the fire. 
(4)  Burning must occur at location and in the volume approved by the fire department. 
(5)  Only site material shall be approved for burning. Site material means grass, clippings, leaves, shrubbery trimmings, tree trimmings, and the like collected from the site. Site material does not include garbage, rubber, plastics, metals, petroleum products, tires, shingles treated or processed lumber, or other hazardous materials, the burning of which is prohibited. 
(6)  There must be a water hose in working order connected to a functioning water source, or other means adequate to control the fire, available at all times the fire is burning. 
(7)  Open burning must be at least fifty (50) feet from any structure, property line, street or public way, and utilities. The size of the fire pile may require additional distance from these landmarks. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 1, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 10-84. - Approved containers required for burning. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful of any person to burn yard material except in a closed metal, brick, concrete, or rock container with a wire mesh screen cover, not greater than one-inch mesh, over such container. The container must be approved by the fire chief or his authorized representative before any container may be utilized by any person. 
    Yard material means grass, clippings, leaves, shrubbery trimmings, tree trimmings and the like that fit inside the approved container. 
(b)  Upon approval of the container, burning may occur only under the following conditions: 
(1)  An attendant must be present with the fire at all times. 
(2)  Calm or light winds; burning is prohibited in high winds. 
(3)  The fire must be out before sunset. 
(4)  Burning is restricted to the location approved and in the volume authorized. 
(5)  Only yard material shall be approved for burning. "Yard material" means grass, clippings, leaves, shrubbery trimmings, tree trimmings, and the like collected from the site. Yard material does not include garbage, rubber, plastics, metals, petroleum products, tires, shingles, treated or processed lumber, or other hazardous materials, the burning of which is prohibited. 
(6)  A water hose in working order connected to a functioning water source which will provide coverage of the container area is required. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 1, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 10-85. - Location of approved containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to burn in an approved container, when the location of the container is within fifteen (15) feet of: 
(1)  Any structure; 
(2)  A material composed in whole or part of combustible or flammable material; 
(3)  A property line; or 
(4)  Utility lines or facilities. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 1, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 10-86. - Hours burning is prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to burn or cause to be burned any site material or yard material within the city between sundown and sunrise. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 1, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 10-87. - Transfer of permits. 
    Burning permits shall not be transferrable from one (1) location to another or from one (1) person to another. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 2, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 10-88. - Expiration of permit. 
    A burning permit shall expire on the date specified on the face of the permit and may not be extended; provided, in the case of a controlled burn permit, when the occurrence of adverse weather or a burn ban prevents the burn, the fire chief or his representative may extend the time period of the permit. In all other cases, once a burning permit has expired, a new application and fee payment is required to secure a new permit. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 2, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 10-89. - Display of permit. 
    The burning permit shall be displayed on site of the permit address and available to any person who requests to see the permit. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 2, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 10-90. - Forfeiture of permission to burn. 
    A permit may be forfeited and permission to burn withdrawn for a failure to comply with any rules or conditions of the burn permit, or violation of local or state laws, as determined by the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 2, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 10-91. - Notice of violations; enforcement procedures. 
    The police chief and fire chief or persons so authorized by them, with respect to violations of any provisions of this article, may give notice to the offender to appear in the criminal division of the district court of the city. Such notice shall state the name and address of the offender and the date of violation; shall contain a statement of the nature of the violation; and shall be signed by the person having knowledge of the violation who is also a member of the police department or fire department. 
    The notice shall contain a printed statement in which the offender promises to appear in the criminal division of the district court, without the issuance of a warrant or other process, which shall be signed by the offender. Upon the failure to sign the notice to appear, the police chief or fire chief or their authorized representative, shall swear out a complaint and the usual procedure upon the filing of complaints in the district court shall govern the arrest and trial of the offender. Upon the offender's signing the agreement to appear and his appearance as set out in the notice, no warrant shall issued for the arrest of the offender. 
    For the purpose of discharging the duties imposed by this article, and to enforce its provisions, the police chief or fire chief or any person designated by them, is empowered to enter upon any premises where a violation of this article is or has occurred. No person shall interfere with the police chief or fire chief or their representative who are carrying out or attempting to carry out their normal or reasonable responsibility herein. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 2, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 10-92. - Fines for violations. 
    An offender shall be issued a warning citation for a first violation of any provision of this article, unless circumstances warrant more serious enforcement action. 
    Any person convicted of a second violation of a provision of this article, shall be fined the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), plus court costs. 
    Any person convicted of a third violation of a provision of this article, shall be fined the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00), plus court costs. 
    Any person convicted of a fourth or more violation of a provision of this article shall be fined the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00), plus court costs, and be ineligible to apply or obtain a burn permit for one (1) year. 
    Nothing in this section shall limit the ability of a prosecuting authority from seeking more serious penalties for a violation of this article if the circumstances warrant. 
(Ord. No. 6255, § 2, 8-4-08) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6255, § 2, adopted August 4, 2008, contained a scrivener's error which provided for the inclusion of two sections both labeled 10-91; hence, at the discretion of the editor, the latter section was renumbered as section 10-92.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Penalty for failure to obey sanitation requirements. 
    No person operating a hotel, restaurant, boardinghouse, or public eating place shall fail or refuse to carry out the instructions of sanitation offered by the state department of health. 
(Code 1967, § 14-14) 
Sec. 12-2. - Sale of ice cream from vehicles. 
    Any person wishing to engage in the sale of ice cream or other frozen products from wagons, push-carts or other vehicles in the city shall first present to the city collector a letter of compliance from the state department of health. 
(Code 1967, § 14-18) 
Sec. 12-3. - [Food service; sanitary protective devices or utensils required.] 
    While preparing food in accordance with sections 2-401 et seq. of the Arkansas Department of Health Rules and Regulations Pertaining to Food Services Establishment ("the rules"), all persons engaged in the activity of food services to the general public shall utilize sanitary protective devices and/or utensils so as to handle with least direct contact with such food. Such protective devices and/or utensils shall be either disposable or cleaned and sanitized in accordance with the requirements of section 5-101 et seq., of the rules relating to personnel. This provision shall be in addition to sections 3-201, et seq., of the rules pertaining to personnel. 
    The inspection department will monitor and enforce the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 5835, § 1, 10-4-99; Ord. No. 5844, §§ 1, 2, 11-15-99)

ARTICLE II. - HEALTH FACILITIES BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Public Facilities Board Act, A.C.A. § 14-137-101 et seq. 

Sec. 12-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Act shall mean the Public Facilities Board Act [A.C.A. § 14-137-101 et seq.]. 
    Board shall mean the city health facilities board (Jenkins Housing) created in this article. 
    Corporation shall mean Jenkins Housing, Inc., an Arkansas nonprofit corporation. 
    Projects shall mean two (2) ten-bed intermediate care facilities in the city for the mentally retarded that are or will be constructed and equipped by the corporation. 
(Ord. No. 5321, 7-3-89) 
Sec. 12-27. - Findings. 
    The city council hereby finds and determines: 
(1)  The facilities and services afforded by the projects will be made available to the mentally retarded, without discrimination on the basis of race, creed, religion or sex. 
(2)  The projects are necessary in order to properly meet the requirements of the citizens and residents of the city and the state for health care facilities and services for the mentally retarded which are not being, and cannot be, reasonably met by other available health care facilities. Proper planning dictates that provision should be made for financing any additional facilities that may be required in the future in order for the corporation to satisfy the increasing health care needs of the citizens and residents of the city and the state ("subsequent projects"). 
(3)  Financing of the projects and subsequent projects under the act is and will be necessary for accomplishing the projects and subsequent projects and will insure the availability of quality health care facilities and services to the public at the lowest possible cost, thereby benefitting the public in general and the citizens and residents of the city in particular. 
(4)  The city is authorized by the provisions of the act to provide financing of health care facilities through the creation of a public facilities board and the issuance of revenue bonds by such a public facilities board. 
(5)  It is in the best interest of the city and its citizens and residents to create a public facilities board under the act and to limit the authority of that board to accomplishing, financing, contracting concerning, and otherwise dealing with health care facilities to be operated by the corporation. 
(Ord. No. 5321, § 1, 7-3-89) 
Sec. 12-28. - Creation. 
    Pursuant to the authority of the act, there is hereby created and established the "City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas Health Facilities Board (Jenkins Housing)" with authority to accomplish, finance, contract concerning, and otherwise deal with health care facilities to be operated by the corporation. 
(Ord. No. 5321, § 2, 7-3-89) 
State Law reference- Authority to create board, A.C.A. § 14-137-107. 
Sec. 12-29. - Powers. 
    The board is empowered, from time to time, to own, acquire, construct, reconstruct, extend, equip, improve, sell, lease, contract concerning or otherwise deal in or dispose of health care facilities, including the making of mortgage loans with respect thereto (including specifically the projects and subsequent projects); provided, however, that the authority of the board shall be limited to such health care facilities as are sold or leased to the corporation or are otherwise dealt in, disposed of, or concerning which a loan is made to the corporation, pursuant to a contract between the board and the corporation. Each subsequent project shall be located within the city, but need not necessarily be at the same location and shall be operated by the corporation. The board shall have all of the powers provided for in the act, subject to the limitations of this article, and shall carry out its duties in accordance with the act. The board is hereby authorized and directed, in all dealings with the corporation to take all appropriate action with the corporation necessary to comply with the constitution and laws of the United States and of the state. 
(Ord. No. 5321, § 4, 7-3-89) 
State Law reference- Board powers, A.C.A. § 14-137-111 et seq. 
Sec. 12-30. - Issuance of bonds. 
    The board is authorized to issue revenue bonds from time to time and to use the proceeds, either alone or together with other available funds and revenues, to accomplish the purposes for which the board is created. Such revenue bonds shall be obligations only of the board and shall not constitute an indebtedness for which the faith and credit of the city or any of its revenues are pledged, and the principal and interest on the bonds shall be payable from and secured by a pledge of revenues derived from the health care facilities financed, in whole or in part, from bond proceeds or from any debt previously incurred and refinanced by bonds, and as authorized by, and in accordance with the provisions of the act, together with such other collateral as may properly be pledged. Each bond issue must be approved by the city council prior to delivery of such bonds to the purchaser thereof. 
(Ord. No. 5321, § 5, 7-3-89) 
State Law reference- Bond issues, A.C.A. § 14-137-115 et seq.
