(f)  Any law enforcement officer acting under this section shall seize as evidence the firearm, weapon, modern or primitive, bow and equipment, pistol, rifle, apparatus or implement unlawfully in the possession of the perpetrator as well as any animal or game killed or injured in the possession of the perpetrator when cited or arrested for a violation of subsections (a), (b) or (e) of this section. 
(g)  A violation of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor. The perpetrator must appear in court and upon conviction thereof, a fine of no less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be assessed and any firearm, weapon, bow and equipment, pistol, rifle, apparatus, implement seized by the law enforcement official pursuant to this ordinance shall be deemed contraband and shall be forfeited to law enforcement by the Court to be destroyed, sold, or if capable of lawful use, retained by the law enforcement agency responsible for the arrest. 
(h)  Repeat offenders shall be punished by double such sum provided for in subsection (d) of this section for each repetition thereof. 
(Code 1967, §§ 23-23, 23-24; Ord. No. 6049, § 1, 3-17-03; Ord. No. 6122, §§ 1-8, 12-6-04) 
Sec. 14-27. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6119, § 1, adopted Nov. 15, 2004, repealed § 14-27 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to hunting prohibited within the city limits as enacted by Ord. No. 5629, § 1, adopted Oct. 2, 1995; as amended. 
Secs. 14-28-14-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PUBLIC PEACE AND ORDER 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 14-51-14-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NOISE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to prevent noise, A.C.A. § 14-54-103(8). 

Sec. 14-76. - Sound devices on vehicles and aircraft. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate in the city any wagon, airplane, truck or vehicle upon which or in which there is placed any sound device whereby announcements or broadcasts are made, or music is played, unless a permit shall have been granted by the mayor therefor. Any person desiring a permit shall make application to the mayor for the same. If it shall appear to the mayor that it will be detrimental to the best interests of the public, such permit shall not be granted. The mayor is hereby given the power and authority to designate, in the event any permit is granted, the conditions of such permit, and such conditions shall be imposed so that the peace and quiet of the inhabitants of the city shall not be interfered with. 
(b)  If any person should be granted a permit in accordance with this section and shall violate the terms and conditions thereof, the mayor is hereby authorized to revoke the permit. Such person shall be guilty of violation of the provisions hereof and subject to the penalties provided by section 1-8. 
(Code 1967, § 23-37) 
Sec. 14-77. - Sound devices on premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain and operate in any place or on any premises in the city, without a permit from the mayor, any loud-speaking device for the purpose of playing music, making commercial announcements or for emitting any sounds whereby such sounds will be cast upon the public streets and places or shall so be placed and operated that such sounds coming therefrom can be heard to the annoyance, distraction or inconvenience of travelers upon any street or public place or of persons in the neighboring dwellings or premises. 
(Code 1967, § 23-38) 
Sec. 14-78. - Hours, noisy outdoor amusements must close. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of, or any person employed at, any place where an outdoor amusement is operated to operate or conduct such business between the hours from 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. of each day whereby noise emitting therefrom shall disturb the peace and quiet of inhabitants or occupants of any occupied building. 
(Code 1967, § 23-39) 
Sec. 14-79. - Loud and unnecessary noises prohibited. 
(a)  The creation of any unreasonably loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises in the city is prohibited. Noises of such character, intensity and duration, as to be detrimental to the life or health of any individual, or in the disturbance of the public peace and welfare, is prohibited. 
(b)  The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises, and noises in violation of this section, but this enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(1)  The blowing of train horns, except in case of giving necessary warning signals in conformity with law. 
(2)  The sounding of any horn or signal device on any automobile, motorcycle, bus, or other vehicle while not in motion, except as a danger signal if another vehicle is approaching apparently out of control, or if in motion only as a danger signal after or as brakes are being applied and deceleration of the vehicle is intended; and the creation by means of any such signal device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time. 
(3)  The loud playing of radios, phonographs, televisions, tape decks, amplifiers, loudspeakers, musical instruments, vehicle alarm systems or other devices not enumerated here but which cause loud or irritating noises which are plainly audible from a distance of fifty (50) feet from its source or in such manner as to annoy or disturb the quiet comfort or repose of persons in any office, hospital or in any dwelling, hotel, or other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity, particularly between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(4)  Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, or singing on the public streets, particularly between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of any person in any hospital, dwelling, hotel or any other type of residence, or of any person in the vicinity. 
(5)  The keeping of any animal, bird or fowl which by causing frequent or long-continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any person in the vicinity. 
(6)  The use of any automobile, motorcycle, or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such manner as to cause loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noise. 
(7)  The blowing of any steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or as a warning of fire or danger, or upon request of proper city officials. 
(8)  To discharge into the open air the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motor vehicle or motor boat engine except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
(c)  None of the terms of prohibition of this section shall be applied to or enforced against: 
(1)  Any vehicle of the city while engaged in necessary public business. 
(2)  Excavations or repairs of bridges, streets, or highways by or on behalf of the city, county or the state during the night, when the public welfare and convenience renders it impossible to perform such work during the day. 
(3)  The reasonable use of amplifiers or loudspeakers in the course of public addresses which are noncommercial in character. 
(4)  Noises generated by public or private school athletic contests, band practices or performances, or other school activities or functions, so long as said events are conducted between the hours of 7:30 a.m. o'clock and 11:00 p.m. o'clock. 
(Code 1967, §§ 23-40-23-42; Ord. No. 5560, § 1, 12-26-93; Ord. No. 5628, § 1, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 6162, 1-17-06) 
Secs. 14-80-14-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - JUVENILE CURFEW[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Provisions enacted by Ord. No. 5463, adopted Oct. 21, 1991, have been included herein at the discretion of the editor as Art. IV, §§ 14-121-14-127. Ord. No. 5471, adopted Dec. 16, 1991, repealed § 8 of said Ord. No. 5463, which pertained to a sunset clause for said ordinance. 

Sec. 14-121. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. 
    City is the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas. 
    Emancipated minor means a minor who no longer has a parent-child relationship as a result of marriage, or as a result of being recognized as an adult by order of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
    Legitimate parentally-approved errand means a minor performing a necessary task at the direction of the minor's parent, and that the nonperformance of the errand, or delay of performance until after curfew hours have abated, would result in injury or undue hardship. 
    Minor is any unemancipated or unmarried person under the age of eighteen (18) years of age. 
    Parent is any person having legal custody of a minor (i) as a natural parent, (ii) as an adoptive parent, (iii) as a legal guardian, (iv) as a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of the court. 
    Public place means a publicly or privately owned place to which the public or substantial numbers of people have access. A public place does not include the residence of a minor or, the residence of a minor's parent or a responsible adult. 
    Responsible adult means a person at least twenty-one (21) years of age to whom a parent has expressly given permission to accompany a minor. 
(Ord. No. 5463, § 1, 10-21-91; Ord. No. 5610, § 1, 3-6-95; Ord. No. 6271, § 1, 2-3-09) 
Sec. 14-122. - Curfew for minors. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any minor to be upon the streets, sidewalks, parks, playgrounds, public places and vacant lots, or to ride in or upon, drive or otherwise operate or be a passenger of any automobile, bicycle, or other vehicle in, upon, over or through the streets, or other public places between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., Sunday through Thursday, or 12:00 midnight and 5:00 a.m., Friday and Saturday. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any minor to be upon the streets, sidewalks, parks, playgrounds, public places and vacant lots, or to ride in or upon, drive or otherwise operate or be a passenger of any automobile, bicycle, or other vehicle in, upon, over or through the streets, or other public places: 
(1)  Between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 3:45 p.m., when the public schools are in session; or 
(2)  If the hours in subsection (1) are different from the hours of a regular school day at the school where the minor is registered to attend, the time between the normal start time and normal dismissal time for students at the school where the minor is registered to attend. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any parent to permit a minor to be upon the streets, sidewalks, parks, playgrounds, public places and vacant lots, or to ride in or upon, drive or otherwise operate, a vehicle in, upon, over or through the streets, or other public places as set forth in subsections (a) or (b). The fact that a minor is in violation of the provisions of subsections (a) or (b) hereinabove, without a defense as set forth in section 14-123, shall create a rebuttable presumption that a parent is in violation of this subsection. This article is intended to hold neglectful or careless parents to a reasonable community standard of parental responsibility. It shall be no defense that a parent was indifferent to the activities or conduct or whereabouts of such juvenile. In the case of a first violation by a juvenile, the citation issued shall constitute written notice of the violation and subject the juvenile to the penalties in the curfew ordinance. Any subsequent violation by the juvenile will result in full enforcement of the curfew ordinance, including parental responsibility and assessment of applicable penalties against the parent in district court. 
(Ord. No. 5463, § 2, 10-21-91; Ord. No. 5610, § 2, 3-6-95; Ord. No. 6271, § 1, 2-3-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6271, § 1, adopted Feb. 3, 2009, changed the title of section 14-122 from "Curfew for juveniles" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 14-123. - Exemptions. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the provisions of section 14-122, the Minor Curfew Ordinance does not apply: 
(1)  At any time a minor that is accompanied by a parent, or by a responsible adult authorized by a parent to take the parent's place to accompany the minor for a designated period of time and purpose within a specified area. 
(2)  If the minor is employed, for a period of time forty-five (45) minutes after work, provided that circumstances suggest the minor is returning from work to a place of residence. 
(3)  When a minor is returning home from an activity that is supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, a civic organization, a public or private school, or any entity that takes responsibility for the minor, provided that the activity has not concluded for more than forty-five (45) minutes. 
(4)  At any time the minor is on a legitimate parentally approved errand. 
(5)  At any time the minor is on a trip in interstate commerce. 
(6)  At any time the minor is required to leave a residence because of an emergency. 
(7)  At any time the minor is engaged in an activity that is protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution, or the freedom of speech, religion or expression provisions in Article II of the Arkansas Constitution, provided that the juvenile has on his or her person, the certification issued by the chief of police or the person designated by the chief of police to receive such information at the police department at 200 East 8th Avenue, of a written communication, signed by the juvenile and countersigned by the parent of the juvenile, with their home address and telephone number, specifying when, where, and in what manner the juvenile will be on the streets at night (during hours when this division is otherwise applicable to such minor) in exercise of a First Amendment or Article II right. 
(b)  If a minor being questioned about the possible violation of the Minor Curfew Ordinance provides a law enforcement officer with sufficient reason to believe that the minor is entitled to an exemption under subsection (a) above, the law enforcement officer shall take no more enforcement actions under this article, provided the officer may make a report of the minor's identity, the exemption claimed, and other necessary information to note the possible violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 5463, § 3, 10-21-91; Ord. No. 5610, §§ 3, 4, 8-7-95; Ord. No. 6271, § 1, 2-3-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6271, § 1, adopted Feb. 3, 2009, changed the title of section 14-123 from "Exceptions" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 14-124. - Penalties and law enforcement. 
(a)  A minor found to be in violation of this article shall be subject to the following penalties in juvenile court: 
(1)  A fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00); and/or 
(2)  An order to perform community service. 
(3)  Such other disposition including suspension, probation, or conditions for suspension for probation, as determined by the judge of the juvenile court in accordance with Arkansas law. 
(b)  If, after the first offense by a juvenile, a parent violates the curfew ordinance, this shall be treated as a first offense by the parent. For parental offense, a parent may be cited/charged and fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) in district court. 
(c)  A parent of a minor charged with violation of this article may be notified of such violation and required to appear before the juvenile court for any hearing which involves the minor. 
(d)  At the discretion of the law enforcement officer, any minor arrested or cited for violation of the Minor Curfew Ordinance may be released to immediately return home or to school, may be escorted to their home or school, or may be taken into custody and delivered to an appropriate location, or juvenile authority, to be held until a parent can be located to take custody of the minor. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall preclude a law enforcement officer from taking any or all appropriate actions for a minor's violation of any other local or state law. 
(Ord. No. 5463, § 4, 10-21-91; Ord. No. 6271, § 1, 2-3-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6271, § 1, adopted Feb. 3, 2009, changed the title of section 14-124 from "Parental responsibility" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 14-125. - Curfew for minors driving vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any minor to operate, or be in actual physical control, of a motor vehicle upon the streets, public places, or private drives, within the city between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. Sunday through Thursday, or 12:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. Friday and Saturday. Pursuant to this provision no minor shall be permitted to operate a motor vehicle in violation of the provisions of this article. In addition to any other criminal or traffic penalties that may be imposed, or any other actions available under [sub]section 14-124(d) of this article, unless a minor has a defense available to him or her under section 14-123 of this article, a law enforcement officer with sufficient reason to believe that a minor has violated the provisions of this article shall attempt to contact the registered owner of the motor vehicle operated by the minor for purposes of having the registered owner retrieve the vehicle. If no contact can be made, or if the registered owner refuses to immediately come and retrieve the vehicle, the officer may take any necessary action to protect the vehicle including having the vehicle impounded at a facility selected by the city. Any such impoundment shall be at the sole expense of the registered owner. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any parent to permit a minor to operate a motor vehicle in violation of the provisions of this article. In addition to any other criminal or traffic penalties that may be imposed, unless a minor has a defense available to him or her under section 14-123 of this article, a law enforcement officer with sufficient reason to believe that a minor has violated the provisions of this article may take any action set forth in [sub]section 14-124(d) of this article. The fact that a minor is in violation of the provisions of subsection (a) hereinabove, without a defense as set forth in section 14-123 of this article, shall create a rebuttal presumption that the parent is in violation of this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 5463, § 5, 10-21-91; Ord. No. 6271, § 1, 2-3-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6271, § 1, adopted Feb. 3, 2009, changed the title of section 14-125 from "Enforcement procedure" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 14-126. - Defense from school-hour curfew violation. 
    With respect to the hours between 9:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday only, it is a defense that the public or private school which the minor attends was not in session, that the minor is being home schooled in accordance with Arkansas law and a recess has been declared by the home school teacher, that the minor is a high school graduate or has an equivalent certification, or that the minor is on an excused absence from his or her place of schooling, provided that a disciplinary suspension or expulsion is not deemed an excused absence for the purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 5463, § 6, 10-21-91; Ord. No. 6271, § 1, 2-3-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6271, § 1, adopted Feb. 3, 2009, changed the title of section 14-126 from "Penalties" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 14-127. - Construction. 
    Severability is intended throughout and within the provisions of this Curfew Ordinance. If any provision, including any exception, part, phrase, or term, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is held invalid, the application to other persons or circumstances shall not be affected thereby and the validity of the Curfew Ordinance in any and all other respects shall not be affected thereby. 
(Ord. No. 5463, § 7, 10-21-91; Ord. No. 6271, § 1, 2-3-09) 
Secs. 14-128-14-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SURVEILLANCE CAMERAS REQUIRED INSIDE CERTAIN COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6416, §§ 1-6, adopted Dec. 3, 2012, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore these provision have been included as Art. V, §§ 14-151-14-156, at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 14-151. - Definitions. 
    Convenience store includes filling station and other establishments which, in addition to selling gasoline products, also sell fast food, snacks, tobacco products, soft drinks, alcoholic beverages, and other items. Such establishments may be called "J-marts," "Buzz Buys," "truck stops," or similar descriptions. 
    Fast food restaurant means an establishment engaged in the primary business of the preparation of food on-site for sale to customers over the counter or via a drive up window or station; filing station means all establishments falling within the definition of said entity found in section 29-2 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas. 
    Package store means an establishment primarily engaged in the sale of alcoholic beverages by the package or container. 
(Ord. No. 6416, § 1, 12-3-12) 
Sec. 14-152. - Surveillance cameras required. 
(a)  Every fast food restaurant, filing station, convenience store, and package store which commences operation on or after January 1, 2013, shall have installed, and shall maintain in good working order, one or more surveillance cameras providing a clear and unobstructed view of the check out/cash register(s) area of the establishment, with sufficient definition and lighting to recognize the face of the customer and clerk, no later than July 1, 2013. The video recorded by the camera(s) shall be maintained by the store for at least thirty (30) days in digital or other format readily accessible. 
(b)  Fast food restaurants, filing stations, convenience stores, and package stores existing and in operation before January 1, 2013, are exempted from the requirement for installation and maintenance of surveillance cameras, but are encouraged to install and maintain surveillance cameras as described above. Provided, that for any such exempted establishment, if in a preceding calendar year there shall be in excess of five (5) calls for police assistance to the location which result in reports of criminal activity required to be included in the police department's crime statistics for the year, the establishment shall no longer be exempt. The chief of police shall provide written notice that as a consequence the establishment shall be required to comply with the provisions of this article for the installation and maintenance of surveillance cameras, and subject to all penalties for a violation of the requirement. The notice shall further state that the establishment shall have six (6) months of the date of the notice to install and maintain surveillance cameras in compliance with the provisions hereof. 
(c)  All establishments covered by this article and establishments voluntarily utilizing surveillance cameras shall display prominently a sign stating, "These premises protected by surveillance cameras." 
(Ord. No. 6416, § 2, 12-3-12) 
Sec. 14-153. - Responsibility for compliance. 
    The owner or operator shall be responsible for ensuring that the establishment complies with the provisions of this article, and may be cited for any violation hereof. A manager or clerk on duty who intentionally terminates or interferes with the operation of a surveillance camera in an establishment which is covered by or has voluntarily complied with the provisions of this article may also be cited for such conduct. 
(Ord. No. 6416, § 3, 12-3-12) 
Sec. 14-154. - Noncompliance unlawful. 
    If shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for an owner or operator a fast food restaurant, filing station, convenience store, and package store to be open for business to the public if not in compliance with the requirements of this article when the provisions hereof apply to the establishment. It shall be unlawful for a manager or clerk on duty to intentionally terminate or interfere with the operation of a surveillance camera in an establishment covered by this article or which has voluntarily complied with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 6416, § 4, 12-3-12) 
Sec. 14-155. - Penalty. 
    A person who violates the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a violation and assessed a penalty of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each violation. A separate and discrete violation occurs each day that the individual operates an establishment that is out of compliance. 
    The penalty may be treated as a civil penalty and paid directly to the city collector, in which case it shall be deposited in a separate account by the finance director and utilized by the police department exclusively as reward money for combating crime. 
    For recalcitrant offenders, a citation may be issued as provided in section 14-156 hereof, and the offender prosecuted in the district court for a criminal violation. The prescribed penalty shall be the range of fine for a violation, exclusive of court costs. 
(Ord. No. 6416, § 5, 12-3-12) 
Sec. 14-156. - Verification. 
    As part of the fire department's annual inspection, the fire department shall inspect the establishment's video surveillance equipment to determine whether it is working properly. If the establishment is in violation of the provisions of this article, the fire department shall notify the police department no more than ten (10) business days after the inspection. The police department shall inspect and verify the violation, and, upon verification, issue the offender a citation. 
(Ord. No. 6416, § 6, 12-3-12) 
Chapter 15 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Departments generally, § 2-121 et seq. 
State Law reference- Municipal courts, A.C.A. § 16-17-101 et seq. 

Sec. 15-1. - Taxing of funds collected for costs in misdemeanor cases. 
(a)  Imposition, amount. All funds collected for costs shall be as provided by law from each defendant as costs upon each judgment or conviction. Upon each plea of guilty in misdemeanor cases in the municipal court where an arrest of the defendant was made by an officer of the city there shall be taxed and collected the sum of one dollar ($1.00). 
(b)  Disposition of funds collected. All funds collected pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, shall be deposited in the city treasury and shall be paid over to the custodian of the policemen's pension and relief fund and credited by him on his records to such fund. 
(Code 1967, § 22-1.1) 
Sec. 15-2. - Collection of fines, costs; reports; appeals. 
(a)  The municipal clerk shall not handle any fines, forfeitures, penalties, fees and costs taxed and assessed in the municipal court arising out of the violations of city ordinances, but it shall be the duty of the chief of police to collect such fines, forfeitures, penalties, fees and costs. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to keep a record of such money collected, and to make or cause to be made a monthly report of such money collected; and the same shall be turned over to the city collector, together with the money so collected by him during the month. 
(b)  In case of appeals from the decisions of the municipal judge in case of violations of city ordinances, the municipal clerk shall prepare such cases for appeals, and shall see that the proper affidavits and bonds are made as provided by law for appeal cases. The transcripts of such appeals shall be filed with the clerk of the circuit court within the time provided for in appeal cases, and the record of the chief of police shall show such cases as have been appealed. 
(Code 1967, § 22-1) 
Sec. 15-3. - Fines, costs, payable in cash. 
    In all cases where fines, forfeitures, penalties, fees or costs are levied in the municipal court, such fines, forfeitures, penalties, fees and costs shall be paid in cash. It is hereby made the duty of the chief of police to see that such fines, forfeitures, penalties, fees and costs are paid in cash. 
(Code 1967, § 22-2) 
Sec. 15-4. - Duties of clerk. 
    The municipal clerk shall be on duty at every session of the municipal court; shall docket the cases, swear witnesses, issue such papers as he may be called upon to issue, take acknowledgments, etc.; and shall comply with the state law in making bond for the faithful performance of his official duties, such bond to be in the amount as prescribed by the municipal judge. 
(Code 1967, § 22-4) 
Sec. 15-5. - Bail bond fees. 
    A fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid to the city for taking and entering bail bonds for each person who is incarcerated or jailed in the city jail. If one (1) person is incarcerated or jailed for more than one (1) offense in any one (1) given day, there shall be no further bail bond fee than the ten dollars ($10.00) mentioned above. If the same person is on a different day incarcerated or jailed in the city jail, an additional bail bond fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid to the city. 
(Code 1967, § 22-6; Ord. No. 5339, § 1, 10-2-89) 
Sec. 15-6. - Additional costs for conviction of public drunkenness and driving under the influence of intoxicants assessed; tax levied; uses. 
(a)  Costs assessed. The city council authorizes and directs the municipal court to levy and tax the following court costs: 
(1)  Costs on criminal convictions, in addition to such costs as are provided by law: for any conviction on a charge of public drunkenness, $1.00. 
(2)  For any conviction on a charge of driving while under the influence of intoxicants, $5.00. 
(b)  Imposition of tax. The municipal court shall tax such costs in all such cases arising out of violations of city ordinances or state laws. Costs so collected shall be kept in a separate account by the clerk, accounted for, and paid over to the city treasurer at the same time and in the same manner as other court costs in the first class of accounts. 
(c)  Use of funds. Costs collected under this section shall be paid into a fund to be used for the purchase, maintenance and operation of equipment designed to test the fact and degree of intoxication of persons arrested on charges of public drunkenness or driving under the influence of intoxicants. Surplus funds, if any after accomplishment of the above purposes, may be used in defraying any other legitimate administrative expenses of the municipal court. 
(Code 1967, § 22-7) 
State Law reference- Authority to impose above costs, A.C.A. § 16-17-109. 
Sec. 15-7. - Records check fees; requests; sale of form books. 
(a)  There is hereby imposed a fee known as the records check fee, which fee will be charged by the municipal court clerk to all individuals or corporations requesting individual records checks. 
(b)  The amount of the fee shall be five dollars ($5.00) for each records check. 
(c)  All requests for records checks shall be in writing and records shall be mailed to the person so requesting. 
(d)  This fee shall not apply to requests from courts of law, law enforcement agencies and any branch of the armed services. 
(e)  Defendants with a case pending trial may obtain his record by mail free of charge, otherwise the normal fee shall apply. 
(Code 1967, § 22-8) 
Sec. 15-8. - Levy of additional court costs; creation of criminal justice fund. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and shall be collected from each defendant upon plea of guilty, nolo contendere, forfeiture of bond, or determination of guilt for misdemeanors or traffic violations in the municipal court the sum of three dollars ($3.00). 
(b)  The monies collected by the levy of this additional court cost shall be deposited in the municipal court account until monthly settlement is made for court costs and money collected by this levy shall then be deposited into a bank account known as the "Criminal Justice Fund of the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas" and such monies shall be used solely for reimbursing the county for expenses incurred in incarcerating city prisoners. 
(Code 1967, § 22-9) 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-141 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority to impose above fee, A.C.A. § 16-17-111. 
Sec. 15-9. - Mayor to appoint and authorize inspectors to issue citations. 
    Designated representatives of the mayor are hereby empowered and authorized to issue citations to require alleged violators of the Pine Bluff Municipal Code to appear in the Municipal Court of Pine Bluff to answer charges of these violations. The mayor shall designate in writing the individuals who are authorized to issue citations. This list shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 5676, § 1, 2-18-97) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5676, § 1, adopted February 18, 1997, did not specifically amend the Code; hence inclusion as § 15-9 was at the discretion of the editor. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Cross reference- Notice of violation; enforcement procedures, § 10-79. 
Chapter 16 - NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 5; health and welfare, Ch. 12; solid waste, Ch. 23; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 28. 
State Law reference- Authority to legislate on matters pertaining to municipal affairs, A.C.A. § 14-43-601 et seq.; authority to define and abate nuisances, A.C.A. § 14-54-104(3)(D). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Abatement, jurisdiction generally. 
(a)  In every case in which a person shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or any other ordinance of the city in relation to nuisances, it shall be the duty of the city council to make an order requiring the removal, abatement, or prevention of the nuisance shown in such case, and to order and direct that if within a reasonable and given time therein named, the same shall not be removed, abated, or prevented by the person or persons proceeded against therefor, such nuisance shall be abated or removed by the City of Pine Bluff Inspection Department with such assistance as may be necessary. The person proceeded against shall be responsible for all costs and expenses incurred in the removal, abatement, or prevention by the City of Pine Bluff. 
(b)  (l)  Whenever a property, excluding a single-family residence, has been determined to be a public nuisance by action of the city council, it shall be the affirmative duty of the owner or person in control of the property to remove or abate the nuisance within the time period specified by the city council in the order, resolution, or notice determining the property to be a nuisance. 
(2)  An owner or person in control of the property, excluding a single-family residence who fails to take action to remove or abate the nuisance within the time period specified, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as hereinafter provided. Each day that the nuisance remains unabated after the expiration of the time period specified by the city council for abatement of the nuisance shall constitute a separate and distinct offense for which the owner or person in control of the property may be charged and punished. 
(3)  A person convicted of violating this subsection shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as follows: 
a.  For an offense less than ten (10) days duration, a fine not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), excluding costs. 
b.  For an offense more than ten (10) but less than twenty (20) days in duration, a fine not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), excluding costs. 
c.  For an offense more than twenty (20) but less than thirty (30) days in duration, a fine not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), excluding costs, or incarceration in the Jefferson County Detention Facility for no more than ten (10) days, or both a fine and incarceration within the prescribed parameters. 
d.  For an offense thirty (30) or more days in duration, a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), excluding costs, or incarceration in the Jefferson County Detention Facility for term not less than thirty (30) or more than one hundred eighty (180) days in duration, or both a fine and incarceration within the prescribed parameters. 
(4)  The city retains the authority, after expiration of the period in which the owner or person in control was to abate the nuisance, to enter upon the property and take all necessary steps to raze and remove the offensive condition, as provided in subsection (a) and under Arkansas law, while also charging the responsible party with a violation of this subsection. 
(c)  (1)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or person in control of a property to permit or suffer any condition on the property to obstruct a sidewalk, public highway, street, or other right-of-way. For purposes of this subsection, "obstruct" means a condition which physically intrudes on the sidewalk, public highway, street, or right-of-way, or which has been determined by the fire, police or street department, or the Arkansas Highway and Transportation Department, to constitute a hazard to pedestrians or traffic on any of the foregoing to the extent that all or a portion thereof must be closed for public safety. 
(2)  An owner or person in control of the property shall be give written warning and a time frame within which to take action to eliminate the condition constituting the obstruction. An owner or person in control of the property who fails to take action which eliminates the condition which obstructs the sidewalk, public highway, street, or right-of-way, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished by a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) excluding costs, and each day the obstructing condition persists shall constitute a separate and discrete [distinct] offense for which the owner or person in control of the property may be charged and punished. 
(d)  When an inspector shall have reasonable grounds to believe that structural integrity or foundation of a structure may be compromised, the inspector may request that the owner or person in control of the property provide the inspector with an inspection report of a structural engineer. If the owner or person in control of the property is unwilling to do so, the inspector may, with the approval of the chief inspector and the mayor, arrange for such an inspection, either with the consent of the owner or person in control by applying to the district court for an order or warrant for entry onto the property, and bill the costs of the inspection to the owner or person in control. 
(Ord. No. 5435, § 1, 5-20-91; Ord. No. 6440, § 1, 5-20-13; Ord. No. 6492, §§ 1-3, 9-15-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5435, § 1, adopted May 20, 1991, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as § 7-29. Said provisions, however, have been included herein as § 16-1 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 16-2. - Summary abatement of unsafe and dangerous structures. 
(a)  Upon certification by the police chief, fire chief or chief inspector, any building, house, walls, or party walls or any portion thereof, chimneys or other structures, which are or become unsafe and constitute an immediate danger to the public health and safety because of fire, excavation, abandonment, improper erection or construction, or from any other cause, shall be summarily razed and removed or made secure by the inspection department. 
(b)  When summary abatement is authorized, notice to the owner, agent or occupant of the property is not required. Following summary abatement, the inspection department shall cause to be posted on the property liable for the abatement a notice describing the action taken to abate the nuisance. A copy of this notice shall also be mailed to the all persons having interest in the property which appears of record. 
(Ord. No. 5435, § 2, 5-20-91; Ord. No. 5745, 4-6-98) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5435, § 2, adopted May 20, 1991, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein as § 16-2 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; code enforcement board of adjustments and appeals, § 7-271 et seq. 
Sec. 16-3. - Additional rules for burned-out structures. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Burned-out structure means any residential or commercial structure attached, affixed or found on any real property within the city limits, which, due to fire or any other natural or human caused casualty, has the interior thereof open to the elements, and is unfit for human habitation. 
    Owner of real property includes a renter, lessee, occupant, agent, or person with control over the premises. 
    Person means both an individual or business entity. 
(b)  After receipt of a notice issued pursuant to section 16-4 below, it is unlawful and a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not less than one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), for an owner of real property to suffer or permit to remain on said property a burned-out structure. Each day the structure remains on the property shall constitute a separate offense for which the person may be convicted and fined. 
(c)  The chiefs of the fire and emergency services department and the police department, shall each be under a duty to provide written notice to the code enforcement department of the address of any burned-out structure. Said notice shall be provided within three (3) business days after the chief learns of the existence of the structure. 
(d)  The code enforcement department shall, within three (3) business days after receiving notice from either the fire or police chief, conduct an inspection of the structure, determine it if constitutes a burned-out structure, post the property accordingly, secure it as best as possible, and take expedited steps to notify owner of the real property of the obligation to immediately remediate the structure, as well as the city's intention to declare the structure a public nuisance pursuant to the city's established procedures. 
(e)  An owner of real property which is the site of a burned-out structure who, within fifteen (15) days after receipt of insurance proceeds paid as compensation for the damage to the burned-out structure, fails to raze and remove the structure, or, should the owner elect to repair the structure, obtain the requisite permit from the inspection department to commence repairs to the burned-out structure, commits an offense punishable by a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and shall also be personally liable at law to the city for the full amount of the costs incurred by the city in remediating the burned-out structure, plus reasonable administrative and court costs, which may be entered as a judgment against the offender by the district court or recoverable by the city in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 6599, § 1, 3-19-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6599, § 1, adopted March 19, 2018, created a new § 16-3 and renumbered former §§ 16-3, 16-4 and 16-5 as new §§ 16-4, 16-5 and 16-6. 
Sec. 16-4. - Accumulation of waste and placement of trash cart in driveways and along public rights-of-way more than thirty-six hours prior to scheduled collection prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for the occupant of any residence to place, permit to be placed, allow or countenance the accumulation of, waste in the driveway or along the street right-of-way, of said residence more than thirty-six (36) hours prior to the next scheduled waste collection day. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for the occupant of any residence to place, permit to be placed, allow or countenance, a trash cart to remain in the driveway or along the public right-of-way for more than thirty-six (36) hours prior to the next scheduled collection day for the residence. 
(c)  Any person found guilty of violating paragraphs (a) or (b) shall be fined a sum not exceeding ten dollars ($10.00) for each violation. Each day the waste or trash cart shall remain at the residence in violation of paragraphs (a) or (b) shall constitute a separate offense for which the offender may be cited, and, upon conviction, fined up to ten dollars ($10.00). 
(d)  As used herein: 
    Occupant includes the individual or entity reflected on the city's records as the party to be billed for the waste collection service at the residence, and/or any adult physically residing at the residence at the time of the violation. 
    Trash cart includes any container provided a residence by the city or city contractor for the collection of waste or any container, however obtained, made of metal, plastic or other material and used by the residence as a receptacle for waste. 
    Waste shall include: appliances, water tanks, furniture, construction debris, dead animals, tree trimmings, grass cuttings, dead plants, weeds, leaves, dead trees or branches, paper, pasteboard, rags, clothes, shoes, books, rugs, carpets, glass, floor sweepings, food, garbage, or any other item or items discarded for the apparent purpose of being carried away from the premises for disposal as waste. 
(Ord. No. 5704, §§ 1-4, 8-18-97; Ord. No. 6599, § 1, 3-19-18) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 16-3. See editor's note in § 16-3. 
Sec. 16-5. - Nonresident/out-of-state real property owners to designate a local agent. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  The owners of real property located within the city, whose principal residence, or in the case of a business, whose principal office, is located outside the State, shall designate a resident agent to accept receipt and service of the notices issued by the city pertaining to enforcement of the city's fire and housing codes and city ordinances pertaining to the cutting of overgrown weeds and grass and the removal of waste and trash from lots. 
(2)  The resident agent must be either an individual who resides in, or, if a business entity, has a staffed office located in the county duly appointed by the owner in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(3)  The resident agent shall be authorized by the owner to accept, in behalf of the owner, all notices and other documents issued or generated by the city in the administrative enforcement of its housing and other technical codes, and in the enforcement of the city's ordinances concerning the cutting of overgrown grass and weeds and the removal or accumulated waste and trash from lots. 
(b)  Designation of local agent to be filed with city. The nonresident, out-of-state owner must designate a resident agent no later than sixty (60) days subsequent to the date of the first publication of this ordinance in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. A copy of the document making the designation of the resident agent must be filed with the city collector's office no later than twenty (20) days after the designation is made. Said document must include the name, address and telephone number of the property owner and of the agent, and specifically authorize the resident agent to accept all notices and other documents issued or generated by the city in the administrative enforcement of its housing and other technical codes, and in the enforcement of the city's ordinances concerning the cutting of overgrown grass and weeds and the removal or accumulated waste and trash from lots. 
    Any change in the address and telephone number of the property owner or agent, or any change in agent, must be reported to the city collector's office within ten (10) days of the change. 
(Ord. No. 6109, §§ 1, 2, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 6599, § 1, 3-19-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6109, §§ 1, 2, adopted Sept. 7, 2004, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 16-4 at the editor's discretion. 
Editor's note- Formerly § 16-4. See editor's note in § 16-3. 
Sec. 16-6. - Disposal of solid waste-Approved container or dumpster required. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, "solid waste" has the same meaning as it is defined in section 16-83 of this chapter. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, to "dispose" of solid waste encompasses any act of storage, abandonment, throwing away, or leaving for collection things included in the definition of "solid waste". 
(c)  No person shall dispose of solid waste except by placing the solid waste in a container or dumpster which has been approved for the purpose by the City. 
(d)  Any person or commercial entity (any for-profit or non-profit entity) in violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, be fined a sum between two hundred dollars ($200.00) and five hundred dollars ($500.00), and ordered to remedy the violation at his or its own expense, or where the city has acted to remedy the condition, to reimburse the city the full cost of the remedial action. Every day that the person or commercial entity is in violation of this section shall constitute a discreet and separate offense for which the person may be prosecuted and convicted. 
(Ord. No. 6497, § 1, 11-3-14; Ord. No. 6599, § 1, 3-19-18) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 16-5. See editor's note in § 16-3. 
Secs. 16-7-16-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LOT CLEARING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Lot clearing, A.C.A. § 14-54-901 et seq. 

Sec. 16-26. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Garbage shall mean all solid or semisolid kitchen refuse subject to decay or putrefaction, tin, cans, bottles, paper and cardboard boxes, and all market waste of animal or vegetable matter which was intended to be used as food. 
    Refuse shall mean both garbage and trash, dead animals and in addition thereto, any other material or substance. 
    Trash shall mean any refuse other than garbage or putrescible matter. It shall include discarded flower decorations, cuttings of grass and weeds, fallen leaves, branches, trees and vine. 
(Code 1967, § 31-1) 
Sec. 16-27. - Accumulation of refuse. 
    The accumulation of waste, refuse, trash and other deleterious substances on the premises of residences, commercial institutions, open or vacant lots, and in the streets and alleys greatly increases the danger of fire and spread of infections, contagious and epidemic diseases and shall constitute a public menace and nuisance. 
(Code 1967, § 31-2) 
Sec. 16-28. - Clearing lots of weeds, debris and growth. 
    The person occupying or in possession of any lot or other real property within the city shall cut weeds; properly store garbage, rubbish and other unsightly and unsanitary articles and things that may be upon the property, to be collected and removed; eliminate, fill up or remove stagnant pools of water or any other unsanitary thing, place or condition which might become a breeding place for mosquitoes, flies and germs harmful to the health of the community. 
(Code 1967, § 31-3) 
State Law reference- Authority to so require, A.C.A. § 14-54-901. 
Sec. 16-29. - Inspections; authority of inspector to order clearing of weeds, etc. 
(a)  The inspection department or other authority designated by the mayor, in his discretion, is hereby empowered: 
(1)  To make or cause to be made inspection trips to determine that: 
a.  Refuse, garbage and trash are being properly stored, collected and removed; 
b.  Proper charges are being assessed; 
c.  Weeds, debris and growth are properly cut and cleared from any lot or other real property within the city. 
(2)  To order, in the name and by the authority of the city, the owner or persons occupying or in possession of any lot or other real property to: 
a.  Properly store refuse, garbage and trash for collection and removal; 
b.  Cut weeds; 
c.  Eliminate, fill up or remove stagnant pools of water or any other unsanitary thing, place, or condition. 
(b)  Such order shall: 
(1)  Be in writing. 
(2)  Include a statement of the reasons why it is being issued, and the section of the Code that is alleged to be in violation. 
(3)  Allow no more than ten (10) days for performance of any act the notice requires to be completed. 
(4)  State that if the alleged violation is not corrected within the time set forth in the notice, the city employee designated by the inspection department administrator, the administrator's agent, or his duly authorized representative shall institute legal proceedings charging the person with a violation of this section. 
(5)  State that no further notice, warning or grace period will be given for any repeat violation of the same subsection of this section within the remainder of the calendar year. 
(c)  The property owner and, where applicable, the person responsible for the violation, shall be notified by one (1) or more of the following methods: 
(1)  By delivery to the owner, agent or responsible party, personally. 
(2)  By leaving notice at the usual place, abode or business of the owner, agent or responsible party, with a person of suitable age and discretion. 
(3)  By depositing the notice in the United States mail, addressed to the owner, agent or responsible party, at his last known address by certified mail, postage prepaid thereon. 
(4)  By posting and keeping posted for a period of not less than twenty-four (24) hours, a copy of the notice in a conspicuous place on the premises alleged to be in violation. 
(5)  By depositing the notice in the United States mail, addressed to the owner, agent or responsible party, at his last known address by regular mail with an affidavit stating the date mailed, with postage prepaid thereon. This form of notice shall only be used in conjunction with one (1) or more other forms of notice permitted by this subsection. 
(d)  No further notice, warning, or grace period is required to be given for any alleged repeat violation of the same subsection of this section within the remainder of the calendar year. 
(e)  In case the owner of any lot or other real property is unknown or his whereabouts is not known or he is a nonresident of this state, a copy of the written notice shall be posted upon the premises in some prominent place. 
(f)  Any owner or occupant of a lot or real property who shall neglect or refuse to comply with an order of the inspection department issued in accordance with section 16-29(a)(2) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and fined a sum of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per offense, exclusive of court costs. Each day that the owner or occupant of the property fails to comply with the order of the inspection department shall be considered and deemed a separate offense. The inspection department and police department shall have authority to issue a citation to the owner or occupant to enforce this section. 
    The issuance of a citation shall not preclude further enforcement action pursuant to sections 16-31 through 16-33. 
(Code 1967, § 31-5; Ord. No. 6099, § 1, 7-19-04; Ord. No. 6116, §§ 1-4, 11-15-04) 
State Law reference- Notice to unknown or nonresident owner, A.C.A. § 14-54-902. 
Sec. 16-30. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The city inspection department shall continue to enforce this article in part by responding to complaints of private citizens. In order to encourage greater compliance and to provide for a fairer and a more uniform enforcement of this article, the city inspection department shall cite other lots that are in violation of this article that are located in the same block as the lots on which the city receives complaints from private citizens. 
(b)  To avoid potential abuses in the present enforcement program, the city inspection department shall maintain a list of the names and addresses of private citizens who make complaints of violations of this article, but in order to protect confidentiality shall not make the names available for inspection, except by court order. 
(Code 1967, § 31-6(c)) 
Sec. 16-31. - Performance of work by city; lien. 
    If the owner of any lot or other real property within the city shall neglect or refuse to remove, abate or eliminate any such condition as are provided for under this article, after having been given seven (7) days' notice in writing to do so, then the inspection department or other authority designated by the mayor is authorized to do whatever may be necessary to correct such condition and to charge the cost thereof to the owner or owners of such lot of other real property; and the city shall have a lien against such property for such cost. The seven-day notice required by this section shall apply to lien procedure only and shall not be necessary nor considered as a prerequisite to the issuance of a warrant. 
(Code 1967, § 31-6(a); Ord. No. 5333, § 1, 8-21-89) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to perform work and have lien for same, A.C.A. § 14-54-903. 
Sec. 16-32. - Collection of lien. 
(a)  The lien provided for in this article may be enforced and collected in either one (1) of the following manners: 
(1)  The lien may be enforced at any time within eighteen (18) months after work has been done by an action in the chancery court. 
(2)  The amount of the lien herein provided may be determined at a hearing before the city council held after thirty (30) days' written notice by certified mail to the owner or owners of the property, if the name and whereabouts of the owner or owners be known, and if the name of the owner or owners cannot be determined, then only after publication of notice of such hearing in a newspaper having a bona fide circulation in the county for one (1) insertion per week for four (4) consecutive weeks. The determination of the council shall be subject to appeal by the property owner in chancery court. The amount determined at such hearing, plus ten (10) percent penalty for collection, shall be certified by the council to the county tax collector, placed on the tax books as delinquent taxes and collected accordingly. The amount, less three (3) percent thereof, when so collected, shall be paid to the city by the county tax collector. 
(b)  In any situation in which the city issues an order for the removal or razing of a building or house under the provisions of A.C.A. § 14-56-203, as amended, and such order is not complied with by the owner of such building or house and the city then removes or razes such building or house, a lien is hereby granted and given against such real property for the cost of such removal or razing. The lien granted by this section shall also be enforced pursuant to the lien enforcement procedures set forth in this section. 
(Code 1967, § 31-6(b), (d)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, A.C.A. § 14-54-904. 
Sec. 16-33. - Assessment of attorney's fee for prosecution of foreclosure actions and liens. 
    If the city attorney files a foreclosure action to enforce the amount of a lien filed against any property as provided in this article, a reasonable attorney's fee will be added to the total amount of the lien in the amount of ten (10) percent of the total lien filed. Any judgment rendered in such a foreclosure action shall include the costs as set out above, plus ten (10) percent of the total lien filed. Any judgment rendered in such a foreclosure action shall include the costs as set out above, plus ten (10) percent of the total amount of the lien as a reasonable attorney's fee for the prosecution of such an action. 
(Code 1967, § 31-7) 
Sec. 16-34. - Yard waste in public rights-of-way. 
(a)  Violation. It shall be unlawful and a violation of city ordinance to blow or rake leaves, pine straw or grass clippings into the street right of way or blow leaves or pine straw into open ditches within the City of Pine Bluff. 
(b)  Penalty. The penalty therefore shall be the same as that for littering, one hundred dollars ($100.00) per offense. 
(c)  Enforcement. This section shall be enforced by the police department, the inspection department and the street department by citation. 
(Ord. No. 6051, §§ 1-3, 3-17-03; Ord. No. 6077, 9-15-03; Ord. No. 6165, § 2, 2-21-06) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6051, §§ 1-3, adopted March 17, 2003, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 16-34 at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 16-35. - Removal of dead trees; hanging dead limbs. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person having supervision or control of any lot, tract, parcel of land or portion thereof, within the corporate limits or within the jurisdiction of the board of health to suffer or permit dead trees and hanging dead limbs dangerous to the safety of persons or property of another. 
(b)  The inspection department, or an employee designated by the director thereof, shall be responsible for enforcement of this section. Whenever the representative determines that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of the provisions of this section, he/she shall give notice of such alleged violation to the person responsible therefor, that such alleged violation shall constitute a nuisance. Such notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing. 
(2)  Include a statement of the reasons why it is being issued and the section of the Code that is alleged to be violated. 
(3)  Allow a maximum of thirty (30) days for performance of any act which it requires. 
(4)  State, that if such alleged violations are not voluntarily corrected within the stated time as set forth in the notice, the city employee designated by the inspection department shall institute legal proceedings, charging the person with a violation of this section. 
(c)  The person responsible for the violation shall be notified by one (1) or more of the following methods: 
(1)  By delivery to the owner, agent or responsible party personally. 
(2)  By leaving notice at the usual place, above or business of the owner, agent or responsible party, with a person of suitable age and discretion. 
(3)  By depositing the notice in the United States Post Office, addressed to the owner, agent or responsible party, at his last known address by certified mail, postage prepaid thereon. 
(4)  By posting and keeping posted for a period of not less than twenty-four (24) hours, a copy of the notice in a conspicuous place on the premises alleged to be in violation. 
(d)  Violations of this section may be presented by the issuance of a citation by a code enforcement officer or law enforcement officer as provided by law, or by issuance of a criminal information or criminal summons. 
(Ord. No. 6066, §§ 1, 2, 6-2-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6066, §§ 1, 2, adopted June 2, 2003, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 16-35 at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 16-36. - Community forestry plan. 
(a)  Purpose . It is the purpose of this section to promote and protect the public health, safety, and general welfare of citizens and visitors by providing for the development of a community forestry plan to address the planning, maintenance, and removal of public trees within the city in order to promote the benefits of our community forest resources. 
(b)  Definitions . 
    Hazardous tree is a tree or tree parts with a high probability of falling and causing injury or property loss; also, a tree harboring insects or a disease that could be detrimental to surrounding trees. 
    Person is an individual, firm, corporation, partnership, business, group of individuals, city department, or other entity which acts singly or collectively for a common purpose. 
    Public grounds are any publicly owned land in the city limits, including street rights-of- way, easements, alleys, parks, medians, substations, treatment plants, plazas, squares, public buildings, and any other area designed for public use. 
    Public trees are trees growing on property owned by the city. 
    Street right-of-way is that portion of a street dedicated to public use, or conveyed to the public for use as a street, or an area subject to a prescriptive easement for public use as a street, but in any case limited to that area maintained by the city as a way for vehicular traffic. 
    Tree is any self-supporting woody perennial plant, usually having a main stem or trunk and many branches, and at maturity normally attaining a trunk diameter greater than three (3) inches at DBH and a height over ten (10) feet, and including crape myrtles and other woody plants with multiple stems. 
(c)  Administration . The Pine Bluff Tree Board shall be advisory in nature with the purpose of providing advice to the mayor and city council as to the management of the community forest in Pine Bluff, in accordance with the intents and purposes of this section. 
(d)  Establishment of a tree board . The purpose of the tree board shall be promoting the responsible planting of trees on public property, public education about trees, promotion of proper maintenance of trees, advocating trees within the city, and developing innovative and joint funding for projects from a variety of sources. 
(1)  The tree board shall consist of a total of seven (7) members. A minimum of five (5) members must be residents of the city, who shall be appointed by the Mayor of Pine Bluff and approved by the city council. A maximum of two (2) members may be non-resident "experts" or certified arborists, who are ineligible to become officers. 
(2)  Initial appointees to the tree board shall serve staggered terms. Each position shall be numbered, with initial appointees to positions one (1) through three (3) serving one (1) year terms; initial appointees to positions four and five shall serve two (2) year terms; and initial appointees for positions six (6) and seven (7) serving three (3) year terms. The position number for each initial appointee shall be set forth when the appointment is confirmed by the city council. All subsequent appointments shall be for three (3) year terms. Initial appointees are eligible for reappointment. 
(3)  Administrative support to the tree board shall be appointed by the mayor from employees of the Departments of Streets, Parks or Inspection & Zoning. 
(4)  Members of the tree board shall serve without compensation. 
(5)  The tree board may call special meetings as necessary to carry out its duties. 
(6)  The tree board shall choose its own officers, keep a journal of its proceedings, and file them with the city clerk. 
(7)  It shall be the responsibility of the tree board to study, investigate, consult, develop, and update annually a written plan for the care, protection, pruning, planting, or removal of trees and shrubs in parks, and in other public areas. The plan will include standards for tree planting and care. Such plan will be presented annually to the city council and upon their acceptance and approval shall constitute the official comprehensive tree management plan. 
(8)  The tree board will investigate available grants, loans, or contributions from other governmental agencies, public or private corporations, or individuals. 
(9)  The tree board will encourage and foster the planting of trees and other vegetation for the beautification of the city, and disseminate information to the public concerning proper selection and care of trees. 
(e)  Tree planting, maintenance, and removal . It is the public policy of the city to maintain existing trees and to provide and encourage the planting of new trees on public grounds within Pine Bluff to the greatest extent possible. 
(1)  The city shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain, and remove trees, plants, and shrubs within the public right-of-way of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares, and public grounds, as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve and enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. 
(2)  The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the visibility of any traffic control device, sign, or sight triangle at intersections. The discretion to prune such trees or shrubs is vested in the chief of police. 
(3)  Each city department shall be responsible for enforcing this section on lands for which it is otherwise responsible. The mayor or his or her designee will ensure that the applicable department will administer this section in its assigned area of responsibility. 
(4)  It shall be a violation of this section to damage, destroy, or mutilate any tree in a public right-of-way or any other public grounds, or attach or place any rope or wire, sign, poster, handbill, or any other object to any such tree. Staking and guying materials are permitted. 
(5)  Trees shall not be planted to conceal a fire hydrant from the street or impede the line of sight on any street. 
(6)  Public utility companies shall notify the city prior to performing above or below ground tree care on any tree located on city-owned property for the purpose of maintaining safe line clearance, and shall carry out all such work in accordance with accepted arboricultural practices. 
(f)  Tree protection and landscaping . 
(1)  Subdivision and development plans shall be designed to preserve natural vegetation areas as much as possible. Streets, parcels, structures, and parking areas shall be laid out to minimize the destruction of wooded areas or outstanding tree specimens. Developers of land are encouraged to designate wooded areas as park reserves or wildlife habitat. 
(2)  No person shall deposit, place, store, or maintain upon any public place of the municipality, any stone, brick, sand, concrete, or other materials which may impede the free passage of water, air, or nutrients to the roots within the drip line of any tree growing therein except by written permit of the city. 
(g)  Penalty . Any person violating any provision of this section shall be upon conviction or a plea of guilty subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 6474, §§ 1-7, 12-16-13) 
Secs. 16-37-16-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ABANDONED, WRECKED, DISMANTLED OR INOPERATIVE MOTOR VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5660, adopted Aug. 5, 1996, has been codified herein at the discretion of the editor as superseding the provisions of former Art. III, §§ 16-51-16-58, which pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1967 §§ 31-20-31-27. 

Sec. 16-51. - Short title. 
    This article [Ordinance No. 5660] shall be known and may be cited as the "Abandoned, Wrecked, Dismantled or Inoperative Motor Vehicle Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 5660, § 1, 8-5-96) 
Sec. 16-52. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following term, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(a)  City is the City of Pine Bluff. 
(b)  Motor vehicle is any vehicle which is self-propelled and designed to travel along the ground and shall include, but not be limited to, automobiles, buses, motor-bikes, motorcycles, motorscooters, trucks, tractors, campers and trailers. 
(c)  Junked motor vehicle is any motor vehicle, as defined by subsection (b) above, which does not have lawfully affixed thereto an unexpired license plate or plates and the condition of which is wrecked, dismantled, partially-dismantled, inoperative, abandoned or discarded. 
(d)  Abandoned vehicle shall mean any motor vehicle to which the last registered owner of records thereof has relinquished all further dominion and control and/or any motor vehicle which is inoperable. There shall be a presumption that the last registered owner thereof has abandoned such vehicle, regardless of whether the physical possession of the vehicle remains in the technical custody or control of such owner if it has remained inoperable or if the owner has relinquished dominion or control of such vehicle for seventy-two (72) hours. 
(e)  Inoperable motor vehicle shall mean any vehicle placed on blocks or one that does not have current, valid license plates, or has one (1) or more wheels removed, or is in a state of disrepair or is incapable of being moved under its own power. 
(f)  Person shall mean any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 5660, § 2, 8-5-96; Ord. No. 5769, §§ 1, 2, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 16-53. - Prohibited conduct. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person having supervision or control of any lot, tract, parcel of land or portion thereof, within the corporate limits of the city to suffer or permit the storage of a junk and/or abandoned vehicle, which is not contained in an enclosed storage building or carport, for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, unless it is in connection with an automotive sales or repair business enterprise which operates under a duly licensed and exhibited privilege license and is located in a properly zoned area. 
(Ord. No. 5660, § 3, 8-5-96; Ord. No. 5769, § 3, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 16-54. - Notice. 
    Whenever the city employee designated by the mayor or his duly authorized agent or representative determines that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provisions of this section, he shall give notice of such alleged violation to the person responsible therefor, that such alleged violation shall constitute a nuisance. Such notice shall: 
(a)  Be in writing. 
(b)  Include a statement of the reasons why it is being issued, and the sections of the code that are alleged to be in violation. 
(c)  Allow a maximum of thirty (30) days for performance of any act it requires. 
(d)  State, that if such alleged violations are not voluntarily corrected within the stated time as set forth in the notice, the city employee designated by the mayor or his duly authorized agent or representative shall institute legal proceedings, charging the person with a violation of this section. 
(e)  The person responsible for the violation shall be notified by one (1) or more of the following methods: 
(1)  By delivery to the owner, agent or responsible party, personally. 
(2)  By leaving the notice at the usual place, abode or business of the owner, agent or responsible party, with a person of suitable age and discretion. 
(3)  By depositing the notice in the United States Mail, addressed to the owner, agent or responsible party, at his last known address by certified mail, postage prepaid thereon. 
(4)  By posting and keeping posted for a period of not less than twenty-four (24) hours, a copy of the notice in a conspicuous place on the premises, alleged to be in violation. 
(f)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit a person owning said vehicle or having control or supervision of property whereupon such a vehicle has been abandoned for more than seventy-two (72) hours from waiving these notice provisions. 
(Ord. No. 5660, § 4, 8-5-96; Ord. No. 5769, § 4, 8-3-98) 
Sec. 16-55. - Penalty; abatement remedies. 
    Violations of the provisions of this section may be prosecuted by the issuance of a criminal information or by the issuance of a citation by a law enforcement officer as required by law. Any person convicted of a violation of the provisions of this article shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00, or double such sum for each repetition thereof. The penalty for allowing continuance thereof of a violation that is continuous with respect to time is a fine not to exceed $250.00 for each day that the same is unlawfully continued. A violation which is continuous with respect to time is a public nuisance and may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a "penalty" does not prevent the simultaneous granting of equitable relief in appropriate cases. 
(Ord. No. 5660, § 5, 8-5-96) 
Sec. 16-56. - Severability. 
    If any provision of this article [Ordinance No. 5660] or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of the article which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of this article are declared to be severable. 
(Ord. No. 5660, § 6, 8-5-96) 
Sec. 16-57. - Repealer. 
    All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are repealed to the extent of such conflict. 
(Ord. No. 5660, § 7, 8-5-96) 
Secs. 16-58-16-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MOSQUITO CONTROL 

Sec. 16-76. - Mosquito breeding places. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to have, keep, maintain, cause or permit within the city any collection of standing or flowing water in which mosquitoes breed or are likely to breed, unless such collection of water is treated so as to effectively prevent such breeding. 
(b)  Such collection of water shall be held to be those contained in ditches, ponds, depressions, privy vaults, cisterns, tanks, shallow wells, barrels, flush closets, or other similar water containers. 
(Code 1967, § 17-28) 
Sec. 16-77. - Methods of treatment. 
    The methods of treatment of any collection of water specified in section 16-76, directed toward the prevention of breeding of mosquitoes, shall be approved by the inspection department and may be one (1) of the following: 
(1)  Complete emptying every seven (7) days of unscreened containers, together with their thorough drying or cleaning. 
(2)  Covering completely the surface of the water with kerosene, petroleum or paraffin oil once every seven (7) days. 
(3)  Cleaning and keeping sufficiently free of vegetable growth and other obstructions. 
(4)  Filling or draining to the satisfaction of the department. 
(Code 1967, § 17-29) 
Sec. 16-78. - Failure of owner to remedy. 
    Should the person responsible for conditions giving rise to breeding of mosquitoes fail or refuse to take necessary measures to prevent same, within three (3) days after due notice has been given to them, the inspection department is hereby authorized to do so, and all necessary costs incurred by it for this purpose shall be a charge against the property owner or other person offending as the case may be. Such cost shall be subject to collection as provided by law. 
(Code 1967, § 17-30) 
Sec. 16-79. - Evidence of breeding places. 
    The natural presence of mosquito larvae in standing or running water shall be evidence that mosquitoes are breeding there. Failure to prevent such breeding within three (3) days after notice by the inspection department shall be deemed a violation of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 17-31) 
Sec. 16-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL 

Sec. 16-81. - Title. 
    This article may be referred to as the "Unlawful Dumping Prevention Ordinance of the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas." 
(Ord. No. 6345, § 1, 3-7-11) 
Sec. 16-82. - Penalty. 
    Any person engaging in a prohibited activity as set forth in section 16-84 of this article commits a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be sentenced as follows:
