(1)  For a first offense, a fine not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or incarceration in the Jefferson County Detention facility for no more than three (3) days, or both a fine as incarceration as specified in this paragraph. 
(2)  For a second or more offense, a fine not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or incarceration in the Jefferson County Detention facility for not more than one (1) year, or both fine and incarceration as specified in this paragraph. 
(Ord. No. 6345, § 2, 3-7-11) 
Sec. 16-83. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following definitions apply: 
    Knowingly shall have the meaning as set out in A.C.A. § 5-2-202(2). 
    Person means any individual, corporation, company, firm, partnership, association, trust, state agency, government instrumentality or agency, institution, county, city, town, municipal authority, venture, or other legal entity, however organized. 
    Solid waste means any garbage, refuse, sludge, trash, junk, appliance, air conditioners or heaters, tires, vehicles or vehicle parts, trees or tree limbs, construction debris (e.g., lumber, bricks, concrete, shingles, tin, pipes, etc.), oil or gasoline, contaminated water or dirt, or other discarded material or substance. 
    Unlawful dump means any place at which solid waste is placed, deposited, abandoned, dumped, or otherwise deposed of in a manner that is prohibited by the laws or regulations of the United States, the State of Arkansas, Jefferson County, or the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas. The city council finds that an unlawful dump: 
(1)  Constitutes a public nuisance, is a fire, health or safety hazard; 
(2)  Is a potential source of surface or groundwater contamination; 
(3)  Serves as a breeding ground for rodents and other vermin, and mosquitos or harmful insects; 
(4)  Contains other substances and conditions harmful to the public health and safety. 
    Unlawful dumping means the illegal placing, depositing, dumping, or causing to be placed, deposited, or dumped by any person, on public or private property, an solid waste that is prohibited by this article or by federal or state law, or county ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 6345, § 3, 3-7-11) 
Sec. 16-84. - Prohibited activities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly permit the presence of an unlawful dump on private property which the person owns, occupies, or for which the person exercises actual control, unless the property has been approved as a landfill or otherwise approved by the Arkansas Department of Environmental Quality for the deposit of solid waste. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly engage in unlawful dumping on public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 6345, § 4, 3-7-11) 
Sec. 16-85. - Posting of public property. 
    The inspection department shall identify and make record of those city properties which are vacant and provide a report of this information to the mayor and city council within one hundred and eighty (180) days of the effective date of this article. The mayor shall submit with this report a plan for the posting of a notice on the properties prohibiting unlawful dumping and warning of the penalties prescribed by this article for the activity. The notice shall further state that federal or state law or county ordinance may provide additional penalty for the activity. The size of the notice shall be at least two (2) feet by two (2) feet with appropriate font. 
(Ord. No. 6345, § 5, 3-7-11) 
Sec. 16-86. - Conformity with other laws. 
    The provisions of this article are intended to complement the laws and regulations of the United States, the State of Arkansas, or Jefferson County regarding unlawful or illegal dumps or dumping. Should a provision of this article conflict with any such law or regulation, the other law or regulation shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 6345, § 6, 3-7-11) 
Chapter 17 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 17-1-17-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ARTS AND SCIENCE CENTER FOR SOUTHEAST ARKANSAS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- A resolution enacted December 19, 1966, created the Board of Trustees of the Civic Center Arts Museum, named members with a term of three (3) years or until their successors were appointed, and gave it authority, subject to approval, to employ persons and make expenditures for the operation and administration of the arts museum area. A resolution enacted March 4, 1968, amended the prior resolution by adding a provision that the board was authorized and empowered to undertake the administration of functions then being administered by the Community Arts Center (also known as the "Little Firehouse Arts Center"), and increased the membership from six (6) to nine (9), with staggered terms. Ord. No. 4139, §§ 1-4, enacted May 5, 1969, amended said resolution by changing the name of the board. Ord. No. 5232, adopted Dec. 21, 1987, changed the name of the center from the "Southeast Arkansas Arts and Science Center" to the "Arts and Science Center for Southeast Arkansas." 

Sec. 17-26. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, the word "center" shall mean the Arts and Science Center for Southeast Arkansas. 
(Code 1967, § 2-183) 
Sec. 17-27. - Created, established as commission. 
    The Arts and Science Center for Southeast Arkansas is hereby created and established as a commission of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-181) 
Sec. 17-28. - Compliance with Internal Revenue Code. 
    The board of trustees provided for in this article is expressly created to and shall comply with the provisions of Section 170(b)(A)(v) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1964 as amended. 
(Code 1967, § 2-182) 
Sec. 17-29. - Administration of affairs by board of trustees, composition. 
    The affairs of the center, subject to the limitations of its creating ordinance and any other ordinance having application thereto and the laws of the State of Arkansas, shall be administered, managed and operated by a board of trustees (hereafter referred to as "the board") consisting of not less than sixteen (16) trustees having three-year terms and one (1) trustee (immediate past chairman) having a one-year term. 
(Code 1967, § 2-183; Ord. No. 5571, § 1, 4-4-94; Ord. No. 6206, § 1, 12-18-06; Ord. No. 6524, § 1, 7-20-15) 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions generally, § 2-181 et seq. 
Sec. 17-30. - Objectives, purposes of center. 
    The objectives and purposes to be carried on and fostered by the center are as follows: 
(1)  To provide and operate facilities serving the city, the county and Southeast Arkansas, for the practice, teaching, performance and enjoyment of the arts and understanding of the sciences. 
(2)  To encourage participation of area residents in its programs and to promote cultural growth of the area. 
(3)  To provide opportunities for the citizens of this area to be exposed to the arts through practice, display, teaching and performances. 
(4)  To cooperate with other educational institutions and groups having similar aims and purposes. 
(Code 1967, § 2-185) 
Sec. 17-31. - Political activity prohibited. 
    Neither the board of trustees nor the center shall become involved in any way in any political campaign on behalf of any candidate for public office. 
(Code 1967, § 2-186) 
Sec. 17-32. - Funds. 
    The funds of the center shall be controlled by the board of trustees subject to the reporting and auditing procedures and requirements of the city council. Upon termination of the center at any time or for any reason, all of its funds and properties shall belong to the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-187) 
Sec. 17-33. - Filling of board vacancies. 
    Trustees shall be appointed to fill vacancies by the mayor with the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 2-188) 
Sec. 17-34. - Authority of board of trustees. 
    The board of trustees of the center is hereby expressly authorized: 
(1)  To make bylaws for the management and direction of the affairs and business of the center, and to amend, alter, add to and repeal the same so long as they are not in conflict with any of the provisions of this article or of any applicable law of the state. 
(2)  To provide for officers to be elected from among their number; to elect such officers; to appoint an executive committee from among their number which shall have and may exercise all powers of the board between meetings of the board except the power to alter or amend the bylaws or to elect officers. 
(3)  To employ a director and such other employees as they may find necessary and appropriate for the administration and management of the affairs of the center commensurate with funds available for that purpose and to set the salary, benefits, conditions and terms of the employment of all such persons, and to terminate at any time such employment. 
(4)  Shall set and supervise the policy for the operation and maintenance of the physical assets of the center. 
(5)  May adopt budgets and provide for disbursements of all funds under the control of the center and may make or authorize its agents and officers to make in its behalf such contracts relating to the affairs, business or property of the center as shall not contravene any of the restrictions or limitations herein set forth and contained. 
(6)  May accept or reject gifts to the center upon whatever reasonable basis they shall determine. 
(Code 1967, § 2-189) 
Secs. 17-35-17-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CIVIC AUDITORIUM COMPLEX COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions, etc., generally, § 2-181 et seq. 
State Law reference- Auditorium commissions, A.C.A. § 14-141-101 et seq. 

Sec. 17-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commission shall mean the Pine Bluff Civic Auditorium Complex Commission created in this article. 
    Commissioners shall mean the members of the commission. 
Sec. 17-52. - Creation, composition. 
    The Pine Bluff Civic Auditorium Complex Commission is hereby created in the city. The commission shall be composed of seven (7) qualified electors of the city. No member of this commission shall hold any remunerative elective office in the city, state, or federal government while a member of this commission. The mayor shall be an ex officio member of the commission. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment by the mayor, subject to approval of the council. Each commissioner shall file the oath required by state law of public officials. 
(Code 1967, § 2-196) 
Cross reference- Limitation on terms of members of civic auditorium complex commission, § 2-181. 
State Law reference- Authority to create auditorium commission, A.C.A. § 14-141-102; auditorium commission membership, A.C.A. § 14-141-104 et seq. 
Sec. 17-53. - Duties and powers. 
    If the employment of managers, janitors and other employees by the civic auditorium complex commission shall necessitate monies to be appropriated from the general fund of the city, the city council shall have the power to fix the salary of any such employee or to disapprove of the creation of the position. 
(Code 1967, § 2-197) 
Sec. 17-54. - Purchase of supplies; advertising for bids. 
    The commissioners under this article shall have, in addition to other powers enumerated herein, the exclusive right and power to make purchases of all supplies, apparatus and other property and things requisite and necessary for the management and operation of the city auditorium and related facilities. It shall be the duty of the commissioners to make all purchases in accordance with the purchasing ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 2-199) 
Sec. 17-55. - Meetings, attendance; quarterly reports of receipts and disbursements; annual audit. 
(a)  The commission shall meet as often as may be necessary, and shall be subject to special call by the chairman. The commission shall meet at least monthly each year. It shall be the duty of the secretary of the commission to notify all members in writing at least seven (7) days in advance of the monthly meetings. 
(b)  The failure of any commissioner, having received due notice, to attend any two (2) consecutive meetings of the commission and offering no sufficient excuse therefor, shall constitute cause for removal from the commission. The secretary shall report the dates of the nonattendance of the commissioner to the chairman of the commission who shall then forward such information to the city council for appropriate action. 
(Code 1967, § 2-202) 
State Law reference- Authority to remove members, A.C.A. § 14-141-106. 
Sec. 17-56. - Appropriations to make up deficits or maintain auditorium. 
    Upon each quarterly report being made to the mayor and city council by the commissioners, the city council may appropriate funds from the general revenue fund of the city or from such other funds as the city may have available, to make up any deficits or to provide such funds as may be necessary to carry on the operations of the auditorium and related facilities. The city council may at any time, other than when the quarterly report is filed, appropriate such funds as it deems necessary from the general revenue fund, or from such other funds that the city may have available, for the purpose of maintaining and operating the auditorium. 
(Code 1967, § 2-203) 
Secs. 17-57-17-75. - Reserved.

ARTICLE V. - PARK RULES 

Sec. 17-96. - Glass containers prohibited on beaches of city parks; penalty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, bring in or dump, deposit or leave any bottles or broken glass on the beaches of city parks. 
(Code 1967, § 24-1(a)) 
Sec. 17-97. - Digging in public parks; parking on practice fields; penalty for violation. 
(a)  Permit and fee for digging in public parks. It shall be a misdemeanor to dig in the city parks without first obtaining a permit for such digging from the parks and recreation commission for a fee of one dollar ($1.00) per day per person. 
(b)  Digging in undesignated areas. It shall be a misdemeanor to dig in any area not designated by the commission as a proper area for such digging. 
(c)  Parking on practice fields. It shall be a misdemeanor to park anywhere in the open areas of the city parks so designated as practice fields. 
(Code 1967, § 24-2) 
Sec. 17-98. - Vehicular traffic in city parks restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a public park or recreation area to drive any vehicle on any area except the park roads or parking areas or such areas as may on occasion be specifically designated as temporary areas for driving or parking. 
(Code 1967, § 24-3) 
Sec. 17-99. - Trades, etc., in parks; permission. 
    All persons desiring to sell, trade, barter or exchange any commodity, article or thing of any nature within the limits of any public park of the city shall prior to such sale, barter or exchange secure the permission of the parks and recreation commission. 
(Code 1967, § 24-30) 
Sec. 17-100. - Dogs and animals limited in Townsend, Oakland and Regional Parks. 
    No person shall permit pets of any kind within the confines of Townsend Park Baseball and Softball Field, Oakland Park Softball Fields or the Regional Park Softball Complex. No pets of any kind, other than those animals trained for handicapped persons, are allowed in Regional Park during Freedomfest. 
(Code 1967, § 24-5; Ord. No. 5314, § 1, 6-5-89) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 5. 
Sec. 17-101. - Horses prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a public park or recreation area to ride or lead a horse except on designated bridle trails; horses shall be thoroughly broken and properly restrained, and ridden with due care, and shall not be allowed to graze or go unattended. 
(Ord. No. 5514, § 1, 9-8-92) 
Chapter 18 - SOLICITATIONS AND TRANSIENT MERCHANTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6138, § 1, adopted May 2, 2005, repealed ch. 18 in its entirety. Sections 2, 3, and 5 of said ordinance retitled ch. 18 and provided for sections 18-1-18-4 and 18-10-18-14 to read as herein set out. Formerly, said chapter pertained to similar subject matter as enacted by Code 1967. 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxation and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 13. 

PART A. - SOLICITATIONS 

Sec. 18-1. - Soliciting funds for religious or charitable purposes within city limits without notification to the city collector. 
(a)  Any person representing a religious or charitable organization who desires to solicit funds from any person who is not a member of the solicitor's religious or charitable organization, or who desires to accept donations from such nonmembers which distributing literature or merchandise need not notify the Pine Bluff City Collector prior to a solicitation. The person(s) engaged in such activity shall, each January of each year, list on a form provided by the Pine Bluff City Collector, his or her name, permanent address, telephone number, name of the group represented, and the name and address of an officer or official within that group who can verify that the solicitor is, in fact, a representative of the group which he or she purports to represent. 
(b)  After fulfilling the notice requirements contained in (a) above, the person desiring to solicit and/or accept donations while distributing literature or merchandise shall be permitted to carry on such activities within the corporate limits of this city daily from 8:00 a.m. until 8:00 p.m. 
(c)  The penalty for violation of this part shall, upon conviction in the Pine Bluff District Court, or any other court with jurisdiction, shall be fined a sum not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 6138, § 3, 5-2-05) 
Sec. 18-2. - Outdoor solicitations regulations. 
(a)  Solicitations-Definitions. 
(1)  "Business" shall mean any person, firm or corporation for which a business license has been issued pursuant to applicable ordinance of the City of Pine Bluff. Each business license issued by the city shall constitute a single-business location for the purposes of this part even if the actual conduct of the single business requires multi-locations. 
(2)  "Business license" shall mean any license, operating permit, franchise agreement or similar instrument issued by the City of Pine Bluff pursuant to the ordinances of the city governing the particular business involved. 
(3)  "Public right-of-way" means the streets and sidewalks within the City of Pine Bluff designated for use by vehicular and pedestrian traffic, including any unused portion of a dedicated street right-of-way. 
(4)  "Solicitation(s)" is hereby defined to include any activity whereby an individual(s) appeals, entreats, implores or petitions on behalf of a person, firm or corporation in an effort to sell, bargain or otherwise convey goods or services. 
(5)  "Solicitor" shall mean any person who conducts solicitations on behalf of a business as defined above. 
(b)  Solicitation-Regulation. 
(1)  Outdoor solicitation of any pedestrian or motorist within the City of Pine Bluff is hereby prohibited except as hereinafter provided. 
(2)  Outdoor solicitation of pedestrians may be conducted by one (1) individual solicitor per business license. Such outdoor solicitation must be conducted directly in front of the business if located on street level or on premises of the business. It is the intent of this part that only one (1) solicitor be permitted per location per address; hence one (1) solicitor must on behalf of all business when multiple businesses are conducted from a single business address or location, and only one (1) solicitor shall be permitted for any business which operates from multiple locations. Under no circumstance shall any business be permitted any combination which allows more than one (1) solicitor to act on behalf of a particular business. Solicitors may solicit only at the address to which the business license is issued. 
(3)  All solicitations shall be done in a conversational tone from a fixed position in a manner which does not impede or otherwise disrupt pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
(4)  The use by a solicitor of any ancillary items (e.g., stools, racks, chairs, display boards, etc.) is hereby prohibited within the public right-of-way. 
(5)  The solicitor shall wear or otherwise display identification which clearly identifies the business on whose behalf solicitations are made and the solicitor's name. In addition, the solicitor shall wear or otherwise prominently display an identification badge issued by the City of Pine Bluff as required by subsection (c). 
(c)  Solicitation-Permit. Each business desiring the use of an outdoor solicitor shall so indicate on their business license application and shall specify the address from which the solicitation will be conducted. The city collector shall issue to any business meeting the requirements of this ordinance, one solicitation identification badge per business license issued. The badge shall be considered a permit to conduct solicitation in accordance with this part. 
(d)  Solicitation activities not regulated. This part shall not apply to real property or facilities controlled or operated by independent city boards or commissions, or on premises owned or operated by the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff or the State of Arkansas, so long as all other permit/license requirements imposed by the state or the city are met. 
(Ord. No. 6138, § 3, 5-2-05) 
Sec. 18-3. - Soliciting funds from occupants of vehicles. 
    No person, firm, corporation or other organization shall undertake to solicit funds from occupants of automobiles or other motor vehicles which are moving or parked on publicly owned street within the corporate limits of the City of Pine Bluff. 
(Ord. No. 6138, § 3, 5-2-05) 
Sec. 18-4. - Penalty. 
    The penalty for violation of any provision of sections 18-1 through 18-4 of this Code shall, upon conviction in the Pine Bluff District Court, or any other court of competent jurisdiction, shall a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation. 
(Ord. No. 6138, § 3, 5-2-05) 
Secs. 18-5-18-9. - Reserved. 
PART B. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS 

Sec. 18-10. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases shall have the following meaning for the purpose of this part: 
(a)  Transient merchant means any person, firm, corporation, partnership, or other entity which engages in, does, or transacts any temporary or transient business, trade, profession, vocation, or occupation within the corporate limits of the city, either in one (1) location or traveling from place to place, from a motor vehicle, tent, open-air stand, area or table, trailer, concession, or other transient or portable structure, vehicle or device, for fees or remuneration. 
(b)  Temporary, transient or portable business means any business, trade, profession, vocation, or occupation conducted either in one (1) location or in traveling from place to place within the corporate limits of the city, from a motor vehicle, tent, open-air stand, area or table, trailer, concession, or other transient or portable structure, vehicle, or device and offering for sale or selling goods, wares, merchandise, services, entertainment, food, or beverages, or any other thing or item of value for fees or remuneration, regardless of duration, and not otherwise established and classified as a permanent business. 
(c)  Peddler means any person, firm, corporation, partnership, or other entity who operates as a transient merchant and shall be considered synonymous with transient merchant. 
(d)  Prohibited area means (1) the street or highway right-of-way as marked or plainly visible, including the area between the sidewalk (if one is present) and the right-of-way, (2) an area in which Arkansas law prohibits solicitation or sale by transient merchants, and, (3) any property (wherever located) the owner of which (or person in rightful possession) has not consented to the presence and activity of the transient merchant on the property. 
(e)  Parcel of real property means the legal boundary and description of each plot of real property as identified by a unique parcel number in the records of the Jefferson County Tax Assessor's Office. 
(f)  Day means a twenty-four (24) hour period beginning at 12:01 a.m. and ending at 11:59 p.m. on the same date. 
(g)  Non-profit or community organization means any organization recognized and designated as a not-for-profit organization under the applicable federal and state income tax rules and regulations. 
(h)  Permanent business means any business, trade, profession, vocation, or occupation located within the city operating on a continuing basis, from a fixed local business address, paying the appropriate occupation tax or business license fee and not otherwise temporary, transient, or portable in nature as defined in this section. 
(Ord. No. 6138, § 5, 5-2-05; Ord. No. 6434, § 1, 4-1-13) 
Sec. 18-11. - Regulations. 
    The following regulations shall apply to the conduct of all temporary and transient businesses with the corporate limits of the city: 
(a)  " Prohibited area. " Temporary or transient merchants and transient businesses may not set up, conduct business, or sell in a prohibited area as defined in subsection 18-10(d). 
(b)  " Zoning and code compliance. " Any temporary or transient business located in the city must comply with the applicable portions of the zoning code. Any such business operated from a structure shall comply with all applicable building and technical codes. 
(c)  " Business license. " All transient merchants shall apply for a transient merchant license which shall only be granted upon payment of the appropriate license fee, presentation of proof of an Arkansas Sales Tax Permit (as otherwise required by law) and written permission from the property owner on whose property the temporary or transient business will be located. 
(d)  " Operation days limited. " Transient merchants shall only be permitted to operate for four (4) occasions, not exceeding thirty (30) consecutive days in any given calendar year. 
(e)  " License fee. " The transient merchant license fee shall be as follows and shall be in lieu of any other city occupational tax or license fee: 
(1)  A transient merchant, peddler or temporary business: 
a.  Which is not a large scale merchandise entity, and 
b.  Which does not engage in door-to-door sales, and 
c.  Which does not offer a motor vehicle or vehicles for sale; 
shall pay a fee of twelve dollars ($12.00) per day or fifty dollars ($50.00) per month. 
(2)  A transient merchant, peddler or temporary business: 
a.  Which is not a large scale merchandise entity, and 
b.  Which does not engage in door-to-door sales, but 
c.  Offers for sale motor vehicles; 
shall pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per motor vehicle offered for sale and the fee set forth in paragraph (1) above. 
(3)  A transient merchant, peddler or temporary business: 
a.  Which is not a large scale merchandise entity, but 
b.  Which does engage in door-to-door sales, regardless of product line; 
shall pay a fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per week per person OR three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) per month per person. 
(4)  A large scale merchandise entity will pay a fee based upon the inventory value of its products as calculated as follows: five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the first ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) of inventory, and fifty dollars ($50.00) per one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) of inventory thereafter. "Large scale merchandise entity" means a transient merchant, peddler or temporary business with an inventory of products which are offered for sale in the city having a value of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or more, OR which employs or contracts with five (5) or more persons to act as salespersons for the entity in the city. 
(f)  " License display. " Any transient merchant licensed pursuant to this part shall post the license in a conspicuous place on the premises licensed. 
(g)  " Identification required. " Any person engaged in door-to-door sales must file with the city collector's office and with the police department accurate photographic identification of the person(s) engaged in the activity. 
(Ord. No. 6138, § 5, 5-2-05; Ord. No. 6282, §§ 1(a)-(c), 5-4-09; Ord. No. 6434, § 2, 4-1-13) 
Sec. 18-12. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this part shall not apply to: 
(a)  " Salespersons. " Sales at wholesale to retail merchants by commercial travelers or selling agents in the usual course of business. 
(b)  " Trade shows. " Transient merchants registered with and part of a trade show or convention and conducted within the confines of the trade show or convention area. 
(c)  " Catalogue sales. " Sales of goods, wares, or merchandise by sample catalogue or brochure for future delivery. 
(d)  " Fairs, carnivals, and amusement parks. " Activities conducted primarily for amusement or entertainment and located within the county fairgrounds, the convention center complex, an established amusement park, or the city parks (when approved by the parks and recreation commission and when all required permits/licenses are obtained). 
(e)  " Non-profit events and concessions. " Any yard sale, trade show, fair, auction, concession stand, bazaar, or fund raiser, sponsored and operated exclusively (or in combination with another exempted entity) by a school, church, incorporated (under the laws of the State of Arkansas) charitable non-profit organization, or governmental entity, and strictly when the event is not-for-profit, supportive of the purposes of the organization or entity, and does not compete with for profit or commercial entities. This exemption shall not apply to the week preceding and including any officially recognized federal or state holiday. 
(f)  " Garage sales. " Garage sales held on the premises devoted to residential use, for which the seller has obtained a valid yard sale permit from the city collector. 
(g)  " Food service establishment. " Any food service establishment classified as a "mobile food unit" or "seasonal operation" by the Arkansas State Board of Health which is licensed, regulated and approved by the said board of health. 
(h)  " Home sales. " Sales made by a seller at residential premises pursuant to invitation issued by the owner or legal occupant of the premises or to "home solicitation sales." 
(i)  " State, university, or county activities. " Merchants participating in activities hosted or sponsored by the State of Arkansas, the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff (UAPB), or Jefferson County, provided the activities occur on premises owned or operated by the government or the university, and the participating businesses have a valid occupation license, and, in the case of UAPB, are authorized by the university (or its agent) to sell UAPB merchandise. During the UAPB "Homecoming" parade scheduled as part of the University's football schedule, merchants with a valid occupation license and who are authorized by UAPB (or its agent) to sell UAPB merchandise, may be allowed along the parade route on the day of the parade, and for the Homecoming week (defined as 12:01 a.m. on the preceding Monday until 12:00 midnight the following Sunday), merchants with a valid occupation license and who are authorized by UAPB (or its designated agent) to sell UAPB merchandise, may utilize the University Avenue/U.S. Highway 79 corridor (Pullen Street north to the city limits). 
(Ord. No. 6138, § 5, 5-2-05; Ord. No. 6282, § 1(d), 5-4-09) 
Sec. 18-13. - Association. 
    A transient merchant not otherwise exempted from the provisions of this part shall not be relieved or exempted from the provisions of this part by reason of associating himself temporarily with any local dealer, auctioneer, trader, contractor, non-profit organization, or merchant or by conducting such temporary or transient business in connection with or in the name of any local dealer, auctioneer, trader, contractor, non-profit organization, or merchant. Any otherwise permanent business which engages or attempts to engage in activities that are temporary, transient, or portable in nature (e.g., roadside stands), regardless of the intended duration, shall comply with the requirements of this part for that portion of business that is temporary, transient, or portable in nature. 
(Ord. No. 6138, § 5, 5-2-05) 
Sec. 18-14. - Penalty and revocation. 
    Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this part, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation. Additionally, the license issued under the provisions of this part may be revoked by the city collector of a court for any of the following reasons: 
(a)  Violation of the conditions and regulations under which the license was granted; 
(b)  Failure to give full, complete and accurate information on the license application; and 
(c)  Violation of any city ordinance, state or federal law, including the provisions of this part. 
(d)  The police department or code enforcer shall have the power to issue citations for the violation of any provision set forth in this article. Any person/business owner who is cited for a violation, herein, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(e)  The City of Pine Bluff may file a civil lawsuit to enjoin continued operation of the business. The Pine Bluff Police Department shall have the authority to suppress any business who continues to operate in violation of this article, in accordance with the parameters set forth in A.C.A. § 14-54-103. 
The full amount of the license fee shall be forfeited and no part thereof shall be refunded when the license is revoked. 
(Ord. No. 6138, § 5, 5-2-05; Ord. No. 6282, § 1(3), 5-4-09; Ord. No. 6422, §§ 2, 3, 12-17-12) 
Chapter 19 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-71 et seq.; departments, § 2-121 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority to legislate on matters pertaining to municipal affairs, A.C.A. § 14-43-601 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Equalization of benefits of sick leave for policemen, firemen and nonuniformed employees. 
(a)  Policemen, firemen, and nonuniformed employees may accumulate sick leave to a maximum of ninety (90) days. 
(b)  Upon retirement or death, any fireman, policeman or nonuniformed employee who has unused accumulated sick leave shall be paid for such sick leave at the regular rate of pay in effect at the time of retirement or death, provided however, that payment for unused sick leave shall not exceed four and one-half (41/2) months' salary. 
(c)  Retirement for purposes of this section entails both separation from employment and eligibility to receive retirement benefits from the retirement plan in which the employee is enrolled, which includes attainment of the required age. 
(d)  All firefighters working 24-hour shifts employed by the City of Pine Bluff or August 12, 2005, shall receive credited sick leave due them from and after August 12, 2005, until August 12, 2006, at the rate of twenty (20) 24-hour days. Thereafter, all firemen working 24-hour shifts who are employed by the Pine Bluff Fire Department shall receive ten (10) 24-hour days of sick leave per year, beginning one (1) year after the date of employment. All other firemen working eight-hour shifts shall be entitled to twenty (20) eight-hour days of sick leave per year, beginning one (1) year after the date of employment. 
(Code 1967, § 30-8; Ord. No. 5720, § 1, 10-6-97; Ord. No. 6031, § 1, 10-7-02; Ord. No. 6189, § 1, 8-7-06) 
State Law reference- Authority to so provide for police officers and firefighters, A.C.A. §§ 14-52-107, 14-53-108. 
Sec. 19-1.1. - Buy back of accrued sick leave exceeding ninety days for nonuniformed employees. 
(a)  It is hereby provided that the city shall pay the sum of twenty dollars ($20.00) per day for each sick leave day lost by any nonuniformed or uniformed employee because he or she has accrued more than ninety (90) days sick leave at the end of the calendar year. Sick leave for firemen working twenty-four (24) hours shifts, and exclusively for payback purposes alone, shall be two (2) days for each twenty-four (24) hour shift, to a maximum of ten (10) shifts or twenty (20) sick days annually, For all other uniformed or nonuniformed personnel, a sick leave day shall be eight (8) hours for purposes of this provision. 
(b)  The foregoing shall not be construed to create any vested right in the employee to receive same and payments are contingent upon available funding. 
(Ord. No. 5671, §§ 1, 2, 1-6-97; Ord. No. 6168, § 1, 3-6-06; Ord. No. 6318, § 1, 6-7-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5671, §§ 1, 2, adopted January 6, 1997, did not specifically amend the Code; hence inclusion as § 19-1.1 was at the discretion of the editor. See the Code Comparative Table. 
[Sec. 19-1.2. - Sick leave bank.] 
(a)  There is hereby established a "Sick Leave Bank" for the use of uniformed employees. Uniformed employees means all firefighters and all sworn police officers, who by virtue of their employment are automatically eligible to participate in the bank. 
(b)  The sick leave bank shall be administered by a committee consisting of the chiefs of the fire and police departments, the human resources director, and a representative of the mayor's office, who shall preside as chair. The committee is charged with developing uniform criteria for the allocation of sick leave from the bank, which shall be approved by the city council and distributed to all uniformed employees. 
(c)  Any uniformed employee who has been employed as least one (1) year with the City of Pine Bluff, and who has earned sufficient sick leave, may elect to contribute in normal work shift increments. The maximum contribution to the sick leave bank shall be eighty (80) work hours for a uniformed police officer, and the nearest equivalent number of hours for a fire firefighter, with the administering committee to fix the maximum hours contribution for a fire fighter, taking into account the difference in normal work shifts for firemen and policemen, but in no event exceeding a maximum annual contribution of eighty-eight (88) hours for firemen. The employee may elect the contribution on a form to be developed by the administering committee, which shall be signed by the employee. Once a contribution is made it is irrevocable. 
(d)  A uniformed employee is eligible to apply for sick leave from the sick leave bank if he or she: 
(1)  Is in good standing with the department; 
(2)  Has exhausted all paid annual and sick leave and other compensatory time; 
(3)  Submits written verification from his or her treating physician that the employee is incapable of returning to work in any capacity at the time all leave and compensatory time has been exhausted; 
(4)  The illness or injury is not job related or covered by worker's compensation. An employee may receive a maximum of two hundred forty (240) hours of sick leave from the sick leave bank in any 12-month period. An employee need not have personally contributed to the sick leave bank to be approved for or receive sick leave from the bank. 
(e)  The administering committee of the Sick Leave Bank may approve sick leave for any uniformed employee who meets the criteria set forth in subsection (d) at the time this section goes into effect. It shall make quarterly reports to the mayor and city council of the balance of hours in the sick leave bank. The balance of hours in the bank should not exceed ten thousand (10,000). 
(f)  No uniformed employee shall be required to contribute to the sick leave bank. Once hours are contributed, the amount contributed will be subtracted from the employee's earned sick leave allocation and he or she will no longer have any right to the use of the hours or entitled to compensation upon retirement for the hours contributed. 
(Ord. No. 6298, §§ 1-6, 11-2-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6298, §§ 1-6, Nov. 2, 2009, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, said provisions have been included as § 19-1.2, at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 19-2. - Nonuniformed employees handbook adopted by reference. 
    The Nonuniformed Employees Handbook for the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, is hereby approved and adopted on this 5th day of September, 1995, and incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 5626, § 1, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 5645, § 1, 2-20-96; Ord. No. 5661, § 1, 8-5-96; Ord. No. 6008, 6-3-02; Ord. No. 6082, § 1, 10-20-03; Ord. No. 6240, §§ 1-5, 2-19-08; Ord. No. 6242, §§ 1-3, 3-3-08; Ord. No. 6245, §§ 1-4, 6-2-08; Ord. No. 6295, 10-19-09; Ord. No. 6364, §§ 1-3, 10-3-11; Ord. No. 6435, 4-15-13; Ord. No. 6436, 4-15-13; Ord. No. 6437, 4-15-13; Ord. No. 6518, 6-1-15; Ord. No. 6519, 6-1-15; Ord. No. 6520, 6-1-15; Ord. No. 6526, § 1, 8-17-15; Ord. No. 6527, § 1, 8-17-15; Ord. No. 6528, § 1, 8-17-15; Ord. No. 6608, § 2(App. A), 8-20-18)

Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-71 et seq. 
Sec. 19-3. - Regulations and policies regarding alcohol and drug use and testing. 
(a)  The attached "Regulations and Policies Respecting Alcohol and Drug Use and Testing" as revised are hereby approved and adopted as if restated word for word herein. 
(b)  All personnel policies of the City of Pine Bluff are hereby revised and amended to include the revised policy and incorporate the 1994 DOT final rules. 
(c)  The personnel director for the City of Pine Bluff is hereby directed to coordinate efforts by the city to ensure compliance with the DOT rules. 
(d)  Compliance with the policy and DOT rules by CDL's, transit employees, and all nonuniformed employees is a condition of employment with the City of Pine Bluff. 
(e)  Any laboratory, medical review officer, substance abuse professional or any other professional who receives payment for testing, evaluating, record keeping, or other services mandated by the DOT rules must qualify under the rules and perform such services in accordance with 49 CFR Parts 40, 653, 654, and 382. 
(f)  Alcohol and drug testing will be administered to covered employees as mandated by the DOT rules and the revised policy. 
(g)  Prohibited conduct and the consequences of prohibited conduct to an employee shall be as delineated in the revised policy. 
(h)  In the event any conflict is found to exist between the provisions of the revised policy and the DOT Rules, the DOT Rules shall govern and be followed. 
(i)  If any provision of the revised policy be held invalid by a court of law or superseded by subsequent legislative or administrative action, such holding shall in no way affect the validity of the remaining provisions of the revised policy, which shall remain in full force and effect. 
(j)  The need to adopt the revised policy and the DOT Rules, which are effective January 1, 1996, is necessary for the effective, efficient, and safe operation of the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, and to protect the health and welfare of its citizens and employees, and therefore, an emergency is hereby declared to exist and this section shall be in full force and effect from and after the date of its adoption. 
(Ord. No. 5631, §§ 1-8, 11-6-95; Ord. No. 5641, §§ 1-10, 1-2-96; Ord. No. 5794, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-99; Ord. No. 6009, 6-3-02; Ord. No. 6143, §§ 1-3, 6-20-05; Ord. No. 6231, §§ 1-3, 11-19-07; Ord. No. 6393, §§ 1-3, 6-4-12) 
Editor's note- The "Regulations and Policies Respecting Alcohol and Drug Use and Testing" adopted in this section are not set out at length in this volume but are on file and available for inspection in the offices of the city. 
Sec. 19-4. - Authority to appoint and remove the chief of the police and fire departments. 
    The Mayor of the City of Pine Bluff, in accordance with A.C.A. Section 14-42-110(a)(1), and subject to the provisions thereof, shall have the power to appoint and remove the chiefs of the fire and police departments of the city. 
(Ord. No. 5839, 10-18-99; Ord. No. 5840, §§ 1, 2, 11-1-99; Ord. No. 6173, §§ 1, 2, 5-1-06) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5840, §§ 1, 2, adopted Nov. 1, 1999, did not specifically amend this Code; hence its inclusion as § 19-4 was at the discretion of the editor. See the Code Comparative Table.

ARTICLE II. - NONUNIFORMED EMPLOYEES PENSION PLAN[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5551, §§ 1-12, adopted July 19, 1993 amended former Art. II, §§ 19-26-19-43, relative to nonuniformed employees pension plan, to read as herein set out. The provisions of former Art. II derived from Code 1967, §§ 30-22-30-35; Ord. No. 5287, 12-19-88; Ord. No. 5530, § 1, 12-7-92 and Ord. No. 5544, 6-7-93. 

Sec. 19-26. - Establishment, name and purpose; continuation. 
    The retirement system known as "The Retirement System of the City of Pine Bluff," which was created and established effective July 1, 1971, is continued. The terms of this system are restated in their entirety by this article. 
    The purpose of the system is to provide retirement and incidental benefits for eligible nonuniformed employees of the city who complete required periods of service with the city. This system has been established and will be maintained for the exclusive benefit of its members and their beneficiaries. Except as otherwise provided in the system, no part of the contributions to the system will revert to the city or be used for or diverted to purposes other than the exclusive benefit of its members and their beneficiaries. 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 1, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 6253, § 1, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 19-27. - Definitions and service rules. 
(a)  Words/phrases. The words and phrases listed in this paragraph (a) have the following meanings and are applied as described in the system unless a different meaning or application is plainly required by context: 
    Actuarial equivalent means a benefit of equal value computed by using the 1983 Individual Annuity Mortality Table for females with no adjustment and an interest rate of six (6) percent per annum. 
    Beneficiary means a person designated by a member of the system who is or may become entitled to receive a benefit under the system. 
    Child means a son or daughter born to or adopted by an individual. 
    Code means the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. 
    Compensation means any earnings reportable as W-2 wages for federal income tax withholding purposes, except that compensation ((i) does not include (a) reimbursements or other expense allowances, fringe benefits (cash and non-cash), moving expenses, deferred compensation and welfare benefits and (b) elective deferrals described in Code § 125. Compensation (ii) does include elective deferrals under Code § 402(g), § 402(h), § 403(b), § 457(b) or § 132(f)(4). Compensation will include employee contributions to this plan which are treated as employer contributions under Code § 414 (h)(2). Differential wage payments (as defined in Code § 3401(h)(2) paid to an individual in active qualified military service shall not be treated as compensation under this section. 
    For any system year beginning after December 31, 1988, the retirement board will take into account no more compensation than the compensation limitation prescribed by Code § 401(a)(17) ("compensation limitation"). The compensation limitation is two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) for the 1989 system year, a higher indexed amount for the 1990 through 1993 system years, and one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000.00) for the 1994 system year. For system years beginning after December 31, 1994, the compensation limitation is the adjusted dollar amount determined in accordance with Code § 401(a)(17). For system years beginning after December 31, 2001, the compensation limitation is two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00), as adjusted for cost-of-living increases in accordance with Code § 401(a)(17)(B). The cost-of-living adjustment in effect for a calendar year applies to annual compensation for the system year that begins with or within such calendar year. This limitation also applies to any twelve-month period for which the system measures a member's compensation and on a pro-rated basis to any measuring period less than twelve (12) months. When determining final average compensation for any system year beginning after December 31, 1988, the compensation for any prior system year is subject to the compensation limitation in effect for that prior system year, using two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) as the compensation limitation in effect for any system year beginning prior to January 1, 1990. For system years beginning before January 1, 1997, the compensation limitation applies to the combined plan compensation of the member and his spouse or lineal descendant under the age of nineteen (19) who is also a member. If the combined compensation of the member and a spouse or lineal descendants who are also members entitled to accrue benefits for a system year exceeds the compensation limitation, compensation for each member in the family unit means his compensation as adjusted by this paragraph ("adjusted compensation"). Adjusted compensation is the amount which bears the same ratio to the compensation limitation as the affected member's compensation (without regard to the compensation limitation) bears to the combined compensation of all the affected members in the family unit. The adjustment required by this provision will apply only for system years in which Code § 401(a)(17) (or a successor Code provision) applies to family members on an aggregated basis. 
    Contributions plus interest means at any applicable distribution date the amount of contributions made to the system by a member (including those "picked-up" by the city) plus interest which has been credited to his account and which has not yet been distributed to him under the system. A member's account is credited each December 31 with interest equal to five (5) percent of the member's previous December 31 account balance. 
    Elected official means an employee who was elected to his office by the people of Pine Bluff. 
    Employee means an individual employed by the city in nonuniformed employment, and includes both a regular employee and an elected official as the context requires. The term "employee" does not include an individual employed by the city police department, fire department or any other uniformed city department who is eligible for benefits under or membership in any other retirement system or plan (except Federal Social Security) by virtue of his employment with such department. 
    Final average compensation means for an employee his average monthly compensation for his five (5) consecutive calendar years of service in which his compensation is the highest of his last ten (10) calendar years of service prior to his separation from service. For purposes of fifty (50) percent election official benefit computations, (section 19-30(a)(3)b., section 19-30(c)(4)b., and the second sentence of section 19-30(d)(2), final average compensation means the average annual compensation of the elected official during his last five (5) calendar years of service as an elected official only (whenever rendered) prior to his separation from service. 
(1)  Notwithstanding the provisions of the above section 19-27(a), this subsection 19-27(a)(1) provides that, for regular employees that satisfied the eligibility requirements for a normal retirement allowance on or before December 31, 2012, based on the eligibility requirements effective prior to January 1, 2013, average compensation means for an employee his average monthly compensation for his three (3) consecutive calendar years of service in which his compensation is the highest of his last ten (10) calendar years of service prior to his separation from service. For purposes of fifty (50) percent elected official benefit computations, (section 19-30(a)(3)b., section 19-30(c)(4)b., and the second sentence of section 19-30(d)(2), final average compensation means the average annual compensation of the elected official during his last three (3) calendar years of service as an elected official only (whenever rendered) prior to his separation from service. 
    Former employee means an individual formerly employed by the city who retired from service before July 1, 1971 and was receiving as of July 1, 1971, a pension under the Arkansas State Employees' Retirement System by virtue of such former city employment. 
    Hour of service means each hour for which the city, either directly or indirectly, pays an employee, or for which the employee is entitled to payment, for the performance of duties, or for reasons other than for the performance of duties, such as leave of absence, vacation, holiday, sick leave, illness, layoff, jury duty or military duty. 
    Married member means a member who has been lawfully married continuously for the one-year period prior to his death or earlier benefit payment event for which marital status is relevant. An "unmarried member" is a member who is unmarried or has been lawfully married continuously for less than one (1) year prior to his death or earlier benefit payment event for which marital status is relevant. 
    Member means each regular employee and each elected official who becomes a participant in the system by reason of his employment as provided in section 19-28. 
    Regular employee means each employee who is not an elected official that regularly performs thirty (30) or more hours of service per week. 
    Retirement board means the City of Pine Bluff Retirement Board (described in section 19-36) which will administer the system. 
    Retirement fund means the trust (described in section 19-37) known as the "City of Pine Bluff Retirement Fund." 
    Service means any period of time during which an employee is employed by the city, including any period of authorized unpaid leave of absence. 
    Severance from employment means a separation from service with the city of not less than thirty (30) consecutive days in duration. Effective for employees employed as of September 1, 2002, any employee who was previously employed under the federally funded Community Employment Training Act (CETA) or equivalent program will accrue service credit for the years in which the employee was a CETA employee in the same manner as if the employee had worked for the city during the same period, but only if the former CETA employee makes member contributions for the period of the CETA service in the same amount as would have been required for service with the city. 
    Spouse means the individual to whom a member is lawfully married at the time of his death or earlier benefit payment event for which marital status is relevant. 
    System means the retirement system of the city as stated in this article and later amendments to it by ordinance (if any). Reference to sections and paragraphs of the system are to this article and later amendments to it by ordinance (if any). 
    System year means the fiscal year of the system, a twelve (12) consecutive month period ending every December 31. 
(b)  Years of service rules. The following phrases and service rules have the following meanings and are applied in the system unless a different meaning or application is plainly required by context: 
    [Year of service.] For a regular employee, a "year of service" means a twelve (12) consecutive month computation period during which he regularly performs thirty (30) or more hours of service per week (and fractional year of service when the fractional year is continuing and consecutive to year of service). For an elected official, a "year of service" means a twelve (12) consecutive month computation period during which he is in service (and fractional year of service when the fractional year is continuing and consecutive to year of service). The initial computation period is the twelve (12) consecutive month period which begins with the employee's employment commencement date. Subsequent computation periods are each twelve (12) consecutive month period which begins with the anniversary of the employee's commencement date. 
    Employment commencement date is the date on which the employee first performs an hour of service for the city. If an employee has a severance from employment, he establishes a new employment commencement date on the date he first performs an hour of service for the city after the severance from employment. 
    [Forfeiture of years earned.] Except as provided in section 19-30, subparagraph (c)(2), with respect to former disabled individuals, if an employee has a severance from employment and is paid a benefit of any type under this system, the employee loses all years of service earned under the system through his severance from employment. If the employee thereafter re-enters the system as a member, he will do so as a new member without credit for any previous years of service. 
    Current service means service rendered by an employee after July 1, 1971. 
    Prior service means service rendered by an employee or former employee before July 1, 1971, and for an employee or former employee whose participation in the state employee's retirement system was terminated by the establishment of this system, all credited service rendered by this individual before July 1, 1971, as an employee for any public employer as such terms are defined under that state system. 
    Years of service means the total number of years of service of an employee (both as a regular employee and as an elected official), and where applicable for an employee or former employee, the total number of years of service rendered after July 1, 1971 plus the number of years of prior service. 
(c)  Construction. Where appropriate to the context, pronouns or other words expressed in one (1) number and gender in this system will include the other numbers and genders. The headings inserted in this system are for convenience only, are not a part of this system and may not be used in a construction of it. Use of the word "person" refers to both natural persons (i.e. individuals) and artificial persons (e.g. corporations, partnerships, etc.) as appropriate to the context. The uncapitalized use of a defined word or phrase has been used when making a generic reference to an individual, a position, etc., and includes a defined word or phrase within such reference in proper context. 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 2, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 5632, § 1, 11-20-95; Ord. No. 5633, § 1, 12-4-95; Ord. No. 6035, 11-4-02; Ord. No. 6094, § 1, 6-7-04; Ord. No. 6166, § 2, 3-6-06; Ord. No. 6229, § 3, 11-5-07; Ord. No. 6253, § 2, 8-4-08; Ord. No. 6281, § 1, 5-4-09; Ord. No. 6340, § 1, 12-20-10; Ord. No. 6418, § 1, 12-3-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6281, § 2, adopted May 4, 2009, provides a retroactive effective date of April 28, 2009, and applies to applications for a retirement pension which were pending at the time the Retirement Board voted for the recommended change. 
Sec. 19-28. - Membership. 
(a)  Eligibility and participation. Each regular employee and each elected official must become a participant in the system as a condition of his employment with the city. Every employee in service on July 1, 1971 became a participant in the system on July 1, 1971. Each regular employee and elected official will become a participant in the system on their date of hire as an employee. Each member of the system is subject to all of the provisions of this article and later amendments by ordinance (if any) to it and to all rules and regulations adopted from time to time by the retirement board. 
(b)  Status notice. It will be the duty of the head of each department of the city to give notice in writing to the retirement board of any new employee, of the change in status of any member in his department resulting from leave of absence, resignation, reinstatement, dismissal, death, marriage, remarriage, etc. and of any change of beneficiary made by a member. The head of each department will furnish additional information concerning any member as the retirement board may require. 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 3, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 5958, § 1, 8-6-01; Ord. No. 6094, § 2, 6-7-04; Ord. No. 6229, § 4, 11-5-07; Ord. No. 6253, § 3, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 19-29. - Contributions. 
(a)  Member contributions. Each member is required to participate to the system as a condition of employment. The rate of contribution by a member through December 31, 1988 was six (6) percent of his compensation. After December 31, 1988, the rate of contribution by a member will be three (3) percent of his compensation. Effective April 1, 1997, member contributions will be treated as contributions paid by the city in lieu of contributions by the member and will be paid directly to the system. The city intends for this "pick-up" arrangement to meet the requirements of Code § 414(h)(2) or any successor provision. 
(b)  Payroll deduction. Member contributions will be paid through payroll withholdings by the city from the member's compensation. The retirement board will adopt rules and regulations governing payroll withholding for member contributions. All amounts deducted for each pay period by the city will be paid as soon as practical into the retirement fund and credited by the retirement board to the individual accounts of the members. Every member is deemed by acceptance of his employment to have consented and agreed to his member contributions to the system. Each payroll payment, less the member's contribution, will be a full and complete discharge of all claims and demands by the member for the service rendered by the member during the time period covered by the payment, other than the claims to the benefits to which the member may be entitled under the system. 
(c)  City contributions. At the end of each month, the city will pay into the retirement fund the balance of the contributions required to fund the benefits provided by the system. As of December 31, 1988, the city made monthly payments in satisfaction of its contributions to the system at the rate of ten and one-half (10.5) percent of the total compensation of each member. After December 31, 1988, the city will make monthly payments in satisfaction of its contributions to the system at the rate of seven (7) percent of the compensation of each member. These contributions of the city into the retirement fund are hereby made obligations of the city. The city council or applicable commissions of the city will appropriate annually amounts necessary to make these contributions. 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 4, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 5958, § 2, 8-6-01; Ord. No. 6094, § 3, 6-7-04; Ord. No. 6229, §§ 5(a), 5(b), 11-5-07; Ord. No. 6253, § 4, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 19-30. - Retirement dates and allowances. 
(a)  Normal retirement. 
(1)  Eligibility-Regular employee. A regular employee is eligible for a normal retirement allowance on the earlier of the date he has: 
a.  Completed ten (10) years of service and attained age sixty-five (65); 
b.  Completed twenty (20) years of service and attained age fifty-five (55); or 
c.  Completed twenty-eight (28) years of service regardless of age. 
d.  Notwithstanding the above, a regular employee hired after December 31, 2012, is eligible for a normal retirement allowance on the earlier of the date he has: 
i.  Completed ten (10) years of service and attained of age sixty-five (65), or 
ii.  Completed twenty-five (25) years of service and attained of age fifty-five (55), or 
iii.  Completed thirty (30) years of service regardless of age. 
(2)  Eligibility-Elected official. An elected official is eligible for a normal retirement allowance once he has completed ten (10) years of service as an elected official and attained age fifty-five (55). 
(3)  Normal retirement allowance. The normal retirement allowance of a member whose benefit begins to be paid (or is paid in lump sum) after September 16, 1999, is equal to the larger of: 
a.  A monthly benefit of two and one-tenth (2.1) percent of his final average compensation multiplied by his years of service after December 31, 1988 plus three and two-tenths (3.2) percent of his final average compensation multiplied by his years of service prior to January 1, 1989; 
b.  A monthly benefit of fifty (50) percent of his final average compensation if he has ten (10) or more years of service as an elected official. 
Example 1: If an elected official has twenty (20) years of service prior to January 1, 1989 as a regular employee and ten (10) years of service after January 1, 1989 as an elected official, after August 2, 2004, he will receive a normal retirement allowance equal to eighty-five (85) percent of his final average compensation (since this allowance is larger than the fifty (50) percent final average compensation allowance he would be entitled to as an elected official). 
Example 2: If a regular employee has eight (8) years of service prior to January 1, 1989 as a regular employee and ten (10) years of service after January 1, 1989 as an elected official, after August 2, 2004, he will receive a normal retirement allowance equal to fifty (50) percent of his final average compensation (since this allowance is larger than the forty-six and six-tenths (46.6) percent of final average compensation allowance he would be entitled to as a regular employee). 
(4)  Beginning date. A member's normal retirement allowance will begin to be paid (or if permitted, be paid in lump sum) to him on the first day of the month following the date on which he has satisfied the age and service requirements for the benefit and had a severance from employment, or as soon as is administratively practical following this date. 
(5)  Prior law. A member whose normal retirement allowance began being paid (or was paid in lump sum) prior to August 2, 2004, received the allowance calculated according to the terms of the system in existence at the time the benefit began being paid (or was paid in lump sum). 
(b)  Early retirement. 
(1)  Eligibility. A regular employee is eligible for an early retirement allowance once he has completed ten (10) years of service and attained age fifty (50). Elected officials are not eligible for an early retirement allowance. 
(2)  Early retirement allowance. The early retirement allowance of a regular employee whose benefit begins to be paid (or is paid in lump sum) after August 2, 2004, is equal to a monthly benefit of two and one-tenth (2.1) percent of his final average compensation multiplied by his years of service after December 31, 1988, plus three and two-tenths (3.2) percent of his final average compensation multiplied by his years of service prior to January 1, 1989. 
(3)  Beginning date. A regular employee's early retirement allowance will begin to be paid (or if permitted, be paid in lump sum) to him on the date at which he becomes eligible to receive a normal retirement allowance. With the consent of the retirement board, a retirement allowance which is the actuarial equivalent of the early retirement allowance described in the previous sentence may begin to be paid (or if permitted, be paid in lump sum) to the member on the first day of the month following the date he has a severance from employment, or as soon as is administratively practical following this date. 
(4)  Reserved. 
(c)  Disability retirement. 
(1)  Eligibility. A member who has completed ten (10) years of service and becomes disabled while in service will receive a disability retirement allowance for so long as he continues to be disabled. If a member is still disabled at the date at which he would have otherwise become eligible to receive a normal retirement allowance had he continued in service, he will continue to receive the disability allowance until his death regardless of his recovery from disability. 
(2)  Recovery from disability. If a disabled member recovers from disability, is re-employed and required to further participate in the system under section 19-28, paragraph (b), the retirement board will restore his years of service to the date of his disability retirement. The recovered member will then continue to accrue benefits under the system based on his years of service at and after the disability. 
(3)  Disability definition. "Disabled" means that the member, because of a physical or mental disability, is unable to perform the duties of his customary position of employment or is unable to engage in any substantial gainful activity for an indefinite period which the retirement board considers will be of long continued duration. The retirement board may require the member to submit to the physical examination of as many as two (2) physicians in order to confirm disability. The retirement board may require a member to submit evidence of his continued eligibility for the disability allowance at any time he is receiving the disability allowance. The retirement board may not require such evidence to be furnished more frequently than semi-annually. In the event that a disabled member refuses or fails to submit evidence of his continued disability when requested by the retirement board, the trustee upon written notice from the retirement board will discontinue the disability allowance until the member submits satisfactory evidence of his continued disability. 
(4)  Disability retirement allowance. The disability retirement allowance of a member whose benefit begins to be paid (or is paid in lump sum) after August 2, 2004, is equal to the larger of: 
a.  A monthly benefit of two and one-tenth (2.1) percent of his final average compensation multiplied by his years of service after December 31, 1988, plus three and two-tenths (3.2) percent of his final average compensation multiplied by his years of service prior to January 1, 1989; 
b.  A monthly benefit of fifty (50) percent of his final average compensation if he has ten (10) or more years of service as an elected official. 
(5)  Beginning date. A member's disability retirement allowance will begin to be paid to him on the first day of the month following the date his disability is determined by the retirement board, or as soon as is administratively practical following this date. The disability retirement allowance will not be actuarially reduced for payment prior to the time the member would have otherwise become eligible to receive a normal retirement allowance had he continued in service. 
(6)  Prior law. A member whose disability retirement allowance began being paid (or was paid in lump sum) prior to August 2, 2004, received the allowance calculated according to the terms of the system in existence at the time the benefit began being paid (or was paid in lump sum). 
(d)  Deferred retirement. 
(1)  Eligibility. If a member has a severance from employment with ten (10) or more years of service but he has not satisfied the age requirement for a normal retirement allowance, he can become eligible for a deferred retirement allowance by electing not to receive his contributions plus interest as a termination benefit. He will become eligible to receive the deferred retirement allowance when he attains age sixty-five (65). If this member is re-employed by the city and required to further participate in the system under section 19-28, paragraph (a), he will then continue to accrue benefits under the system based on his years of service at the time of his separation from service plus his years of service after his re-employment. 
(2)  Deferred retirement allowance. The deferred retirement allowance of a regular employee is equal to a monthly benefit of two and one-tenth (2.1) percent of his final average compensation multiplied by his years of service after December 31, 1988, plus three and two-tenths (3.2) percent of his final average compensation multiplied by his years of service prior to January 1, 1989. An elected official's deferred retirement allowance is equal to a minimum annual benefit of fifty (50) percent of his final average compensation. 
(3)  Beginning date. A member's deferred retirement allowance will begin to be paid (or if permitted, be paid in lump sum) to him on the date at which he attains age sixty-five (65). With the consent of the retirement board, a retirement allowance which is the actuarial equivalent of the deferred retirement allowance described in the previous sentence may begin to be paid (or if permitted, be paid in lump sum) to the member on the first day of the month following the date he attains age fifty (50), or as soon as is administratively practical following this date. 
(4)  Prior law. A member whose deferred retirement allowance began being paid (or was paid in lump sum) prior to August 2, 2004, received the allowance calculated according to the terms of the system in existence at the time the benefit began being paid (or was paid in lump sum). 
(e)  Normal form of retirement allowance. The retirement board will compute a member's retirement allowance in the form of a straight life annuity. 
(f)  Application for retirement benefits. A regular employee or an elected official may elect to retire at any time after he has satisfied the age and service requirements applicable to his retirement allowance. In order for a normal or early retirement allowance to begin to be paid (or if permitted, be paid in lump sum) to a member, a member (or his representative) must make written application to the retirement board not less than thirty (30) days nor more than ninety (90) days prior to his requested retirement date and separation from service. A member who becomes disabled must apply to the retirement board for certification of his disabled status as soon as is practical. A member will elect a deferred retirement allowance in accordance with retirement board procedures. All applications and elections concerning retirement allowance will be made in writing and on forms approved by the retirement board. 
(g)  Minimum retirement benefit. If a member's or spouse's normal, early, disability or deferred retirement allowance results in a monthly benefit of less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), the member or spouse will receive a monthly benefit of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per month. If a deceased member's children under age twenty-two (22) or other beneficiaries are sharing a member's benefit, all of the member's children under age twenty-two (22) or beneficiaries will receive a combined benefit of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per month or such larger amount as they are entitled to receive under the terms of the system. 
(h)  1997 cost-of-living adjustments. Effective May 1, 1997, a member, spouse, member's child or beneficiary who receives or is receiving a normal, early, disability or deferred retirement allowance in the form of an annuity payable monthly will receive an increased monthly benefit which is the larger of: 
(1)  The monthly benefit that the member, spouse, member's child or beneficiary receives (or would receive without regard to subsection (g) above) multiplied by the total number of years since the date the member, spouse, member's child or beneficiary began receiving the retirement allowance and multiplied times one point zero two (1.02); or 
(2)  The minimum retirement benefit of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) pursuant to subsection (g) above. 
(i)  1999 benefit increase. Effective the first day of the month following September 16, 1999, a member, spouse, member's child or beneficiary who receives or is receiving a normal, early, disability or deferred retirement allowance in the form of an annuity payable monthly will receive an increased monthly benefit which is fifty dollars ($50.00) more per month than the benefit that member, spouse, member's child or beneficiary is otherwise entitled to receive under the system. This increased benefit is prospective only and does apply to benefits received monthly beginning after September 16, 1999. 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 5, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 5632, § 2, 11-20-95; Ord. No. 5633, §§ 2-6, 12-4-95; Ord. No. 5688, §§ 1-9, 3-21-97; Ord. No. 5828, § 1-9, 8-16-99; Ord. No. 5958, §§ 3-9, 8-6-01; Ord. No. 6067, §§ 1-7, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 6103, §§ 1-8, 8-2-04; Ord. No. 6253, § 5, 8-4-08; Ord. No. 6418, § 2, 12-3-12) 
Sec. 19-31. - Forms and optional forms of payment. 
(a)  Form of benefit. 
(1)  Married member. Except as limited by subparagraph (b)(2), the normal, early or deferred retirement allowance of a married member will be paid in one hundred (100) percent joint and survivor's annuity form unless the married member elects lump sum payment with retirement board consent. The annuity for the married member is an immediate life annuity payable monthly to the married member for his life which is equal to the life annuity he would have received were he not married, with a survivor's annuity payable monthly after his death to his spouse for her remaining life which is one hundred (100) percent of the annuity payable to the married member during his life. 
(2)  Unmarried member. Except as limited by subparagraph (b)(2), the normal, early or deferred retirement allowance of an unmarried member may be paid in one (1) of the following forms, each of which, except for the joint and fifty (50) percent survivor annuity described in subsection d. below, shall be the actuarial equivalent of a the benefit payable to such member in the form of a straight life annuity: 
a.  Immediate straight life annuity form; 
b.  Lump sum payment with retirement board consent as described in subparagraph (b)(1); 
c.  An unmarried member may elect to receive his normal or early retirement allowance in joint and one hundred (100) percent survivor annuity form. The joint and one hundred (100) percent survivor annuity for an unmarried member is an immediate joint life annuity payable monthly to the unmarried member for his life, with a survivor's annuity payable monthly after his death to his designated beneficiary for the beneficiary's remaining life which is one hundred (100) percent of the annuity payable during the unmarried member's life; or 
d.  An unmarried member may elect to receive his normal or early retirement allowance in an unreduced joint and fifty (50) percent survivor annuity form. The unreduced joint and fifty (50) percent survivor annuity for an unmarried member is an immediate joint life annuity payable monthly to the unmarried member for his life, with a survivor's annuity payable monthly after his death to his designated beneficiary for the beneficiary's remaining life which is fifty (50) percent of the annuity payable during the unmarried member's life. This joint and fifty (50) percent survivor annuity payable to the unmarried member during his lifetime will be in the same amount as the member's immediate straight life annuity. 
(3)  Disabled member. Except as limited by subparagraph (b)(2), the disability retirement allowance of a member will be paid in immediate straight life annuity form.
