(4)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subparagraphs (a)(1) and (a)(2), and except as limited by subparagraph (b)(2), the normal, early or deferred retirement allowance for any member who has not satisfied the eligibility requirements for a normal retirement allowance on or before December 31, 2012, will be paid in one (1) of the following forms, each of which, shall be the actuarial equivalent of a benefit payable the form of a life annuity: 
a.  Immediate straight life annuity form; 
b.  Lump sum payment with retirement board consent as described in subparagraph (b)(1); 
c.  Fifty (50) percent joint and survivor annuity form; or 
d.  One hundred (100) percent joint and survivor annuity form. 
(b)  Lump sum. 
(1)  More than $5,000.00. A member may request in writing that the retirement board make payment of twenty-five (25) percent, fifty (50) percent, seventy-five (75) percent or one hundred (100) percent of his normal, early or deferred retirement allowance in lump sum form if this lump sum amount is in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and the balance, if any, subject of subparagraph (b)(2) in annuity form as described in subsection (a) above. If the retirement board (in its sole discretion) determines that payment of all or the applicable portion of the member's retirement allowance in lump sum form will not harm the soundness of the system, all or the applicable portion of the member's retirement allowance will be paid to him in lump sum form and the balance in annuity form. This alternative lump sum form of payment will be the actuarial equivalent of all or the applicable portion of the member's straight life annuity retirement allowance described in section 19-30. 
(2)  $5,000.00 or less. If the member's normal, early disability or deferred retirement allowance determined in lump sum form is five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or less, the member's retirement allowance will be paid to him in lump sum form and may not be paid in annuity form. 
(3)  For distributions on or after March 28, 2005, if the present value of the member's retirement allowance determined in a lump sum is greater than one thousand dollars ($1,000), distribution may not be made prior to age sixty-five (65) without the member's consent. 
(c)  Early payment actuarial adjustment. Each form of benefit paid under this section 19-31 before the member's applicable retirement date with retirement board consent (see section 19-30, subparagraphs (b)(3) and (d)(3), will be the actuarial equivalent of the member's straight life annuity retirement allowance as described in section 19-30 (computed by disregarding the effect of a subsidized survivor annuity under section 19-31, subparagraph (a)(1)). 
(d)  Direct rollover of eligible rollover distributions. A distributee may elect, at the time and in the manner prescribed by the Plan Administrator, to have any portion of an eligible rollover distribution paid directly to an eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee in a direct rollover. An eligible rollover distribution is any distribution of all or any portion of the balance to the credit of the distributee, except that an eligible rollover distribution does not include any distribution that is one (1) of a series of substantially equal periodic payments (not less frequently than annually) made for the life (or life expectancy) of the distributee or the joint lives (or joint life expectancies) of the distributee and the distributee's designated beneficiary, or for a specified period of ten (10) years or more; any distribution to the extent such distribution is required under Section 401(a)(9) of the Code; and any hardship distribution. An eligible retirement plan is an individual retirement account described in Section 408(a) of the Code, an individual retirement annuity described in Section 408(b) of the Code, an annuity plan described in Section 403(a) of the Code, a qualified trust described in Section 401(a) of the Code, an annuity contract described in section 403(b) of the Code and an eligible plan under Section 457(b) of the Code which is maintained by a state, political subdivision of a state, or any agency or instrumentality of a state or political subdivision of a state that accepts the distributee's eligible rollover distribution and that agrees to separately account for amounts transferred into such plan from this plan. A distributee includes an employee or former employee. In addition, the employee's or former employee's surviving spouse and the employee's or former employee's spouse or former spouse who is the alternate payee under a qualified domestic relations order, as defined in Section 414(p) of the Code, are distributees with regard to the interest of the spouse or former spouse. A direct rollover is a payment by the plan to the eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee. For purposes of the direct rollover provisions above, a portion of a distribution shall not fail to be an eligible rollover distribution merely because the portion consists of after-tax employee contributions which are not includible in gross income. However, such portion may be transferred only to (i) an individual retirement account or annuity described in Section 408(a) or (b) of the Code, or (ii) to a qualified defined contribution plan described in Section 401(a), 403(a) or 403(b) of the Code that agrees to separately account for amounts so transferred, including separately accounting for the portion of such distribution which is includible in gross income and the portion of such distribution which is not so includible. The system will allow a direct trustee-to-trustee transfer from this plan as a qualified rollover contribution to a Roth IRA described in Code § 408A. 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 6, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 5632, § 3, 11-20-95; Ord. No. 5633, §§ 7, 8, 12-4-95; Ord. No. 6114, § 1, 10-4-04; Ord. No. 6123, § 1, 12-20-04; Ord. No. 6253, § 6, 8-4-08; Ord. No. 6340, § 2, 12-20-10; Ord. No. 6418, § 3, 12-3-12) 
Sec. 19-32. - Death benefits. 
(a)  Member eligible for normal retirement. 
(1)  Married member. Except as limited by section 19-32, paragraph (d), if a married member dies after having become eligible under section 19-30, paragraph (a), for a normal retirement allowance but before the allowance has begun to be paid (or if permitted, been paid in lump sum) to him, his spouse will be paid a death benefit which is equal to the one hundred (100) percent subsidized survivor annuity that would otherwise be payable to this spouse under section 19-31, subparagraph (a)(1), if the married member's retirement allowance had begun to be paid under that subparagraph the day before his death. The death benefit will be payable in immediate straight life annuity form to the spouse. 
(2)  Unmarried member. Except as limited by section 19-32, paragraph (d), if an unmarried member dies after having become eligible under section 19-30, paragraph (a), for a normal retirement allowance but before the allowance has begun to be paid (or if permitted, been paid in lump sum) to him, his designated beneficiary will be paid a death benefit which is the actuarial equivalent of the member's straight life annuity retirement allowance computed under section 19-30. The death benefit will be payable in immediate straight life annuity form to the designated beneficiary. 
(3)  More than $5,000.00 lump sum. A spouse or designated beneficiary may request in writing that the retirement board make payment of his death benefit in lump sum form if this lump sum is in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). If the retirement board (in its sole discretion) determines that payment of this death benefit in lump sum form will not harm the soundness of the system, this death benefit will be paid to him in lump sum form. This alternative lump sum form of payment will be the actuarial equivalent of the death benefit described in section 19-32, subparagraph (a)(1) or (a)(2) (as applicable). 
(b)  Age 50; 10 years of service or 20 years of service. 
(1)  Married member. Except as limited by subsection (d), if an age fifty (50) or older married member has completed ten (10) years of service, or if any married member regardless of age has completed twenty (20) years of service but a retirement allowance has not yet begun to be paid (or if permitted been paid in lump sum) to him and he dies (whether in service or while waiting to become eligible for a deferred retirement allowance), a monthly death benefit equal to two and one-tenth (2.1) percent of the deceased member's final average compensation multiplied by his years of service after December 31, 1988, plus three and two-tenths (3.2) percent of his final average compensation multiplied by his years of service prior to January 1, 1989 will be payable to his spouse for her life. 
(2)  Unmarried member. Except as limited by subsection (d) if an age fifty (50) or older unmarried member has completed ten (10) years of service or if any unmarried member regardless of age has completed twenty (20) years of service, but a retirement allowance has not yet begun to be paid (or if permitted, been paid in lump sum) to him and he dies (whether in service or while waiting to become eligible for a deferred retirement allowance), a monthly death benefit equal to two and one-tenth (2.1) percent of the deceased member's final average compensation multiplied by his years of service after December 31, 1988, plus three and two-tenths (3.2) percent of his final average compensation multiplied by his years of service prior to January 1, 1989 will be payable to his designated beneficiary for the beneficiary's life. 
(3)  More than $5,000.00 lump sum. A spouse or designated beneficiary may request in writing that the retirement board make payment of his death benefit in lump sum form (if this lump sum is in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). If the retirement board (in its sole discretion) determines that payment of this death benefit in lump sum form will not harm the soundness of the system, this death benefit will be paid to him in lump sum form. This alternative lump sum form of payment will be the actuarial equivalent of the death benefit described in section 19-32, subparagraph (b)(1) or (b)(2) (as applicable). 
(c)  After disability retirement. If a member who is receiving a disability retirement allowance dies, a monthly death benefit will be paid to his spouse if he is married at death, or if not, to his children under age twenty-two (22). The monthly death benefit will be equal to fifty (50) percent of the monthly disability allowance being paid to the disabled member at this death. This monthly death benefit will be paid to the deceased member's spouse for the remainder of her life, and after her death, in equal shares to each of his then living children who are under age twenty-two (22) (if any) at each monthly payment date until the last child attains age twenty-two (22). If the deceased member was not married, this monthly death benefit will be paid in equal shares to each of his then living children who are under age twenty-two (22) (if any) at each monthly payment date until the last child attains age twenty-two (22). 
(d)  $5,000.00 or less lump sum. If the spouse's or designated beneficiary's death benefit determined in lump sum form is five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or less, the death benefit will be paid to the spouse or designated beneficiary in lump sum form and may not be paid in annuity form. 
(e)  Other members. If a member who is not described in section 19-32, paragraphs (a), (b) and (c), dies while in service, a death benefit will be paid to his spouse if he is married at death, or if not, to his designated beneficiary. This death benefit will equal the deceased member's contributions plus interest and will be paid in a lump sum as soon as it is administratively practical for the system to do so. 
(f)  In the event that a member dies while performing qualified military service (as defined in Code § 414(u)), the beneficiary of the member shall receive any additional benefits provided under the plan as if the member had resumed service with the employer and then terminated employment on account of death. The additional benefits shall not include benefit accruals relating to the period of qualified military service. 
(g)  For distributions made after December 31, 2007, the system permits a direct trustee-to-trustee transfer, to an individual retirement account or annuity ("IRA") established on behalf of an individual who is a designated beneficiary of the member and who is not the surviving spouse of the member. When made such transfer shall be treated as an eligible rollover distribution. 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 7, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 5632, § 4, 11-20-95; Ord. No. 5633, § 9, 12-4-95; Ord. No. 5958, § 10, 8-6-01; Ord. No. 6067, § 8, 6-16-03; Ord. No. 6103, § 9, 8-2-04; Ord. No. 6253, § 7, 8-4-08; Ord. No. 6340, § 3, 12-20-10) 
Sec. 19-33. - Other benefits. 
(a)  Separation benefit. If a member has a severance from employment without being eligible for a normal, early or disability retirement allowance, he will be paid an amount equal to his contributions plus interest in a lump sum as soon as it is administratively practical for the system to do so, unless he is eligible to elect to qualify for a deferred retirement allowance and he so elects. 
(b)  Revoked deferred retirement allowance. With the consent of the retirement board and prior to the time that his deferred retirement allowance becomes payable to him, a member may request that his election to qualify for a deferred retirement allowance be revoked. In this event, this member will be paid an amount equal to his contributions plus interest in a lump sum as soon as it is administratively practical for the system to do so. 
(c)  Minimum benefit. If the total amount of benefits paid under the system to a member, his spouse, designated beneficiary or children, as and if applicable, is ever less than the member's contributions plus interest, the difference between these two (2) amounts will be paid in a lump sum to the member's designated beneficiary, or if no such beneficiary designation is on file with the retirement board, to his then surviving children in equal shares, or if none, to his probate estate as soon as it is administratively practical for the system to do so. 
(d)  No other benefits. No other benefits other than those that are specifically described for a situation are payable under the system. 
(1)  Lump sum. If a member, spouse, member's child or beneficiary receives payment of his normal, early, disability or deferred retirement allowance in lump sum form, or elects to receive payment of his contributions plus interest, as applicable, there will be no further benefits paid from the system to the member, spouse, member's child or beneficiary for any reason. A member, spouse, member's child or beneficiary who accepts a benefit in the form of a lump sum, waives the right to receive any future increases to benefit calculation even if any such increases have a retroactive application to others. 
(2)  Other retirement programs. Any employee or former employee otherwise covered by the system, including any elected official, who receives a retirement benefit from another retirement program which is pursuant to employment with the city waives the right to receive any retirement allowance from this system by accepting the benefit from the other retirement program. For purposes of this paragraph (2), the term "retirement program" will not include a retirement program which is funded entirely by contributions from the individual employee. 
(e)  Military service. Effective as of December 12, 1994, notwithstanding any provision of these resolutions to the contrary, benefits and service credits with respect to qualified military service will be provided in accordance with Code § 414(u). 
(f)  Required distributions. 
(1)  Notwithstanding any other provision of these resolutions, distribution shall commence no later than the required beginning date. The required beginning date is April 1 following the later of: (i) the calendar year in which the member reaches age seventy and one-half (70 1/2), or (ii) the calendar year in which the member retires. 
(2)  Under no circumstances shall a member be permitted to select any method of payment unless, under the terms of the method selected, the entire interest of such member will be distributed in accordance with final regulations prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury under § 401(a)(9) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including the incidental benefit requirements of § 401(a)(9)(G) over the life of the member (or over the lives of the member and spouse) or over a period not extending beyond the life expectancy of the member (or the joint life expectancy of the member and spouse). 
(3)  Under any option elected by a member that provides for payments to a beneficiary after the death of the member, the benefits payable with respect to the member in the event of the member's death shall not be more than incidental, as determined under the final regulations under Code § 401(a)(9). 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 8, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 5688, § 10, 3-21-97; Ord. No. 6253, § 8, 8-4-08; Ord. No. 6340, § 4, 12-20-10) 
Sec. 19-34. - Code § 415 limitation on benefits. 
(a)  The annual retirement allowance otherwise payable to a member at any time shall not exceed the maximum permissible benefit, as determined in (b) below. If the retirement allowance the member would otherwise accrue in a limitation year produces an annual pension benefit in excess of the maximum permissible benefit, the rate of accrual will be reduced so that the annual pension benefit will equal the maximum permissible benefit. If a member is, or has ever been, covered under more than one (1) defined benefit plan maintained by the employer, the sum of the member's annual benefits from all such plans, determined as of the same retirement age, may not exceed the maximum permissible benefit. If the sum of the annual benefits does exceed the maximum permissible benefit, the benefits from the plan in which benefits are currently being accrued will be reduced first. In the case where benefits are being accrued under more than one (1) plan, including this system, the accruals under this system will be reduced prior to the benefits in the other plan(s). 
(b)  Determination of annual pension benefit and maximum permissible benefit. 
(1)  Annual pension benefit. For purposes of this section, the term "annual pension benefit" shall mean for any limitation year, the retirement allowance, expressed in a form payable at normal retirement age, payable annually in the form of a straight life annuity. Except as provided below, a benefit payable in a form other than a straight life annuity must be adjusted to an actuarially equivalent straight life annuity before applying the limitations of this section. 
    No actuarial adjustment to the benefit is required for: (1) the value of a qualified joint and survivor annuity; (2) the value of benefits that are not directly related to retirement benefits (such as the qualified disability benefit, pre-retirement death benefits, and post-retirement medical benefits); and (3) the value of post-retirement cost-of-living increases made in accordance with Code § 415(d) and the regulations thereunder. 
    Solely for purposes of determining whether a benefit exceeds the limits of Code § 415 under this section, for benefits payable other than in the form of a lump sum, the actuarially equivalent straight life annuity is equal to the greater of: (i) the annual amount of the straight life annuity (if any) payable to the member under the system at the same annuity starting date as the form of benefit payable to the member; or (ii) the annual amount of the straight life annuity commencing at the same annuity starting date that has the same actuarial present value as the form of benefit payable to the member, computed using a five (5) percent interest assumption and the applicable mortality table for that annuity starting date. 
    Solely for purposes of determining whether a benefit exceeds the limits of Code § 415 under this section, for benefits payable in the form of a lump sum, the actuarially equivalent straight life annuity is the greatest of: (i) the annual amount of the straight life annuity commencing at the annuity starting date that has the same actuarial present value as the particular form of benefit payable, computed using the interest rate and mortality table specified in section 19-27; (ii) the annual amount of the straight life annuity commencing at the annuity starting date that has the same actuarial present value as the particular form of benefit, computed using a five point five (5.5) percent interest assumption and the applicable mortality table for the distribution; or (iii) the annual amount of the straight life annuity commencing on the annuity starting date that has the same actuarial present value as the particular form of benefit payable (computed using the applicable interest rate and the applicable mortality table), divided by one point zero five (1.05). The terms applicable interest rate and applicable mortality rate shall be as defined in the final Code § 415 regulations. 
(2)  Maximum permissible benefit. For purposes of this section, the term "maximum permissible benefit" shall mean, for any limitation year, the defined benefit dollar limitation, as defined below. This amount may be further adjusted in subsection (c). The "defined benefit dollar limitation" shall be one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00), as adjusted, effective January 1 of each year, under Code § 415(d) in such manner as the IRS shall prescribe, and payable in the form of a straight life annuity. The new limitation will apply to limitation years ending with or within the calendar year for which the adjustment applies. Unless otherwise provided by law, adjustments for increases in the cost of living shall not be taken into account for any year before the year for which such adjustment first takes effect. 
(3)  Adjustments to the maximum permissible benefit. 
a.  If the member has less than ten (10) years of participation, the defined benefit dollar limitation described above, shall be multiplied by a fraction, the numerator of which is the number of years of participation and the denominator of which is ten (10). A member is credited with a year of participation (computed to fractional parts of a year) for each accrual computation period for which the member is credited with the period of service required under the terms of the plan in order to accrue a benefit for the accrual computation period, and the member is included as eligible to participate in the plan for at least one (1) day of the accrual computation period. A member who is permanently and totally disabled within the meaning of Code § 415(c) shall be credited with a year of participation (or part thereof) with respect to that period. In no event will more than one (1) year of participation be credited for any twelve-month period. 
b.  For purposes of determining a member's "maximum permissible benefit," the defined benefit dollar limitation above shall be adjusted for commencement of benefits before the attainment of sixty-two (62) or after the attainment of sixty-five (65). If benefits commence before the member attains age sixty-two (62), the defined benefit dollar limitation applicable to the member is an annual benefit payable in the form of a straight life annuity beginning at the earlier age that is the actuarial equivalent of the defined benefit dollar limitation at age sixty-two (62), with the actuarial adjustment as provided in the final Code § 415 regulations. 
If benefits commence after the member attains age sixty-five (65), the defined benefit dollar limitation applicable to the member is an annual benefit payable in the form of a straight life annuity beginning at the later age that is actuarially equivalent to the defined benefit dollar limitation at age sixty-five (65), with the actuarial adjustment as provided in the final Code § 415 regulations. 
(4)  Notwithstanding anything else in this section to the contrary, the benefit otherwise accrued or payable to a member hereunder shall be deemed not to exceed the maximum permissible benefit limitation if: 
a.  The retirement benefits payable for a system year under any form of benefit with respect to such member under this plan and under all other defined benefit plans (regardless of whether terminated) ever maintained by the employer do not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) multiplied by the member's number of years of service or parts thereof (not to exceed ten (10)) with the employer; and 
b.  The employer has not at any time maintained a defined contribution plan, a welfare benefit fund, an individual medical account, or simplified employee pension, in which the member participated. For this purpose only, employee contributions under a defined benefit plan (whether voluntary or mandatory) are not treated as a defined contribution plan. 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 9, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 5632, § 5, 11-20-95; Ord. No. 5633, § 10, 12-4-95; Ord. No. 6253, § 9, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 19-35. - Administration. 
(a)  Retirement board. The city retirement board will administer the system continued by this section under the provisions of this section and later amendments by section (if any) to it and under the direction of the city council. The retirement board will consist of the mayor, city clerk, chairman of the finance committee, the finance director, streets superintendent, wastewater utility manager, the airport manager and a nonadministrative employee-at-large and a retired member currently receiving benefits from the city retirement fund (nominated and serving in accordance with section 19-38 of this Code or any successor section). Members of the retirement board will serve without compensation, but will be reimbursed for necessary expenses incurred by them as members of the retirement board. The mayor will be the ex-officio chairman and the city clerk ex-officio secretary of the retirement board. The retirement board will meet at any time that the business of the system requires and the chairman will have the power to call meetings any time that it is necessary in order to carry out the business of the retirement board. Five (5) members of the retirement board will constitute a quorum to transact any business, but it will require not less than five (5) affirmative votes to carry out any matter before the board. 
(b)  Administration, management and control. Except as otherwise limited by this article and later amendments by ordinance (if any) to it and applicable law, the retirement board will have all powers as may be necessary to discharge its duties of management, direction and control of the system, including but not limited to the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To construe and interpret the system, decide all questions of eligibility and determine the amount, manner and time of payment of any benefits under it; 
(2)  To make a determination as to the right of any person to a benefit and to afford any person dissatisfied with such determination the right to a hearing on the issue; 
(3)  To receive from the city and from members such information as is necessary for the proper administration of the system; 
(4)  To prepare and distribute, in such manner as the board determined to be appropriate, information explaining the system; and 
(5)  To receive and review reports of the financial condition and of the receipts and disbursements of the retirement fund from the trustee. 
In the exercise of its powers, the retirement board will have no power to add to, subtract from or modify any of the terms of the system, nor to change or add to any benefits provided by the system nor to waive or fail to apply any requirements of eligibility for a retirement allowance or other benefit under the system without the approval of the city council. 
(c)  Rules and regulations. The retirement board may, subject to approval of the city council, establish such rules and regulations as it deems proper for the administration of the system and the retirement fund. 
(d)  Employment of actuary and other agents. The retirement board, with the approval of the city council, will employ an actuary, who will be the technical advisor to the retirement board on matters relating to the operations of the system and may engage such other technical service or employ such other persons as may be necessary to transact the business of the system. 
(e)  Medical service and advice. The retirement board will secure such medical service and advice as may be necessary to carry out the disability provisions of the system. 
(f)  Records and accounts. The retirement board will keep at all times correct detailed records and accounts of the system and all transactions and matters relating to its administration. 
(g)  Annual report and audit. As soon as practical after the close of each calendar year, the retirement board will transmit to the city council an annual audit and actuarial report setting forth the financial condition of the system and its operation for the preceding calendar year. The retirement board will use the auditors selected for the city's annual financial audit of its operations. 
(h)  Authorization of benefit payments. The retirement board will issue directions to the trustee concerning all benefits which are to be paid from the system pursuant to its terms. The board will keep on file, in such manner as it deems convenient or proper, all trustee reports. 
(i)  Payment of expenses. All expenses incurred incidental to the administration, termination or protection of the system and retirement fund, including but not limited to actuarial, legal, accounting and trustee fees will be paid by the trustee from the retirement fund and, until paid, will constitute a first and prior claim and lien against the retirement fund. 
(j)  Conflict of interest. Except as herein provided, no member or employee of the retirement board will have any personal interest, direct or indirect, in the making of any investments from the retirement fund, or in the gains or profits accruing therefrom. Nor will any member or employee of the retirement board directly or indirectly for himself or as an agent or partner of others, borrow any funds or deposits of the retirement fund, or in any manner use the same except to make such current and necessary payments as are authorized by the retirement board. 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 10, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 6129, § 1, 1-18-05; Ord. No. 6253, § 10, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 19-36. - Retirement fund and trustee. 
(a)  Retirement fund. There is a trust created under this section which will be known as the "City of Pine Bluff Retirement Fund" and this retirement fund will consist of all the moneys or other assets paid into this trust in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Appointment of trustee. With the approval of the city council, the trustee will be appointed by the city under a formal declaration of trust and the trustee will hold and administer the retirement fund. The trustee will serve at the pleasure of the city and will have such rights, powers and duties as the city provides in such declaration of trust as amended from time to time with the approval of the city council. 
(c)  Responsibility of the trustee. All contributions under the system will be paid to the trustee and will be held in trust and invested and reinvested by the trustee. All property and funds of the retirement fund, including income from investments and from all other sources, will be retained in trust for the exclusive benefit of the members, as provided in the system, and will be used to pay benefits to members or their beneficiaries or pay expenses of administration of the system and retirement fund. 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 11, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 6253, § 11, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 19-37. - Miscellaneous. 
(a)  Effect of social security payments. No modification of the benefits provided in this article and later amendments by ordinance (if any) to it will be made because of any amount or amounts payable to a member or beneficiary under the provisions of the Federal Social Security Act. 
(b)  Former city employee pensions. Any pension being received by a former employee as of July 1, 1971, under the Arkansas State Employees' Retirement system by virtue of such former city employment, will be assumed and administered under this retirement system. Each pension so assumed and administered will be adjusted to reflect the retirement benefits and conditions of payment extended under this system as if such former employee had retired on or after July 1, 1971, from service. Accordingly, this system will be interpreted by virtue of this provision to refer to and to include all former employees wherever appropriate concerning membership participation in this system and eligibility for retirement allowances. 
(c)  No assignments of benefits. Except with respect to any indebtedness owing to the city for which the city is given a lien on the debtor's distributive share of the retirement fund, any option, benefit or other right accrued or accruing to any person under the provisions of this article will not be subject in any manner to anticipation, alienation, sale, transfer, assignment, pledge, encumbrance, charge, garnishment, execution or levy of any kind, either voluntary or involuntary, prior to actually being received by the person entitled to the benefit under the system. The retirement fund will not in any manner be liable for the debts, contracts, liabilities, engagements, reports of any persons entitled to benefits under the system. 
(d)  Disclaimer of liability. Neither the city, the trustee nor the retirement board guarantees the retirement fund in any manner against loss or depreciation and they will not be liable for any act or failure to act which is made in good faith pursuant to the provisions of the system or retirement fund. The city will not be responsible for any act or failure to act of the retirement board or the trustee. The trustee will not be liable for any act or failure to act of the city or the retirement board. The retirement board will not be responsible for any act or failure to act of the city or the trustee. 
(e)  Indemnification of retirement board. The retirement board will be indemnified by the trustee from the assets of the retirement fund against liability arising by reason of any act or failure to act made in good faith pursuant to the provisions of the system, including expenses reasonably incurred in the defense of any claim relating thereto. 
(f)  Employee indebtedness. In the event that an employee is discharged from employment with the city because of embezzlement or fraud in connection with his employment, conversion or misappropriation of city property or other event which results in the employee owing the city an indebtedness, and the reasons for this discharge are confirmed by the retirement board after the employee is afforded a hearing before the retirement board on the charges, the indebtedness owed to the city will be a lien against the benefits that the employee or his beneficiaries are entitled to receive under the system. The city will be entitled to receive the amount owed it by the employee from the system prior to any other payments being made to the employee or his beneficiaries. 
(g)  Facility of payment. The trustee may, in its discretion, do one or more of the following with respect to any payment that would be made to any individual at a time when he or she is under a legal disability (including minority): 
(1)  Take any action necessary to have a legal guardian appointed for such individual, if none has already been appointed, and make the payment to such legal guardian, without having to see to the proper application of such payment; or 
(2)  Name a custodian for the individual (who may be the trustee) under any appropriate uniform transfers (or gifts) to minors act, and make such payment to the custodian without having to see to the proper application for such payment. 
(h)  No beneficiary designation/death of beneficiary. If a member fails to name a beneficiary to receive a benefit, or if the beneficiary named to receive the benefit predeceases him, then the trustee will pay the benefit in the following order of priority: 
(1)  The member's spouse; 
(2)  The member's surviving children in equal shares; and 
(3)  The personal representative of the member's probate estate. 
(i)  Loans. The system does not allow the trustee to make loans to a member or a beneficiary from the assets of the trust for any reason. 
(j)  Qualified domestic relations orders. Distributions from the system are to made to an "alternate payee" in accordance with the retirement system for nonuniformed employees of the city regulations regarding qualified domestic relations orders as adopted by the retirement board on February 27, 1997. 
(k)  Required period between employment service. An employee who has separated from service and received payment from the city retirement system shall not be eligible to apply for re-employment or to be rehired with the city until at least thirty (30) consecutive days has passed from the official date of separation and the date the person physically returns to duty in a position with the city. The employee shall not be entitled to any city benefits during the separation of service. 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 12, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 5688, § 11, 3-21-97; Ord. No. 6166, § 1, 3-6-06; Ord. No. 6253, § 12, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 19-38. - Amendment of system. 
(a)  Authority. The city reserves the right acting by the city council to make amendments at any time to the system which will not cause any part of the retirement fund to be used for or diverted to any purposes other than for the exclusive benefit of the members and beneficiaries of the system. 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 13, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 6253, § 13, 8-4-08) 
Sec. 19-39. - Termination/discontinuance of contributions. 
(a)  Right to terminate/discontinue contributions. The city may temporarily suspend contributions to the system, permanently discontinue contributions to the system or terminate the system at any time. Any temporary suspension of contributions will not constitute or require a termination of the system or retirement fund and will not preclude later contributions to the system. In the event of any suspension of contributions, the retirement fund will remain in existence as provided in this ordinance and the provisions of the system and retirement fund will remain in force. 
(b)  Termination. In the event of termination of the system, the trustee will determine the value of the retirement fund as of the next business day following the date of such termination. The trustee will then allocate the assets of the council system among the members and beneficiaries according to the following priorities: 
(1)  Benefits payable to each member of beneficiary equal to the member's contributions plus interest; 
(2)  Benefits in excess of the contributions plus interest payable as an annuity: 
a.  In the case of a member or beneficiary benefit which was in pay status as of the termination date; 
b.  In the case of a member benefit which would have been in pay status as of the last day of the system year prior to the termination date as if the member had retired this date and his benefits had then commenced (in the normal form of annuity under the system); 
(3)  Any other benefits under the system. 
If surplus assets exist after these allocations, the surplus assets will be allocated to each member or beneficiary in the ratio in which each member or beneficiary's total benefit bears to the total benefits of all members and beneficiaries. If assets are insufficient to provide all benefits under the system, the trustee will allocate such assets to satisfy obligations within each category by order of priority. If assets are insufficient to provide all benefits under a priority category, the trustee will allocate assets to members and beneficiaries within that category in the ratio in which each member and beneficiary's total benefit bears to the total benefits of all members and beneficiaries within that category. 
(c)  Manner of distribution. Any distribution after termination of the system or permanent discontinuance of contributions will be made as soon as administratively feasible at times and in amounts, in case or in kind, or in nontransferable annuity contracts as the retirement board, determines in its sole discretion. Each such distribution will be final and conclusive and not subject to question by any person. 
(d)  Residual amounts. In no event will the city receive any amounts from the retirement fund upon liquidation of the retirement fund except pursuant to section 19-37, paragraph (c), for indebtedness due from an employee. 
    EMERGENCY CLAUSE: Since it has been determined by the city that it is in the best interest of the city and its employees to immediately operate a retirement system pursuant to the above described conditions, an emergency is declared to exist, and this article will take effect and be in full force and effect from and after the date of its passage and approval. 
(Ord. No. 5551, § 14, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 6253, § 14, 8-4-08) 
Secs. 19-40-19-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AFFIRMATIVE ACTION POLICY FOR CIVIL SERVICE EMPLOYEES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5566, adopted March 7, 1994, has been codified herein at the discretion of the editor as Art. III, §§ 19-101-19-105. 
Cross reference- Officers and employees generally, § 2-71 et seq.; fire department, § 10-26 et seq.; police department, § 21-26 et seq. 

Sec. 19-101. - Affirmative action mandate. 
(a)  The City of Pine Bluff hereby adopts a temporary five-year Affirmative Action Plan in an effort to increase the number of minorities and females in the City of Pine Bluff civil service positions. Accordingly, it shall be necessary to utilize race and gender as a factor in the hiring decisions. Such factors will only be considered if the potential candidate is otherwise qualified under the criteria set forth by the city. 
(b)  In order to correct an identified manifest imbalance, the City of Pine Bluff shall embark on an effort to increase the number of minority civil service employees in the uniformed departments by hiring at a percentage slightly higher than the racial and gender population of the city's relevant labor market. 
(c)  A progress report shall be provided to the office of the mayor on a quarterly basis and shall be maintained on record within the department of personnel for the City of Pine Bluff. 
(Ord. No. 5566, § I, 3-7-94) 
Sec. 19-102. - Recruitment goal. 
    The goal of the city in implementing this program is for the sworn officer and firemen workforce in the Pine Bluff Police Department and the Pine Bluff Fire Department to closely reflect the racial and gender composition of individuals in the relevant labor market in Pine Bluff and Jefferson County. Toward that end, the city is adopting this program to achieve greater representation of minorities and females in the sworn officer and firemen ranks. 
(Ord. No. 5566, § II, 3-7-94) 
Sec. 19-103. - Recruiting activities. 
(a)  Recruiting activities shall be ongoing and intense and shall be targeted at the minority and female population. The Pine Bluff Police Department and the Pine Bluff Fire Department, under the direction of the mayor, shall recruit from said population within sixty (60) days of the application deadline through the use of the following institutions: 
(1)  Daily newspaper, not less than two (2), with general circulation in the minority community, in and around the Jefferson County area. 
(2)  Public radio station, not less than two (2), minority managed and with a listening audience within the Pine Bluff area. Not less than one (1) such station shall be located outside, but yet serve the Jefferson County area. 
(3)  Historical Black Colleges; the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff, and not less than one (1) other similar institution selected at random. 
(4)  The local Employment Security Division. 
(5)  Other means which can be determined as effective and feasible in achieving the stated goal. 
(b)  The Pine Bluff Police Department will train a black officer in recruiting skills and assign such officer sufficient hours to meet the goals stated herein. The duties of the officer includes making recruiting presentations at each high school in Pine Bluff, contacting such civic and community organizations as in their judgement would likely produce black or female applicants and maintaining contact with the placement personnel department at the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff. The officer will participate, as allowed by the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff and other institutions, in job placement, seminars, fairs, and other such recruiting related activities sufficient to meet the goals referred to above. 
(c)  General information provided for the purpose of recruitment, as well as information provided to applicants shall include, but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Eligibility criteria for applicant; 
(2)  Where application may be obtained; 
(3)  Beginning salary; 
(4)  Fringe benefits; 
(5)  Deadline for submitting application. 
(Ord. No. 5566, § III, 3-7-94) 
Sec. 19-104. - In-service training. 
    All sworn uniformed personnel in the Pine Bluff Police Department shall periodically experience in-service training for community, race, and public relations. The Pine Bluff Police Department shall enlist the participation of minority community leaders as well as the faculty resources within the Social and Behavioral Science Department at the University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff. 
(Ord. No. 5566, § IV, 3-7-94) 
Sec. 19-105. - Semi-annual assessment. 
    This plan shall be reviewed and assessed as to its effectiveness on a semi-annual basis for the purpose of determining any necessary modification(s). 
(Ord. No. 5566, § V, 3-7-94) 
Sec. 19-106. - [Equal opportunity policy; city police and fire departments.] 
    That in compliance with Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended, and all other applicable state and federal laws, the city's police and fire departments adopt the following statement concerning their employment policies: 
It is the policy of the police and fire departments of the city that no eligible person shall be denied the right of employment or advancement within the city's police and fire departments, nor shall any persons be denied admission or access to any of the city's police and fire departments' programs or activities offered to the public on the basis of political or religious affiliation, race, sex, age, national origin, color, handicap or disability, or veteran status. 
The city's police and fire departments will attempt to refrain from contracting or associating with firms which openly and knowingly practice any form of discrimination in their employment practices. 
The city police and fire departments recognize the right of all citizens to take part in and to be provided equal opportunities in all public activities carried on by the police and fire departments. The city police and fire departments will work toward the following goals and objectives as it relates to the Equal Employment Opportunity Policy: 
(1)  To insure an environment that all provide an equal opportunity for public employment to all eligible segments of society; and, 
(2)  To increase the employment of female and minority citizens within the police and fire departments consistent with state and federal law. 
(Ord. No. 5845, § 1, 11-15-99) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5845, § 1, adopted Nov. 15, 1999, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, its inclusion as § 19-106 was at the discretion of the editor. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Secs. 19-107-19-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EDUCATION AND TRAINING FOR NONUNIFORMED PERSONNEL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 5725, §§ 1-6, adopted December 1, 1997, did not specifically amend the Code. Hence, inclusion as Article IV, §§ 19-116-19-121 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 19-116. - College or university credit hours. 
(a)  Nonuniformed employees who, after the effective date of this article (December 1, 1997) and consistent with its provisions, enroll in and accrue college or university credit hours shall be compensated therefor at the rate of fifty cents ($0.50) per hour per month, provided the employee submits proof of the hours through certified transcript from the college or university substantiating the hours claimed. 
(b)  The maximum amount any nonuniformed employee may receive is sixty dollars ($60.00) per month. 
(c)  "College or university hours" means hours accrued on the semester system or convertible thereto at an accredited institution of higher learning. For the purposes of this article, "accredited institution of higher learning" is an institution which maintains academic programs leading to an award of an associates, bachelors, masters or doctors degree in a particular academic field, and which was accredited by an authority empowered under state law to conduct such evaluations. 
(d)  The educational institution and the courses which the employee wishes to enroll in must be approved in advance by the employee's department head and the mayor. All courses must bear a clear, direct, and rational relationship to the employee's job duties to be eligible for the benefits under this article. 
(Ord. No. 5725, § 1, 12-1-97) 
Sec. 19-117. - Training certificates. 
(a)  Nonuniformed employees who earn a certificate issued by a recognized authority shall be compensated at the same rate of fifty cents ($0.50) per hour per month if credit hours can be obtained. 
(b)  The training certificate must be issued by an agency or entity accepted by the city as bona fide and the training must bear a clear, direct, and rational relationship to the employee's job duties. 
(c)  The maximum compensation for training certificates shall be sixty dollars ($60.00) per month. 
(Ord. No. 5725, § 2, 12-1-97) 
Sec. 19-118. - Burden of proving eligibility. 
    The employee has the burden of proving eligibility for benefits claimed pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 5725, § 3, 12-1-97) 
Sec. 19-119. - Exclusions. 
    College or university hours or training certificates attained in cases where the city has paid the tuition or costs of securing same shall be excluded from consideration for benefits. College or university hours enrolled in or accrued, or training certificates earned or awarded, prior to the effective date of this article, or which were accrued or obtained subsequent hereto without advance approval of the employee's department head and the mayor, are excluded from consideration for benefits. 
(Ord. No. 5725, § 4, 12-1-97) 
Sec. 19-120. - Benefits contingent. 
    All benefits provided for herein are contingent upon the financial good health of the city and no entitlement or vested right is created or intended to be created in any nonuniform employee to receive the benefits provided for herein. 
(Ord. No. 5725, § 5, 12-1-97) 
Sec. 19-121. - Limitation of benefits. 
    Maximum benefits payable pursuant to sections 119-116 and 19-117, or any combination thereof, shall be sixty dollars ($60.00) per month. 
(Ord. No. 5725, § 6, 12-1-97) 
Sec. 19-122. - Sick leave bank for non-uniformed employees. 
(a)  There is hereby established a "sick leave bank" for the use of non-uniformed employees. Non-uniformed employee means an employee who is not a firefighter or sworn police officer, and who, by virtue of his or her employment, is automatically eligible to participate in the bank. 
(b)  The sick leave bank shall be administered by a committee consisting of the director of the human resources department, a representative designated by the city attorney, and a representative of the mayor's office, who shall preside as chair. The committee is charged with developing uniform criteria for the allocation of sick leave from the bank, which shall be approved by the city council and distributed to all non-uniformed employees. 
(c)  Any non-uniformed employee who has been employed as least one (1) year with the city and who has earned sufficient sick leave, may elect to contribute in normal work shift increments. The maximum contribution to the sick leave bank shall be eighty (80) work hours for a non-uniformed employee. The employee may elect the contribution on a form to be developed by the administering committee, which shall be signed by the employee. Once a contribution is made it is irrevocable. 
(d)  A non-uniformed employee is eligible to apply for sick leave from the sick leave bank if he or she: 
(1)  Is in good standing with his or her department; 
(2)  Has exhausted all paid annual and sick leave and other compensatory time; 
(3)  Submits written verification from his or her treating physician that the employee is incapable of returning to work in any capacity at the time all leave and compensatory time has been exhausted; 
(4)  The illness or injury is not job related or covered by worker's compensation. An employee may receive a maximum of two hundred forty (240) hours of sick leave from the sick leave bank in any 12-month period. An employee need not have personally contributed to the sick leave bank to be approved for or receive sick leave from the bank. 
(e)  The administering committee of the sick leave bank may approve sick leave for any non-uniformed employee who meets the criteria set forth in subsection (d) at the time this section goes into effect. It shall make quarterly reports to the mayor and city council of the balance of hours in the sick leave bank. The balance of hours in the bank should not exceed ten thousand (10,000). 
(f)  No non-uniformed employee shall be required to contribute to the sick leave bank. Once hours are contributed, the amount contributed will be subtracted from the employee's earned sick leave allocation and he or she will no longer have any right to the use of the hours or entitled to compensation upon retirement for the hours contributed. 
(Ord. No. 6597, § 1, 3-19-18) 
Secs. 19-123-19-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PINE BLUFF POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENT UNIFORMED EMPLOYEES RULES AND REGULATIONS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6359, § 1, adopted July 18, 2011, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, said provisions have been included as Art. V, §§ 19-131-19-138 and App. A, at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 19-131. - Organization of the review committee. 
    As used herein, the term chief(s) refers to either the police or fire chief, or both, as context dictates. 
(1)  The review committee. 
a.  The review committee (hereinafter "review committee" or "committee") will be comprised of a chair and two (2) other members. 
1.  The chair will be an assistant city attorney selected by the city attorney. 
2.  One (1) committee member will be drawn from a pool of all department heads. 
3.  The second committee member will be drawn from a pool of all employees. Members of the employee pool will be comprised of a list of employees provided by each department head with the review and approval of the mayor and director of the human resources department. 
4.  Additional criterian for the pools, as may be necessary, may be created by the chiefs and the mayor with the assistance of the Human Resources Department. 
b.  The director of human resources will coordinate the selection of the review committee members for a particular hearing, ensuring amongst other things, that they are not in the appealing employee's department and that the department head member is not from the same department as the appealing employee. Both the affected employee and the respective chief will be notified by the human resources department of the date and time of the selection of the committee members and may attend the selection if they choose to do so. 
c.  The appealing employee and the respective chief will be given advance notice of the names of the employees that comprise the review committee. 
1.  Selected review committee members must notify the director of human resources of any circumstances that could interfere with their ability to make an unbiased decision. 
2.  If the appealing employee or the respective chief is concerned about a committee member's possible bias, they must inform the director of human resources within five (5) business days of the date of the notice of appointment of the committee. 
3.  The director of human resources will evaluate the ability of the committee member(s) to make an unbiased recommendation. The director of human resources will make a recommendation to the mayor who will make the final determination as to whether a committee member should be replaced. 
d.  All three (3) members of the committee must be present to conduct any business and a majority vote of the committee will be required for any decision of the committee to be considered final. 
(2)  Residence. Review committee members shall be citizens of the State of Arkansas. 
(3)  Minutes. The date and place of each meeting of the review committee, names of the committee members present, and all official acts of the committee shall be recorded in the minutes prepared by the chair. Minutes will be maintained in the human resources department with copies in the respective department when deemed necessary by the chief of that department. 
(4)  Meetings. Meetings of the review committee will occur when necessary and will be called by the director of human resources in cooperation with the chiefs as more specifically enumerated in subsection 19-137(i)(3). 
(5)  Rule of order. The review committee shall not be bound by any rules of order, evidence or procedure in its meetings. All parties will be allowed to present information and documentation that includes but is not limited to statements, writings, audio and video recordings, photographs and electronic records. 
(Ord. No. 6359, § 1(Ch. 1), 7-18-11) 
Sec. 19-132. - Other city policies and procedures, as applies. 
(a)  The City of Pine Bluff may, as more specifically enumerated herein, or as may be found in other city policies and procedures: 
(1)  Prescribe, amend and enforce rules and regulations governing the fire and police departments. 
(2)  Make rules which set out the qualifications of applicants for any position on the police or fire department. 
(3)  Conduct open competitive examinations to test the relative fitness of applicants for police and fire positions. 
(4)  Hold competitive examinations for promotion and create and maintain eligibility lists for each rank of employment in the police and fire departments, as needed. 
(5)  Reject as eligible all persons who do not meet reasonable requirements of the city or state with regard to age, sex, or physical condition, or those who have been guilty of a felony, or those who have attempted fraud or deception in connection with the examination, application or any part of the hiring or promotion process. 
(6)  Certify to the department head the three (3) standing highest on the eligibility list for appointment or promotion. 
(7)  Appoint temporary employees in cases of emergency. 
(b)  Director of the human resources department. The director of the human resources department shall, in conjunction with the city attorney's office, hold and keep a record of any and all examinations for uniformed positions insuring, where necessary, the sanctity and security of the exams, the answers and responses to the exams, the scores and other related materials thereto. The chiefs and mayor will be allowed access to, and copies of, all materials necessary for managing the day to day operations of the departments including but not limited to hiring and promotions. 
(Ord. No. 6359, § 1(Ch. 2), 7-18-11) 
Sec. 19-133. - General provisions. 
(a)  Purpose of rules. It is the purpose of these rules to establish procedures for handling personnel activities and transactions Pine Bluff Fire and Police Departments and in such manner as to insure that the primary and controlling factor in making appointments and dismissals, in determining promotions and demotions, and in doing all other things which may in any way affect any employee or prospective employee coming within the purview of these rules will always be the merit and fitness of the individual concerned without regard to race, color, national origin, religion, sex, political opinions or affiliations. 
(b)  Positions covered by these rules and policies. These rules and policies shall apply to uniform positions and employees within the fire and police departments. 
(c)  Political activity. 
(1)  Political activity defined. 
Political activity shall be defined as publicly or privately supporting or advocating the following: An issue of public concern which may be before, or which may come before, the United States Congress, the Arkansas State Legislature, the Pine Bluff City Council, or any political subdivisions of any of those bodies; a political candidate for any federal, state, county, or city office. Such activity may consist of public statements of support or opposition to a position or candidate; working as a volunteer in a political campaign of any kind; appearing in photographs which may be used in political advertisements; and any other activity which may tend to identify the individual officer or employee as a supporter or opponent of the candidate or issue in question. 
(2)  Activity prohibited. 
a.  No police officer, firefighter or employee of either department, shall, when on duty, when in uniform, or when otherwise acting in an official capacity, engage in any political activity as herein defined. 
b.  No superior officer (any person above the rank and file) in the police or fire police departments shall order, coerce or otherwise intimidate any subordinate officer or employee with the intent to cause such person to engage in political activity as defined in this section, whether such activity be on or off duty, in uniform or out of uniform. 
c.  Exceptions. Police officers and firefighters may, when in the course and conduct of their duties, or in a personal matter, appear before the city council and any subcommittees thereof, and the Arkansas Legislature and any of its subcommittees, and make statements or give testimony on issues presented to those bodies. 
(3)  Investigation of complaints. Complaints received by the City of Pine Bluff shall be referred to the chief of the department whose employee is the subject of the complaint. The chief of that department shall then cause an investigation to be made and if the allegations are determined to be well-founded, the chief may take such disciplinary action as set forth in section 19-137 of these rules as may be warranted. The chief shall keep the mayor and the human resource department well informed of these matters. 
(Ord. No. 6359, § 1(Ch. 3), 7-18-11) 
Sec. 19-134. - Recruitment, examinations and certification. 
(a)  Recruitment. The City of Pine Bluff shall make every effort to attract qualified applicants to compete in examinations for positions in the police and fire departments. 
(1)  Notice of entry exams. Public notice shall be given of all open competitive examinations at least thirty (30) days, where practicable, in advance of the closing date for receipt of applications by posting notices thereof at city hall and where practicable, by public advertisement in a newspaper of bona fide circulation in the city. 
(2)  Applying for a uniformed position with the police or fire department. Admission to entry level examinations shall be open to all citizens of the United States, who, according to the determination of the police or fire chief meet the requirements specified in the public notice of such examinations, and who filed application on the prescribed form(s) on or before the closing date for filing such application. 
(3)  Minimum/maximum age. No person shall be eligible for appointment on the police department who has not reached the age of twenty-one (21) by the closing date for receiving applications. No person shall be eligible for appointment on the fire department who has not reached the age of twenty-one (21) by the closing date for receiving applications. These minimum age requirements for hiring purposes are designed to follow those required by state certification regulations. Should those state regulations change then the City of Pine Bluff will defer to them rather than this policy. 
No person who has reached age thirty-five (35) may be eligible for appointment to the fire department, except that any person who has at least two (2) years of previous experience as a paid firefighter with another department and whose years of experience as a paid firefighter when subtracted from the person's age leaves a remainder of not more than thirty-five (35) years. In addition, any person who is applying for a position with the fire department in which the primary functions of the job involves duties that are administrative, managerial, or supervisory in nature. 
(b)  Applicant entry process. 
(1)  Written examination. This is the first step in the hiring process. This examination shall include a written demonstration of each competitor's knowledge and skill in the field for which the examination is being held. The test should demonstrate mental ability and general educational attainments. A minimum score of seventy (70) percent on the written examination is required of all applicant examinees to proceed in the employment process. No fractional score will be rounded up. 
a.  Police department. In cases of emergency or when necessary, which the chief and mayor shall decide, the written examination requirement may be dispensed with for all certified law enforcement officers as recognized by the State of Arkansas (full-time and part-time I and II, etc.) currently employed by the City of Pine Bluff or another law enforcement agency and in good standing with his/her department or unemployed but who's certification is in good standing with the State of Arkansas. A letter of such good standing, or other such relevant paper work or forms, shall be provided by the chief executive officer of that agency, or the State of Arkansas, prior to the applying officer's interview with the City of Pine Bluff and shall be made a permanent part of the applicant's personnel file with the Pine Bluff Police Department. All other applicant entry requirements and the Minimum Standards of the Arkansas Commission on Law Enforcement Standards and Training shall remain inviolate. Persons qualified for employment under this rule shall be placed on a separate eligibility list, to be utilized only upon expiration of any pre-existing list. Certified officers hired under this rule shall be on probation for a period of one (1) year from their date of hire. 
b.  Fire department. In cases of emergency or when necessary, which the chief and mayor shall decide, the written examination requirement may be dispensed with for all certified fire fighters as recognized by the State of Arkansas, currently employed by the City of Pine Bluff or another fire fighting agency and in good standing with his/her department or unemployed but who's certification is in good standing with the State of Arkansas. A letter of such good standing, or other such relevant paper work or forms, shall be provided by the chief executive officer of that agency, or the State of Arkansas, prior to the applying firefighter's interview with the City of Pine Bluff and shall be made a permanent part of the applicant's personnel file with the Pine Bluff Fire Department. All other applicant entry requirements and the standards of the State of Arkansas shall remain inviolate. Persons qualified for employment under this rule shall be placed on a separate eligibility list, to be utilized only upon expiration of any pre-existing list. Certified firefighters hired under this rule shall be on probation for a period of one (1) year from their date of hire. 
(2)  Physical agility test. Applicants making a passing score on the written examination shall successfully complete the respective department's (police or fire) physical agility test to proceed in the employment process. This test will be job-related and demonstrate the applicant's ability to perform the public safety tasks required of the department. 
(3)  Background check. The backgrounds of applicants, including but not limited to educational history, military service, criminal records, employment history and personal references will be compiled and used by the city in the employment process. 
(4)  Polygraph examination for police officers. As a part of the background check, a polygraph examination shall be given to applicants for the Police Department. The test shall be conducted by a certified polygraph operator to determine the eligibility and truthfulness of applicants who have successfully completed the written and physical agility tests. Firefighters are exempt from the polygraph test for hiring purposes. 
(5)  Oral examination/interview. An oral examination/interview will be conducted for applicants successfully completing the written and physical agility tests. Education, training and experience, which shall be based upon information in the application form, and such other data as may be secured through the interview, polygraph examination, or from other sources, and which shall be subject to investigation as to truth and completeness, shall be utilized to assess the relative fitness of applicants for the positions. 
The oral examination/interview panel(s) for hiring purposes will be comprised of the following: Three (3) to five (5) individuals from within the respective department selected by the chief who may defer to the mayor or the human resources department as may be necessary. 
All candidates shall be asked a pre-established set of questions which are designed to allow them to demonstrate their oral communication skills, general knowledge, and reasons they are applying for the position. A minimum average score of seventy (70) percent shall be required before an applicant will be placed on the eligibility list and a conditional offer of employment extended. 
Once a candidate has obtained a passing score of seventy (70) percent on the oral examination/interview, then additional points shall be added to each candidate's score based upon the following: 
a.  Five (5) points for previous military service in the Army, Air Force, Marine Corp, Navy or Coast Guard with an honorable discharge (including those honorably discharged from the Reserves or National Guard). 
b.  Three (3) points for candidates who live within the city limits of Pine Bluff. 
c.  Five (5) points for those with a four (4) year college degree. 
d.  Three (3) points for those with a two (2) year associates degree. 
Thereafter, employment is conditioned on successful completion of the medical and psychological examinations, continued eligibility and selection by the chief of the respective department. 
(6)  Final rating. Each competitor passing the examination shall be notified of his final rating soon as the rating has been completed. A competitor who fails the examination shall be notified of his failure. 
(7)  Physical/mental examinations. 
a.  Physical-medical examination. All applicants for appointment or reinstatement shall undergo suitable physical examination: 
For police officers, that which is prescribed by the Arkansas Commission on Law Enforcement Standards and Training; for firefighters a baseline physical examination as required by the City of Pine Bluff. 
The physical-medical examination must be conducted by a competent physician of the City of Pine Bluff's choice. The mayor, human resource director and chiefs shall choose such a physician in these instances. If, in the opinion of the physician, the applicant is not physically and/or mentally qualified to perform satisfactorily the duties of the position, said applicant shall not be given any further consideration for appointment to a position. 
b.  Psychological examination-Police officers. The psychological examination must be conducted by an individual licensed to practice psychiatry or psychology and qualified to perform such evaluations in the State of Arkansas, as selected by the police chief with the approval of the mayor and assistance from human resources as may be necessary. The policies, rules and regulations of the Arkansas Commission on Law Enforcement Standards and Training Specifications shall apply. The psychiatrist or psychologist shall state in writing that the individual is "RECOMMENDED" as a police officer for that person to be eligible for hire. 
Firefighters are exempt from the psychological examination requirements of the Arkansas Commission on Law Enforcement Standards. 
c.  Re-examination. The police or fire chief may require re-examination of eligibles or employees to determine whether they possess the required physical or mental fitness for present or prospective duties. The police or fire chief with approval of the mayor, and assistance from human resources as may be necessary shall select the physician or psychiatrist/psychologist. 
If, in the opinion of the psychiatrist or psychologist, the officer is unfit for duty, rehabilitative measures may be taken, where applicable, or termination may occur. Rehabilitative measures are not a prerequisite to termination. 
Any employee who refuses or fails to have such examination made when instructed to do so may be punished by suspension without pay for not more than thirty (30) days or by discharge from the department. 
(c)  Promotional opportunities. It is the policy of the City of Pine Bluff to provide promotional opportunities whenever possible to qualified employees. Employees are encouraged to take advantage of these opportunities by qualifying themselves for advancement through further education and study, and by a high level of performance, service, interest and loyalty. 
(1)  Notice of promotional examinations. Notice of promotional competitive examinations need only be circulated in offices where there are employees eligible to compete. These notices should be posted as far in advance of the testing as possible, with a minimum of ten (10) days required. 
(2)  Eligibility to compete in promotional examinations. 
a.  Employees only. A promotional competitive examination will be limited to eligible employees of the organizational unit concerned, where possible. The Police or Fire Chief may determine and specify in the notice of promotional examinations the rank or ranks in the organizational unit eligible to compete. The chief will determine whether the promotional opportunity will be restricted to qualified applicants in the department. (See exception, subsection (h) below) 
b.  Requisite service. No firefighter shall be eligible for examination for advancement to the rank of engineer until that firefighter shall have served at least three (3) years as a firefighter, except in the case of an emergency as determined by the chief and mayor. 
No person shall be eligible for examination for advancement to the rank of lieutenant, captain, or battalion chief until that person shall have served at least one (1) year in the preceding rank, except in case of an emergency as determined by the chief and mayor. 
No person shall be eligible for examination for promotion to any rank, who is not certified as an emergency medical technician by June 1, 2012. 
An emergency may be decided by the mayor and respective chief and made part of the records of that department. 
(d)  Promotional process. The police or fire chief may use any combination of selection techniques as follows, provided that for each cycle of a particular promotion the same criteria is used: 
(1)  Written examination-Promotional process. This examination shall include a written demonstration of each competitor's knowledge and skill in the field for which the examination is being held. The test should demonstrate mental ability and general educational attainments. 
a.  Minimum score-Promotional process. In order to advance in the promotional process, a minimum score of seventy (70) percent is required on the written examination (police officers or firefighters). A maximum of thirty (30) points toward the overall promotional rating may be attained on the written examination. 
b.  Allocation of points-Promotional. 
Process. Written examination points shall be given in the following manner: One (1) point for each percentage point scored over seventy (70) percent and above, i.e., a candidate who scores seventy-five (75) percent will receive five (5) points and one who scores ninety-five (95) percent will receive twenty-five (25) points. Under this "point-for-point" rule as well as the 30-point written exam scale, a candidate who scores seventy (70) percent will be considered to have passed the examination but will receive zero (0) written examination points. No fractional score will be rounded up. 
(2)  Practical examination-Promotional process. When it is deemed necessary by the respective chief, use of a practical exercise as part of promotional procedure may be implemented. A practical examination may also be used anytime the chief considers this method to be the best method of selecting the best qualified person for a particular promotion. If used in lieu of a written exam, scoring requirements of minimum score, subsection (d)(1)a., above, shall apply. 
When a combination of written examination and practical examination are used, the candidate must successfully pass the written examination in order to proceed to the practical examination. One-half (1/2) of the points will be assigned to each examination. These scores will be averaged to reach the candidate's written exam score. The same 30-point scale and point-for-point award referred to in subsection (d)(1)b., allocation of points, above, shall apply to the averaged scores and be employed toward the overall final rating. 
(3)  Oral examination/interview. 
a.  In lieu of written exam. This type of examination may be used in lieu of or to supplement the written examination or to obtain information regarding the abilities of the competitors not readily obtainable in a written examination. If the chief chooses this form of examination, persons with special qualifications or expertise from outside the departments may be selected to assist the chief in conducting the oral examination/interview. When used in lieu of a written examination, the "minimum score" requirements, above, shall apply and points shall be allocated as stated above. 
The panel(s) performing oral examinations/interviews for the purpose of promotions will be comprised of the following people: 
1.  Police department. The panel shall consist of three (3) to seven (7) people selected by the chief or chief's designee, who may defer to the mayor or the human resources department when necessary. Those selected shall be peers from the public safety industry (fire fighting, police, emergency medical, etc.) who hold the equivalent or higher rank of the relevant position in question.
