The panel(s) may also include community leaders from both the private and public sectors. When community leaders are chosen for a particular panel they may not outnumber those from public safety industry on that particular panel. 
2.  Fire department. Three (3) to seven (7) people selected by the chief or chief's designee, who may defer to the mayor or the human resources department when necessary. Those selected shall be peers from the public safety industry (fire fighting, police, emergency medical, etc.) who hold the equivalent or higher rank of the relevant position in question. The panel(s) may also include community leaders from both the private and public sectors. When community leaders are chosen for a particular panel they may not outnumber those from public safety industry on that particular panel. 
b.  Oral examination and interview. The oral examination/interview will be used to supplement the written examination and to obtain information regarding the abilities of competitors not readily obtainable in the written examination. The chief will also use this opportunity to assess a candidate's efficiency rating 3 [] and his/her educational and vocational attainments. [] Factors to be considered in this process, besides formal education and vocation accomplishments, include physical fitness, awards, disciplinary actions, training, and experience. This information may be obtained from evaluation forms, personnel files and other such data as may be secured through the interview or from other sources. 
All candidates shall be asked the same pre-established set of questions which are designed to allow them to demonstrate their knowledge, skills and abilities in the areas of oral communication and problem-solving. These questions may be developed by the chief in consultation with department staff who may be chosen at the discretion of the chief. The chief may receive assistance from the Mayor and Human Resource Department, as may be necessary or as may be directed by the Mayor. Also, questions may be purchased from an outside consultant as necessary. 
A maximum of thirty (30) points 5 [] toward the overall promotional rating of one hundred (100) points shall be obtained from the oral examination/interview, except when an oral examination is used in lieu of a written examination. In that event, the examination may be more extensive than described in this section and shall be scored separately (thirty (30) points) as provided for in subsection (d)(1)b., allocation of points, above. 
The interview will be scored and the points allocated by the panel as follows: 
1.  Ten (10) points for oral communication skills; and 
2.  Twenty (20) points for problem solving ability. 
All of the compiled information, with the exception of written test scores, will be sealed and held by the chief of the department until immediately after the interviews are completed. The chief will then score and compile the results and complete the eligibility list using all materials and results from the process (oral interview(s), written testing, documentation, etc.). 
(4)  Staff evaluation and point allocation. 
a.  Fire department evaluations: 
1.  Firefighter: Evaluated by a staff panel made up of a lieutenant, station captain, battalion chief and deputy chief. 
2.  Engineer: Evaluated by a staff panel made up of a lieutenant, station captain, battalion chief and deputy chief. 
3.  Lieutenant: Evaluated by a staff panel made up of a captain, battalion chief, and deputy chief(s). 
4.  Captain: Evaluated by a staff panel made up of a deputy chief(s) and a battalion chief. 
5.  Battalion chief: Evaluated by a staff panel made up of a deputy chief and the fire chief. 
The following allocation of points shall apply for promotions for PBFD: 
(i) Test: 0-30 points (ii) Staff: 10 points (iii) Chief: 25 points (iv) Oral interview: 20 points (v) Seniority: 10 points (vi) Education: 5 points maximum (To be allocated as follows: Associates Degree one (1) point, Bachelors Degree three (3) points and a Masters Degree five (5) points.)  
b.  Police department evaluations: 
1.  Officer: Evaluated by shift sergeant, lieutenant deputy chief and assistant chief. 
2.  Sergeant: Evaluated by lieutenant deputy chief and assistant chief. 
3.  Lieutenant: Evaluated by a captain, deputy chief and assistant chief. 
4.  Captain: Evaluated by deputy chief and assistant chief. 
The following allocation of points shall apply for promotions for PBPD: 
(i) Test: 0-10 points (ii) Staff: 10 points (iii) Chief: 30 points (iv) Seniority: 15 points (v) Oral interview: 30 points (vi) Education: 5 points maximum (To be allocated as follows: Associates Degree one (1) point, Bachelors Degree three (3) points and a Masters Degree five (5) points.)  
c.  Guidelines for allocation of points by chief. A chief may allocate up to ten (10) points for an average employee. A chief may allocate from ten (10) to thirty (30) points for employees who demonstrate excellent leadership skills and the ability to defuse or calm situations without the use of force. Further, this person must possess the desire to improve himself/herself and must have sought and received additional training/education outside of the minimum required by the department. Additionally, in allocating points, the chief may consider volunteer activities of the employee that have bettered the Pine Bluff community. 
d.  Failure of a chief of a department to follow guidelines. If serious allegations are made that a chief of a department has failed to follow the aforementioned guidelines, the mayor shall investigate and determine whether the guidelines have been followed. If it is determined that the guidelines were not followed in a particular instance, the mayor may limit or disallow the chief's points and the promotional period shall be complete with eighty-five (85) points being the maximum. In the event the chief's points are not completely eliminated, a pro-rata composite score will be used wherein the chief's points are diminished accordingly. 
(5)  Length of service-Promotional process. Candidates for promotion will be awarded .5 of one (1) point for each complete year of service, up to twenty (20) years, for a total of ten (10) points. 6 [] 
(6)  Final rating-Promotional process. Each competitor passing the examination shall be notified of his final rating as soon as is practicable after the rating has been completed. A competitor who fails the examination shall be notified of his failure. Any examinee shall be permitted to inspect his/her test in person in the chief's office by contacting the chief or his/her designee or in the offices of the Human Resources Department and shall be permitted to check his/her test with the answer sheet. A manifest error on the test shall be corrected if called to the attention of the chief, but such correction shall not invalidate any appointment previously made from such register; however the chief will make any required changes to the register based upon the corrective action taken. 
(e)  Eligible lists (applicant and promotional). 
(1)  Types of lists. Eligibility lists shall be of two (2) kinds: (1) entrance lists from which the original appointments shall be made and (2) promotion lists from which promotional appointments shall be made. These lists shall be made after each examination and at such times as the chief certifies the personnel. There shall be an appointment list for patrol positions in the police department and firefighter in the fire department. Promotion lists shall be established from time to time, as required. 
(2)  Duration of lists. All lists for appointment or promotion as kept by the chief with copies being maintained by the human resources department and shall be good for one (1) year from the date of certification. At the expiration of this period, all right of priority under the lists shall cease. However, when the chief believes it to be in the best interest of the city the chief may extend the validity of the appointment list for up to an additional year beyond the original year, for a total of not more than two (2) years. 
(3)  Chief's selection. The department head may select for appointment or promotion one (1) of the highest ranking of the three (3) on the respective list and notify the Mayor or his designee, the human resources department, and any other necessary city departments thereof. 
(4)  Order on list. The names of successful competitors shall be entered upon the appropriate list in order of their final rating by the chief. The original of this list shall be placed on file in the office of the respective chief as well as a copy being provided to the human resources department. 
(5)  Reinstatement to list. The name of any probationary or regular employee who is laid off because of lack of funds or curtailment of work or staff shall be returned to its former relative position on the list from which certification was made, provided such list has not expired or been exhausted. 
In the event a list has expired or been exhausted, the names of such regular or probationary employees shall be placed on re-employment list by classification and in order of lay-off. Upon re-establishment of the position, the employee last laid off shall be given preference in re-employment provided the position is the same classification he was in prior to the lay-off. 
(6)  Supplemental examinations. The chief's shall, from time to time, make a review of existing employment and promotional lists to determine whether there is an adequate number of eligible's available to meet the needs of the service. When it is determined by the chief's that a particular list is inadequate or will become inadequate in a short period of time, the chief(s) may order a supplemental examination for that class of positions. 
(f)  Removal of name from eligible lists. The chief may remove the name of an eligible from a list for any number of reasons, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  The eligible declines appointment when offered to him/her under such conditions as he/she as indicated previously he/she would accept. 
(2)  The eligible cannot be located by the postal authorities. It shall be deemed impossible to so locate an eligible when communication mailed to him/her at his/her last known address is returned unclaimed. 
(3)  The eligible is separated from the uniformed service (promotional list). 
(4)  He/she is physically unfit to perform effectively the duties of the position in which he/she seeks employment. 
(5)  He/she is addicted to the use of narcotics or the excessive use of intoxicating liquors. 
(6)  He/she has been convicted of a crime or has engaged in conduct below the standard of the department, as prescribed in departmental rules and regulations. 
(7)  He/she has made a false statement of material fact in his/her application. 
(8)  He/she has used or attempted to use political pressure or bribery to secure an advantage in the examination or appointment. 
(9)  He/she has directly or indirectly obtained information regarding examinations to which, as an applicant, he/she was not entitled. 
(g)  Suspension of competition. In the case of a vacancy in a position requiring peculiar or exceptional qualifications of a scientific, professional, or expert character, upon satisfactory evidence that competition is impracticable and that the position can best be filled by the selection of some person designated who is of recognized attainment, the chief may, after being authorized by the mayor, suspend competition in that case. Suspension shall not be general in application but rather each case must be handled on its own merits and the finding of such necessity recorded in the records of the department. 
(h)  Temporary employees. In cases of emergency, temporary employees may be appointed by the department head of the police or fire department or his/her designee, without examination, and pending appointment from an eligible's list. A finding of an emergency and the reason therefore shall be placed in the records of the respective department. No temporary appointment shall continue longer than sixty (60) days, nor shall excessive temporary appointments be allowed, except in times of grave danger, of which the chief and mayor shall decide and make a record thereof. 
(i)  Re-employment of employees who left employment voluntarily. An employee (of either the fire department of police department) who has left his/her employment voluntarily shall be eligible for re-employment within twelve (12) months. Re-employment shall be conditioned on the applicant being current on all certifications and the existence of an opening. That further, the employee shall be a probationary employee pursuant to subsection 19-136(a), for a period of twelve (12) months from the date of re-employment. 
(Ord. No. 6359, § 1(Ch. 4), 7-18-11; Ord. No. 6423, § 1, 12-17-12) 
Footnotes: 
--- () --- 
Note- Examinations may include a rating of the candidate's efficiency. In determining a candidate's efficiency rating, the department head may utilize a promotional rating of the candidate (evaluation points) by department staff of the respective departments. Within the police department, "staff" may include the individual's immediate supervisor, supervising lieutenant, deputy chief and assistant chief. Within the fire department, "staff" may include the deputy chief, training officer, and battalion chiefs. See Appendix A.

Sec. 19-135. - Separation. 
(a)  Medical/psychological examination. 
(1)  Elimination from employment consideration/continuation. [See physical/psychological examinations, Chapter 4, Section (2)(G)(I, II, III)]. 
(b)  Lay-offs. In the event that it shall become necessary to reduce the personnel of either the police or fire department, reduction shall be done from the lowest rank, continuous seniority having priority (contingent upon the completion of any probationary period). 
    The names of such persons so removed shall be placed at the top of the re-employment list in order of lay-off and said person shall be called to work ahead of those who have not previously been employed; provided, however, that upon return, such person must satisfy the chief of his/her physical fitness by passing an appropriate physical examination before a doctor, or doctors, to be approved by the chief and the mayor with the assistance of the human resource department as may be necessary. 
(c)  Other types of separation. In addition to lay-offs, the other types of separation fall into several categories: resignation, dismissal for cause, and retirement. 
(1)  Voluntary resignation. Upon voluntary separation from the service, an employee shall submit to his/her department head a letter of resignation. A copy of his/her letter shall be forwarded to the all appropriate city offices and departments as may be directed by the chief or mayor. 
(2)  Dismissal for cause. The chief may, at any time, dismiss an employee of the department for cause (see section 19-137, discipline, for un-exclusive listing of "cause") provided pre-deprivation notice and hearing are provided as is more specifically articulated herein and in each departments operational policies, unless circumstances dictate to the contrary. The chief or his/her designee shall notify the employee by letter as to the reasons for the dismissal and the effective date thereof. A copy of this letter must be forwarded to all appropriate city offices and departments. 
(Ord. No. 6359, § 1(Ch. 5), 7-18-11) 
Sec. 19-136. - Probationary period. 
(a)  Probationary period. Every person appointed or promoted from an eligibility list shall be required to successfully complete a probationary period. Newly appointed uniformed employees shall serve a period of probation of twelve (12) months before the appointment is complete. Promoted employees shall serve a six (6) month probationary period prior to the promotion being complete. A promotee may be reduced in rank by the chief during the probationary period and he/she shall not be allowed to appeal the decision. 
(b)  Purpose. The police and fire departments shall use the probationary period to closely observe and evaluate the work of all employees who are newly appointed or promoted and to encourage their effective adjustment to the job and service to city government. 
    A probationary period of service may not extend or be extended beyond the statutory or authorized period of service. Retention of employees after the probationary period shall become equivalent to a full appointment or promotion. 
    A department head must make a decision before the completion of the probationary/work test period as to whether a probationary employee (new hire) should be dismissed or placed in the uniform service. If the department head fails to carry out his duty, the employee shall automatically be removed from probationary status. If the department head fails to demote a promoted employee within the probationary period, then he/she shall be deemed to have completed his/her probationary period. 
(c)  Termination or discipline of a probationary employee. A new employee may be disciplined or terminated at any time during the probationary period in compliance with rules, regulations and standards of conduct of the respective departments. 
    The discipline or termination of a new employee during the probationary period shall not be subject to appeal under the rules set forth in section 19-137. 
(Ord. No. 6359, § 1(Ch. 6), 7-18-11) 
Sec. 19-137. - Conduct and disciplinary procedures. 
(a)  Employee conduct. All employees in the fire or police department shall be governed by the rules and regulations set out by the chiefs of their respective departments once those rules and regulations have been adopted by the city council. This section is intended to embody any existing rules and regulations and their subsequent modifications, additions or deletions, as approved by the city council. 
(b)  Corrective action. Any supervisor may take corrective action by orally admonishing employees as necessary. This action may be taken in an effort to correct a situation that, if uncorrected, may require formal disciplinary action. 
(c)  Disciplinary action. The following are declared to be causes for disciplinary action, through charges may be based on causes other than those enumerated: 
(1)  Neglect of duty. 
(2)  Dishonesty. 
(3)  Disobedience to orders. 
(4)  Making a false official report. 
(5)  Insubordination or failure to obey a lawful order of a superior officer. 
(6)  Discourteous treatment of the public or fellow employees. 
(7)  Conviction of a criminal charge. 
(8)  Feigned chronic physical or mental ailment or defect to escape duty. 
(9)  Solicitation of or acceptance of personal gifts, rewards, or anything of monetary value for the performance of duty or with the expectation of giving better service or treatment. 
(10)  Negligent or willful damage to public property or waste of department supplies. 
(11)  Absence without leave, failure to report after a request for leave has been disapproved, or absence from one's duty or post without good cause. 
(12)  Excessive absenteeism. 
(13)  Shirking of duty, or exhibiting cowardice in the performance of duty. 
(14)  Violations of the rules of the City of Pine Bluff or his/her department. 
(15)  Use of illegal drugs; abuse of controlled substances or illegal possession of controlled substances. 
(16)  Intoxication on duty. 
(17)  Failure to comply with random or other drug testing requirements. 
(d)  Types of disciplinary action. The chief of police or the fire department or their acting designee may use any of the following disciplinary actions to maintain control of their departments. The following types of formal disciplinary action may be among those used: 
(1)  Written reprimand. 
(2)  Suspension. 
(3)  Reduction in rank and pay. 
(4)  Dismissal. 
(e)  Written reprimand. The chief of police or fire or his/her designee may issue an official written reprimand. The reprimand must state clearly that the employee is being formally reprimanded and must be placed in the employee's personnel file for a period of one (1) year from the date of the reprimand. There shall be no appeal from a written reprimand. Written reprimands will be made available for review by the subject employee in the Human Resources Department as well as the relevant department. 
(f)  Suspension. The chief of police or fire or his/her designee may, for just cause, suspend an employee without pay for any length of time up to thirty (30) calendar days for each violation of these rules or regulations or those of his/her respective department. An employee who is so suspended shall be given written notice of the reasons for the action and of his/her right to appeal this action. Upon notice of suspension, the officer is prohibited from exercising any arrest or police authority vested in the officer by the State of Arkansas and/or the City of Pine Bluff and may not exercise such in the course of private employment or otherwise during the suspension. The right of appeal shall not apply to a suspension of a probationary employee (either a promoted employee on probation or a new employee during his/her probationary period). 
(g)  Reduction in rank or pay. The chief of police or fire or his/her designee may, for just cause, reduce an employee temporarily or permanently in rank or pay. An employee who is so reduced in rank or pay shall be given written notice of the reasons for the action and of his/her right to appeal this action. The right of appeal shall not apply to a reduction in rank of a probationary employee (either a promoted employee on probation or a new employee during his/her probationary period). 
(h)  Dismissal. The chief of police or fire or his acting designee may, for just cause, dismiss an employee. An employee who is dismissed shall be given written notice of the reasons for the action and of his/her right to appeal this action. The right of appeal shall not apply to a dismissal of a probationary employee (a new employee during his/her probationary period). 
(i)  Appeal procedure. 
(1)  Review of disciplinary decision. Any employee suspended, reduced in rank and pay, or dismissed from the uniformed service may, by his/her written request to the chief or their designee and copy delivered to the human resources department, have the action reviewed by the review committee (see section 19-131). Said request must be made within ten (10) days after notification by the chief of said disciplinary action. Thereupon, the committee shall grant a review of the matter. 
The employee shall have the right to be heard and to present information and documentation on his/her own behalf. No parties to the review shall be represented by counsel during the review committee's meeting(s). However, the appealing employee may have in attendance one (1) person of their choosing (minister, family member, doctor, friend, spouse, attorney, etc.) provided that person does not participate, in any way, in the review. The employee shall identify the attendee and provide the attendee's contact information to the review committee. The reasons concerning the suspension, reduction in pay and rank, or dismissal and the reply shall constitute a part of said review. Further, all parties to the review shall be given ample opportunity to respond to the opposing parties information and documentation. 
The employee shall be granted a review by the committee not more than fifteen (15) days after the request is made; provided, however, that the employee be notified of the date and place of said review ten (10) days prior to the date thereof. The chairman of the committee shall preside at the review and shall determine and decide all questions relative to the committee meeting. Upon completion of the review, the committee will have ten (10) days in which to issue and make its decision unless exceptional circumstances arise and in that instance the decision shall be rendered as soon as is possible. 
(2)  Scheduling the appeals review. 
a.  The human resources department will schedule a date for the committee to hear the review and give notice to the interested parties as required herein. Every effort will be made to schedule the review on the appealing employee's work time, but due to the periodic difficulty of convening such a meeting, this may not always be possible. In the event that the review is scheduled on the appealing employee's day off, they will not be paid for the time. 
b.  If the employee wishes to withdraw the request to review, the withdrawal must be made in writing and presented to the chief and the director of human resources. 
(3)  The appeals review. 
a.  The committee will hold a review that allows both parties to fully explain themselves. 
b.  At the close of the review the committee will adjourn the meeting and deliberate, and vote, in private. The committee will then reconvene and announce its decision. In no event shall the committee take longer than ten (10) days to make its decision. 
c.  Upon the concurrence of at least two (2) committee members, the committee may make one (1) of the following decisions regarding each matter before the committee: 
1.  That the disciplinary action be upheld as originally imposed; 
2.  That the discipline imposed be overturned and no other discipline be imposed; or, 
3.  That the discipline imposed be modified to impose another disciplinary action, whether less or more severe than the discipline originally imposed. 
d.  The committee's findings and recommendation(s), signed by all members, will be submitted to the mayor, chief, and the director of human resources. The committee will have the discretion to utilize the director of human resources (or designee) to assist in the preparation of the finding and recommendation document. 
(4)  Wrongful discipline-Remedies available. In the event that it is determined by the committee that the original suspension, discharge, or reduction in rank of any employee was incorrect, the employee shall be entitled to be made whole regarding pay and benefits regularly paid by the city, but in no event shall gain a windfall. 
(j)  Solicitation. No uniformed employee of the city government shall directly or indirectly solicit any money, service, favor, or any other valuable consideration for carrying out his/her duties as an employee of the government. 
(k)  Obstruction of rights. No uniformed officer or employee of the city government shall consciously and by overt act deprive any person of any rights to which such person is entitled under any law, ordinance, rule or regulation of the city government. 
(l)  Impartiality. Each uniformed officer and employee of the city government performing inspection or regulatory functions shall discharge his/her inspection and regulatory duties fairly and impartially and his/her determinations shall be made without discrimination on account of sex, race, creed, friendship, political, or organizational affiliation. 
(Ord. No. 6359, § 1(Ch. 7), 7-18-11) 
Sec. 19-137.1. - Assistant chief of police/deputy fire chief disciplinary appeals process. 
(a)  Uniformed employees who have been appointed to serve in the capacity of assistant chief of police/deputy fire chief shall be permitted to appeal disciplinary actions imposed by the respective chiefs, to the City Council of the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas. The city council may override the disciplinary action(s) by the respective chiefs, by two-thirds ( 2/3 ) majority of the total membership of the council vote. An appeal must be made in writing and filed with the city clerk no later than ten (10) days after the disciplinary action. 
(b)  The assistant chief of police/deputy fire chief will not be permitted to appeal disciplinary actions through the review committee, pursuant to section 6 [of Ordinance Number 6378]. 
(c)  This section in no way diminishes the authority of the respective chiefs to appoint or remove the assistant chief of police/deputy fire chief, except as specifically provided. 
(d)  In the event that an assistant chief police/deputy fire chief has been subjected to disciplinary action by the respective chief, this appeals process is available as long as his/her right to appeal under Ordinance Number 6359 has not expired, upon the passage of this section. 
(Ord. No. 6378, §§ 1-4, 2-13-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6378, §§ 1-4, adopted Feb. 13, 2012, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore these provisions have been added as § 19-137.1 at the editor's discretion. Section 6, as referenced in subsection (b) above, states: "An appeal lodged in a timely manner and as provided in Section 1 shall be considered sufficient to secure review before the review committee authorized by Ordinance 6359, should this Ordinance be vetoed by the Mayor and the veto is not overridden by the City Council." 
Sec. 19-138. - Miscellaneous. 
(a)  Leave of absence. Any request for an excused absence without pay for a period of twenty (20) work days or less may be granted by the police chief/fire chief and/or his/her designee without the necessity of preparing formal leave papers. Upon approval of the chief and the mayor, a leave of absence without pay may be granted for up to sixty (60) work days in any calendar year. Requests for such leave of absence shall be made in writing to the chief and the mayor and also filed by the requestor with the human resources department. Additional unpaid leave as an accommodation for qualified individuals with disabilities, who are unable to return from a medical leave within a specific time, will be considered on a case by case basis. This leave of absence policy is exclusive of any rights under the Family Medical Leave Act, or other federal or state law. 
    Since a leave of absence will impact upon the department's staffing availability to perform essential services, approval will be limited to extraordinary circumstances. Such application shall be made as far in advance as possible. 
(b)  Availability of city and department rules and regulations. City and departmental rules and regulations shall be available to all employees. Any employee who desires to review any rules and regulations may request from his supervisor permission to review same. The supervisor will make a copy available for review within a reasonable period of time from the request. 
(c)  Amending or changing rules and regulations. The Pine Bluff City Council is responsible for approving any additions, deletions and changes to these rules and regulations. The review committee may make recommendations for any such amendments. When doing so the review committee should submit their recommendations to the city's public safety committee and in turn the public safety committee, after review, will submit those recommendations and any other that may generated within the public safety committee, to the council as a whole. The chiefs of the police and fire departments, or their designees, shall make all city rules and regulations available to all departmental employees. 
(d)  Severability clause. If any provision of these policies, rules, and regulations or the application of any rule, regulation or circumstance is held invalid by a final judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity shall not affect other provisions or applications of these policies, rules and regulations which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end, the provisions of these regulations are declared to be severable. 
(e)  Emergency clause. Because the members of the civil service commission collectively tendered their resignations, effective June 16, 2011, the Pine Bluff Police Department and the Pine Bluff Fire Department employees are without recourse to address employment issues which may arise in their respective departments. Therefore, an emergency is declared to exist and this article is in full force and effect from its passage and the order of dismissal is filed of record. 
(f)  Conflict clause. That all ordinances, resolutions, or parts thereof, in conflict with this article are hereby repealed to the extent of any conflict. 
(g)  Referenced materials. The Policy and Procedures Manual of the Pine Bluff Police Department, the Working Rules and Regulations of the Pine Bluff Fire and Emergency Services Department and the Pine Bluff Police Department Job Description Manual are considered part of these rules and regulations as though set out word-for-word herein and shall be so considered as may be amended by periodic action of the Pine Bluff City Council. 
(Ord. No. 6359, § 1(Ch. 8), 7-18-11)

PINE BLUFF FIRE DEPARTMENT 
EMPLOYMENT REQUIREMENTS 
      
  Citizen of the United States. 
  At least 18 years of age, but not older than 35 years of age (see subsection 19-134(a)). 
  No felony convictions. 
  Must pass a written examination. 
  Possess a valid driver's license. 
  Must pass a physical agility test, successfully complete medical and related examinations and evaluations. 
  Must be of good moral character. A comprehensive background investigation will be conducted. 
  Must have acceptable vision (visual acuity must not exceed 20/100 in either eye, correctable to 20/20 or better in each eye). 
  Must establish residency consistent with city residency requirements. 
  High School Diploma or GED equivalent. 
PINE BLUFF POLICE DEPARTMENT 
EMPLOYMENT REQUIREMENTS 
      
  Citizen of the United States. 
  At least 21 years of age. 
  Possess a valid driver's license. 
  Must past test and successfully complete medical and related examinations and evaluations. 
  A comprehensive background investigation will be conducted. 
  Must have acceptable vision (uncorrected visual acuity must not exceed 20/100 in either eye, correctable to 20/20 or better in each eye). 
  Must possess normal hearing in each ear. 
  Must establish residency consistent with city residency requirements. 
  High school diploma or GED equivalent. 
APPLICANT DISQUALIFICATIONS: 
1.  Having a conviction for, being under indictment for, or currently charged with any felony offense. 
2.  Having a conviction for or currently charged with a class "A, B," class "C," or any unclassified misdemeanor, which in the opinion of the chief or the chief's designee would call into question the moral character or judgment of the applicant. 
3.  Having a conviction for a class A misdemeanor offense consisting of domestic violence/domestic abuse. 
4.  Having a conviction for driving under the influence (DWI or DUI) within three (3) years preceding the date of application, or more than one (1) conviction at any time. 
5.  Currently being on probation for any felony offense, or any offense involving moral character. 
6.  Illegal use of any controlled substance, except for the use of marijuana more than three (3) years from the date of the application. 
7.  Having an excessive record of traffic convictions or negligent traffic collisions. 
8.  Not being of good moral character, or being known to habitually associate with those of questionable moral character. 
9.  Having been discharged from military service with a dishonorable discharge, or a general discharge indicating (a) bad conduct, or (b) any other characterization indicating bad character. 
10.  Being a member of any organization which advocates the overthrow of the government by force or violence. 
11.  Having been discharged from any commissioned or recruit position within a law enforcement agency for disciplinary reasons, resigning to avoid suspension or discharge or having resigned during a disciplinary investigation without a final judgment being rendered. 
12.  Having resigned or being terminated from the Pine Bluff Police Department due to a lack of proficiency in an academic or skill area will disqualify the applicant for a period of twelve (12) months from the date of resignation or termination. 
13.  Failing to cooperate fully with and keep all scheduled appointments with staff personnel involved in the selection process, failing to provide added personal information as needed, or failing to submit information update/changes within ten (10) days of the change; refusal to submit, if requested, to a polygraph exam to resolve any conflicts which might arise during the background investigation. 
14.  Making any false statement of fact, being deceptive by statement or omission in the applicant screening checklist and/or the written application or by any means in any part of the selection process. Disqualification is for a minimum of two (2) years from the date of application. 
15.  Failure to supply the needed documents and/or submit the application within the specified time limits. 
16.  Making false statements, falsely swearing to statements or in any other manner falsifying testimony in any official matter or in any significant business transaction. 
17.  Without being specifically enumerated in the above disqualifications if circumstances exist which indicate the applicant is clearly unsuited for a career with the Pine Bluff Police Department, the applicant will be rejected. 
    All interpretations regarding these rules will be made by the chief of police or his designee, and when necessary and practicable in consultation with the mayor and approval by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 6359, § 1, 7-18-11) 
Chapter 20 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Grider Field airport zoning, § 6-46 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; flood damage prevention, Ch. 11; signs and advertising, Ch. 22; subdivisions, Ch. 25; zoning, Ch. 29. 
State Law reference- Authority to legislate on matters pertaining to municipal affairs, A.C.A. § 14-43-601 et seq.; municipal planning, A.C.A. § 14-56-401 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Temporary appointment, designation of duties in absence of employee. 
    In the absence of an employee from the positions of planning director, assistant planner, zoning administrator or zoning enforcement officer, the mayor shall have the authority to assign, designate or name, with the approval of the city council, any person to fill such position, as a temporary appointee, and to assign such duties and responsibilities to such appointee as may be deemed consistent therewith in the discharge of the duties and responsibilities of that position, for such time as may be deemed necessary and proper. 
(Code 1967, § 26-16) 
Sec. 20-2. - Duties and responsibilities of director. 
    The planning director shall be directly responsible to the mayor, and shall be responsible to the planning commission for the coordination and performance of all work items contained within those planning activities that pertain to the directives of the planning commission. The planning director shall have the following duties and responsibilities, in addition to those which may be designated and assigned by the planning commission and/or mayor: 
(1)  Administers the municipal planning program. 
(2)  Directs the planning staff and coordinates their activities with other staff members. 
(3)  Execution of the development of municipal planning standards and implementation of the city's comprehensive planning program. 
(4)  Acts as chief advisor to the planning commission. 
(5)  Coordinates planning activities with those of other city departments and various regional, state and federal agencies. 
(Code 1967, § 26-9) 
Sec. 20-3. - Assistant planner. 
    The position of assistant planner is hereby created. The assistant planner shall be appointed by the planning director, after consultation with the planning commission, to serve at the pleasure of the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1967, § 26-10) 
Sec. 20-4. - Zoning administrator-Appointment. 
    The position of zoning administrator is hereby created. The zoning administrator shall be appointed by the planning director, after consultation with the planning commission, to serve at the pleasure of the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1967, § 26-12) 
Sec. 20-5. - Same-Duties, responsibilities. 
    The zoning administrator shall be directly responsible to the planning director and shall have the following duties and responsibilities, in addition to those which may be designated and assigned by the planning director: 
(1)  Handle all zoning requests for variances, and the enforcement of all policies and regulations embodied in the zoning ordinance. 
(2)  Responsible for all preliminary and final plats that are presented to the planning commission for review. 
(3)  Serve as an advisor to the planning commission and is responsible for providing them with all necessary information concerning requests for rezoning, variances and subdivision plats. 
(4)  Responsible for publishing or seeing that appropriate legal notices are published in regard to rezoning requests and other areas that fall within his jurisdiction for notifying or seeing that surrounding property areas are notified. 
(5)  Deal with the public in matters relating to rezoning variances and subdivision plats. 
(6)  Attend all planning commission meetings on all matters included within his jurisdiction. 
(7)  Supervise the enforcement of all zoning ordinances, and exercise the power to make affidavit for the warrant of arrest for any person violating the terms of the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1967, § 26-13) 
Sec. 20-6. - Zoning enforcement officer-Appointment. 
    The position of zoning enforcement officer is hereby created. The zoning enforcement officer shall be appointed by the planning director and zoning administrator, after consulting with the planning commission, to serve at the pleasure of the mayor and city council. 
(Code 1967, § 26-14) 
Sec. 20-7. - Same-Duties, responsibilities. 
(a)  The zoning enforcement officer shall be directly responsible to the zoning administrator and shall have the following duties and responsibilities in addition to those which may be designated and assigned by the zoning administrator: 
(1)  Work at the direction of the zoning administrator and assist the administrator in the fulfillment of his duties. 
(2)  Enforce the provisions of the zoning ordinances on a day-to-day basis. 
(3)  Conduct field work and data collection relative to the preparation of the various rezoning petitions that come before the planning commission. 
(4)  Post all legal notices required by the zoning ordinance. 
(5)  Enforce all zoning ordinances, and exercise the power to make affidavit for the warrant of arrest for any person violating the terms of the zoning ordinance. 
(b)  The zoning enforcement officer shall exercise the duties and responsibilities of the zoning administrator in the absence of the zoning administrator. 
(Code 1967, § 26-15) 
Secs. 20-8-20-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions, etc., generally, § 2-181 et seq. 
State Law reference- Planning commissions, A.C.A. § 14-56-401 et seq. 

Sec. 20-26. - Created. 
    In order to direct the future physical development of the city and to encourage its social and economic improvements in accordance with modern city plan-principles and to insure the orderly, efficient and economic arrangement and development of future special works projects, there is hereby created a commission to be known as the city planning commission. 
(Code 1967, § 26-1) 
State Law reference- Authority to create planning commission, A.C.A. § 14-56-404. 
Sec. 20-27. - Membership; terms. 
(a)  The city planning commission shall consist of nine (9) members appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. They shall reside within the city limits and be qualified by knowledge or experience to act upon matters pertaining to the physical, social and economic development of the city. 
(b)  All terms shall be for three (3) years and the terms shall expire on June first of such year. Appointments to fill vacancies shall be for the unexpired terms only. Five (5) members shall constitute a quorum. 
(Code 1967, § 26-2) 
State Law reference- Planning commission membership, A.C.A. §§ 14-56-404, 14-56-405. 
Sec. 20-28. - Reports; employees; appropriations. 
    The planning commission shall make periodic reports to the mayor and city council covering their investigations, transactions, and recommendations, and such other reports relative thereto, as it may deem proper or as requested by the mayor or city council. The commission may employ such employees as may be necessary and approved by the city council, and the city council may make such appropriations for this commission as may be necessary and proper. 
(Code 1967, § 26-6) 
Sec. 20-29. - Legislation. 
    It shall also be the duty of the planning commission to prepare and recommend such national, state, and municipal legislation as may be necessary in carrying out the recommendations or suggestions of the commission. 
(Code 1967, § 26-7) 
Chapter 21 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Cruelty to police dogs, § 5-35. 
State Law reference- Authority to legislate on matters pertaining to municipal affairs, A.C.A. § 14-43-601 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Authorized fees. 
    The police department is authorized to assess a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per copy to a requester for a police or accident report; and is further authorized to assess a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each request by a person to be fingerprinted. Notice of the fees will be conspicuously posted by the police department to apprise a requester of the cost associated with each service. 
(Ord. No. 6560, § 1, 1-17-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6560, § 1, adopted Jan. 17, 2017, added provisions to the Code but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as § 21-1. 
Secs. 21-2-21-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Departments, § 2-121 et seq. 
State Law reference- Municipal police departments, A.C.A. § 14-52-101 et seq.; police officer training, A.C.A. § 12-9-101 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-26. - Classification of personnel. 
    There is hereby created and established within the police department of the city the following positions: 
(1)  One (1) chief of police. 
(2)  One (1) assistant chief of police, which shall be appointed by and serve at the discretion of the chief of police, and which shall be appointed by and serve at the discretion of the chief of police, and which shall be exempt from civil service coverage and protection. 
(3)  Four (4) deputy chiefs of police. 
(4)  One (1) captain. 
(5)  Thirteen (13) lieutenants. 
(6)  Twenty-two (22) sergeants. 
(7)  One hundred sixteen (116) patrolmen. 
(Code 1967, § 28-1; Ord. No. 5328, § 1, 7-3-89; Ord. No. 5464, § 1, 10-21-91; Ord. No. 5539, § 1, 3-15-93; Ord. No. 5627, § 1, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 5800, §§ 1, 2, 3-15-99; Ord. No. 5878, § 1, 4-17-00; Ord. No. 5968, § 1, 10-1-01; Ord. No. 6036, § 1, 11-4-02; Ord. No. 6052, 3-17-03; Ord. No. 6056, § 1, 4-21-03; Ord. No. 6341, § 1, 12-20-10; Ord. No. 6498, § 1, 11-3-14; Ord. No. 6554, §§ 1(a), (b), 11-7-16) 
Sec. 21-27. - [Birthday compensation.] 
    Uniformed employees of the police department shall be entitled to eight (8) hours of paid leave at regular compensation to be taken on their birthday. In the event the officer's birthday falls on a day in which the officer is off-duty, the leave must be taken on a duty-day within thirty (30) days of the birthday. 
(Ord. No. 5785, § 2, 12-21-98) 
State Law reference- Authority to establish police department, A.C.A. § 14-52-101; council to establish number of subordinate police officers by general ordinance, A.C.A. § 14-52-201. 
Sec. 21-28. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6043, adopted Feb. 2, 2003, repealed § 21-28 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained administrative services manager; position created, as enacted by Ord. No. 5920 adopted Nov. 6, 2000. 
Sec. 21-29. - Part-time I and II law enforcement officer; position(s) created. 
(a)  Position created. There is hereby created within the police department the positions of part-time I and part-time II law enforcement officer under the conditions and restrictions set out in this division, whose services include, but not limited to, traffic direction at rodeos and parades, etc., prisoner transport, public relations functions, minor report calls, and back-up for primary full-time officers. 
(b)  Hours. Part time I and II officers shall work on an as needed basis at the request of the chief of police or his designee or any other time authorized by guidelines established with the approval of the chief of police. Part time II officers shall work less than twenty (20) hours per week; part time I officers shall work between twenty (20) but less than forty (40) hours per week. 
(c)  Eligibility, appointment, training and certification. Only persons who have served a minimum of six (6) months in the Pine Bluff Police Department Auxiliary Force and are members in good standing, or who have previously been employed at least six (6) months as a law enforcement officer and who retired or left law enforcement in good standing, are eligible for consideration as part-time I or II law enforcement officers. Individuals selected are encouraged to continue to attend all training possible, and auxiliary members may, on a voluntary basis, continue ride along training privileges when not called to work as a part-time officer. The chief of police is solely authorized to appoint part-time I and II officers, but all appointees must meet the state minimum standards guidelines for part-time I and II law enforcement officers as outlined in the State of Arkansas Commission on Law Enforcement Standards Training Manual Regulations, and any amendments thereto. (These standards are already followed for auxiliary appointments.) 
(d)  Compensation. Part-time officers shall be compensated at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00) per hour. Additionally part-time officers shall be covered by worker's compensation, unemployment insurance, and subject to social security withholding. 
(e)  Direction and control of officers. Part-time officers shall be called to duty by the chief of police, his designee, or any division commander, following guidelines for use of part-time officers. Part-time officers will work under the direction and control of the division commander requesting their service. 
(f)  Not in civil service. Part-time officers shall serve at the discretion of the chief of police and shall not be considered as covered by or within the control of laws and regulations relating to civil service for police officers. 
(g)  Equipment, support and uniforms. The city may provide such equipment and support as needed to perform assigned tasks. The uniform shall be the same as a full-time officer. 
(h)  Rank. There shall be no rank structure other than that of part-time I patrolman or part-time II patrolman. 
(i)  Discipline. All disciplinary actions regarding part-time officers will follow Department Policies and Procedures Manual Policy 1210. 
(Ord. No. 5970, §§ 1-9, 10-15-01; Ord. No. 6139, § 1, 5-16-05) 
Sec. 21-30. - Residency requirements for personnel of the police department. 
    Notwithstanding any other city ordinance or resolution, applicants for employment with the Police Department of the City of Pine Bluff, and the uniformed officers thereof, shall not be subjected to or required to meet a residency requirement except they shall be required to establish residency within the State of Arkansas no later than thirty (30) days after day of hire and maintain same within the state thereafter while employed as a police officer of the city. 
    It shall be the responsibility for each officer to establish residence at a location sufficiently proximate to his assigned duty station within the City of Pine Bluff so as to allow him to report for duty on time to work his shift, and to be able to respond promptly to summons from the police department in the event of emergency or other situation requiring prompt report to duty. An officer who fails to report to duty when scheduled or promptly when so summoned may be disciplined in accordance with department policy. 
(Ord. No. 6021, §§ 1, 2, 6-17-02) 
Sec. 21-31. - Policy and procedures manual. 
    An amendment to the Pine Bluff Police Department's Policy and Procedures Manual addressing certain issues concerning off-duty employment is hereby adopted by reference as if set out herein. A copy of the department's policy and procedures manual, as amended, is maintained on file with the city clerk for public review. 
(Ord. No. 6272, 2-17-09; Ord. No. 6311, 3-15-10; Ord. No. 6326, 8-2-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6326, adopted Aug. 2, 2010 revised policies number 106, 120, 220 and 221. Ord. No. 6311, adopted March 15, 2010 revised policies number 110, 130, 220, 402 and 550. Ord. No. 6272, adopted Feb. 17, 2009, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein as § 21-31 was at the discretion of the editor. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
Secs. 21-32-21-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - AUXILIARY POLICE OFFICERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Auxiliary law enforcement officers, A.C.A. § 12-9-301 et seq. 

Sec. 21-51. - Position created. 
    There is hereby created within the police department the position of auxiliary law enforcement officer under the conditions and restrictions set out in this division. 
(Code 1967, § 28-31) 
State Law reference- Authority to appoint auxiliary law enforcement officers, A.C.A. § 12-9-306. 
Sec. 21-52. - Hours. 
    An auxiliary law enforcement officer shall work at the request of the chief of police or any other time with the approval of the chief of police. 
(Code 1967, § 28-33) 
Sec. 21-53. - Appointment, training and certification. 
    The chief of police is solely authorized to make the appointment to this position, but he must first receive a written application from the prospective member and make a determination that such applicant is a man of good moral character. The chief of police is also required to keep a current record of all men so appointed. All selections, training and certification shall be consistent with existing laws of this state and the regulations of the state commission on law enforcement standards and training. 
(Code 1967, § 28-34) 
State Law reference- Training of auxiliary law enforcement officers, A.C.A. § 12-9-304. 
Sec. 21-54. - Compensation. 
    There shall be no compensation provided to auxiliary law enforcement officers. 
(Code 1967, § 28-35) 
Sec. 21-55. - Direction and control of force. 
    All auxiliary law enforcement officers shall be called into duty only by the chief of police of the regular police department, and shall, during the complete temporary duty, be under his direction and control, or under the direction and control of the officer he so designates. 
(Code 1967, § 28-36) 
State Law reference- Auxiliary law enforcement officers to have authority of police officer when working under supervision of full-time certified police officer, A.C.A. § 12-9-303. 
Sec. 21-56. - Not in civil service. 
    Auxiliary law enforcement officers shall not be within the control of the laws relating to civil service. 
(Code 1967, § 28-37(c)) 
Sec. 21-57. - Equipment, support. 
    The city may provide equipment or support as may be necessary to perform the assigned task, but under no circumstances shall these benefits be construed as wages. 
(Code 1967, § 27-37(d)) 
Sec. 21-58. - Rank. 
    Auxiliary law enforcement officers shall operate an order of rank and authority that roughly resembles the same rank and authority of the regular police department. The designated head of the auxiliary law enforcement officers shall not have, however, the power to discharge any such members, this right in power to be exercised only by the chief of police of the regular police department. 
(Code 1967, § 28-38) 
Secs. 21-59-21-70. - Reserved.
