ARTICLE V. - QUALITY OF LIFE DIVISION 

Sec. 21-101. - Division established. 
(a)  There is established within the inspection department a "quality of life" division consisting of seven (7) personnel: one (1) police lieutenant; one (1) police patrolman; and five (5) nonuniform environmental quality officers. 
(b)  The division will be under the overall supervision of the director of the inspection department. 
(c)  The five (5) environmental quality officer positions will be appointed by the mayor and included in the roster of nonuniform personnel of the police department. The environmental quality officers shall enforce the city's ordinances and regulations pertaining to offensive conditions and nuisances, and shall exercise all the powers and the duties prescribed in section 7-27 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, as applicable, regarding code inspectors, excepting that the environmental quality officers shall not be subject to the direction or supervision of the chief inspector. The environmental quality officers shall have the specific authority to issue, in the name of the city, citations to offenders for violations of the city's ordinances and regulations pertaining to offensive conditions and nuisances, for prosecution in the district court. 
(d)  Notwithstanding any provision of the International Property Maintenance Code (2009 ed. and 2012 ed.), or any other technical code adopted by the city, environmental quality officers are not subject to the administrative supervision of the chief inspector or code official. 
(Ord. No. 6562, 2-21-17) 
Sec. 21-102. - Duties of the division. 
    The quality of life division will have the primary responsibility for enforcement of the city's ordinances and technical codes concerning property maintenance, nuisances conditions and structures, and combating urban blight. The division will not be involved in enforcement of the technical codes concerning plumbing, electricity, HVAC, stormwater, or new construction, which is the responsibility of the inspection department. 
(Ord. No. 6562, 2-21-17) 
Chapter 22 - SIGNS AND ADVERTISING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; planning and development, Ch. 20; zoning sign regulations, § 29-139. 
State Law reference- Authority to legislate on matters pertaining to municipal affairs, A.C.A. § 14-43-601 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Posting bills, signs, etc., prohibited. 
    Posting of any bills, cards, notices, signs or advertisements of any kind whatever upon any telegraph or electric pole, fence and private buildings, or post within the city is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1967, § 33-1) 
State Law reference- Placing signs on utility poles, A.C.A. § 5-67-103. 
Sec. 22-2. - Signs on city property forbidden without permit. 
    No person shall paint, print, post or in any way affix any picture, bill or advertising matter of any kind upon any post, hydrant, curb, sidewalk or other public improvement in any public ground or street, nor upon any bridge or part of same, or public building, structure or erection of any kind, belonging to the city unless express consent therefor shall have been first granted by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 33-3) 
Sec. 22-3. - Painting and posting signs without permission. 
    No person shall paint, print, post or in any way affix any picture, bill or advertising matter of any kind upon any post, fence, billboard or sign board or upon any building or erection or structure of any kind within the city contrary to the provisions of this Code and unless the building or object upon which same may be placed is the property or under the control of the person so doing, or unless the consent of the owner or the person in control thereof shall first be obtained. 
(Code 1967, § 33-4) 
Secs. 22-4-22-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIGN REGULATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5596, adopted Nov. 21, 1994, amended former Art. II, §§ 22-21-22-29, relative to outdoor advertising on Pine Bluff Expressway, in its entirety to read as herein set out. The provisions of former Art. II derived from Code 1967, §§ 33-18-33-22. 

Sec. 22-21. - Purpose and scope. 
(a)  Primary purpose. The purpose of these sign regulations are to improve visual aesthetics and to provide for public safety and general welfare. This sign ordinance is adopted under the zoning authority of the City of Pine Bluff in furtherance of the more general purposes set forth in the zoning ordinance. 
(b)  Secondary purposes. To provide a range of guidelines which reflect unique communication needs in different landuse zones. 
(1)  To promote innovative design. 
(2)  To encourage renovation and maintenance. 
(3)  To protect property values. 
(4)  To provide equal treatment under the law and consistent enforcement. 
(5)  To enhance the City of Pine Bluff's ability to attract sources of economic development and growth. 
(c)  Scope. 
(1)  Use of all signs is regulated according to zone. 
(2)  The number and area of signs outlined in the specific zones are intended to be maximum standards. Placement and scale of signs are determined primarily by type, length of street frontage, street classification and surrounding conditions. 
(3)  Signs of a commercial nature intended to be viewed from a vehicular or pedestrian public right-of-way. 
This section does not regulate: 
-  Building design, particularly decorative or architectural features except for letters, trademarks, moving parts or moving lights. 
-  Official traffic or governmental signs. 
-  The content or message of signs. 
-  Signs not intended to be viewed from public right-of-way. 
-  Window displays. 
-  Product dispensers and point of purchase displays. 
-  Scoreboards on athletic fields. 
-  Flags and insignia of government or non-commercial organizations, except when displayed in direct connection with commercial promotion. 
-  Gravestones, barber poles, religious symbols, commemorative plaques, street numbers. 
-  Signs smaller than one (1) square foot in area and which bear only property numbers, post office box numbers, names of occupants or premises. 
-  Any display or construction not defined by the ordinance as a sign. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-22. - Applicability. 
    A sign may be erected, placed, established, painted, created, or maintained in the City of Pine Bluff only in conformance with the standards, procedures, exemptions, and other requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-23. - Definitions. 
    Words and phrases used in this article shall have the meanings set forth in this section. Words and phrases not defined in this section but defined in the zoning ordinance of the City of Pine Bluff shall be given the meaning set forth in such ordinance. All other words and phrases shall be given their common, ordinary meaning, unless the context clearly requires otherwise. Section headings or captions are for reference purposes only and shall not be used in the interpretation of this section. 
    Area. (see "Sign, Area of"). 
    Awning. A shelter projecting from and supported by the exterior wall of a building constructed of nonrigid materials on a supporting framework (compare "Marquee"). 
    Clearance (of a sign). The smallest vertical distance between the grade and the lowest point of any sign, including framework and embellishments, extending over that grade. 
    Copy. The wording on a sign surface in either permanent or removable letter form. 
    Festoons. A string of ribbons, tinsel, small flags, pinwheels or pennants. 
    Frontage, building. The length of an outside building wall on a public right-of-way. 
    Height (of a sign). The vertical distance measured from the highest point of the sign, including decorative embellishments, to the grade of the adjacent street or the surface grade beneath the sign, whichever is less (compare "Clearance"). 
    Maintenance. For the purposes of this article, the cleaning painting, repair or replacement of defective parts of a sign in a manner that does not alter the basic design or structure of the sign. 
    Mansard. A steeply sloping ornamental roof-like structure commonly used on exterior walls of buildings having flat, or nearly flat roofs. 
    Owner. A person recorded as such on official records. For the purposes of this article, the owner of property on which a sign is located is presumed to be the owner of the sign unless facts to the contrary are officially recorded or otherwise brought to the attention of the administrator, e.g., a sign leased from a sign company. 
    Parapet. The extension of a false front or wall above a roofline. 
    Person. For the purposes of this article, any individual, corporation, association, firm, partnership or legally recognized entity. 
    Point of purchase display. Advertising of a retail item accompanying its display, e.g., an advertisement on a product dispenser. 
    Premises. A parcel of land with its appurtenances and buildings which, because of its unity of use, may be regarded as a conveyable unit of real estate. 
    Roofline. The top edge of a roof or building parapet, whichever is higher, excluding any cupolas, pylons, chimneys or minor projections. 
    Setback. The distance from the property line to the nearest part of the applicable building, structure, or sign measured perpendicular to the property line. 
    Sign, types: 
    Abandoned sign. A sign which no longer identifies or advertises a bona fide business, lessor, service, owner, product or activity, and/or for which no legal owner can be found. 
    Animated sign. Any sign that uses movement or change of lighting to depict action or create a special effect or scene. 
    Awning sign. A sign painted on, printed on, or attached flat against the surface of an awning. 
    Banner sign. A sign made of fabric or any nonrigid material with no enclosing framework. 
    Beacon. Any light with one or more beams directed into the atmosphere or directed at one or more points not on the same zone lot as the light source; also, any light with one or more beams that rotate or move. 
    Bench sign. Any sign attached, painted or otherwise mounted on benches, in which copy is to be viewed from the right-of-ways. 
    Billboard. (See "Off-Premise Sign"). 
    Building marker. Any sign indicating the name of a building and date and incidental information about its construction, which sign is cut into masonry surface or made of bronze or other permanent material. 
    Building sign. Any sign attached to any part of a building, as contrasted to a freestanding sign. 
    Canopy sign. Any sign that is a part of or attached to an awning, canopy, or other fabric, plastic, or structural protective cover over a door, entrance, window, or outdoor service area. A marquee is not a canopy. 
    Changeable copy sign (automatic). A sign on which the copy changes automatically on a lampbank or through mechanical means, e.g., electrical or electronic time and temperature units. 
    Changeable copy sign (manual). A sign on which copy is changed manually in the field, e.g., readerboards with changeable letters. 
    Construction sign. A temporary sign identifying an architect, contractor, subcontractor, and/or material supplier participating in construction on the property on which the sign is located. 
    Directional/information sign. An on-premise sign giving directions, instructions or facility information and which may contain the name or logo of an establishment but no advertising copy, e.g., parking or exit and entrance signs. 
    Directory sign. Any sign located on or in a building or premise depicting the uses in the building or on the premises. 
    Double-faced sign. A sign with two (2) faces. 
    Electrical sign. A sign or sign structure in which electrical wiring, connections or fixtures are used. 
    Electronic message center. (see "Changeable Copy Sign Automatic"). 
    Flashing sign. A sign which contains an intermittent or sequential flashing light source used primarily to attract attention. Does not include changeable copy signs, animated signs, or signs which, through reflection or other means, create an illusion of flashing of intermittent light (compare "Animated Sign," "Changeable Copy Sign"). 
    Freestanding sign. A permanently attached sign supported upon the ground by poles or braces and not attached to any building. 
    Government sign. Any temporary or permanent sign erected and maintained by the city, county, state, or federal government for traffic direction or for designation of or direction to any school, hospital, historical site, or public service, property, or facility. 
    Ground sign. The entire bottom of a sign is in contact with or in close proximity to the ground. (May be grouped with pole signs under freestanding signs). 
    Identification sign. A sign whose copy is limited to the name and address of a building, institution, or person and/or to the activity or occupation being identified. 
    Illegal sign. A sign which does not meet the requirements of this Code and which has not received legal nonconforming status. 
    Illuminated sign. A sign with an artificial light source incorporated internally or externally for the purpose of illuminating the sign. 
    Incidental sign. A sign, generally informational, that has a purpose secondary to the use of the zone lot on which it is located, such as "no parking," "entrance," "loading only," "telephone," and other similar directives. No sign with a commercial message legible from a position off the zone lot on which the sign is located shall be considered incidental. 
    Marquee sign. Any sign attached to or supported by a marquee structure. 
    Nameplate. A nonelectric on-premise identification sign giving only the name, address and/or occupation of an occupant or group of occupants. 
    Nonconforming sign. A sign which was erected legally but which does not comply with subsequently enacted sign restrictions and regulations. 
    Off-premise sign. A structure advertising an establishment, merchandise, service or entertainment, which is not sold, produced, manufactured or furnished at the property on which said sign is located, e.g. "billboards" or "outdoor advertising." 
    On-premise sign. A sign which pertains to the use of the premises on which it is located. 
    Painted wall sign. A sign which is applied with paint or similar substance on the face of a wall. 
    Pennant. Any light weight plastic, fabric or other material whether or not containing a message of any kind, suspended from a rope, wire, or string, usually in series, designed to move in the wind. 
    Political sign. For the purposes of this article, a temporary sign used in connection with a local, state or national election or referendum. 
    Portable sign. Any sign designed to be moved easily and not permanently affixed to the ground or to a structure or building. 
    Projecting sign. Any sign fixed to a building or wall in such a manner that its leading edge extends more than six (6) inches beyond the surface of such building or wall. 
    Real estate sign. A temporary sign advertising the real estate upon which the sign is located as being for rent, lease or sale. 
    Roof sign. Any sign erected and constructed wholly on and over the roof of a building, supported by the roof structure, and extending vertically above the highest portion of the roof. 
    Rotating sign. A sign in which the sign itself or any portion of the sign moves in a revolving or similar manner. Such motion does not refer to methods of changing copy. 
    Snipe sign. A temporary sign or poster affixed to a tree, fence, etc. 
    Subdivision identification sign. A freestanding or wall sign identifying a recognized subdivision, condominium complex, or residential development. 
    Temporary sign. A sign not constructed or intended for long-term use, and not permanently attached to the ground, a building or structure. 
    Under-canopy sign. A sign suspended beneath a canopy, ceiling roof or marquee. 
    Wall sign. Any sign attached parallel to, but within six (6) inches of, a wall, painted on the wall surface of, or erected and confined within the limits of an outside wall of any building or structure, which is supported by such wall or building, and which displays only one sign surface. 
    Window sign. Any sign, pictures, symbol, or combination thereof, designed to communicate information about an activity, business, commodity, event, sale, or service, that is placed inside a window or upon the window panes or glass and is visible from the exterior of the window. 
    Sign. Any device, fixture, placard, or structure that uses any color, form, graphic, illumination, symbol, or writing to advertise, announce the purpose of, or identify the purpose of a person or entity, or to communicate information of any kind to the public. 
    Sign, area of. That area enclosed by one continuous line connecting the extreme points or edges of a sign. The area shall be determined using the largest sign area or silhouette visible at any one time from any one point. This area does not include the main supporting sign structure but all other ornamental attachments, inner connecting links, etc., which are not a part of the main supports of the sign, are to be included in determining sign area. 
    Use. The principle purpose for which a building, lot, sign or structure is intended, designed, occupied or maintained. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-24. - General provisions. 
(a)  Signs prohibited. The following are prohibited in all districts: 
-  Abandoned Signs. 
-  Festoons, beacons (exception in Sections 22-27 and 22-32). 
-  Signs which imitate or resemble official traffic or government signs or signals. 
-  Snipe signs. 
-  Moving, flashing, blinking, revolving, or any other similar sign, except electronic message boards. 
-  Permanent sale or come-on signs. 
-  Signs on fences. 
-  Any sign not meeting the requirement for a visibility zone. 
-  Signs placed on vehicles or trailers which are parked or located for the primary purpose of displaying said sign, excluding signs or lettering on buses, taxis or vehicles operating during normal course of business) are prohibited, except said signs are permitted during a period of sixty (60) days before early voting commences before an election or referendum and shall be removed no later than ten (10) days after the election or referendum is over. 
-  Inflatable signs and tethered balloons (exception in section 22-27 and 22-32). 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94; Ord. No. 6483, § 1, 5-12-14) 
Sec. 22-25. - Permits required. 
    Unless otherwise provided by this article, all signs shall require permits and payment of fees as described in section 22-42 of this ordinance. No permit is required for the maintenance of a sign or for a change of copy on painted, printed or manual changeable copy signs. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-26. - Signs not requiring permits. 
    Signs listed below do not require permits but must conform with all other provisions of the article: 
-  Construction signs of thirty-two (32) square feet or less. 
-  Directional/informational signs of nine (9) square feet or less. 
-  Holiday or special event decorations which remain up less than sixty-one (61) days. 
-  Nonilluminated nameplates of two (2) square feet or less. 
-  Nonilluminated political signs. 
-  Public signs or notices, including emergency signs. 
-  Window signs. 
-  Incidental signs. 
-  Real estate signs defined as: 
Residential. For Sale, Rental or Lease: One (1) sign per street frontage, not exceeding four (4) square feet in area and five (5) feet in height. Must be unlit. Must be removed within fifteen (15) days after close of escrow, or rental or lease. Open house signs for the purpose of selling a single house or condominium and not exceeding four (4) square feet in area and five (5) feet in height are permitted. 
Commercial and Industrial. For Sale, Rental or Lease: One (1) sign per street frontage no greater than sixty-four (64) square feet in area and no higher than twelve (12) feet. Shall be removed upon sale, rental or lease. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-27. - Temporary signs. 
    Signs publicizing special events such as grand openings, carnivals, parades, charitable events and holiday sales may be placed for up to twenty-one (21) days per event if a permit is obtained, and if promotion sales are not involved. Such signs may include balloons, inflated devices, search lights, beacons, pennants, streamers and banners extending across public right-of-way, if they have a minimum height of eight (8) feet. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-28. - Sign construction and maintenance. 
    All signs must comply with applicable state, federal and City of Pine Bluff regulations, building, and electrical codes. 
    All signs, including those specifically exempt from permits and fees, shall be maintained and kept in good repair. Display surfaces must be kept clean, neatly painted, free from rust and corrosion. Owners must repair dilapidated or damaged signs within thirty (30) days after being notified by the city. Noncompliance shall constitute a nuisance and penalties may be assessed. 
    No sign may be placed or designed so as to simulate or interfere with traffic control devices or official highway directional/informational signs. Signs shall not interfere with internal parking areas, traffic lanes, nor be placed in designated parking spaces and/or area. 
    The general area in the vicinity of any sign shall be kept free and clear of sign material, debris, weeds, trash and refuse. Landscaping and grass shall be neatly maintained at all times. Plants and vines shall not be allowed to grow on the sign or sign structure. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-29. - Lighting. 
    All signs may be lighted unless otherwise prohibited. Illuminated signs may not face the front, side or rear of lot lines of any residential lot if such signs are within fifty (50) feet of the lot line(s). 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-30. - Changeable copy. 
    May be used unless otherwise specified. Must be properly maintained and free of confusing terms, colliding letters, and/or missing letters. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-31. - Sign contractor's license. 
    All required local, state and federal licenses are required for any person or entity engaged in the business of erecting, altering, relocating, constructing or maintaining signs. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-32. - Regulation by zone. 
(a)  Signs allowed in all zones: 
(1)  Any sign not requiring a permit. 
(2)  One (1) construction sign for each street frontage of a construction project which shall not be illuminated, not greater than forty-eight (48) square feet in a residential area or not greater than sixty-four (64) square feet in all other zones. May be erected sixty (60) days prior to beginning of construction and shall be removed within thirty (30) days of completion of construction. 
(3)  Nonilluminated building nameplates attached to the building if not greater than two (2) square feet. 
(4)  Nonilluminated political signs not greater than thirty-two (32) square feet per sign, not to exceed one (1) per twenty-five (25) feet of lot frontage and no more than five (5) signs per lot. Such signs shall be erected no earlier than sixty (60) days before an election or referendum and shall be removed within ten (10) days following the said election or referendum. No political signs shall be placed on public property, facilities, or equipment. 
(5)  Temporary special event signs and decorations for special events or grand openings, may be erected up to fourteen (14) days prior to the special event and shall be removed within seven (7) days following said event. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94; Ord. No. 5646, § 1, 3-4-96) 
Sec. 22-33. - Signs permitted in residential zones. 
    In addition to those permitted in section 22-32 signs are permitted in residential zones (R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4, RMF, RHR, RPUD) as follows: 
(a)  Subdivision identification signs. Maximum of one per subdivision, neighborhood, or development on any external street frontage, no greater than forty-eight (48) square feet in area. 
(b)  Apartment or condominium signs. Maximum of one (1) identification sign per entrance to apartment or condominium complex not to exceed forty-eight (48) square feet in area. 
(c)  Permitted nonresidential uses (e.g. churches, schools, and synagogues.) One (1) freestanding sign no greater than forty-eight (48) square feet and one (1) wall sign no greater than forty-eight (48) square feet. 
(d)  Home occupation signs. When done in compliance with section 29-2 (Home occupation). 
(e)  Bus benches. When approved through a master plan by the Pine Bluff Transit Department and located at bus stops. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-34. - Signs permitted in the B-1, Neighborhood Business and R-B, Residential-Commercial Transition Zones. 
    In addition to those permitted in sections 22-32 and 22-33 signs are permitted in these zones (B-1 and R-B) as follows: 
(a)  Wall signs or electric awning signs. Total area of such signs shall not exceed ten (10) percent of the aggregate area of the building elevation on which the signs are installed. 
(b)  Under canopy signs. One (1) for each separate occupancy or separate entrance no greater than three (3) square feet. Under canopy signs shall have a minimum clearance of eight (8) feet to grade. 
(c)  Incidental signs. Shall not exceed a total of four (4) square feet per occupancy. Signs shall not be located closer than ten (10) feet from property lines and may not extend more than thirty (30) inches above grade. 
(d)  Freestanding signs or low profile signs. One (1) per street frontage not to exceed one (1) square foot for each lineal foot of property frontage. May not be higher than twenty (20) feet and must be set back at least ten (10) feet from property lines. Minimum clearance of nine (9) feet over any pedestrian way. 
    The total of all signs mounted on or attached to a building shall not exceed fifteen (15) percent of the aggregate area of the building elevation on which the signs are installed. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-35. - Signs permitted in the B-5, Central Business District Zone. 
    In addition to those permitted in section 22-32 and 22-33 signs are permitted in this zone (B-5) as follows: 
(a)  Wall signs or electric awning signs. Total area of such signs shall not exceed fifteen (15) percent of the aggregate area of the building elevation on which the signs are installed. 
(b)  Under canopy signs. One (1) for each separate occupancy or separate entrance no greater than four (4) square feet. Under canopy signs shall have a minimum clearance of eight (8) feet to grade. 
(c)  Incidental signs. Shall not exceed a total of eight (8) square feet per occupancy. Signs shall not be located closer than ten (10) feet from property lines and may not extend more than thirty (30) inches above grade. 
(d)  Freestanding signs or low profile signs. One (1) per street frontage not to exceed one (1) square foot for each lineal foot of property frontage. May not be higher than twenty (20) feet and must be set back at least ten (10) feet from property lines. Minimum clearance of nine (9) feet over any pedestrian way. 
(e)  Billboard or off-premise signs. Shall be located only along controlled access highways. 
(f)  Bus benches. When approved through a master plan by the Pine Bluff Transit Department and located at bus stops. 
    The total of all signs mounted on or attached to a building shall not exceed fifteen (15) percent of the aggregate area of the building elevation on which the signs are installed. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-36. - Signs permitted in commercial and industrial zones. 
    In addition to those permitted in sections 22-32 and 22-33 signs are permitted in these zones (B-2, B-3, B-4, CI-PUD, I-1, I-2, I-3 and I-4) as follows: 
(a)  Freestanding signs. One (1) per street frontage per lot not to exceed one hundred fifty (150) square feet. May not project beyond property lines or exceed other structures allowed in the district. For lots in excess of one hundred (100) feet of street frontage one additional freestanding sign may be allowed for each additional one hundred fifty (150) foot increment of street frontage. Signs with a minimum clearance of nine (9) feet from the base of the sign to the ground may be located five (5) feet from property lines. Signs lower than nine (9) feet must be setback a minimum of twenty (20) feet from property lines. 
(b)  Wall and electric awning signs. May be used in any combination but their combined total area may not exceed ten (10) percent of the aggregate wall area upon which they are installed. 
(c)  Projecting wall signs. May be used instead of wall or freestanding signs but may not project over property lines and must provide nine (9) feet clearance over pedestrian ways. 
(d)  Roof signs. May be used instead of wall signs or electric awning signs. May not exceed twenty (20) percent of the total height of the building to which it is attached. 
(e)  Under canopy signs. One (1) per each separate occupancy or separate entrance not to exceed three (3) square feet. Must provide nine (9) feet clearance to pedestrian way. 
(f)  Incidental signs. Not to exceed a total of four (4) square feet in aggregate area per occupancy. Signs shall not be located closer than ten (10) feet from property lines and may not extend more than thirty (30) inches above grade. 
(g)  Temporary signs. May be used no more than twenty (20) days per property per calendar year. Permits are required. Must be installed in accordance with building and electrical codes. 
(h)  Billboards and off-premise signs. The maximum area for any one sign face shall be six hundred seventy-two (672) square feet. Signs in excess of three hundred (300) square feet shall be limited to properties bordering controlled access highways and along State Highways within one-half (1/2) mile of City Limits lines. Exceptions will be made for temporary extensions for creative purposes, not to exceed five (5) feet from sign perimeter. The maximum height shall be forty-five (45) feet to the top of the sign bordering controlled access highways and thirty-five (35) feet in all other zones, measured from the grade of the centerline of the street to where the sign is oriented. No billboard/off-premise sign structure shall be located less than seven hundred fifty (750) feet from the nearest billboard/off-premise structure. For purpose of this section separation distance measurement shall be from both sides of the right-of-way. Signs shall have a minimum setback of twenty (20) feet from property line to the outer perimeter of the sign structure. The structural elements of billboards/off-premise signs shall be of metal unipole construction and shall not have more than one (1) display area facing one (1) direction. 
(i)  Portable signs. Signs shall setback a minimum of twenty (20) feet from property lines. 
(j)  All off-site signs within one thousand three hundred twenty (1,320) linear feet from the nearest point of the right-of-way of a designated scenic corridor shall henceforth be prohibited. Provided, further, that the Highway 65 Southern Bypass and all future extensions thereof are hereby designated a scenic corridor together with such other roadways as may be so designated by ordinance of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94; Ord. No. 5911, 9-5-00) 
Sec. 22-37. - Nonconforming signs. 
(a) Determination of Legal Nonconformity. 
    Existing signs as of the adoption of this article [Ordinance No. 5596] may be designated "legal nonconforming" if: 
-  They are properly maintained and are of no danger to the public. 
-  They were installed in conformance with a valid permit or variance and complied with all applicable laws on the date of adoption of this article. 
    A legally established sign which fails to conform to this article shall be allowed continued use, except that the sign shall not be: 
-  Altered in any way so as to extend its useful life, unless to bring it into compliance. 
-  Expanded, moved, or relocated, unless required by street renovation. 
-  Reestablished after a business has been abandoned for ninety (90) days or more. 
-  Reestablished after damage or destruction of more than fifty (50) percent and the display cannot be repaired within thirty (30) days of being damaged. This provision applies to structural condition only, not to facial copy. 
    Existing nonconforming signs shall not prevent the installation of conforming signs. 
    Any nonconforming sign shall be brought into conformance or removed if a conditional use permit or a building permit which adds square footage to the building is issued for the site where the sign exists. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-38. - Loss of legal nonconforming status. 
    Any legal nonconforming sign will no longer be legal if it is relocated, replaced or altered in any way except in a manner which will bring it into compliance. This does not apply to copy changes or normal maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-39. - Maintenance and repair of nonconforming signs. 
    Legal nonconforming signs are subject to all requirements regarding safety, maintenance, and repair. However, if any such sign is damaged more than fifty (50) percent or deteriorates more than fifty (50) percent it must be brought into conformance with this Code. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-40. - Construction specifications. 
    All signs shall be installed in compliance with current Pine Bluff building and electrical codes. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-41. - Administration and enforcement. 
(a)  Code administrator. The zoning administrator and zoning staff are authorized to process applications for permits and variances, shall hold public hearings as required and will enforce and carry out all provisions of this code. The administrator is authorized to establish procedures consistent with this function. 
    The zoning administrator and/or staff is empowered, upon presentation of proper credentials, to enter or inspect any building, structure, or premises in the city for the purpose of inspection of a sign to ensure compliance with all applicable codes and ordinances. Such inspections will be carried out during normal business hours unless an emergency exists. 
(b)  Applications for permits. Applications for required sign permits shall be made in writing using a form supplied by the zoning department which includes: 
(1)  Name and address of the owner of the sign. 
(2)  Street address or location of the property on which the sign is to be located, along with the name and address of the property owner. 
(3)  A stated type of sign or sign structure as defined in this article. 
(4)  A site plan with measurements showing the proposed location of the sign along with the locations of all existing signs on the same premises. 
(5)  Specifications and drawings showing the materials, design, dimensions, structural supports, and electrical components of the proposed sign. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-42. - Permit fees. 
    The initial permit fee must be paid at the time the application for permit is made. Permit fees shall be as follows: 
(a)  Billboard/off-premise signs ..... $ 40.00 
(b)  On-premise, freestanding, ground signs, etc. ..... $ 10.00 
If a permit is denied, the administrator shall give written notice to the applicant including a statement of the reasons, citing code sections and interpretation of perceived nonconformity within ten (10) days of verbal denial. The administrator may suspend or revoke an issued permit if the application contains any false statement or misrepresentation of fact. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-43. - Permit conditions, refunds, and penalties. 
    If an applicant for a sign permit decides not to erect the sign, the permit fee, less a nominal charge, may be refunded upon request, provided that no inspections have been made and no work authorized by the permit has been done. Such request must be made within ninety (90) days of issuance of the permit and the permit materials must be returned to the administrator. The specified permit fee shall be doubled if any sign is installed or placed on any property prior to issuance of a permit. Payment of the doubled fee shall not relieve any person of other requirements or penalties prescribed in this article. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-44. - Inspection upon completion. 
    When work authorized by a permit has been completed, the zoning department staff and inspection department shall be notified so that a final inspection may be made. Certain types of signs may require interim inspections prior to completion. In such cases the administrator will advise the applicant in writing at the time the permit is issued. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-45. - Variances for signs. 
    Variances from certain requirements of this code may be made at the time of application for a permit. Variances may be granted by the board of zoning adjustment if the literal application of the Code would create a hardship and if the following criteria are met: 
(a)  The hardships are unique to that specific property. 
(b)  The granting of the variance is not contrary to the general objectives of this Code and the city's land use plan. 
(c)  A public hearing is held according to normal procedures to allow for public input regarding the proposed variance. Public hearings for sign variances shall follow the same general provisions required for rezoning and conditional use requests handled by the city planning commission. 
In granting a variance, the board of zoning adjustment may attach additional requirements to carry out the objectives of this article. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-46. - Violations. 
    A written order shall be issued by the zoning department to an alleged violator if the administrator determines that a violation exists. The order shall include specific references to the sections of this Code which pertain to the alleged violation. The alleged violator shall have seven (7) days to correct the violation or to appeal in writing to the board of zoning adjustment. 
    If, upon inspection, the administrator finds a sign is abandoned, is defective or in any way endangers the public, a written order shall be issued to the owner of the sign stating the nature of the violation and requiring that the sign be removed or repaired within seven (7) days of the date of receipt of the order. 
    In cases of emergency, the administrator may cause the immediate removal of a dangerous or defective sign without notice. Signs removed in this manner must present a hazard to the public safety as defined in the local building or traffic codes. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-47. - Removal of signs by the administrator. 
    The administrator may cause the removal of an illegal sign in cases of emergency, or for failure to comply with the written orders of removal or repair. After removal or demolition of the sign, a notice shall be mailed to the sign owner stating the nature of work and the date on which it was performed. The notice will include a demand for payment of costs as certified by the administrator. 
    If the amount specified in the notice is not paid within sixty (60) days of the notice, it shall become an assessment upon a lien against the property owner, and will be certified as an assessment against the property together with a ten (10) percent penalty for collection in the same manner as real estate taxes. 
    The owner of the property upon which the sign is located shall be presumed to be the owner of all signs thereon unless documented facts to the contrary are presented to the administrator, as in the case of a leased sign. 
    For purposes of removal, the definition of sign shall include all embellishments and structures designed specifically to support the sign. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-48. - Penalties. 
    Failure to comply with the provisions of this article may subject the violator to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each week or portion thereof that the violation continues, up to a maximum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-49. - Appeals. 
    Applicants who disagree with rulings of the administrator following the submission of a proper application for a permit may appeal such decisions to the board of zoning adjustment within sixty (60) days of receipt of the initial application by the administrator. If appealed, any action authorized by the permit in question shall be held in abeyance pending the decision of the board of zoning adjustment. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-50. - Inventory and abatement. 
    The city shall start a program to inventory and identify all illegal or abandoned signs within its jurisdiction no later than six (6) months from the date of adoption of this article. Abatement of illegal or abandoned signs will commence within one (1) year of the end of the six-month period. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Sec. 22-51. - Conflict, severability and effective date. 
(a)  Repeal. This article [Ordinance No. 5596] specifically repeals Chapter 29, Article V, Section 29-139 to the City of Pine Bluff Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  Conflict. If any portion of this code [article] is found to be in conflict with any other city regulation, the provision which establishes the stricter standard shall prevail. 
(b)  Severability. If any part of the code [article] or its application to any person or circumstance is held invalid by the decision of any court or competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this code [article], or the application of the provision to other persons or circumstances is in effect and shall remain in full force and effect. 
(c)  Effective date. This code [article] shall take effect and be in force thirty (30) days after adoption. 
(Ord. No. 5596, § 1, 11-21-94) 
Chapter 23 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Health and welfare, Ch. 12; nuisances, Ch. 16; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 28. 
State Law reference- The Water, Sewer, and Solid Waste Management Systems Finance Act of 1975, A.C.A. § 14-230-101 et seq.; solid waste disposal generally, A.C.A. § 14-232-101 et seq.; Joint County and Municipal Solid Waste Disposal Act, A.C.A. § 14-233-101 et seq.; Arkansas Solid Waste Management Act, A.C.A. § 8-6-201 et seq.; Litter Control Act, A.C.A. § 8-6-401 et seq.; unlawful dumping, A.C.A. § 8-6-501 et seq.; authority to legislate on matters pertaining to municipal affairs, A.C.A. § 14-43-601 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Removal, collection by unauthorized persons. 
    No unauthorized person shall disturb, remove or collect any refuse, trash, or garbage situated in any container located within the city. 
(Code 1967, § 15-12) 
Sec. 23-2. - Unlawful discarding and dumping of solid waste; increased surveillance of known dump sites. 
(a)  Purpose . This section is intended to discourage the unlawful discarding or dumping or solid waste in the city. It is intended to complement existing state and local laws concerning the subject. 
(b)  Definitions . 
(1)  "Municipality" or "city" means the City of Pine Bluff, Arkansas. 
(2)  "Person" means any individual, corporation, company, firm, partnership, association, trust, institution, venture, or other legal entity, however organized. 
(3)  "Solid waste" means any garbage or refuse, sludge from a waste-water treatment plant, water supply treatment plant, or air pollution control facility, and other discarded material, such as, e.g., but not limited to, appliances, furniture, construction and building materials, motor vehicles, motor vehicle parts, scrap metal, carpet, logs and lumber, waste from industrial, commercial, mining, and agricultural operations, and from community activities, hot water tanks, wire fences, bed springs, old papers, glass or plastic, tree stumps, broken concrete, brush, tree limbs, cans, or any material deleterious to the public health and safety. 
(4)  "Unlawful discarding or dumping" means the disposal of solid waste by a person in a manner or at a location not authorized by law. 
(c)  Conduct prohibited/penalty . 
(1)  a.  No person shall discard, place, or dump solid waste on any property, public or private, within the city, at any time, unless the property has been approved for such discarding, placement or dumping by the city or by another governmental agency authorized to do so. 
b.  No person shall deposit in a residential trash container or open top container intended for residential use any commercial or industrial construction or demolition debris, residue or solid waste. 
(2)  A person convicted of violating the provisions of this section shall (1) for the first offense, be fined $100.00; (2) for a second offense, be fined between two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and five hundred dollars ($500.00); and, (3) for a third or more offense, be fined between five hundred dollars ($500.00) and one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or incarcerated in the Jefferson County Detention Center for no more than forty-eight (48) hours, or be sentenced to a fine and incarceration within the prescribed parameters. In addition, the district court, in addition to or in lieu of the penalties set forth herein, may also order the offender to perform up to fifteen (15) days of community service engaging in trash and rubbish pickup. 
(d)  Rebuttable presumption . A rebuttable presumption shall arise in a prosecution for unlawful discarding or dumping brought under this section to the effect that, if it can be proved that one (1) or more items of solid waste bear the name or names of one (1) or more persons in such a form as to indicate that the person or persons were the owners of those items and those items were unlawfully discarded or dumped, then the person or persons are presumed to have committed the unlawful discarding or dumping. 
(e)  Known sites of unlawful dumping . Locations known to law or code enforcement as the sites of the unlawful dumping shall be monitored by the police and inspection departments and when feasible, given increased observation in the attempt to apprehend offenders. The use of video cameras is authorized to monitor sites when and if funds become available. 
(Ord. No. 6471, §§ 1-5, 12-16-13) 
Secs. 23-3-23-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL SERVICE 

Sec. 23-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garbage shall mean and include all rejected food waste and shall include every refuse accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter used or intended for food or intended for the preparation used in cooking, dealing in or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruits and/or vegetables. 
    Trash shall mean and include refuse other than food stuff, such as paper, clothing, grass, leaves, wood, ashes, tin and glass. 
(Code 1967, § 15-1) 
Sec. 23-27. - Collection and removal. 
(a)  No person, firm, corporation, company, or organization of any kind other than the city, its agents, employees and contractors shall collect, convey over any of the streets or alleys of the city or dispose of any garbage, refuse, waste, or trash accumulated in the city. 
(b)  This section shall not prohibit the actual producers of refuse or trash, or the owners of premises upon which refuse has accumulated, from personally collecting, conveying and disposing of such refuse, provided such producers or owners comply with all governing laws and ordinances. 
(c)  This section shall not prohibit collectors of refuse from outside of the city from hauling such refuse over city streets, provided such collectors comply with all city codes. 
(Code 1967, § 15-2; Ord. No. 5357, § 1, 12-18-89) 
Sec. 23-28. - Removal of ashes. 
    Ashes will only be removed after a suitable cooling-off period. 
(Code 1967, § 15-1) 
Sec. 23-29. - Containers required. 
    The occupants of every private residence and business and industrial building shall provide suitable water and flytight containers made of substantial material with tightfitting covers for the holding of garbage which shall be placed at a point on the premises where the garbage collector can conveniently have access to same. Garbage containers must not be larger than twenty (20) gallons in capacity and shall have handles suitable as aids in loading the cans. 
(Code 1967, § 15-6) 
Sec. 23-30. - Preparation of garbage for collection. 
    All garbage must be drained of liquid substance before it is placed in garbage containers at residences or dwellings. In the operation of business and industrial establishments, all persons occupying such business or commercial buildings shall place any and all raw garbage in sealed plastic bags, or similar containers, prior to the deposit of such raw garbage in sanitation containers. 
(Code 1967, § 15-7) 
Sec. 23-31. - Burning or dumping of garbage. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to burn any garbage except in incinerators that have been approved by the health and fire departments. It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or throw garbage, trash, refuse, leaves or any accumulation of same on any vacant lot, street or alley in the city or around any sanitation containers situated in the city. 
(Code 1967, § 15-8) 
Sec. 23-32. - Frequency of collection, preparation for collection. 
    Garbage shall be collected from private residences by the city, its agents, employees and/or contractees, at least twice each week during all months of the year, and from business houses in the city as often as required. It is the duty of the occupants of every dwelling and/or business house in the city to have garbage, refuse and waste on their respective premises properly placed in approved containers and available for regular collection. 
(Code 1967, § 15-9) 
Sec. 23-33. - Pickups not required if containers placed inside fence enclosing dog. 
    No pickups of garbage, trash and refuse shall be required if the containers are placed within a fence which encloses a dog of any breed or size. The failure of the city, its agents, employees and/or contractees to pick up garbage, trash and refuse situated within a fence enclosing a dog shall not free the occupant of that residence from the obligation of paying the sanitation fees provided for above. 
(Code 1967, § 15-10) 
Sec. 23-34. - Refuse, debris resulting from building operation. 
    This chapter does not in any way obligate the city, its employees, agents and/or contractees, to clean or pick up refuse or debris resulting from demolition of or construction on property where buildings are being removed or repaired or under construction, nor wood nor limbs resulting from removal of trees on private property. No city employee, agent and/or contractee shall clean or pick up any other waste matter other than garbage, trash and refuse unless it is placed in a sealed bag, the bag is placed in an acceptable container and the container is placed in the front of the occupant's residence as near to the curb of the street as possible. Wood waste products shall not be placed in such sealed bags, but shall be bundled and tied and placed at the curbside provided they shall not exceed two (2) inches in diameter and three (3) feet in length. 
(Code 1967, § 15-13) 
Sec. 23-35. - Sanitation fund. 
    All proceeds collected under this article shall be placed in a special account to be known as the sanitation fund. 
(Code 1967, § 15-14) 
Sec. 23-36. - Sanitation fee. 
    All residential customers in the city shall be required to pay a monthly sanitation fee for each residential unit occupied as a residence. The mayor is hereby authorized and directed to effectuate such changes as may be necessary to ensure that proceeds collected shall be sufficient to fund all costs associated with sanitation collection and disposal services. 
(Code 1967, § 15-3; Ord. No. 5286, § 1, 12-19-88; Ord. No. 5357, § 2, 12-18-89) 
Sec. 23-37. - Payment of fee; refunds. 
(a)  The residential customer fee provided for in section 23-36 shall be payable in advance and shall be collected by the General Waterworks Company on each residential meter for all residential units in the city. 
(b)  The residential customer fee shall not be abated or refunded by reason of there being a lack of use of any residence or building for a period of time unless the water has been disconnected from the residence or building. 
(Code 1967, § 15-4) 
Secs. 23-38-23-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WASTE MANAGEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6329, §§ 1-6, adopted Aug. 16, 2010, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, said provisions have been included as Art. III, §§ 23-61 and 23-62, at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 23-61. - Self-hauling. 
(a)  It shall be illegal for any person, residential unit owner or tenant, or commercial or industrial enterprise or governmental entity to permit or contract with any third person or company other than Waste Management of Arkansas to haul waste generated upon the property of the residential unit owner or tenant or commercial or industrial enterprise or governmental entity. A person, business or governmental entity generating waste at its own property may use its own vehicles to collect and transport that waste from its premises to a properly-licensed disposal facility, provided they comply with all applicable laws, regulations and ordinances pertaining to the collection, transportation and disposal of such waste. 
(b)  Scrap metal businesses or other recycling facilities that receive or acquire waste products from a premises owner who is self-hauling may then self-haul the reusable or recyclable waste products received from the premises owner to a final destination of the facilities choice so long as the facilities comply with all applicable laws, regulations and ordinances. 
(c)  The provision of subsections (a) and (b) shall be known as the "self-hauling" provisions of the Waste Management contract. 
(Ord. No. 6329, §§ 1-3, 8-16-10) 
Sec. 23-62. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Effective thirty (30) days from the first date of publication of this article, a penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per first occurrence and two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per day for each day the violation shall continue shall be assessed against any persons, businesses and/or corporations which violate the self-hauling provisions of the city's contract with Waste Management of Arkansas. 
(b)  Any person, residential unit owner or tenant, commercial or industrial enterprise or governmental entity who shall be convicted of a second or subsequent offense of this article shall be fined a penalty of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each occurrence and five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for each day the violation shall continue. 
(c)  The institution of criminal proceedings under this article shall not prohibit Waste Management or the City of Pine Bluff from seeking injunctive relief in addition to fines and penalties. 
(Ord. No. 6329, §§ 4-6, 8-16-10) 
Chapter 24 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Authority to legislate on matters pertaining to municipal affairs, A.C.A. § 14-43-601 et seq.; general authority relative to streets, sidewalks, etc., A.C.A. §§ 14-54-104, 14-54-601 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Prohibiting drainage into streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow the drainage, throwing or flowing of unclean water of any kind into any of the streets of the city, or to allow the flow of large quantities of water of any kind into such streets or alleys except for sprinkling purposes. 
(Code 1967, § 34-9) 
Sec. 24-2. - Obstructions and encroachments generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, create or maintain any obstruction of any street, alley, sidewalk or public way, except as specified by ordinance or law. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any building or structure, including newspaper tubes, upon any street, alley, sidewalk or public way, except as specified by ordinance or law. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect a basketball goal, whether temporary or permanent in nature, within the public street or highway. It shall be unlawful for any person to play basketball, baseball, softball, volleyball or other game in the public street or highway, or to be a participant in any game in which the public street or highway is used as part of the game area. The penalty for the first violation of this subsection shall be a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), exclusive of court costs. The penalty for a second of subsequent violation of this subsection shall be not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), exclusive of court costs. 
(Code 1967, § 34-10(1), (2); Ord. No. 5284, § 1, 12-5-88; Ord. No. 6097, 7-6-04) 
Sec. 24-3. - Street curb painting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any individual to paint the street curbing within the city, for parking zones or otherwise, unless authorized by the city council. 
(Code 1967, § 34-11) 
Sec. 24-4. - Railroad crossings. 
(a)  Whenever a railroad company or corporation has constructed or will construct a railroad crossing any public road, highway or street in the city, such railroad company or corporation shall be required to maintain the street, highway or public road which crosses such railroad in such a manner that the same shall be safe and convenient to travelers crossing such railroad crossings. 
(b)  The street manager shall as often as he deems necessary carefully examine the conditions of all railroad crossings within the city. Whenever he has reasonable grounds to believe, either by inspection or complaint or otherwise, that any railroad crossing within the city is dangerous or unfit or is not properly constructed or maintained in such a manner that is safe and convenient to traffic crossing such railroad or that is otherwise not maintained in a good state of repair, the street manager shall immediately notify the local general agent of the railroad company or corporation of such unsatisfactory crossing or crossings and request that such crossing be put into a good state of repair so that the same may be safe and convenient to traffic and such company or corporation shall, within thirty (30) days after receiving such notice cause such crossing to be repaired so that the same shall, in the opinion of the street manager, be safe and convenient to traffic. 
(c)  Any railroad company or corporation which shall fail to maintain or repair such crossing in a manner specified by the street manager within the thirty-day period shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 34-17) 
Sec. 24-5. - Closing or blocking of public street or right-of-way. 
    A public street or right-of-way may be temporarily blocked or closed, in whole or part, at the discretion of the mayor, street department manager, or chief of the fire or police department, to protect the public safety, or to promote the public peace, health and welfare, or for the public convenience. 
(Ord. No. 5951, 7-2-01) 
Sec. 24-6. - Assistive devices and other personal mobility vehicles. 
(a)  Definitions. The following definitions apply to this section: 
    "Assistive device" means a manual wheelchair, a motorized wheelchair, and a motorized scooter designed to enhance the mobility of a disabled person. 
    "Personal mobility vehicle" means a motorized means of conveyance with one or more wheels or tires, which is not required to registered or licensed by the State of Arkansas, and the primary purpose of which is not on-the-road transportation. 
    "Safety reflector" means at least one (1) glass or plastic red reflector attached to the assistive device or personal mobility vehicle, which shall be visible from a distance of at least three hundred (300) feet when directly in front of a lawful upper beam head lamp of a motor vehicle. 
(b)  Safety reflectors required. No assistive device or personal mobility vehicle shall use the sidewalks, streets, or rights-of-way under the jurisdiction of the City of Pine Bluff without being equipment with at least one (1) safety reflectors on the front and rear of the wheelchair or personal mobility vehicle. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person who fails to abide by the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a violation and upon conviction shall be subject to a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. 6207, §§ 1-3, 1-2-07) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6207, §§ 1-3, adopted Jan. 2, 2007, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 24-6 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 24-7-24-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET OR ALLEY EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 24-31. - Compliance with article. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make or cause to be made any excavation in any streets, alleys or associated rights-of-way in the city without complying with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1967, § 34-25) 
Sec. 24-32. - Violations, denial of future permits. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. If any person making any excavation as described above fails to comply with this article, no additional permits will be issued for other jobs until all previous work has been completed to the satisfaction of the street department manager or his representative, and in strict compliance with this article. 
(Code 1967, § 34-38; Ord. No. 6047, § 5, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 24-33-24-36. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6047, § 1, adopted March 3, 2003, repealed §§ 24-33-24-36 in their entirety. Formerly, said sections pertained to permit required, separate permits required, permit fee and bond for cost of repaving as enacted by Code 1967 §§ 34-26, 34-27, 34-31-34-33 and 34-37. 
Sec. 24-37. - Method of excavation. 
    When an excavation is to be made in an improved street or alley, and complete resurfacing of the street or alley is not contemplated, the paving shall be cut by saw only so as to provide vertical cuts. Cuts shall be straight and of uniform width. 
(Code 1967, § 34-28; Ord. No. 5793, § 1, 2-16-99) 
Sec. 24-38. - Replacement of pavement; placement of barricades; specifications. 
(a)  Any person or utility making an excavation in any paved or improved street or alley in the city shall notify the manager of the street department, provide the address for the excavation, and obtain a permit prior to making an excavation, unless it is an emergency excavation. In that event, a permit must be obtained by 9 a.m. the next working day. Failure to obtain a permit shall be a violation of section 24-31 and 24-32 and shall result in no further permits being issued to the person or utility company until said permit has been obtained. The person or utility company making the excavation shall make repairs for all excavations made in street right of ways and are responsible for keeping the excavations safe for the motoring public. The person or utility company making the excavation shall be responsible for barricading the excavation and maintaining the barricades until the site is completely repaired. In making an excavation, any person or utility company subject thereto, whether public or private, shall abide by all rules and regulations of the Occupational Safety Hazards Act (OSHA) and the Department of Labor concerning personal safety and proper set up of work zones, safety signs (advance warning five hundred (500) feet, men and equipment working, and end construction) and provision of flaggers while working in street right of ways. The person or utility company making the initial cut shall be responsible for filling it and maintaining barricades until they have permanently repaired the cut. 
(b)  Where such improved streets or alleys are cut, the dirt shall be hauled away and the trench shall be backfilled with Bab or SB-2 crushed stone, preferably Bab. The fill material shall be saturated so as to obtain maximum settlement instantaneously. The trench shall be filled to the top with the fill material. After the fill material has been watered down and settled, the person making the excavation shall call the street manager or his representative for an inspection of the trench. If the trench is approved by the street manager or his representative, the person who made the excavation will be instructed to proceed with the repairs of the improved street or alley in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Repairs shall be made in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Concrete pavements. The width of replaced concrete shall be at least twelve (12) inches wider than the trench width so as to allow at least six (6) inches overlap of slab over trench walls. The replaced concrete shall be reinforced with double layer six (6) inches by six (6) inches, ten-gauge wire mesh or three-eighths-inch round reinforced rods spaced on ten-inch centers both ways. The thickness of the concrete shall match the existing thickness and in no instance shall be less than six (6) inches thick. The finished concrete shall conform to proper grade and alignment. 
(2)  Asphalt pavements. All excavations shall be filled to proper grade and alignment with concrete. 
a.  After the trench has been inspected and accepted, six (6) inches of suitable material, as specified in (b) above, shall be taken out of the trench. Six (6) inches of reinforced concrete shall be placed on the suitable material. The replaced concrete shall conform to the same requirements as outlined in item (1) of this subsection. 
b.  In cases where the excavation is made in, and approximately parallel with, an improved street or alley, the city engineer may authorize filling of the top six (6) inches of the trench with a material other than concrete (such as SB2). After such material has been compacted in a manner acceptable to the street manager, two (2) inches of hot mix or cold asphalt shall be placed on the fill material so as to conform to the proper grade and alignment. 
(3)  Bab or crushed stone streets. After the trench has been inspected and approved, twelve (12) inches of the fill material shall be taken out and replaced with compacted Bab or SB2 crushed stone. 
(d)  If any person makes an excavation during the day, he must fill the trench with acceptable fill material immediately after the improvement has been laid and inspected. This will eliminate the hazards involved with having an open trench for a long period of time. 
(e)  If it becomes necessary for any city employee to answer a call concerning any excavation between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., the person responsible for such excavation shall pay to the city the sum of forty dollars ($40.00) per call. 
(f)  In order to minimize the damage done to streets and/or alleys, no excavations will be made in any improved street or alley during inclement weather. The street manager or his representative shall determine when any excavation is permissible. 
(g)  Fee schedule: 
(1)  Permit fee-Fifteen dollars ($15.00) per address for excavation(s), utility cuts, boring, curb cut or driveway installation. 
(2)  Block permit fee-Continuous longitudinal cuts of more than fifty (50) feet, or five (5) or more cuts in a single block shall be treated as a block permit with a fee of ninety-seven dollars and fifty cents ($97.50) per block. The block permit fee shall be in lieu of individual permits within the block. 
(3)  Inspection fee-Twenty-two dollars and fifty cents ($22.50) per permit plus applicable permit fee. 
(Code 1967, § 34-29; Ord. No. 5793, §§ 2-6, 2-16-99; Ord. No. 6047, §§ 1-4, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 24-39. - Supervision of work. 
    The work of replacing all pavements as herein provided in this article shall be done under the supervision and direction, and to the satisfaction, of the street manager or his representative, and the street manager or his representative shall prescribe by regulations the manner of such refilling. 
(Code 1967, § 34-30) 
Sec. 24-40. - Backfill material specifications; care of work. 
(a)  Backfill materials used in all replacements should be selected materials, a sample of which has been approved by the street manager or his representative. The backfilling shall be done in a workmanlike manner. 
(b)  The person responsible for improved street and alley excavations shall be responsible for excess fill dirt, dust or any foreign matter caused by such excavation. The person that has made an excavation shall control such items by whatever means that are necessary in order to preserve the health, safety and peace of the citizens of the city. 
(Code 1967, § 34-34) 
Sec. 24-41. - Safety. 
    All excavations shall be properly barricaded and lighted sufficiently to give due and proper notice to all persons of the excavation. The person making each excavation shall properly barricade and light such excavation and maintain such lights and barricades. 
(Code 1967, § 34-35) 
Sec. 24-42. - Placement of mains. 
    The relocation of all old mains and placing of new mains must be located between the sidewalk and curb, unless otherwise approved by the street manager. 
(Code 1967, § 34-36) 
Sec. 24-43. - Final repair of pavement after excavation. 
    Final repairs must be made within forty-five (45) days of the excavation and must be warranted for a period of one year. Any repaired excavation which deteriorates or becomes faulty during the one-year period must be replaced by the person or utility company having made the excavation. Failure to make final repairs within the allotted forty-five (45) days shall result in an additional charge of five dollars ($5.00) per day to the person or utility company until the final repairs have been made. All final repairs must be made with 3,500 PSI concrete. 
    Materials removed while cutting and digging the excavation site to make repairs may not be used to refill any area that is part of the asphalted street or part of a concrete driving lane or driveway and shall be removed from the excavation site the same day the excavation is made and disposed of in a proper manner. In making an excavation, the flowline of any ditch at the site may not be impeded. Dirt must be replaced and landscaped back to the original flowline and condition and any private property affected must be repaired and landscaped to its condition prior to the excavation. 
    Excavations must be back-filled by the utility company with a select material, to wit: sand up to the top of the pipe, no higher, compacted with SB-2, Babs, or flowable fill from the top of the pipe to street elevation in six-inch lifts. 
(Ord. No. 6047, §§ 6-8, 3-3-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6047, §§ 6-8, adopted March 3, 2003, were not specifically amendatory of the Code and have been included as § 24-43 at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 24-44-24-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALK AND CURB CONSTRUCTION, REPAIR, ETC.[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Sidewalk, curb and gutter construction, A.C.A. § 14-301-106 et seq. 

Sec. 24-61. - Violations. 
    Any owner of property abutting on any of the streets of the city and subject to the requirements of this article who shall fail or refuse to comply with the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1967, § 34-59) 
Sec. 24-62. - Responsibilities of owners. 
(a)  The owner of any real property within the city is hereby required to build and to maintain a sidewalk and curbing along such property between the property and street of the kind and materials and in accordance with the specifications as set forth in section 24-66. 
(b)  The owner of any real property abutting upon the streets of the city is hereby required to construct and maintain a sidewalk and curbing along such property where the same abuts thereon of the kind and materials and in accordance with the specifications provided by this article. 
(c)  When any curb or sidewalk falls into a bad state of repair in the opinion of the street manager, such owner shall immediately repair or rebuild the same upon being notified to do so by the street manager or his duly authorized agent. 
(Code 1967, §§ 34-49, 34-52, 34-54) 
Sec. 24-63. - Form of notice to owners. 
(a)  The notice to be given by the city council to property owners, as above provided, shall be in substance as follows: tabs msp 1477

Mr. _____     
          City

    You are hereby notified that unless you construct, reconstruct or repair, as the case may be, a sidewalk and curb in front of (here describe property) within twenty (20) days from the service of this notice, in accordance with chapter 24, article II, the same will be (reconstructed or repaired) by us under a contract with some suitable person, and the cost thereof, together with six (6) percent added thereto and six (6) percent interest and cost, shall constitute a charge against you and shall be assessed as a lien on the property herein described from the date of the commencement of said work, which charge and lien will be assigned to the said person or persons doing said work, or to other persons if so desired by the city, said charge to be recovered and said lien to be foreclosed in appropriate suits against you as provided by law; provided that the city is authorized to accept the actual cost of said work without penalty or interest if the same be paid within ten (10) days after the completion of said work. tabs bottom, 1478 
City Council By ____________        Mayor  
 Attest:  ____________ 
          Clerk 
(b)  The notice provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall be served upon the property owner by delivering him a copy thereof or, if he refuses to receive it, by offering a copy thereof to him or by leaving a copy of the notice at the usual place of abode of the owner, with some person who is over sixteen (16) years of age and a member of his family. If the owner is not to be found in the city, or if the owner is unknown, service shall be made by delivering a copy to the known agent in charge of the property and if there be no known agent in the city, service shall be had by affixing a copy thereof to the property in some public part thereof, or by publishing a copy thereof in some daily or weekly newspaper published in the city for one (1) insertion. Such notice may be served by the city engineer or any member of the police department and the endorsement upon such notice by the officer serving the same shall be sufficient evidence of his action in the premises. 
(Code 1967, §§ 34-56, 34-57) 
Sec. 24-64. - Construction by city. 
(a)  If any curb or sidewalk shall not be constructed, reconstructed, repaired or maintained as provided in this article within the time and in the manner mentioned in the notice and to the satisfaction of the street manager or his duly authorized agent, the city council is hereby authorized to contract for the doing of same in accordance with this article. An accurate account shall be kept by it for the amount paid the person with whom it contracts, together with a concise statement of the facts with reference thereto. 
(b)  If the owner of any real property in the city shall fail or refuse to comply with the provisions applicable thereto, with reference to the building, maintaining or repairing curb or sidewalk in the manner and within the time prescribed therefor, the city council, after having given notice to such owner or agent in charge of the property of its intention to do so, may contract with some suitable person for the construction or repair of sidewalks or curb on the best terms that can be made, which person shall construct, reconstruct or repair the sidewalks or curb in the manner prescribed by these provisions under the direction and supervision and subject to the approval of the street manager and the city council, that the amount paid or to be paid to such person, building, rebuilding or repairing the sidewalks or curb, together with a six (6) percent penalty, six (6) percent interest and cost thereto, shall be and constitute a charge against the owner of the property and shall be and constitute a lien on the property from the date of the commencement of the work. The mayor is hereby authorized to assign in the name of the city such charge and lien occurring to the right to create such charge or lien, to the person with whom the city has contracted or to any other person. Such charge, penalty, interest and cost shall be recovered in an ordinary suit against the owner of the property by the city or its assigns, if such charge has been assigned; and such lien shall be foreclosed by the city or its assignee, in case of assignment, by suit in courts having jurisdiction of the enforcement of liens on real property for the condemnation and sale of property for the payments of the sums so expended by the city, together with penalty, interest and cost of such. Such suits in equity shall be brought in the manner and under the terms now provided for the foreclosure of liens on property by improvement districts so far as is applicable. The city is authorized to accept the actual cost to it of the work without penalty or interest if the same is paid within ten (10) days after the completion of such work. 
(Code 1967, §§ 34-55, 34-58) 
Sec. 24-65. - Concrete required; grade. 
    All curbing shall be of concrete and not less than four (4) inches thick and of a depth to maintain and protect the sidewalks and in no case less than sixteen (16) inches. Such sidewalks shall be of concrete and shall extend from property line to curbline. Sidewalks and curb shall be laid on the proper grade as established by this article, and shall be properly laid, well built and carefully maintained, and be subject to the approval of the street manager. 
(Code 1967, § 34-50) 
Sec. 24-66. - Sidewalk specifications. 
    All concrete sidewalks provided for in these provisions shall be constructed in accordance with the following provisions and specifications: 
(1)  The subgrade shall be four (4) inches below the finish grade and unyielding. All embankments shall be thoroughly tamped with paving rammers having a six-inch square face, and weighing not less than twenty-five (25) pounds. Any soft or wet places appearing in excavation must be removed, refilled with cinders or gravel and tamped as provided for embankment.
